title: Kurdish Struggle Blurs Syrias Battle Lines
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Street names in Syrias far northeastern corner have been changed from Arabic to Kurdish, schools openly teach the Kurdish language, and the countrys most powerful Kurdish militia flies its flag from checkpoints on main roads.

title: U.S. May Move Against Bank Over Jumbo Loan Securities
description: Bank of America disclosed on Thursday that the Justice Department was weighing whether to bring a civil complaint against it over claims that the bank had improperly handled securities backed by jumbo loans.

title: Two Ran Ponzi Scheme to Finance Resort, U.S. Says
description: The Panoramic View Resort and Residences is carved into a cliff on the easternmost tip of Long Island, a beacon for New Yorkers who want to relax within earshot of the Atlantic Oceans crashing waves during the summer months.

title: Careful, Zombies: Granddad Lived Through the Blitz
description: Theres not much difference between regular English soccer fans and the undead variety in Cockneys vs Zombies: Even when expired, theyre still ready to rumble with anyone wearing the colors of a rival team.

title: Root Canal Aside, a Painless Start for a Jets Rookie
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Dee Milliner drew comparisons to the shutdown cornerback Darrelle Revis the instant the Jets drafted him ninth over all after trading Revis to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Milliner must bear that burden as long as he wears green and white.

title: While Praising Troops, Assad Promises Victory
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria lauded his troops and vowed that they would be victorious during a visit to a heavily damaged Damascus suburb on Thursday, while antigovernment activists said a rebel attack detonated a weapons depot in the city of Homs, killings dozens of people.

title: LinkedIns Profits Soar as User Growth Accelerates
description: You receive one of those e-mails from LinkedIn with a request from someone asking to connect with you. Why not, you say, and click accept.

title: Giants Ross Hungry to Keep Career Going Where It Started
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  If Aaron Ross needs assurance about his standing in the Giants franchise, he has only to glance at the Super Bowl banners hanging in the teams indoor practice facility. Both bear his name.

title: An Aging Sculptor and, Yes, His Nymph-Muse
description: How picturesque, one might coo when glimpsing the isolated artists shack in the French Pyrenees where the main action of The Artist and the Model takes place. How shabby and ideal. There is nothing unappealing in this World War II-era film from the Spanish director Fernando Trueba about the relationship between a sculptor (Jean Rochefort) and his late-life muse, a voluptuous vagabond played by Aida Folch.

title: Apes Need Vaccines, Too
description: SAN ANTONIO  BIOMEDICAL research with captive chimpanzees, an enterprise that has helped save millions of human lives, is being dismantled. The National Institutes of Health, citing a reduced need for chimps in research as well as their likeness to humans, recently decreed that all but 50 of the 451 chimps that are federally owned or supported will be retired and moved to sanctuaries.

title: Saboteurs in the Potato Salad
description: Just now, a cell of several hundred people has been dispatched into the American summer, to picnics, town halls, radio stations, hospitals and Little League playing fields, with a mission to derail the economic recovery and drum up support for sabotaging federal law. Theyre not terrorists, nor are they agents of a foreign government. This is your United States Congress, the Republican House, on recess for the next five weeks.

title: A Republican Case for Climate Action
description: EACH of us took turns over the past 43 years running the Environmental Protection Agency. We served Republican presidents, but we have a message that transcends political affiliation: the United States must move now on substantive steps to curb climate change, at home and internationally.

title: Pentagons Questions Now Need Answers
description: WASHINGTON  Chuck Hagel is looking for a few good ideas.

title: Sex, Money and Gravitas
description: Can a woman effectively run the Federal Reserve? That shouldnt even be a question. And Janet Yellen, the vice chairwoman of the Feds Board of Governors, isnt just up to the job; by any objective standard, shes the best-qualified person in America to take over when Ben Bernanke steps down as chairman.

title: Inquiry on Mine Collapse in Chile Ends With No Charges
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A three-year investigation into the San Jos mine collapse that trapped 33 miners a half-mile underground for 69 days, thrusting them into the glare of international celebrity, has been closed without holding anyone responsible, the prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Rappers of Old, Through a Lens of History
description: Anybody who doesnt appreciate the spirit captured in Jamel Shabazzs photographs doesnt get New York. In a city that increasingly seems to squander the homegrown cultures that have defined it, Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer, Charlie Ahearns rough-and-ready, almost familial documentary, pays tribute to this pavement portraitist of the late-20th century.

title: Jobs and Taxes
description: Job creation and tax reform are two major challenges that have gone unmet as Congressional Republicans have serially obstructed the Obama administrations agenda.

title: Sentencing Reform Starts to Pay Off
description: In 2010, Congress passed the Fair Sentencing Act, which reduced the vast disparity in the way the federal courts punish crack versus powder cocaine offenses. Instead of treating 100 grams of cocaine the same as 1 gram of crack for sentencing purposes, the law cut the ratio to 18 to 1. Initially, the law applied only to future offenders, but, a year later, the United States Sentencing Commission voted to apply it retroactively. Republicans raged, charging that crime would go up and that prisoners would overwhelm the courts with frivolous demands for sentence reductions. Senator Charles Grassley of Iowa said the commission was pursuing a liberal agenda at all costs.

title: The Slow Motion Inquiry Into Sandy Hook
description: Connecticut officials continue to keep the public in the dark about the states official investigation into the shooting massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in December, even as state and local police have been discussing it at forums across the nation, sometimes in graphic detail. Though the fullest possible report was promised after the tragedy, its release has been repeatedly postponed, with authorities advising patience while the public grows increasingly puzzled.

title: Mr. Obama Moves on Chemical Plant Safety
description: President Obama took an important step toward making Americas chemical plants safer on Thursday by directing federal agencies to update regulations, coordinate policies and share information with one another and state and local governments. If followed up by strong rules, his order could go a long way toward protecting millions of Americans who live near chemical plants from disasters like the explosion at a Texas fertilizer plant in April that killed 15 people. Across the country, more than 2,500 facilities produce, use or store toxic chemicals that put more than 10,000 people at risk.

title: Obamas Fall Moscow Trip Is Even More in Doubt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is even less likely to go through with a visit to Moscow this fall after Russias decision on Thursday to grant Edward J. Snowden temporary asylum. For Mr. Obama, though, the Snowden affair is only one of myriad reasons to beg off the scheduled meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: The Neocon Revival
description: They say you can define what kind of conservative a person is by what year they want to go back to. Some conservatives, apparently including some in Senator Rand Pauls office, want to go back to the 1850s. They believe that Abraham Lincoln helped put us on the path to the leviathan state. Many other conservatives want to go back to the 1890s. They think Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson and the other Progressives set us on that course.

title: A Wedding Turned Nightmare (but Oh, the Video!)
description: Theres not much new to be wrung out of the wedding-catastrophe plotline, but if youre the kind who is always up for a calamity-filled trip down the aisle, Breakup at a Wedding is a moderately amusing application of the formula.

title: As Suspension Looms, Rodriguez Practices at Padlocked Stadium
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With Alex Rodriguez facing the imminent threat of a lengthy suspension from Major League Baseball, he played a 30-minute simulated game on Thursday afternoon at Steinbrenner Field, the Yankees spring training home. The stadium was padlocked, and the event was closed to the public.

title: Cycling Their Way to Redemption
description: This documentary, covering six years in the development of Rwandas first national cycling team, is heartfelt. The scenery  described here as the Land of a Thousand Hills, ideal for the sport  is compelling. The lessons about professional cycling are detailed. title: Steve Schmidt Says Republican Campaigns Havent Changed. But They Will.

A few years ago, there was universal agreement in the party that marriage is between one man and one woman. It was a position that appealed to the middle of the electorate. Thats not true anymore. Politicians have an acutely honed instinct for self-preservation. Over time I am convinced this issue will be a political liability for people who are opposed to it.

title: The 7.21.13 Issue
T.M.B. (Too Much Baby)
description: Many of my friends on Facebook are having babies. Nearly every time I log on, I see (in my news feed) many pictures of these babies, almost to the point of oversharing. Now, I love babies and feel its acceptable to post a photo from a holiday gathering or a first picture of a newborn. But when this happens every day from a specific acquaintance, is it a violation of the babys privacy? The baby did not sign up for a Facebook account, does not understand the concept of Facebook and obviously was not asked permission to have its pictures on the site. R. D., MANALAPAN, N.J.

I had bought a milling machine and made all of the parts myself out of PVC pipe and Plexiglas, Johnson says. Even the valves  I made those too.

title: In Mongolia, the Skyline by the Steppes

The circular canvas structures, insulated with felt and supported by poles, have housed central Asian nomads since before the time of Genghis Khan  before there even was a Mongolia. Now, half of the nations population lives permanently in or near the capital. Look beyond the gers, to where the offices and condominiums rise, and youll see why: Ulan Bator is booming. Construction cranes spike the sky. Traffic  Hummers and Lexuses, jacked-up jalopies and crammed city buses  churns. Its impossible to ignore the economic surge that copper, gold and coal mining have brought to the city in recent years.

description: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoffs final book; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Juan Gabriel Vsquez discusses his new novel, The Sound of Things Falling; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: David Rakoffs Last Book
description: This week, Paul Rudnick talks about David Rakoffs final book and Juan Gabriel Vsquez discusses his new novel.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Latrobe, Pa.; Germany; Italy
description: Great American Banana Split Celebration, Latrobe, Pa.Latrobe, a small city 40 miles southeast of Pittsburgh that considers itself the birthplace of the banana split, will host a weekend celebration from Aug. 23 to 25 for the 109th anniversary of the famous triple-scoop dessert. In 1904, David Strickler, then a 23-year-old apprentice pharmacist at what became Stricklers Drug Store, above, invented the sundae, which quickly became popular with students of nearby St. Vincent College, according to organizers of the Great American Banana Split Celebration. The three-day event will feature tastings, a banana-themed multimedia art show and street fair, era-themed events like a car rally and sock hop, and, of course, a do-it-yourself banana split bar. Most activities are free.

title: Feeling For | An Old-School Hotel in the Berkshires Thats Perfect for Just Staying Put
description: Sure, its fun to traverse a city in 36 hours or explore some far-flung land over a luxurious two weeks. But when it comes to vacations, sometimes its nice to just pick a spot and stay put. If thats what youre in the mood for, the Wheatleigh Hotel, in Lenox, Mass. is the place for you. Its not new, or of the moment, or even remotely cool, and thats exactly the point.

title: Jobs Recovery in Europe Is Also Painfully Slow
description: THE number of unemployed workers in the euro zone fell in June, the European Unions statistical agency estimated this week.

title: The Whistle-Blowers Quandary
description: IMAGINE youre thinking about blowing the whistle on your employer. As the impassioned responses to the actions of whistle-blowers like Edward J. Snowden have reminded us, you face a moral quandary: Is reporting misdeeds an act of heroism or betrayal?

title: Oregon Embraces University of Nike Image
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The Football Performance Center at the University of Oregon features rugs woven by hand in Nepal, couches made in Italy and Brazilian hardwood underfoot in the weight room that is so dense, designers of this opulent palace believe it will not burn.

title: So Far, So Good
description: With the year more than half over and sweltering weather encouraging us to stay inside and read, I asked some notable people at The Times for their favorite book (so far) of 2013. Unsurprisingly, some busy respondents are still catching up on 2012. Mark Thompson, C.E.O. of The New York Times Company, cited Robert Macfarlanes perambulating travel book The Old Ways. Thompson praised it for rooting the immediate felt experience of walking through a landscape in the deep context of culture and history. Im an inveterate walker myself  now, thanks to Macfarlane, I know why I do it.

title: One Book In . . .
description: Last year in the pages of the Book Review, Drew Gilpin Faust described her elation at finding her favorite childhood book in a rare-book store in London, after she had searched for it for decades. In the old days, devotion to such a quest would often fail, filed in a card catalog under Unrequited Love. But just as the Internet reunites old lovers, so too can it reunite readers with other fugitive objects of love, like the books of childhood, usually with happier outcomes. The Internets shared secrets, though, may also keep some grails tantalizingly out of reach, even as they are in sight.

title: . . . One Book Out
description: Ive decided that books are my enemy, though they used to be my great love. They are taking over. They crowd my dining room, they double up in the bedroom, they make the attic floor sag. We even have a library in the bathroom: shelves and shelves of books where a normal person might have a vanity table or piles of towels.

title: Inside the List
description: COME ON GET HAPPY: The singer and actress Shirley Jones is best known for playing young innocents (Laurey in Oklahoma!), reserved prigs (Marian the librarian in The Music Man) and wholesome matriarchs (Shirley Partridge in The Partridge Family).

title: Paperback Row
description: THE CASUAL VACANCY,  by J. K. Rowling. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $18.) Rowlings first post-Harry Potter novel, a dissection of middle-class life in an outwardly idyllic English town, displays her keen powers of observation. After the sudden death of a parish councilor, a vicious political battle erupts over plans to redraw municipal boundaries and possibly shunt a nearby housing project to a different district.

title: Editors Choice
description: THOSE ANGRY DAYS: Roosevelt, Lindbergh, and Americas Fight Over World War II, 1939-1941,  by Lynne Olson. (Random House, $30.) The savage political dispute between Roosevelt and the isolationist movement, presented in spellbinding detail.

title: The Age Equation in Employment Numbers
description: The rosiest take on the jobs report is that the aging of the countrys population has made the employment statistics look worse than they really are.

title: Our Kind of People
description: In his engrossing novel Memories of a Marriage, Louis Begley gives us a chance to see into two different, often obscured worlds. One is the most private recesses of another couples marriage. The other is high-WASP society  though most people dont usually even know where that particular unmarked door is, let alone get a chance to have it quietly shut in their faces.

title: Every Cheese Has a Story
description: You know those floridly descriptive little signs you find pinned into wedges of aging fromage at your local upmarket cheese shop? Those index-card vignettes that tell you Cheese A is made from the milk of black-snouted Iberian sheep that merrily feed on yarrow and camomile, and Cheese B is dense, ornery and challenging, not unlike fusion-era Miles Davis?

title: How Soon It May Be Too Late
description: Death was early American photographys killer app. Since the first pictures required long exposures, it was convenient to have a subject that held still. There was a psychological angle as well. A 19th-century photographer reported that when he visited a town in upstate New York, all the residents welcomed him except the blacksmith, who at first reviled him as a swindler. But then the blacksmiths son drowned  and the blacksmith came begging for an image of the boy.

title: New Statesman
description: One expects a book by Philip Bobbitt to be over 900 pages (The Shield of Achilles, 2002) or just under 700 pages (Terror and Consent, 2008). Then how can he diet himself down to a mere 200 or so pages of text on Machiavelli? Bobbitt is a great systematizer in the Toynbee mold  Shield gave us six different state systems since 1500 (princely, kingly, territorial, imperial, national, market).

title: Glory Days
description: The boys from Life on Earth  the garage band that rocked Oakpine High on homecoming night, 1969  are back. They scattered in a hurry all those years ago, on an afternoon in June, after a run of great performances (admittedly, standards were low: they knew fewer than 10 songs). Thirty years later theyve reassembled in Oakpine, Wyo., the fictional setting of Ron Carlsons fifth novel, Return to Oakpine. Their hometown is sweetly, stubbornly sunk for all time in the Leave It to Beaver 1950s. Even in 69 there was no hint of peace songs or race riots or long hair on the men. In 99 the town seems to know little of manufactured drugs, the tech boom or Y2K. During high school football home games, Oakpine is as deserted as a town in a movie about the end of the world, not a noise except for the train every two hours.

title: Inner Sins
description: James Purdy, who died in 2009, was so often declared an underappreciated American genius on the basis of his first few novels that it is easy to forget about the later decades of his writing, which were often appreciated not at all. While the early stuff continued to attract admirers (including Jonathan Franzen, who called Purdys 1967 novel Eustace Chisholm and the Works so good that almost any novel you read immediately after it will seem at least a little bit posturing, or dishonest, or self-admiring), he drew diminishing interest both from American publishers, who took on his later books only after they were published overseas, and from reviewers, who often ignored them entirely.

title: Signs of Protest
description: In exploring the darker aspects of Chinese life, Ma Jian and Liao Yiwu speak mostly to the outside world. The work of both writers has been banned in China, and neither lives in his native land. Ma Jian is a longtime resident of London. Liao crossed the border into Vietnam in 2011 and fled to Berlin, where he remains today.

title: Rise and Fall
description: Of all the proponents of human agency against the constraints of geography, culture and historical experience, economists are the most incisive. They obey scientific rigor rather than mere civilizational tendencies. And while the laws of economics yield a determinism all their own, adherence to such laws and the limits they impose, Glenn Hubbard and Tim Kane suggest, will allow any state or people to avoid tragic outcomes, regardless of geographical or other limitations.

title: Lush Life
description: My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains my sense as the poet finishes his reading, but before I can reach for the hemlock, the older gentleman next to me says, Is there a book thatll help me understand this kind of poetry? The poet had gone on for close to an hour, reading poems that were without charm, music, meaning  without people, really, since nothing in them seemed to come from or speak to our common humanity. I have taught and written about poetry for decades; if I was stunned, what chance had the older gentleman, a retired cleric who is a regular at this weekly series, a well-read and earnest listener who wanted so much to like poems that didnt care at all for him? Theres no book thatll help you, I told him. Its not your fault. Its the poems fault. And the poets. The poems are bad, and he shouldnt have read them.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: SHE RISES  By Kate Worsley  Bloomsbury, $26.

title: Bring Up the Bodies
description: Tis the night before Christmas and all through the house not a creature is stirring in John Dufresnes ghoulishly funny crime novel, NO REGRETS, COYOTE (Norton, $25.95). Thats because everyone in the Halliday house  father, mother and three little kiddies in pajamas  is dead, shot in what appears to be a case of parental murder-suicide. But Wylie (Coyote) Melville, a therapist who serves as a volunteer forensic consultant for the Everglades County Police Department, doesnt buy that explanation. Although hes only acting on intuition, Wylie has proved to be a gifted mind reader (I just look, I stare, I gaze, and I pay attention to what I see, he modestly explains), so people tend to put stock in his hunches.

title: Newly Discovered Early Pavarotti Recording Will Be Released
description: A recently discovered recording by Luciano Pavarotti from a 1961 performance at the Reggio Emilia Theater, in Italy, will have its first release in October, when Decca Records includes it on a new compilation of Pavarotti favorites. The company is releasing the set to commemorate the 50th anniversary of his British television debut on on Sunday Night at the London Palladium, a popular weekly variety show, as well as his Covent Garden debut the following month.

title: The Sweet Spot: A Dark and Scary Craving
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love. Nice, huh?

title: The Sweetness of Time Off
description: The last several months have been, in many ways, the richest, most exciting and most creative period of my life. Still, as I prepare to take off most of the month of August, Im feeling edgy, worn out and a bit overwhelmed.

title: 30 Seconds With Matthew Berry
description: Before fantasy sports was a multibillion-dollar industry, Matthew Berry was finding his voice as the Talented Mr. Roto. He wrote about his stat-driven obsessions for several fledging fantasy sports Web sites at the turn of the millennium, including his own starting in 2004.

title: The Sweet Spot: A Dark and Scary Craving
description: In this weeks episode, David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about the sociopathic characters on television we love to hate and love to love. Nice, huh?

title: House Votes to Bar I.R.S. Action on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  In its last action before a five-week summer recess, the House took another jab at President Obamas health care law on Friday, voting to prohibit the Internal Revenue Service from enforcing or carrying out any provision of the law.

title: What I Love | Colin and Eric Jacobsen
description: Brothers and members of Brooklyn Rider, a string quartet, at home in Windsor Terrace.

title: Music to the Rafters in Windsor Terrace
description: The Jacobsen brothers, Colin and Eric, are half the string quartet Brooklyn Rider. Theyre also half the quartet occupying a three-story brick house in Brooklyn. They bought it almost two years ago for reasons they eagerly enumerate: the bones and the vibe were good, the ceilings were tall, the subway was right at the end of the block. Oh, and it scored high on the Vondelstraat and gezellig scales (more about this in a second).

title: Who Abandoned the Health Insurance Credit
description: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

title: From North Korea With Love: A Tablet With No Internet Access
description: TOKYO  The Samjiyon tablet computer, it is safe to say, is no threat to the iPad.

title: A Century in Their Shells
description: A fortunate Eastern box turtle (Terrapene carolina carolina) can lead a very long life, very slowly. Records of individual turtles living well past 100 are not uncommon. One such creature was caught and marked on Marthas Vineyard in 1861, and recaptured several times through 2006. It was a hatchling before the Civil War.

title: British Plan on Taxing Gambling Annoys Many in Gibraltar
description: GIBRALTAR  Gibraltar, the British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula, has long been a political sore point between Britain and Spain. But now, in an Internet gambling dispute, its Briton vs. Briton.

title: Enough to Make an N.F.L. Team Jealous
description: The University of Oregon recently unveiled its new, 145,000 square-foot football complex.

title: Like a Nightclub, Only Its Schubert
description: A Little Night Music is the popular series of late-night concerts presented by the Mostly Mozart Festival in the intimate Kaplan Penthouse. The programs start at 10 p.m. and typically last an hour or less. The penthouse has picture windows with nighttime vistas of the city. Patrons sit at small round tables drinking complimentary wine. Only about 230 people can be accommodated; tickets go fast.

title: Life Was Idyllic, Then Sis Arrived
description: The writer Chad Beguelin is largely known for lighter fare like The Wedding Singer (book and lyrics) and Elf (lyrics), so his domestic comedy Harbor offers a chance to see another side of him. And there were some positive reviews of the plays premiere at the Westport Country Playhouse last year, directed by Mark Lamos, so this first production of the 2013-14 Primary Stages season is worth a look.

title: A Zumba Lesson With, Um, Perks
description: For producers of the kind of quickie docu-shows that certain cable outlets thrive on, seeing Zumba and prostitution in the same sentence has the feel of Christmas morning. And TLC brings us an instant-history look at a real-life case involving those two things out of Kennebunk, Me., when it broadcasts Sex, Lies & Zumba on Tuesday at 10 p.m.

title: For Yankees, Little Bang for Their Buck
description: The Yankees highest-paid hitters have produced few hits this season. Compare hits and salaries across the league.

title: The Basics and More, but Somethings Missing
description: The Nissan Versa Note, a hatchback version of the second-generation Versa, offers comfort, plenty of options and good mileage, but not much fun.

title: Crackling Wit of an Up-and-Comer
description: Having left the Mark Morris Dance Group only last year, John Heginbotham probably has a few years to go before we stop comparing him to Mr. Morris. In his 14 years with the company, this dancer turned choreographer clearly inherited some of Mr. Morriss trademark musicality and wit. These qualities stand out in the repertory of his own troupe, Dance Heginbotham. Since its debut in 2012, critics have also noted a distinctively Heginbothian zaniness. And when was the last time Mr. Morris choreographed to Daft Punk?

title: Sounds That Bridge Disparate Worlds
description: The Moderns Soundings isnt the only aural art show in town this month. Lisa Cooley, a Lower East Side gallery on the former site of Tonic, the experimental music club, has just opened The String and the Mirror, a group exhibition of sonic works by 19 artists. Organized by Justin Luke, director of the gallery Audio Visual Arts, and Lawrence Kumpf, artistic director at Issue Project Room, it includes a few veterans like Marina Rosenfeld and Rolf Julius but mainly focuses on emerging artists.

title: Speaking Spanish to Win Votes in New York
description: Fans of Spanish-language news shows and telenovelas, get ready: The mudslinging and fist-fighting long associated with New York City politics will soon be invading your airwaves.

title: The Man Who Fell Into Movie Acting
description: Its the rare director who can transform the familiar into something that feels as if it were being seen for the first time. The director Nicolas Roeg succeeded handsomely with The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976), part of the retrospective Watch That Man: David Bowie, Movie Star at the Walter Reade Theater. In adapting Walter Teviss 1963 novel about an extraterrestrial on a secret mission who uses alien technology to become a tycoon on Earth, Mr. Roeg takes Japanese Kabuki, New Mexico landscapes, corporate soullessness and Americas television-saturated culture and has us perceive them as an interstellar out-of-towner might.

title: A World of Sounds at a D.J. Marathon
description: Seeking out raw beats from the worlds street-level sound systems is the knack and mission of Diplo, the producer and disc jockey at the core of Major Lazer. For more than a decade, Diplo has culled, adapted and often anthologized an international assortment of beats, from Jamaican dancehall to Brazilian baile funk to Angolan kuduro. Is it exposure, exploitation, networking, diluting, sensationalizing, mongrelizing, trend-surfing, cosmopolitanism? All of the above; its D.J. remix culture. Mad Decent is Diplos label, and hes applying the brand to dance-party marathons in 13 cities headlined by Major Lazer, which is rooted in dancehall but hurls all kinds of bass-heavy beats.

title: Compromise Should Salvage Dell Deal
description: A flawed compromise on the buyout of Dell Inc. will save faces all around.

title: Mugabes Party Appears Headed for Parliamentary Victory in Zimbabwe
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The party of Robert G. Mugabe, Zimbabwes long-ruling president, appeared to be on track to win a huge majority in Parliament after Wednesdays election, the Zimbabwe Election Commission announced Friday, allowing it to recapture parliamentary control from its main challenger, the Movement for Democratic Change.

title: War in the Land of Unculpsalm
description: I was in the book stacks of the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas when the title of an otherwise unassuming green volume, The New Gospel of Peace, caught my eye. I had been looking for an edition of Abraham Lincolns speeches to include in an exhibition tracing the King James Bibles influence on literature and culture. Like many other major Civil War-era figures  Frederick Douglass, Harriet Beecher Stowe  Lincoln was beholden to the language and style of the King James Bible. But Lincoln would have to wait.

title: Scores Killed in 2 Days of Clashes Between Afghan Police and Taliban Fighters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters killed 22 Afghan police officers on Thursday in an ambush of their convoy in an eastern province bordering Pakistan, officials said Friday. It was one of the deadliest episodes in a power struggle between insurgents and the government that has intensified as American-led forces prepare to leave Afghanistan after more than a decade of war.

title: Not Flying Rats, to Him
description: William MacLeod says he was always in the rats with wings camp regarding New York City pigeons, until one day six years ago in Washington Square Park, where he spied a pair of chicks on the ground. He nurtured them for weeks and released them back into the park.

title: Songs for the Club, the Faithful and the Economically Oppressed
description: French Montana

title: East Midtown Rezoning: Still a Bad Idea
description: Mayor Michael Bloombergs hurried plan to rezone a large section of midtown Manhattan got a surprising endorsement this week. Manhattan Borough President Scott Stringer, who has found himself in a heated campaign with former Governor Eliot Spitzer for city Comptroller, offered his conditional approval of the proposal. Mr. Stringers backing is advisory, but it will help Mr. Bloomberg and the real estate community in their quest to build new office skyscrapers around Grand Central Terminal.

title: Still Mine Adds to Movies on Aging
description: She has her good days and her bad days, thats all, Craig Morrison, who is in his late 80s, testily tells his son. Its an intensely self-sufficient mans warning to back off, a we-dont-need-anyones-help declaration that will sound familiar to many readers here.

title: Secrets Found Online, Shared Softly
description: Opera and technology have long had an uneasy relationship. The one has always required the other  from the Baroque spectacle of 17th-century operas, with their deus-ex-machina gimmickry, to the stagecraft required to mount any contemporary production of Wagners Ring cycle.

title: A Restless Creature on New Terrain
description: After 29 years with one of the worlds most demanding ballet companies, some dancers might start to feel worn out. Wendy Whelan, the New York City Ballet principal, has the opposite problem.

title: Not for Followers
description: The rush of compelling ideas for new smartphone apps has slowed. In 2007, Twitter still seemed pretty revolutionary for the way it bridged the gap between public figures and private ones, between celebrity and anonymity. The most widely used new app these days, at least among my 20-something cohort, is Snapchat. It allows the bored user to send innumerable so-called selfies to any friend unlucky enough to have signed up, with the assurance that all pictures will disappear in the span of 10 seconds.

title: Lonely Planets Plans to Make Up for Job Cuts
description: After Lonely Planet announced last month that it was eliminating 70 to 80 positions in a staff of 450, eulogies by travelers who had used its guidebooksflooded Twitter with hashtags like #LPMemories.

title: After the Doctor and a Prince, Hes a Cop
description: The question at the center of Broadchurch, a British crime drama starting Wednesday on BBC America, is who killed a boy found dead on a beach in the picturesque seaside town of the title. Less of a mystery is why it stars David Tennant as Detective Inspector Alec Hardy. Though relatively unknown in the States, this wiry, energetic Scottish actor has long stood out on Britains stages and screens. When he starred in the Royal Shakespeare Companys 2008 production of Hamlet, the critic for The Guardian proclaimed, David Tennant is the greatest Hamlet of his generation. And, while he is one of 11 actors to have played the titular centuries-old Time Lord on the long-running science-fiction series Doctor Who, his portrayal was among the most popular.

title: The Breakup Album, 9 Months After
description: A year ago, the folk-rock duo the Civil Wars seemed to be golden. Their 2011 debut album, Barton Hollow, had sold a half-million copies without a major label and won them two Grammy Awards. They had toured with Adele and Emmylou Harris and collaborated with Taylor Swift on a hit song. More success seemed certain.

title: Classics on the Coast
description: Some highlights from the more than six decades of the Pebble Beach Concours dElegance and surrounding events.

title: The Promise of More Than Perfection
description: Even as a boy growing up in the Midwest, I was interested in food and cooking. Supermarket expeditions to the local A.&P. were entertaining, and so was racing along the aisles astride the shopping cart.

title: Eagles Receiver Who Used Slur Takes Leave Amid Uproar
description: PHILADELPHIA  As a furor escalated over the use of a racial epithet by Eagles receiver Riley Cooper, and Philadelphias mayor criticized the team for issuing no punishment beyond a fine, Cooper took an indefinite leave Friday to seek counseling.

title: Image of the Day: August 2
Celebrating a Bond With Britten
description: Grecchinois, the name of Nicholas Phans engaging blog, reflects the Greek and Chinese heritage of this 34-year-old American tenor, who has fast made a name for himself as an expressive interpreter of the British composer Benjamin Britten. Raised Greek Orthodox in Ann Arbor, Mich., Mr. Phan, who initially studied the violin and played in a youth orchestra, discovered Britten when he played his Young Persons Guide to the Orchestra. In college, as a gay man, he became fascinated with the relationship between Britten and the tenor Peter Pears, who lived together at a time when homosexual acts were illegal in Britain. He cites an experience performing Britten in a recital at Truman State University in Kirksville, Mo., around early 2006 as proof that the music, with its beautiful combination of head and heart, speaks to audiences everywhere.

title: Onstage Together at Last
description: Everything about Annaleigh Ashford, a 28-year-old actress currently starring in Kinky Boots, the Broadway musical, is sunny and bright, like a new penny. Her hair is yellow; she often wears yellow dresses; her eyes shine like sequins.

title: Forensic Art Experts Libel Case Against New Yorker Magazine Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a libel suit brought against The New Yorker magazine and one of its writers by Peter Paul Biro, a forensic art expert who was the subject of a long article in July 2010.

title: Odes to Heat-Struck New York
description: In last Sundays Metropolitan section, Benjamin Weiser exhumed an article about the summer heat that was published in this newspaper in 1852. No mere weather story, it combined meticulous detail, social commentary and references to art and literature  all rendered in spectacularly overwrought prose. We asked readers to write their own over-the-top odes to the temperature in response; a selection is below.

title: Reborn Cosmos Return to the Field
description: They were the Galaticos in the alternate universe of American soccer in the late 1970s and early 80s.

title: Summer on the Jersey Shore, After the Storm
description: Seaside Heights historically embodied both the natural beach-encrusted splendors and the boozy, boardwalk MTV excesses of the Jersey Shore. That status was only enhanced after pictures of its half-submerged roller coaster, long a destination for families in search of fun, became a post-Hurricane Sandy metaphor in news reports for natures triumph over what man had wrought.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Not Just the Flu, Solved!
description: Updated, 12:53 p.m., Monday Aug. 5

title: Answers
description: We asked educators to submit questions theyd llike to see on the SAT. Below, they explain their answers.

title: George Clooney Rebuts Loebs Critique of Sony
description: Daniel S. Loeb has been steadily ratcheting up his critique of Sony in recent days. But the conglomerate found a defender in a somewhat unlikely source: George Clooney.

title: Testing, Testing
description: AS if applying to college isnt taxing enough, the process seems to have been ratcheted up another notch. Ambitious high school students are no longer content with just one college admissions test. Not a single college requires it, but many applicants to the nations most selective colleges and universities are taking  and retaking  both the ACT and the SAT.

title: What Would You Ask?
description: The College Board has announced plans for a fundamental redesign of the SAT, to be introduced in 2015. What should be on it? We invited educators to dream up a question they would like to see. Turn to the answers for an explanation of their choices.

title: Owning Up
description: THE idea of anonymous confessions went viral last semester, with Facebook pages popping up at campuses large and small. The confessions page out of the University of Wisconsin, Madison, which went up in late February, says its the nations largest, with about 500,000 weekly views during the school year.

title: To Catch a Cheat
description: FOR his recent MOOC, Understanding Cheating in Online Courses, Bernard Bull asked his students to share their stories. Cut-and-paste still rules, he found, but with a global twist that trips up plagiarism-detection software. Students are finding papers online in another language and running them through Google Translate.

title: Skipping Class (All of Them)
description: You dont even have to log in. A handful of companies have taken the essay mill to the next level. NoNeedtoStudy.com, WeTakeYourClass.com and BoostMyGrades.com, among others, will take an entire online course for you.

title: Following the Money
description: FOR 18-year-old consumers, financial decisions escalate exponentially. Tall latte or a grande splurge? Lucky Brand or True Religion? State U. or N.Y.U.? Statistics or psych or maybe social work?

title: Sneak Preview
description: SAY farewell to vocabulary flashcards with arcane words like compendious, membranous, mendacious, pugnacious, depreciatory, redolent, treacly and jettison. In the new SAT, to be unveiled in 2015, David Coleman, president of the College Board, wants to get rid of obscure words that are . . . just SAT words, and replace them with more common words like synthesis, distill and transform, used in context as they will be in college and in life.

title: The Costliest Colleges
description: SINCE 2011, the Department of Education has tried to shame colleges over costs. This summers data release shows that 7 of the 10 most expensive private nonprofit colleges (in terms of net price, or total cost of attendance minus average grant aid) are art and music conservatories. In defense: tiny endowments, small studio classes and expensive glassblowing equipment and audio mixers. On the other hand: these are watercolorists and musicians.

title: Talking With Teachers
description: FRESHMAN year at Hamilton College, in Clinton, N.Y., Bret Turner asked a music professor, Why is music important? Enthused by the passionate response, he decided to speak with every teacher on campus about his or her discipline. By the time he graduated, in May, hed chatted with 200 of 223 faculty members, a half-hour to an hour each.

title: Class Warfare Along Partygoer Lines
description: IN the fall of 2004, 53 young women arriving for their first year at a public research university found that one room on their dorm floor had a sign saying, This room is occupied by sociology researchers studying college student social life.

title: Book Review Podcast: David Rakoffs Farewell in Verse
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Paul Rudnick reviews Love, Dishonor, Marry, Die, Cherish, Perish, the final book by David Rakoff, who died of cancer last year at the age of 47. Mr. Rudnick said he was prepared to hate the book, and not just because its so awful to contemplate a world without any more David Rakoff books, or any more David Rakoff. He writes:

title: An $18 Million Lesson in Handling Credit Report Errors
description: Even after sending more than 13 letters to Equifax over the course of two years, Julie Miller could not get the big credit bureau to remove a host of errors that it inserted into her credit report.

title: A Seventh Day, but Not a Day of Rest
description: Stuff doesnt stop for Sundays or holidays, and when you talk about Miriam Linna and her husband, Billy Miller, youre talking about stuff. She collects paperbacks, with an emphasis on pulp fiction; they both collect records, the scruffier the better. Then they recycle the gems through their businesses. From their apartment in a converted school in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, she runs Kicks Books (recent titles include Gone Man Squared by the English beat poet Royston Ellis) and both run the resolutely lo-fi Norton Records. Since 1984, they have also made joyful noises with their garage rock band, the A-Bones, with Ms. Linna, 57, on drums, and Mr. Miller singing. Since Hurricane Sandy flooded their warehouse in Red Hook, they have been working to salvage records and books, including on Sundays. Roaming among their collections is their mixed-breed dog, Queenie.

title: Beyond Dioramas: Natures New Story
description: LOS ANGELES  The traditional natural history museum is powerful and familiar, but it is also strange. It is weighty, ponderous, pieced together from relics of lost worlds. It evolved in the 19th century, displaying the geological cataclysms that molded the earths surface, the creatures that clambered into habitats and the indigenous cultures that were once considered closer to nature. No other museum genre has changed so glacially.

title: Week in Review: Trial Sends Message to Midlevel Employees
description: Former trader is found liable in fraud case. | Traders hiring offers a glimpse of SAC practices. | Banks find S.&P. more favorable in bond ratings. | Million denied bank accounts for past errors. | JPMorgan looks to pay to settle U.S. inquiries. | Hunting for luxury, retail giant buys Saks.

title: What Inspired You to Work in Video Games?
description: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance and pop music.

title: Keep On Truckin
description: The connection may sound obscure, but as David Bowers of Absolute Strategy Research in London notes, there is a surprising correlation between the pace of truck sales and the ability of stocks to outperform bonds.

title: The Trouble With Lemonade Stands
description: Last night at dinner, I announced that I planned to write about lemonade stands and the challenges they present for me.

title: For That All-Important First Tent
description: Gifts to make the outdoorsy couple comfy.

title: Over Canned Octopus, a First Date
description: You should not judge Maiden Lane, a 28-seat wine bar and seafood spot that opened on Tompkins Square Park in April, by its kitchen. It doesnt have one. Thus the concept: cold tins of imported mussels, octopus, sardines and other sea creatures, as well as smoked fish and cured meats for customers not ready to fork their dinner out of cans. The walls are exposed brick, the room not too loud. Wednesdays are theme nights, sometimes involving hot food made on the lone induction burner  this Wednesday will be a celebration of striped bass, featuring the fish in ceviche, crudo and soup.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Bubble for Your Thoughts? Not for Long
description: In May, ACT Inc. announced its test will go digital. Is it the end of the No. 2 pencil and the bubbles on a standardized-test answer sheet?

title: Off the Tracks, Turmoil Aplenty
description: With the 2013 racing season at its midpoint, more or less, two of the biggest series are finding that its anything but business as usual. Each of those series, the Formula One world drivers championship and the Nascar Sprint Cup, have shown cracks in their armor in recent months.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Media Whirlwind Doesnt Faze Park; Afternoon Gusts Do
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland  The storm passed through Friday morning, leaving puddles in its wake. The wind arrived later and tilted the Old Course in favor of the early starters. Inbee Park, who played in the afternoon in the toughest of the conditions, managed to identify the rainbow even as the clouds rolled in and darkened her path to history.

title: Montereys Festival, Rich in Tradition
description: The birth of this countrys classic-car Olympics took place at Pebble Beach, Calif., on the scenic Monterey Peninsula, in the simpler, quieter time of November 1950.

title: Upwardly Mobile, but Not in Any Hurry to Get There
description: Its logical that the less money you spend on a car, the less car you should expect. But as Ive heard repeatedly from automakers, small-car customers in this country have the same lofty expectations as other types of shoppers.

title: Baby BMW Takes On an Entirely New Meaning
description: Lets make one thing clear: McLaren, the British maker of racecars and supercars like the new P1 is not the same company as Maclaren, the British manufacturer of premium baby strollers, known for its 1965 innovation of the folding umbrella model.

title: Pebble Beach Stalwarts, Classics as Their Cause
description: When visitors new to the weeklong festival surrounding the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance see their first million-dollar car, they cant help but be impressed. After all, there arent many like that back home. By the third day, million-dollar vehicles are like the spear-carriers in Aida, mere background for the real action.

title: The Tappin Talkies, in a Movie Classic on Stage
description: THOSE DANCING FEET are the stars of the show presented in Patchogue by the Gateway Performing Arts Center of Suffolk County  but the show is not 42nd Street. This one is Singin in the Rain, a less felicitous translation of a dance-savvy movie into a tap-happy Broadway musical. It shares many of the same elements, including a showbiz setting and a plot involving the vagaries of young love, the machinations of a domineering female star and the rise of a bright-faced ingnue.

title: The Life of Jesus: Reza Aslan Talks About Zealot
description: In a recent interview heard round the world (or at least, round influential Twitter feeds), the Fox News host Lauren Green spoke to Reza Aslan about his new book, Zealot: The Life and Times of Jesus of Nazareth. Ms. Greens focus on why Mr. Aslan, a Muslim, would write about Jesus, created a stir on social media (and traditional media), bringing more attention to the book, which was already on The New York Times best-seller list.

title: Video Shows Irans President-Elect Was Misquoted on Israel
description: Last Updated, 6:46 p.m. | As my colleague Thomas Erdbrink reports from Tehran, Irans state media scrambled on Friday to correct comments wrongly attributed to the countrys president-elect, Hassan Rouhani, after he was incorrectly quoted calling Israel a sore which must be removed.

title: Pictures of the Day: Democratic Republic of Congo
description: Photos from the Democratic Republic of Congo, Pakistan, the West Bank and India.

title: In the Hamptons, Mind Your Manners, or Else
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  The young professionals were promising All Cash up front for a fast rental in the Hamptons. So the agency they contacted in April scrambled to get them into as many of the properties as it could.

title: Meeting the Disapproving Mother
description: RUTHLESS MOTHERS of all degrees have long been a forceful presence in dramatic literature. Oscar Wildes Lady Bracknell, Tennessee Williamss Amanda Wingfield and Gypsy Rose Lees mama are among the maternal monsters who command the stage.

title: The Next Edition
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of the 2012 White House Correspondents Dinner, this citys annual media-politico-Hollywood love fest, Katharine Weymouth convened the sort of Washington power dinner for which her grandmother, Katharine Graham, the pioneering publisher of The Washington Post, was famous.

title: Textbook Funnies
description: AS shipping and receiving coordinator at Bethel Universitys bookstore, Karl Stavem delighted in flipping through textbooks, and always seemed to find humor  especially in word problems that involved implausible dating situations. Last year, Mr. Stavem started curating his collection on Tumblr.

title: Hello, Dolly! in Another Light
description: Thanks to the likes of Carol Channing, Pearl Bailey and Barbra Streisand, we tend to think of Dolly Levi as a flamboyant, stage-devouring diva. But before this exuberant busybody took to song and exclamatory punctuation in Hello, Dolly! she was simply The Matchmaker in the Thornton Wilder play  not low-key, exactly, but suited to more homespun character actresses like Ruth Gordon and Shirley Booth.

title: A Cheap Spying Tool With a High Creepy Factor
description: Brendan OConnor is a security researcher. How easy would it be, he recently wondered, to monitor the movement of everyone on the street  not by a government intelligence agency, but by a private citizen with a few hundred dollars to spare?

title: Aaron Sanchez and John Besh Discover Haitis Evolving Food Culture
description: Earlier this week, the TV personalities and James Beard Award-winning chefs Aarn Snchez and John Besh headed to Haiti on behalf of Oxfams GROW program, which seeks to promote sustainable practices for food production around the world. While there, they checked out urban gardens in Port-au-Prince, and new rice-growing techniques that require less water in the countryside. They also made headlines when they were turned away from a farmers market by a mayor who feared they would take unflattering pictures. In between their various activities, the duo  who happen to be best friends and are planning to open a Mexican restaurant together  cooked up local dishes alongside Haitian chefs, farmers and culinary students. Here, Snchez and Besh share their adventures.

title: Under a Coaster, a Dream, or Maybe a Nightmare
description: In 1996, during an outing to Coney Island, Donna Dennis found herself unexpectedly captivated by the Cyclone roller coaster. But it wasnt the thrill of the ride or the enthusiasm of the crowds that drew her; it was the strange landscape beneath.

title: Prison Life, Real and Onscreen
description: The night before she reports to prison after pleading guilty to smuggling drug money, Piper Chapman, the protagonist of Netflixs popular series Orange Is the New Black, frets about maintaining her blond hair and meticulously groomed eyebrows. She anticipates that at least she can use her incarceration to get ripped, read everything on her Amazon wish list, maybe even learn a craft. She asks her fianc to keep her Web site updated, and when she walks into the penitentiary, shes carrying a burrata sandwich.

title: Movie Review: 'Our Children'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Our Children."

title: Movie Review: 2 Guns
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "2 Guns."

title: Movie Review: The Canyons
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Canyons."

title: Tested by Water and Fire, Yet Staying Put
description: Several decades ago, Katie Gallaghers mother arrived in New York from County Kerry, Ireland, and secured work as a nanny with a prominent Manhattan family that spent the summers in East Hampton. Seduced by the beauty and serenity of the beaches of the ruling class, Ms. Gallaghers mother thought to herself, There must be a place like this for us, her daughter told me. By us she meant people of comparatively meager circumstance, but she also meant the Irish. As it happened, there was a place on the shore for her far from the world of Further Lane, a place with its own codes and dignities and manner of exclusion on the western tip of the Rockaway peninsula called Breezy Point.

title: Wildebeest
description: From The Handsome Familys album Wilderness on Carrot Top Records.

title: Models and Mechanisms (Wonkish)
description: OK, traffic is mysterious  and yes, I have read Tom Vanderbilt. Last week I fought rolling traffic jams all across CT in the middle of the day; today I zipped into Manhattan with barely a delay, late on a Friday afternoon. So I have a bit of time.

title: Two Cities and Cultures, Linked on a Brooklyn Wall
description: On one side, an eagle reaches its claws out toward a big red apple. On the other side, a creature wearing multiple masks moves toward the apple. These are images in a mural meant to depict the struggles of people of different backgrounds to make it to New York City.

title: World Youth Open Championships Unfold in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  There are three tournaments within one taking place here. Along with the Summer Nationals, we have the North American Youth Championships, which started on Thursday and end on Saturday, and the World Youth Open Championships, which begin on Sunday and run through Aug. 11.

title: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Two of Us on the Run
description: A bit of sheer aural joy:

title: Bill Cunningham | Well Tanned
description: Leather skirts can declare victory as the big surprise of summer (and a major fall trend).

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Two big advertising companies merge, fast-food workers strike for higher wages and a former Goldman Sachs trader is found liable for fraud in a mortgage-backed security deal.

title: Far-Flung Students
description: Back to school? Students submitted photographs of themselves and where they come from.

title: Montauk Comes to Queens
description: Imagine a beach club plucked from the East End of Long Island and dropped one block from the subway on Rockaway Beach Boulevard and youll start to get a picture of the Playland Motel, which began taking guests on the first weekend in July and, almost from the moment that it opened, became a destination both for residents of the Rockaways, Queens, and for what are known locally as D.F.D.s, or Down for the Days.

title: When Lindsay Lohan Hijacks a Film, She Also Saves It
description: The Canyons, starring Lindsay Lohan, written by Bret Easton Ellis and directed by Paul Schrader, will open today in New York and on video on demand today and in Los Angeles on Aug. 9. This is no small victory for the filmmakers, considering that when the movie was completed, it was unclear whether it would make it to theaters at all. When Stephen Rodricks article, Here Is What Happens When You Cast Lindsay Lohan in Your Movie, was published in the magazine in mid-January, the film had been rejected by both Sundance and SXSW.

title: Pursuing Elusive 59, Woods Falls a Bit Short
description: The pursuit of golfs magic score of 59 has been a wild ride this year, with two minor tour players reaching it, a 16-year-old amateur carding one and Phil Mickelson leaving a putt hanging on the lip to barely miss the milestone.

title: In Catskills, City Buyers Recolonize Bungalows
description: Zoe Schneider was on the hunt for an affordable country house when her brother forwarded an ad to her from his Boerum Hill Listserv: a little place in the Catskills with a pool, basketball court and a playground. The price: $25,000.

title: After a Fee Dispute With Time Warner Cable, CBS Goes Dark for Three Million Viewers
description: The war between CBS and Time Warner Cable intensified on Friday when the cable company withdrew the CBS stations of its three million customers in markets including New York, Los Angeles and Dallas.

title: Making the Case for Eating Fruit
description: Fresh fruit should not become a casualty in the sugar wars, many nutrition experts say.

title: Words Fortified With Movement, and the Narratives They Push Ahead
description: Steady rain on Thursday did little to dampen the sheer forcefulness of two artists as they strove to get their messages across at Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Both works had as much to do with social issues as with artistic ones, and certain heavy-handed leanings were their downfalls.

title: Snapshots From a Saints Fervid Gallop to Martyrdom
description: SALZBURG, Austria  It always takes some mental adjustment to go from the Bayreuth Festival in Germany to the Salzburg Festival here, as I did on Thursday. Unless you are a resident of Bayreuth or a student at its university, there is only one reason for an outsider to visit that sleepy city: the Wagner festival. There are amenities for visitors but not much else to do.

title: Postal Service Confirms Photographing All U.S. Mail
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service on Friday confirmed that it takes a photograph of every letter and package mailed in the United States  about 160 billion pieces last year  and occasionally provides the photos to law enforcement agencies that request them as part of criminal cases.

title: Egypt General Has Country Wondering About Aims
description: CAIRO  When Egypts first elected president, Mohamed Morsi, promoted Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi to defense minister nearly a year ago, sweeping away an aging cadre of generals, many saw it as a triumph for the Islamist president, and for a fledgling democracy.

title: Fickle Nature, Taunting an Ensemble From the North
description: Last year, when Les Ballets Jazz de Montral was scheduled to perform in New York, Hurricane Sandy intervened. That run was rescheduled and went off without meteorological incident. But when the company returned on Thursday for a Celebrate Brooklyn! show under the Prospect Park Bandshell, the heavens opened up again.

title: Congress Passes First Significant Energy Legislation Since 2009
description: Congress is heading home for its August recess having passed the first significant energy legislation, aside from some tax changes, since 2009, after the Senate approved two bills on Thursday that clear the way for faster licensing of hydroelectric projects.

title: Surprise at TV Critics Gathering: DeGeneres Is to Host the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  The producers of the Academy Awards telecast announced on Friday that they were going back to a prominent television star, Ellen DeGeneres, to host the movie industrys biggest event, the annual Oscar ceremony.

title: Report Paints Dire Picture in Honduran Prison Fire
description: MEXICO CITY  The fire that killed 362 people in a Honduran prison last year started accidentally in an upper bunk in one cell and rapidly spread through locked gates and past frightened police guards, according to a report released Friday by the Organization of American States.

title: Ronnie Cutrone, a Man of Another, Cooler City
description: When the artist Ronnie Cutrone died late last month, at 65 and apparently of natural causes, a quirky and marginal figure slipped off the cultural stage, taking with him a large and vital hunk of late-20th-century New York history.

title: Yesterdays Style, Todays Hits
description: We first met Robin Thicke about a decade ago, zipping through the streets of Manhattan on a bicycle in his debut video, Jesus mane flowing behind him, then doing some sub-Saturday Night Fever moves in a freight elevator. The song was When I Get You Alone, and it sampled Walter Murphys Fifth of Beethoven, the 1976 disco-classical fusion, a hybrid of flash and seriousness that Mr. Thicke appeared perfectly comfortable with, even if few others were: wildly out of step with the sound of the time, his single never hit the American charts.

title: Singer Files Suit Against Met Opera Over Fall
description: Updated, Aug. 5 | Wendy White, the Metropolitan Opera mezzo-soprano who was hospitalized in December 2011 after an eight-foot fall when a piece of scenery broke during a performance, is suing the Met for damages as a result of the accident. The lawsuit was filed on Thursday, but the Met will not be served with papers until Monday, Ms. Whites lawyer, Martin Edelman, said on Friday afternoon.

title: Pressed on Syria, Hezbollah Leader Urges Focus on Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a rare public appearance on Friday, Hezbollahs leader, Hassan Nasrallah, urged Arabs and Muslims to stay focused on opposing Israel despite bitter disagreements over the Syrian war, and declared that his Shiite followers would not bend in the face of rising anti-Shiite sentiment among those who oppose his support for the Syrian government.

title: Chinese Journalist Detained in Beijing, One Day After Human Rights Talk With U.S.
description: BEIJING  A Chinese journalist who had pressed for the release of a prominent human rights activist was detained Friday, one day after the United States completed annual discussions with China on human rights.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Facebook at DefCon and Selling the Moto X With Innuendo
description: The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Heres what they noticed today. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: Letters: Bike Helmets, Please
description: Thanks for My Mademoiselle Summer by Meg Wolitzer (Sunday Styles, July 21). It brought me back 50 years to my days as a Mademoiselle guest editor in 1963. Her description of her time at the magazine rang true for me. To be sure, the June heat in the tiny rooms of the Barbizon Hotel for Women was grueling. But New York in 1963 seemed wondrous and innocent. Anything was possible. It was a blast. It was an honor. I made lifelong friends.

title: The New York Times Editorial Board
description: The editorial board is composed of journalists with wide-ranging areas of expertise. Their primary responsibility is to write The Timess editorials, which represent the voice of the board, its editor and the publisher. The board is part of the Timess Opinion department, which is operated separately from the Times newsroom, and includes the Letters to the Editor and Op-Ed sections.

title: Nickelodeon on the Mend, Profit Soars at Viacom
description: Nickelodeons resurgence and a new online streaming deal with Amazon contributed to a 20 percent increase in profits at Viacom in its latest financial quarter of the year, the company said on Friday.

title: Bank of New York Mellon Wins Sex Bias Case
description: A federal jury in New York decided on Friday that a woman who was one of 11 people in her division at Bank of New York Mellon laid off in 2010 was not a victim of sex discrimination. The case was unusual in that it even went to trial.

title: An Avid Reader Scribbles a Wardrobe
description: Jennifer Weiner, 43, has written many a best-selling beach read. She lives in Philadelphia with her two daughters.

title: In Mandela Legacy, a Place for Winnie?
description: SOWETO, South Africa  WHEN Winnie Madikizela-Mandela stepped out in late June onto the porch of the home here she once shared with Nelson Mandela, still looking as regal and outspoken as when she was known a quarter century ago as the mother of the nation, it was like a fiery echo of the past.

title: Pulling Ahead
description: Sales of hybrid cars have steadily increased in recent years, but sales of electric cars and plug-in hybrids have been anemic by comparison.

title: Pope Sends Message of Respect for Muslims
description: In a demonstration of what the Vatican spokesman called Pope Francis particular attention to relations with the Muslim world, the pope on Friday personally signed the Holy See message for Muslims at the end of Ramadan, calling for mutual respect through education between Christianity and Islam.

title: The Week in Pictures, Aug. 2
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include hunting for treasure at Jones Beach, an interactive art show in a tunnel and mayoral candidates on the stump.

title: Devils Head, Dead Chicken and a Swindle
description: In summer 1956, a bit of criminal history was made in a parlor on Madison Avenue, at precisely the moment when two women cracked open an egg and peered at its contents. There was no yolk, but instead, something sinister: a tiny head, with horns, eyebrows and a black goatee.

title: The Bullpen Takes a Hit
description: The Mets bullpen was shaken up Friday before the club began its three-game series against the Kansas City Royals.

title: Mexico: Blast Caused by Methane Gas, Report Says
description: The Mexican attorney generals office said Friday that methane gas combined with vapors emitted by solvents caused the deadly explosion at the headquarters of Mexicos state-owned oil monopoly, Petrleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, on Jan. 31. The basement blast killed 37 people and injured more than 120 others. In a statement summarizing the results of its investigation, the attorney generals office said that hydrocarbons that had leaked into the ground decades before the building was constructed had contributed to the buildup of methane gas and that an electrical spark had probably ignited the combustible mix. Pemex is suffering from declining production and has long had a poor safety record. President Enrique Pea Nieto has said he hopes to win approval from Mexicos Congress to open up the company to private investment before the end of the year.

title: Repairs to a Storm-Damaged Tunnel Will Disrupt R Line Service for a Year
description: Extensive repair work on a subway tunnel connecting Brooklyn and Manhattan is scheduled to start this weekend, making many R train riders adjust their commutes for more than a year.

title: Spain: Alarms Warned Trains Driver Before Accident
description: At least three alarms went off inside the train that crashed last week in northwestern Spain moments before it derailed, prompting the panicked driver to activate the brakes three times even as he talked on the telephone with another employee, an examination of the trains two black boxes released Friday revealed. The driver, Francisco Jos Garzn Amo, had answered a ticket inspectors call on his cellphone and was traveling at a permitted speed of 199 kilometers per hour, or 123 miles per hour, before the train switched to another track in a reduced-speed zone. During the call, an alarm went off in the drivers cabin. The black boxes recorded Mr. Garzn screaming as he tried to activate the brake. The trains speed dropped to 195 k.p.h., or 121 m.p.h., but another alarm sounded, 500 yards from the curve where the accident took place. Mr. Garzn activated an emergency brake three seconds later. A third alarm sounded, and 13 train cars started derailing. Mr. Garzn activated another emergency brake as the train careened from the tracks and then slammed into a wall at 153 k.p.h., or 95 m.p.h., nearly twice the speed limit. Mr. Garzn was arrested last week and charged with reckless homicide in the deaths of 79 people.
