On Monday, NBC announced that Mr. Seacrest would be the host of The Million Second Quiz, an interactive game show that is taking over nearly two weeks of the networks schedule in September.

title: A Unique Collection Worthy of Framing (Pictures Not Included)
description: At a gallery in Long Island City, Queens, Diego Salazar displays his unique collection of art, which is as lovely as it is peculiar. About 250 pieces hang in his main gallery, stacked one inside the next like Russian dolls. Some are covered in cherubs or crosses, others are gilded, and a few are more than 400 years old.

title: Qaeda Leaders Edict to Yemen Affiliate Is Said to Prompt Alert
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administrations decision last week to close nearly two dozen diplomatic missions and issue a worldwide travel alert came after the United States intercepted electronic communications in which the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the groups affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday, according to American officials.

title: A Year on Mars
description: One year ago, the rover's arrival on Mars ushered in a new era of exploration. Since then, it has been inching toward a mountain that could yield fascinating insights.

title: M.L.B. Suspends Rodriguez and 12 Others for Doping
description: Alex Rodriguez was among 13 players suspended by Major League Baseball on Monday for violating the leagues antidoping rules, the biggest single-day drug action in the sports history.

title: Disney Magic May Not Have Worked on Pixar
description: Robert A. Iger, the chairman and chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, has another Pixar hit on his hands.

title: Leaning In to Lego Camp
description: When my daughter said she wanted to go to a Lego engineering summer camp, I tried to hide my excitement. Ive had an eye on gender gaps in everything from government to the sciences since giving birth to Frankie. As far as I knew, though, she played with dolls, not Legos, on play dates. Frankies sudden interest in engineering felt like a win.

title: Still a Firebrand, 2,000 Years Later
description: Jesus the loving shepherd. Bringer of peace and justice. Teacher of universal morals. Jesus the rabbi. Jesus the philosopher. Jesus the apocalyptic prophet. Jesus the Christ of faith.

title: Weekly News Quiz | July 30-Aug. 5, 2013
description: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events that made news this week.

title: American Psycho-Style Specs From Oliver Peoples and Millers Oath
description: Oliver Peoples frames were the preferred eyewear of the late-80s business set (Patrick Bateman, of American Psycho fame, was a fan) because they were simply the best: carefully made, modern, low-key and refined. Now Larry Leight, the co-founder and creative director of the brand (now owned by Luxottica), is reaching back into his 80s briefcase and issuing a capsule collection called Sir, which includes tortoiseshell versions of three iconic frames  the OMalley, the Finley and the Kent  from 1987, the year Oliver Peoples came out with its first collection.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Riding an Uber Boat and the Origin of O.K., Glass
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. More Scuttlebot can be found here.

title: City Hall's Invisible Library
description: Among the millions of photos and documents in the storerooms below New York Citys municipal library, Edward I. Koch, Michael Jackson and Muhammad Ali are captured at the peak of their powers.

title: Suspension Leaves Many Questions for Now and Later
description: Some questions and answers about Alex Rodriguez, who has been suspended by Major League Baseball but is appealing the ruling and has rejoined the Yankees lineup.

title: The Changing State of Smartphone Competition in China
description: Will Android, a little rice and lot of cheap China Droids overwhelm Apples plans for China?

title: Monday Motorsports: Kimball Gets First IndyCar Win
description: Charlie Kimball took the checkered flag at Sundays Mid-Ohio IndyCar series event, his first victory. Kimball took the lead with 18 laps to go in the 90-lap event, with a pass of Simon Pagenaud. Pagenaud, who didnt give up easily, held on for a tenacious second place, followed by Dario Franchitti and Will Power. Helio Castroneves, the series points leader, finished sixth.

title: Bring on the Frankenburger
description: Updated below, 4:15 p.m. | I first explored livestock-free approaches to keeping meat on menus in 2008 in a pieced titled Can People Have Meat and a Planet, Too?

title: An American Cure
description: La Quercia Prosciutto Americano is produced by Herb Eckhouse in Iowa.

title: Some Prosciutto Fans Turn to Iowa
description: NORWALK, Iowa  The decision came down to this: Would people buy prosciutto from a guy named Herb from Iowa?

title: Comparing Republicans With the Mainstream
description: It seems like every week brings fresh evidence of the disconnect between Republicans and the mainstream. A Pew survey published last Wednesday indicated that 54 percent of Republicans think their ultra-conservative party is just not conservative enough. Todays entry is a Quinnipiac poll that asked voters to rank politicians based on how they felt about them, from a cold zero to a hot 100. The gap between the general population and self-identified G.O.P. voters was vast.

title: Third Point Reinsurance Fund Arm Seeks Up to $370.6 Million in I.P.O.
description: The reinsurance arm of Third Point, the hedge fund run by Daniel S. Loeb, disclosed on Monday that it was seeking to raise up to $370.6 million from its forthcoming initial public offering.

title: Excerpt From 'Meistersinger'
description: A clip from a performance of a new production of  Wagner's "Meistersinger von Nrnberg" at the Salzburg Festival.

title: Nesting Coffins and Low Expectations for a Comet
description: Science giveth, but it also taketh away. This week, a high status medieval coffin was opened to reveal another coffin. And what was being called the comet of the century is shaping up to be an interstellar bummer. But look, here comes the Fireball Champion.

title: Gnarly Moments in the Life of an Extreme Photographer
description: The photographer Mike Escamilla describes himself as a stuntman, professional BMX rider, actor, photographer, filmmaker, director, producer and designer. (Hes also a former X-Games competitor. In 2005 he set world records for the longest back flip and longest 360 on a BMX bike.) And he keeps an itinerary that would exhaust many photojournalists (and make many more envious);since May of this yearhe has been to Spain, Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Russia, Estonia, Latvia, Puerto Rico, Dominica, Ecuador, Germany, San Francisco and Colorado. When I came across his images on Instagram, it was clear that they were shot by someone with daring and an eye for unusual angles, giving new definition to Robert Capas famous advice to photographers: If your pictures arent good enough, you arent close enough.

title: Slow Start for Taxi-Hailing Apps, City Data Show
description: They were billed as a game-changing way to hail taxis in New York City, upsetting the urban democracy of the outstretched arm and geographic savvy, and replacing it with a smartphone app.

title: Can Immunity to the Common Cold Come With Age?
description: Q. My mother, who lived to be 92, never caught my sniffles in her later years, even though I was her sole caretaker. And now that Im in my 60s, I notice that my colds are less severe. Is it possible to develop immunity to the common cold?

title: MoMA Joins Tumblr to Reach Teens
description: The Museum of Modern Art in New York joined Tumblr on Monday with a new Web site aimed at teenagers, called MoMA Teens. Calder Zwicky, an associate educator at the museum, said they have been working on the site for the past nine months.

title: Unforgiving Land (Its Desert Rodents, Especially)
description: Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Canelo Alvarez square off in a high-profile boxing match on Sept. 14, but you dont have to wait until then to see a slam-bang fight. Theres an awfully entertaining one between two Arabian jirds on Tuesday night in Wild Arabia, on Animal Planet.

title: A Back and Forth About Narcissism
description: The social-science journal Emerging Adulthood recently invited Jean M. Twenge and one of her most prominent critics, Jeffrey Arnett, to debate whether todays emerging adults are excessively narcissistic, as Dr. Twenge asserts. Both wrote papers outlining their positions, then each wrote a reply to the other. Excerpts from the discussion follow.

title: In Performance: Young Jean Lee
description: The playwright Young Jean Lee asks some darkly comic existential questions in her pop-music cabaret Were Gonna Die, at the Claire Tow Theater. In this scene she talks about a painful breakup.

title: Loss of a Baby (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Learning From Hurt (1 Letter)
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Seeing Narcissists Everywhere
description: From the triumph of Botox to the rise of social networking and soccer teams that give every kid a trophy, Jean M. Twenge is constantly on the lookout for signs of a narcissism crisis in America.

title: Moroccan Myth, Set to Music
description: You woke me with your dreams, the goatskin-wearing deity Boujeloud says to the Moroccan shepherd Attar in Jajouka, Something Good Comes to You. With the music of your dreams! I want to hear it again, the Pan-like figure implores.

title: Whooping Cough Linked to Shorter Life Expectancy
description: People who are born during whooping cough epidemics and survive them are more likely to die prematurely later in life, according to a new study analyzing 158 years of Swedish population data.

title: The Affordable, and Therefore Enjoyable, Vacation
description: Quality time with my family is on the top of the list of things that I value. In the past, however, when we went on vacation specifically to spend time together, I was often no fun to be around because I was so anxious about money.

title: Cubas Hurricane Watch
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Turkey, Egypt, Israel and Kuwait.

title: A Glance Inside an Obscure Archive
description: A selection of images from New York Citys Department of Records and Information Services.

title: Bezos, Amazons Founder, to Buy The Washington Post
description: The Washington Post, the newspaper whose reporting helped topple a president and inspired a generation of journalists, is being sold for $250 million to the founder of Amazon.com, Jeffrey P. Bezos, in a deal that has shocked the industry.

title: Bank Behind Sale of Washington Post to Amazons Bezos
description: In a week of big media deals, the sale of The Washington Post to Jeffrey P. Bezos of Amazon.com takes the cake.

title: A Photographer Calling the Tune
description: Many aspiring country singers have day jobs, typically along the lines of waiting tables or tending bar. Not Mark Seliger. He has shot famous portraits of public figures  actors, dancers, politicians, rock stars and artists, from Jay Z to the Dalai Lama  for magazines like Time, Rolling Stone, GQ and Vanity Fair.

title: Envoys Visit a Top Islamist Inside a Jail Near Cairo
description: CAIRO  A United States envoy met with a jailed leader of the Muslim Brotherhood on Monday as part of an intensifying international effort to end the political crisis that began after Egypts security services deposed President Mohamed Morsi last month.

title: Dot Earth Makes Time Magazines List of 25 Top Blogging Efforts
description: [Updated, Aug. 6, 10:32 p.m. | Starting Wednesday, Im on the road helping my elder son relocate from New Orleans to Los Angeles, so the blog will be tended sporadically through the weekend. Please consider this an open thread focused on ways to make Dot Earth, and Web discourse more generally, engaging, productive and fun.]

title: A Library Where the Hush Is Over Its Very Existence
description: Nothing on the street outside says that it is there. First-time visitors must push through a revolving door of a court building in Lower Manhattan on faith, and hear their footsteps echo across a vast marble lobby before they finally glimpse a set of wooden double doors near a staircase leading down to a goblin-dark basement.

title: Photography Is My Wife, Music Is My Mistress
description: Mark Seliger has been among the hardest-working men in the celebrity portrait business over the last quarter century, photographing thousands of boldface names, from President Obama and the Dalai Lama to Jay-Z and Johnny Cash.

title: Rodriguezs Suspension, by the Numbers
description: From home runs to earnings, some facts about Alex Rodriguez's career in the wake of his suspension by Major League Baseball.

title: Stars, Gold, Dung Beetles and Us
description: Who was it that first said that people are stardust?

title: Teen Beach Movie Gets Big Ratings for Disney
description: Teen Beach Movie is a certified smash. Disney Channel said on Monday that about 13.5 million people had watched the beach party musical, which had its premiere on July 19. That total includes the number of viewers who watched it live (8.4 million) and a weeks worth of DVR playback viewing, a standard industry measuring stick.

title: A Return to the Lineup and a Fight to Stay
description: CHICAGO  Alex Rodriguez sat in the far corner of the Yankees clubhouse Monday afternoon, staring at a computer screen displaying video images of Chicago White Sox pitcher Jose Quintana, whom he would soon be facing. A mere 30 minutes had passed since Major League Baseball had announced Rodriguez was being suspended for 211 games in connection with its months-long doping investigation, but Rodriguez, the 38-year-old third baseman, appeared unfazed.

title: Bridges Under Construction at Newport Jazz
description: NEWPORT, R.I.  The Newport Jazz Festival, which ended Sunday at Fort Adams State Park here, is 59 now. It had early brilliance followed by middle-age aesthetic confusion, edging into pop and smooth jazz. Over the last nine years, it has corrected its course, entering a new period of steadiness and dignity as it seeks a new framing of jazz  and of its own audience.

title: Nursing Homes Dental Problems
description: Catherine Saint Louis speaks about why daily oral care in nursing facilities is almost universally overlooked, and why that can lead to dangerous complications for residents.

title: Fresh Memo From a Desk Full of Song
description: SALZBURG, Austria  The Salzburg Festival is celebrating Wagners 200th birthday with a fresh, charming and perceptive new production of Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg, which opened here at the Grosses Festspielhaus on Friday. The conductor Daniele Gatti, who won many new admirers for his performances of Wagners Parsifal at the Metropolitan Opera last season, drew a full-bodied and intriguingly intense performance of this composers sunniest score from the great Vienna Philharmonic. The cast over all was admirable, especially the distinguished German baritone Michael Volle, who brought the requisite gravitas and poignant vulnerability to his portrayal of the wise widower Hans Sachs, a shoemaker and the most beloved member of the guild of master singers in the medieval German city of Nrnberg, where the story is set.

title: Small Troupe With Outsize Talent? Youre In
description: In 1998, about a year after Jessica Lang had graduated from the dance division of Juilliard, she went back to ask Benjamin Harkarvy, then the divisions director, for advice. She was interested in choreography, she told him, and since the first piece she had created had been well received, she thought she should start her own troupe. Just because you made one good work, Mr. Harkarvy replied, doesnt mean you should have a company.

title: Florida to Execute a Paranoid Schizophrenic
description: The Supreme Court has declined to stay the execution of John Errol Ferguson, who is scheduled to die at 6 p.m. Monday evening in Florida.

title: In the Operas Shadow, Another Gem
description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival presents top-flight performers in attractive theaters in the historic heart of the city each summer and has a strong following among locals and tourists alike. Sadly, it is overshadowed in national awareness, by the Santa Fe Opera, with its spectacular open-air theater a few miles north of the city and its fancy productions. Critics flock to the opera, often without even bothering to see what is playing at the chamber festival.

title: More Music From Santa Fe
description: The Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival should not be overlooked in favor of the Santa Fe Opera.

title: CDs From Leslie Grace, Derrick Hodge and Tye Tribbett
description: LESLIE GRACE

title: A Reconsideration of Katue Kitasono, Japans Great Poet of Surrealism
description: Until recently, Japans artistic reputation in the United States was limited mainly to the very old and the very new: Edo-period ceramics and paintings, and the manga-inspired Superflat movement of the 1990s that was ushered in by Takashi Murakami. Recently, however, American curators have been taking stock of Japans compelling postwar output with 2013 exhibits like Tokyo 1955-1970: A New Avant-Garde at MoMA, the Guggenheims Gutai: Splendid Playground, about the progressive art collective that operated in the Kansai region, and last years Yayoi Kusama pop art extravaganza at the Whitney.

title: Festival of Short Plays Inspired by Trayvon Martin Case
description: The New Black Fest, which supports innovative plays by and about black people, has brought together seven playwrights to create six plays about race and privilege in the United States in the wake of the Trayvon Martin case.

title: Anita Los Shanghainese Feast
description: Anita Lo, chef and owner of Annisa in Greenwich Village, visits Flushing, Queens, to sample dishes that have inspired her cooking.

title: Anita Lo Finds Memories and Inspiration
description: Anita Lo was riding a train to Flushing, Queens, when she started talking about a creation of hers that, over the last 13 years or so, has become one of the must-try dishes in New York City: the foie gras soup dumpling at Annisa, her restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: Cruise Lines Report Crime Statistics
description: Three major cruise lines have posted on their Web sites the number of serious crimes reported on their ships, the first public airing of such statistics. The lines, Royal Caribbean Cruises, Carnival Corporation and Norwegian Cruise Line, released the figures in the wake of a Senate bill that would require all cruise lines that use American ports to report crime figures. (Currently, the Coast Guard reports crimes that are no longer under investigation by the F.B.I.)

title: Biden Vacationing in the Hamptons
description: EAST HAMPTON  The Hamptons will play host to not one but two potential 2016 presidential aspirants this month, with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. arriving this week for a vacation in Southampton. Former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has rented a house for August here in East Hampton, the next township over.

title: Detroit Manager Hires Christies to Appraise Holdings at City Art Museum
description: The city of Detroit, which has filed for bankruptcy, has formally hired the international auction house Christies to appraise part of the city-owned art collection held by the Detroit Institute of Arts, the auction house said Monday.Any decision about whether to sell the art to satisfy creditors has not been made, city officials have said, though all the citys assets are being evaluated in light of the situation in Detroit, the largest American city ever to file for bankruptcy.

title: How A-Rod Doesnt Add Up
description: Before I played a single game of professional baseball, I was a fan. If my brother and I werent chipping the paint off our parents garage door with wayward pitches during an extra-inning session of Wiffle ball, we were playing simulated games like Strat-O-Matic or baseball on our then popular 80s Intellivision video game system.

title: Going Abroad, to Cut Health Costs
Rock Throwing in the West Bank: A Rite of Passage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecuting Sex Buyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Airport Screenings
The BP Settlement: How the Lawyers See Their Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan: U.S. Military Helicopter Crashes on Okinawa
description: One crew member was missing after a United States military helicopter crashed during a training exercise on Japans southern island of Okinawa on Monday, the Air Force said. The three other crew members were in stable condition after the HH-60 helicopter crashed in an uninhabited training area on an American base, the Air Force said. No Okinawan civilians were injured, the local news media said. Still, Japanese officials in Tokyo expressed concern that the accident could stoke anger against the large American military presence on Okinawa. Defense Minister Itsunori Onodera demanded an investigation.

title: Street Style: Cut Outs
description: The best of readers photos from the week of August 5.

title: Jean-Claude Suares, 71, a Daring Times Op-Ed Artist
description: Jean-Claude Suares, an illustrator who radically altered the way editorial illustration was used at The New York Times as the first art director of its Op-Ed page, died on July 30 in Engelwood, N.J. He was 71.

title: Triple Play: Week 18 Results
description: When Cardinals dropped the first four of their five-game series against the Pirates last week, the 12.5 percent of respondents who predicted St. Louis would relinquish first place looked good. The Cardinals rallied to win three of their final four games of the week, but it wasnt enough to overtake Pittsburgh in the National League Central.

title: Benefits of Breast-Feeding
Sony Rejects Loeb Proposal for Splitting Off Entertainment Unit
description: Updated, 6:31 a.m. | Sony said late on Monday that it planned to keep all of its vast entertainment arm, rejecting a proposal by one of its biggest investors, the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb.

title: Canada: Escaped Snake Kills 2 Children, Police Say
description: Two children were killed in their sleep by a python that escaped from a pet shop, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said Monday. The boys, 5 and 7 years old, were sleeping over at a friends apartment above the store in Campbellton, New Brunswick, when the snake apparently made its way in through a ventilation shaft. An autopsy will determine the exact cause of death, but a police spokeswoman said it appeared that the children had been suffocated. It was not immediately clear how the snake had escaped from the store, but police officers recaptured it.

title: Dying Lawyer Asks Judge to Free Her From Prison
description: Lynne F. Stewart, the outspoken former defense lawyer and a polarizing figure in the criminal justice system, is fighting her final battle.

title: New York Tells Online Lenders to Abide by States Interest Rate Cap
description: Government authorities are homing in on a lucrative loophole that allows online lenders to offer short-term loans at interest rates that often exceed 500 percent annually, the latest front in a crackdown on the payday lending industry.

title: Bankers Pay Deferrals Are Tougher in Europe
description: Soon after the financial crisis, international regulators identified Wall Streets lush pay packages as one of the culprits and proposed an overhaul that was meant to apply equally to employees of American investment banks and their big European rivals.

title: Lawyers of Sound Mind?
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  LAST week, swarms of sun-starved, soon-to-be lawyers emerged from hiding to celebrate completing the bar exam. Passing the exam, however, wont guarantee them admission to the bar. They also have to demonstrate that they possess the requisite fitness and moral character for the practice of law.

title: Striking Olympic Gold
description: Imagine this: its the opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Games in Sochi, Russia. A huge television event, watched the world over. The American Olympians join the proud march of nations. Theyre our emissaries, our exemplars. And as the television cameras zoom in on Team U.S.A., one of its members quietly pulls out a rainbow flag, no bigger than a handkerchief, and holds it up. Not ostentatiously high, but just high enough that it cant be mistaken.

title: Beyond the Airport: The T.S.A.s VIPR Team
description: The Transportation Security Administration issued justification for conducting searches outside airports without probable cause, but an audit raised issues about the training and deployments of the VIPR teams.

title: Michael J. Morwood, Archaeologist Who Helped Find New Human, Dies at 62
description: Ten years ago, Mike Morwood was a leader of archaeological excavations in a limestone cavern on the Indonesian island of Flores, about midway between the continents of Asia and Australia. That was when he had the experience of a lifetime, as he said many times, the discovery of what he called a new human.

title: A Heisman Winner, and a Rule Book, Under Fire
description: The fallout from the latest episode in Johnny Manziels dizzying, TMZ-chronicled off-season extended beyond his inner circle and beyond the campus of Texas A&M and into the offices of the N.C.A.A. That organization, which governs college sports, said nothing about Manziel on Monday, and yet its silence did little to dim the continued criticism lobbed in its direction.

title: Marilyn Monroes Star Still Shines in Ad Campaigns
description: FOR an advertising campaign that aims to appeal to women from 18 to 25, Sexy Hair, the hair care brand, did not hire a celebrity spokeswoman within that age bracket like Selena Gomez or Emma Watson. Rather, the brand is featuring an actress who, had she not died in 1962, would be 87 today: Marilyn Monroe.

title: With No New iPad, Tablet Market Takes a Dip
description: Last fall, Apple introduced both the fourth generation of its popular iPad tablet and a new, mini version. Tech industry researchers figured the double release would mean no new iPads to lift Apples sales in the first half of 2013, as had been the case in other years.

title: T.S.A. Expands Duties Beyond Airport Security
description: WASHINGTON  As hundreds of commuters emerged from Amtrak and commuter trains at Union Station on a recent morning, an armed squad of men and women dressed in bulletproof vests made their way through the crowds.

title: Across Forbidden Border, Doctors in Israel Quietly Tend to Syrias Wounded
description: NAHARIYA, Israel  The 3-year-old girl cried Mama, Mama over and over as a stranger rocked her and tried to comfort her. She had been brought from Syria to the government hospital in this northern Israeli town five days earlier, her face blackened by what doctors said was probably a firebomb or a homemade bomb.

title: A French Town Bridges the Gap Between Muslims and Non-Muslims
description: ROUBAIX, France  Wearing head scarves and long skirts, the women glide along the faded back streets of this poor French town as they make their way to the mosque to hear the last prayer of the evening.

title: Groundwork Laid, Growers Turn to Hemp in Colorado
description: SPRINGFIELD, Colo.  Along the plains of eastern Colorado, on a patch of soil where his father once raised alfalfa, Ryan Loflin is growing a leafy green challenge to the nations drug laws.

title: Art Donovan, a Behemoth of Modesty, Dies at 89
description: Art Donovan, a 300-pound tackle for the Baltimore Colts whose nimble brutality helped propel him to the Hall of Fame and his team to two championships in the 1950s, and whose humor-laced tales about himself and the game won him an equal helping of celebrity, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 89.

title: What Killed Theory? (Wonkish)
description: Noah Smith has an interesting note on the death of theory in economics. Obviously thats an exaggeration, but there has been a measurable decline in the number of papers that offer theoretical innovations as opposed to empirical analysis, and also a harder to measure but unmistakable shift in the professions value structure, with empiricists reaping greater rewards and theorists valued less.

title: In Baseball Suspensions, Justice or a Scapegoat?
Newspapers Are Billionaires Latest Trophies
description: Just $250 million.

title: Falling Tree Shatters Lives and Dreams of a Family
description: The Dikov family keeps an album of photos that document the love story of their son, Aleksander, and his wife, Yingyi Li-Dikov. On each page, they beam, always hugging. In one, Ms. Li-Dikov kneels over a heart drawn in the sand, the initials A and Y at its center.

title: Boston Trial of Crime Boss Is Set to Go to the Jury
description: BOSTON  After 36 days and the testimony of 72 witnesses, the lawyers in the criminal trial of James (Whitey) Bulger made closing arguments to the jury on Monday, with the defense not contesting that Mr. Bulger was a gangland criminal of the first order.

title: A Big Name Back in the Lineup, but Crossed Off Baseballs List
description: CHICAGO  Alex Rodriguez always wanted to be the face of Major League Baseball. That desire consumed him from a very young age, when he embarked on a path of relentless achievement. Fame and money and records  he wanted it all.

title: The A-Rod Problem
description: I started writing a column for The Times about a decade ago, and I endured a tough first few months. That was, in part, because, like anybody starting a new job, I wasnt sure I could pull it off.

title: Lottery Numbers
Terrorism and the Embassies
description: The Obama administrations decision to close nearly two dozen embassies and issue a worldwide travel alert was difficult to quarrel with. We obviously do not have access to the intelligence that was the basis for the extraordinary closures, but American officials who do claim that they uncovered one of the most serious plots against United States and other Western interests since Sept. 11, 2001.

title: The Washington Post: Years of Triumph and Siege
description: Through eight decades of family ownership, The Washington Post became a journalistic powerhouse and the hub of a sprawling corporation with interests beyond media. But its foundations were shaken by the challenges of the Internet age.

title: The Players Who Accepted a 50-Game Penalty
description: Twelve players accepted 50-game suspensions from Major League Baseball on Monday in connection with the investigation into the Biogenesis clinic. Here are snapshots of all 12.

title: Rebels Gain Control of Government Air Base in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Rebel fighters on Monday swept into a sprawling government air base in northern Syria where isolated government troops had fought off their attacks for nearly a year, and by early Tuesday controlled almost all the base, seizing several tanks and other munitions and taking soldiers prisoner, rebel and opposition groups said.

title: Plan Backed by Thompson to Invest in Northern Ireland Ended at a Cost
description: It sounded like a perfectly grand idea.

title: Baseball Lowers the Boom
description: Major League Baseball suspended 13 players on Monday for violating antidoping rules, in its most sweeping and consequential enforcement action of the steroid era. The suspensions were expected but, nonetheless, striking because included was baseballs highest-paid star, Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees, who received the longest suspension ever: 211 games, through the 2014 season.

title: Its Not Just Silvio Berlusconi
description: If the serial high jinks of Silvio Berlusconi were the sole cause of Italys prolonged malaise, his conviction for criminal tax fraud last week might have signaled better times ahead. But the three-time prime minister has hardly been the only reason for Italys economic underperformance and irresponsible political culture.

title: Comforting the Loan-Sharked Brethren
description: Britains new archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, is inviting the humblest of money lenders, credit unions, into the temple. His aim is to undercut the payday lender industry that routinely and notoriously charges usurious interest rates to the working poor, and is now the subject of national scandal.

title: Texas State Senator Says Bid for Governor Is Possible
description: WASHINGTON  Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who captured the national spotlight with an 11-hour filibuster against restricting abortion rights, turned up in Washington on Monday with the news that she was considering a run for governor.

title: Lhotas War on Rats Includes Mint Bags
description: Visiting a distributor of building maintenance supplies in Queens on Monday, Joseph J. Lhota thrust a 13-gallon trash bag toward the face of a reporter.

title: A Mogul Gets a Landmark in the Capital
description: SEATTLE  The Washington of Jeffrey P. Bezos has been the one of disruptive technology, fleece jackets and software engineers. He has shown little interest in the Washington of politics, power suits and Woodward and Bernstein.

title: The Washington Post Reaches the End of the Graham Era
description: In late 2012, Donald E. Graham, the chairman and chief executive of The Washington Post Company, met with the papers publisher, Katharine Weymouth, to look at the papers future for the next three years. Their assessment troubled them.

title: The Plot to Rule College Sports
description: Be careful for what you wish for, goes the proverb. You just might get it.

title: One Weiner Idea: Cameras for the Police
description: Police officers on patrol would be required to wear miniature cameras. New Yorkers earning less than $40,000 would not pay city taxes. Helicopter rides over Manhattan would be banned for tourists and commuters.

title: Corrections: August 6, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Make Off With Things
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  You have to watch her, that Lynn Lempel. You turn your back for one second and shes making off with just about everything.

title: Cannes Villa Is Expected to Play Role in Bribery Case Against Chinese Ex-Official
description: BEIJING  More than a decade ago, a mysterious foreign buyer looking for property in France settled on a villa along the sun-bleached Riviera. The house later became tied to a British businessman, Neil Heywood, whose death in 2011 in China set in motion a political crisis within the upper ranks of the Communist Party.

title: Whats on Tuesday
description: 6:50 A.M. (Cinemax) MATCH POINT (2005) Chris (Jonathan Rhys Meyers), an Irish tennis player recently retired from the professional circuit, climbs the British social ladder after taking a job at a London club, helping its rich members polish their strokes. Soon, he has befriended Tom (Matthew Goode), an heir to a business fortune; has wooed his sister, Chloe (Emily Mortimer); and maneuvered himself into the family firm and into the family as Toms brother-in-law. But then Chris meets Toms fiance, a scrappy American actress, Nola (Scarlett Johansson, above, with Mr. Rhys Meyers), and suddenly the temperature of his life increases from a polite simmer to a full sexual boil. What passes between Chris and Nola is not only desire, but also recognition, which makes their connection especially volatile, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, describing this drama as a Champagne cocktail laced with strychnine. He added: As their affair advances, Ms. Johansson and Mr. Rhys Meyers manage some of the best acting seen in a Woody Allen movie in a long time, escaping the archness and emotional disconnection that his writing often imposes. It is possible to identify with both of them  and to feel an empathetic twinge as they are ensnared in the consequences of their own heedlessness  without entirely liking either one. But it is the films brisk, chilly precision that makes it so bracingly pleasurable. The gloom of random, meaningless existence has rarely been so much fun, and Mr. Allens bite has never been so sharp, or so deep. A movie this good is no laughing matter.

At the time, the reports authors seemed to fear that some investors might think Fannie was too cautious. In any event, a month later, that protection seemed like a joke. description: Deborah Warner, the British director who was to have overseen the Metropolitan Operas new staging of Eugene Onegin, has withdrawn from the production. The Met, in a statement, said that she bowed out because of an unexpected surgical procedure and the expected recovery time.

title: Justice Dept. Sues Bank of America Over Mortgage Securities
description: The Justice Department sued Bank of America on Tuesday, accusing the bank of defrauding investors by vastly understating the risks of the mortgages backing about $850 million in securities.

title: Pennsylvania Gunman Feuded With Officials for Almost Two Decades Over Land
description: Angry that town officials in northeastern Pennsylvania took over his junk-strewn, wooded property at a sheriffs sale last month, Rockne Newell opened fire at a township supervisors meeting on Monday night, killing three people and wounding two others before he was wrestled to the ground by two men, state police officials said on Tuesday.

title: With Cooked Tomatoes, Stick With Cool Reds or Ros
description: Raw tomatoes, high in acid, demand high-acid wines. But cooked-tomato dishes like this crostata are altogether mellower, and so welcome a wider range of wines. A high-acid wine like an unoaked barbera from Asti or Alba would still go beautifully, but so would a Sicilian nerello mascalese from Mount Etna or a good Provenal ros. Serve the reds cool. White wines would work well, too, like a falanghina or fiano di Avellino from Campania, or a good sauvignon blanc on the herbal side. Personally, because I imagine the flavors of this crostata as broad rather than sharp, I would probably stick with reds or ros. Other red options include Beaujolais, lighter pinot noirs like those from Sancerre or the range of light reds from northern Italy, like teroldego, lagrein, grignolino and those from the Valle dAosta.

title: Confessions of a Composeress
description: What is the role of the woman composer and why, after all these years, is she such a burning issue?

title: A Murder Haunts a Rugged Coast
description: Broadchurch comes to BBC America on Wednesday, riding a wave of good tidings. The ratings in Britain this spring were very strong  just shy of what Downton Abbey earned in its first season  and the reviews were rhapsodic. Fox announced last week that it would develop a version of the show, even though the original is getting its own highly publicized American run.

title: MP Taverna Astoria
description: Inside Michael Psilakiss unrestrained take on a Greek taverna.

title: Living in Lloyd Harbor
description: On Long Islands north shore, a village with water views that come with a price.

title: Lloyd Harbor, L.I.: This Market Is No Wading Pool
description: In May, after a dozen years in Manhattan, Brian and Kim Olson and their children left behind their Battery Park City rental for a meticulously renovated four-bedroom colonial they had bought for $1.775 million in Lloyd Harbor. Suddenly, the treks to the Hamptons that they had so consistently made from the city became a thing of the past. Mr. Olson, who grew up in this northwestern Suffolk County village an hour from Midtown, felt rejuvenated by his return, as if permanently on vacation.

title: Indian Music Meets Jazz in Kiplings Wild World
description: CHICAGO  The flora and fauna of India shimmer with eye-filling allure in the inventive new stage adaptation of The Jungle Book, having its premiere at the Goodman Theater here. Adapted from the Disney movie (based on the Rudyard Kipling stories) and directed by Mary Zimmerman, this modestly scaled and refreshingly spectacle-free family musical seeks to kindle childrens imaginations by softly blurring the line between man and beast, relying on the talents of designers and performers to create illusions rather than dazzling the senses with elaborate effects.

title: A Second-Generation Ode to Greece
description: If there are tweezers in the kitchen of MP Taverna Astoria, they are banned from all tasks except, perhaps, yanking bones from branzino fillets before they go on the grill. Tweezers are definitely not asked to airlift feathery microgreens onto plates that endeavor to be meditations on negative space.

title: How Should Gay Couples Fend Off Pressure to Marry?
description: Every other Tuesday, Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience. Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Mayoral Race Is Awash With Clintons Friends
description: The race for mayor has been awkward for the Clinton family. Hillary Rodham Clintons close aide Huma Abedin is married to one of the contenders, Anthony D. Weiner, who has been damaged by his admission that he had a habit of sending sexually explicit messages and pictures to women over the Internet. And in all, Bill Clinton says, five people the family counts as friends are in the running for mayor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Sudan, India, Pakistan and Argentina.

title: Deployment Factors Are Not Related to Rise in Military Suicides, Study Finds
description: In the largest study of its kind, military medical researchers have concluded that deployments to war zones and exposure to combat were not major factors behind a significant increase in suicides among military personnel from 2001 to 2008, according to a paper published on Tuesday.

title: Bloomberg Sees Higher Costs in a Union-Friendly Mayor
description: Warning of the fiscal danger if New York City fails to rein in its spiraling pension and health care costs, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday challenged his would-be successors to take a tough line in negotiations with the citys unions, while worrying aloud that whoever is elected will be too beholden to labor.

title: In a Vivid Dream, the Old Folks Home Bristles With Life
description: SALZBURG, Austria  In the early 1890s, while working with the librettist Arrigo Boito on Falstaff, his final opera, Verdi was immersed in a plan to build a retirement home in Milan for singers and musicians who had fallen upon hard times. The architect was Camillo Boito, the brother of the librettist.

title: As Detroit Flounders, Its Art Scene Flourishes
description: The night of June 20 was the Detroit native and photographer Sebastian Sullens first art exhibition, a group show called Art Ethereal: Beauty and the Beast, named for his contradictory subject: his citys majestic architecture and scarred urban blight. Part of a monthly event called Third Thursday, the show packed the Detroit Mercantile Company, a retro general store and event space. There were carrot cake, beer from a nano-brewery and, in the storefront, You Gotta Save Art! stickers ($2.50) and T-shirts ($25) for sale in support of the Detroit Institute of Arts.

title: A San Francisco Museum, Reborn on the Bay
description: On a recent afternoon along the Embarcadero, San Franciscos downtown waterfront boulevard, vintage streetcars packed with tourists clattered toward Fishermans Wharf, joggers wove through pedestrian herds, and office workers in search of lunchtime sun camped out on every bench, chair and bayside perch. But as lively as this plein-air panorama might have been, it was downright dull compared with the hyperkinetic indoor action at Pier 15, where the new home of the Exploratorium science museum opened recently.

title: Four Touches, and in the Net
description: The Red Bulls third goal against Sporting Kansas City on Saturday, the eventual game-winner, was a thing of beauty.

title: New Tools Pinpoint Natural Gas Leaks, Maximizing a Fuels Green Qualities
description: WASHINGTON  Natural gas is hailed as green and safe, but its environmental benefits and ability to temper climate change are reduced by its tendency to leak into the air undetected. Now, laser technology, some of it borrowed from the telecommunications industry, is giving engineers and scientists crucial new tools to measure leaks and track them to their source.

title: Can Parents Stay Friends With the Child-Free?
description: Time magazines latest cover piece, The Childfree Life, posits a new divide among women. Weve moved on, it says, from pitting working and at-home parents against one another to stirring up unrest between the child-ridden and the child-free  also known as the child-blessed and the childless, depending on your point of view. (You could say women with children versus women without children, but then your title would be too long and not nearly provocative enough.)

title: Dan Silverman Named Chef at Loews Regency Hotel
description: Headliner

title: Copyright Lawsuit Targets Cover Songs on YouTube
description: In the latest sign of friction over the licensing of online music, a group of music publishers has sued Fullscreen, one of the largest suppliers of videos to YouTube, saying that many of Fullscreens videos  particularly cover versions of popular songs  infringe on the publishers copyrights.

title: The Voice of the Syrian Watchtower
description: Mudar Abu Ali is the eyes and voice not of one man in one place, but of many men scattered across the northern Syrian countryside.

title: Melinda Sullivans Gone
description: Ms. Sullivans new work combines two schools of tap-dancing, one rooted in jazz and the other in musical theater.

title: A Show That Marries Pure, Rhythmic Tap to Its Musical-Theater Cousin
description: In her program note to Gone, a new dance-theater work, the choreographer Melinda Sullivan identifies two schools of tap-dancing. One comes out of jazz and is rooted in improvisational solos, emphasizing rhythm over spectacle and story. The other swerved through Broadway and Hollywood, producing the choreographed routines of musical theater. Though the divergence can be overemphasized  with racial connotations that Ms. Sullivans note carefully acknowledges  the distinctions are still in force.

title: Fake Comments Muddy a Debate in Dallas
description: Many people have offered opinions in the long-running and literally heated battle between the Nasher Sculpture Center in Dallas and a next-door condominium called Museum Tower. The condominium stands accused of producing glare that has compromised the museums galleries and garden.

title: Profit Flat at Disney, as ESPN and Parks Smooth   Setbacks in Film
description: LOS ANGELES  The Lone Ranger rode away with the Walt Disney Companys growth in the last quarter and will force the entertainment conglomerate to take a write-down of up to $190 million in the current quarter.

title: Obama's Ideas to Help Homeowners
description: The president outlined his plans to help responsible Americans own homes and addressed he bipartisan effort to overhaul the mortgage finance giants Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae.

title: Scene City: Oprah Returns to the Spotlight
description: Oprah Winfrey, Forest Whitaker, Lenny Kravitz and other co-stars attended the premiere of Lee Daniels The Butler.

title: Long Before Little Charlie Became the Face of Evil
description: Little Charlie Manson was a disagreeable child, Jeff Guinn writes in Manson, an otherwise brawny, deep-digging biography thats much more riveting than might be expected. Its no surprise that the Manson story no longer commands much attention. What a difference more than four decades make. Mr. Guinn is fascinating in his use of hindsight, and it allows him a more probing view of his subject than earlier biographers had. The books essential question is articulated in this opening quotation about the 60s, which he attributes to Tom Hayden: Over and over it came down to that question  what was reality in an unreal time?

title: Front Burner: A Biodynamic Wine Shop in Brooklyn, Hot Chocolate for Cold Sipping and More
description: To Shop: Selecting Wine Thats Biodynamic

title: 10 Questions for Rand Paul
description: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has drawn more attention than most Republican politicians lately, as his party searches for a winning national formula. Clashing with the likes of New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie  a potential 2016 presidential rival  he has promoted a libertarian brand of Republican politics featuring a less aggressive foreign policy, a more tolerant social policy, and smaller government.

title: From Winning to Wow, Festival Fun Unfurls in Crisscrossing Acts
description: VAIL, Colo.  A number of Romantic ballets have central scenes set in the woods. Far from the madding crowd, within the realm of nature, the hero discovers the otherworldly heroine who satisfies his longing as the women of his own milieu do not.

title: In-Demand Artist, Now on View in Vegas
description: Much has been made of the light and space artist James Turrells hat-trick retrospective: three simultaneous major museum shows, including one now at the Guggenheim for which hes created the largest-ever temporary installation in the museums history.

title: The Moto X From Google, iPhones Latest Challenger
description: Its getting harder and harder to invent the iPhone Killer. Even for Apple.

title: Gunfire at Board Meeting Traced to Eviction Dispute
description: Rockne Warren Newell lived alone in the Pocono Mountains of eastern Pennsylvania in utter poverty. His house was on the verge of collapse. His bathroom was a bucket.

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: The Moto X Phone
description: The Timess David Pogue examines the Moto X smartphone, Googles collaboration with Motorola.

title: In Drums and Fans, the Spirit of Korea
description: Theres soul, and then theres S(e)oul. On Sunday afternoon, Lincoln Center Out of Doors teamed up with the Center for Traditional Music and Dance to showcase The S(e)oul of Korea, a program with more to it than an embarrassing title. (What on earth were the presenters thinking?) This three-tiered presentation, which took place at Hearst Plaza, included two musical groups  the New York Korean Traditional Marching Band and Ensemble Sinawi  as well as the dance and music troupe Sounds of Korea.

title: Modern Picnic Wares for Photo-Worthy Alfresco Dining
description: Too often, picnic wares are an afterthought  cheap wicker baskets, plastic gingham blankets, throwaway utensils. Of course, the primary attractions of do-it-yourself alfresco dining are a lavish spread, a natural setting and good company. But now, thanks to a handful of artisans, there are attractive, handcrafted goods for a decidedly modern (and Instagram-friendly) outdoor culinary experience.

title: In American Greetings Deal, Echoes of Larger Buyout for Dell
description: This is a tale of two management-led buyouts.

title: Even Before a Debate, an Unfriendly Exchange
description: It was only a matter of time before the race for mayor developed its own personal feud.

title: Sometimes, Theyre Sort of Who They Say They Are
description: Were the Millers, a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; its the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts. But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative.

title: U.S. Charges Libyan Militia Leader in Benghazi Attack
description: Federal law enforcement authorities have filed murder charges against Ahmed Abu Khattala, a prominent militia leader in Benghazi, Libya, in connection with the attacks on a diplomatic mission there last Sept. 11 that killed the United States ambassador and three other Americans, according to senior law enforcement and United States officials.

title: What a Hero Goes Through to Become a Healer
description: Following the almost $226.5 million box office of the first Percy Jackson movie, the hero (Logan Lerman) has returned to save Camp Half-Blood, the training ground for Greek demigods and employer of the teacher-centaur Chiron (Anthony Head of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, at his Watcher-ly best, replacing Pierce Brosnan). When the magical tree that protects the camp is poisoned, Percy must retrieve the Golden Fleece to heal it.

title: A Challenge in the Woods
description: The sparse, somewhat surreal Kid-Thing, a new feature from the Zellner brothers, is certainly disturbing. Whether it is anything more than that depends on how much time you want to invest in contemplating the fragments youre given.

title: Tapering of Stimulus Could Start as Soon as September, 2 Fed Presidents Hint
description: Two Federal Reserve regional presidents suggested on Tuesday that the central bank could ease its extraordinary efforts to stimulate the economy sooner rather than later, but stopped short of providing an exact time frame.

title: Someone Hacked N.H.T.S.A.s Servers
description: As it turns out, even highway safety regulators are vulnerable to the ravaging hand of cybercriminals. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had some of its servers hacked last week, the agency confirmed on Tuesday.

title: Back to School, With Perks
description: The North Atlanta High School, which opens on Wednesday, cost $147 million, the most expensive school in Georgia history.

title: Leader Says Taliban Will Sit Out 2014 Afghan Election
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Despite efforts to broker a peace deal between the Afghan government and the Taliban, the insurgent group will not participate in the presidential election next year, its leader said in a statement Tuesday.

title: 21st Century Fox Has 16% Jump in Revenue on Higher Cable Fees
description: The entertainment arm of Rupert Murdochs media empire, 21st Century Fox, on Tuesday reported a 16 percent uptick in revenue for the quarter ending in June, thanks in part to the higher subscriber fees for its cable channels.

title: Chasing Milestones Near End of Road
description: As Alex Rodriguez marched toward his career total of 647 home runs, he passed many of the greatest hitters to ever play.

title: Advance Ad Sales for New TV Season Called Lukewarm
description: IT may be the right moment to add another item to the Meh List (Not hot, not not, just meh): the performance of the broadcast networks in selling commercial time ahead of the 2013-14 television season.

title: In the Jets Other Quarterback Battle, the Loser Will Hand In His Playbook
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Coach Rex Ryan opened his news conference Tuesday by announcing that Mark Sanchez would start the Jets preseason opener Friday night in Detroit, and then he went on to field eight consecutive questions about Sanchez and Geno Smith  their projected playing time and all that. It was as if Sanchez and Smith were battling for a job or something.

title: National Push by a Local Immigration Activist: No G.O.P. Retreat
description: ATLANTA  He says the United States is filling up with immigrants who do not respect the law or the American way of life. He refers to Latino groups as the tribalists, saying they seek to impose a divisive ethnic agenda. Of his many adversaries, he says: The illegal alien lobby never changes. Its the Wall Street wing of the Republican Party joining forces with the Chamber of Commerce, the far left and the Democrats in an effort to expand cheap labor and increase voting for the Democratic Party.

title: Kremlin Critic Goes From Jail to Trail
description: MOSCOW  A handful of people hovered curiously around a drab plaza in Tyoply Stan, a neighborhood on the southern edge of Moscow, attracted by volunteers handing out leaflets and a makeshift platform affixed with banners showing a man who despite global renown remains largely unfamiliar here.

title: Strong Earnings for Live Nation in Concert Season
description: With the worldwide concert business shaping up to have one of its best summers in years, the music and ticketing company Live Nation Entertainment on Tuesday reported strong earnings for its second quarter.

title: A $147 Million Signal of Faith in Atlantas Public Schools
description: ATLANTA  The most expensive public high school ever built in Georgia opens Wednesday in an old I.B.M. office building.

title: Many Mayoral Candidates Have Been What Bloomberg Is Not: Close to Cuomo
description: John A. Catsimatidis let Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo borrow a Gulfstream IV jet this spring so he could fly to Binghamton, N.Y., for a wedding. Bill de Blasio was a deputy to Mr. Cuomo during the Clinton administration; William C. Thompson Jr. was a chairman of Mr. Cuomos gubernatorial campaign; and Joseph J. Lhota served in his administration.

title: An Attack on Equality
description: In New York, widely regarded as a gay-friendly city, reports of attacks on same-sex couples are on the rise. Here, one young couple tells their story.

title: Bangladesh Takes Aim at Grameen Bank
description: The government of Bangladesh is considering nationalizing and breaking up the widely admired Grameen Bank, which pioneered the business of lending small amounts of money to poor women who want to start and grow businesses. Lawmakers should reject these destructive ideas and stop meddling in the affairs of this important financial institution, which serves 8.4 million rural women.

title: The Iron Pipeline Thrives
description: When somebody pulls a gun and commits a crime in New York City, that weapon almost certainly comes from somewhere else. Mayor Michael Bloomberg announced last week that 90 percent of the guns used to commit crimes were purchased in other states, according to the latest data from 2011, compared with 85 percent in 2009. This iron pipeline, as this illegal trade is called, is a booming and deadly business.

title: Hope for Childhood Obesity
description: After a long fight to control childhood obesity, there are encouraging signs that the tide is finally turning. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Tuesday that the obesity rate among preschoolers from poor families has fallen in 19 states and American territories, and it has risen in only three states.

title: Whats the Point of a Summit?
description: Update: On Wednesday morning, President Obama canceled a planned summit with the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin,after concluding that there had not been enough progress made on the bilateral agenda to make a meeting worthwhile.

title: Violent and Chaotic, Central African Republic Lurches Toward a Crisis
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic  The two men lay still in the back of the pickup truck, staring up. Over them stood the uniformed rebels, rifles pointing out as the truck sped forward.

title: Tech Magnates Bet on Booker and His Future
description: The conference room in the Mountain View, Calif., headquarters of LinkedIn was packed with the stars of Silicon Valley. Top executives of Facebook, Google and Twitter gathered around a table; the billionaire Sean Parker looked on from a back row. The guest of honor: Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark.

title: Couldnt the Yankees Have Waited a Day?
description: On opening night, the cheat hit cleanup. Of course he did, as the center of a circus that Alex Rodriguez was widely accused of foisting upon the poor (ha!), victimized (ha! ha!) and  more tellingly  offensively undernourished (aha!) Yankees.

title: The Tea Partys Path to Irrelevance
description: WASHINGTON  THE Tea Party has a new crusade: preventing illegal immigrants from gaining citizenship, which they say is giving amnesty to lawbreakers. Judson Phillips, the founder of Tea Party Nation, recently told Politico that his members were more upset about the amnesty bill than they were about Obamacare.

title: Diversity and Doctor Who
description: BELGRADE LAKES, Me.  YOU could hear the sighs of disappointment spreading across the nerd-universe on Sunday when the BBC announced, with much fanfare, that the Scottish actor Peter Capaldi would be the new star of Doctor Who.

title: Daring to Fail
description: Secretary of State John Kerry has pulled off a major achievement in getting Israelis and Palestinians to say yes to the United States. Can he now get them to say yes to each other?

title: An Attack on Equality
description: New York is regarded as a gay-friendly city in a state that has legalized gay marriage, but this Op-Doc video shows that it can still be dangerous for a same-sex couple to walk down the street holding hands.

title: Ex-Madam, Now Candidate For Comptroller, Is Arrested
description: Even in the topsy-turvy world of New York City politics, it is not every day that a candidate for city comptroller is arrested one month before a primary. But when the candidate is Kristin Davis, little is surprising.

title: New Leaks Into Pacific at Japan Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  Tons of contaminated groundwater from the stricken Fukushima nuclear plant have overwhelmed an underground barrier and are emptying daily into the Pacific, creating what a top regulator has called a crisis.

title: Bezos Brings Promise of Innovation to Washington Post
description: The big news in newspapers  that Jeffrey P. Bezos is buying The Washington Post  was not even 24 hours old when shock and wisecracks about the unexpected $250 million deal began to give way to acceptance and even envy.

title: Reince Is Right
description: WASHINGTON  Reince Priebus says a lot of goofy things, but the chairman of the Republican National Committee has a point.

title: At Home in This Village: Yiddish Speakers
description: NEW SQUARE, N.Y.  The very name of the village is a linguistic anomaly: New Square. Sounds as plain English as you can get, except that it was supposed to be called New Skvir after a Ukrainian town and was inadvertently Anglicized years ago as a result of a clerical error. (It is not shaped like a square, either.)

title: When Younger Players Showed Way on Testing
description: CHICAGO  Paul Konerko is not a crusader. He never has been, and he is not comfortable being cast in the role. He is a ballplayer, studious about the art of hitting, professional in his demeanor, and he would prefer to leave it at that.

title: Messages by Qaeda Chief Spur New Look at His Sway
description: WASHINGTON  The world has heard a good deal in recent days from a stern, 62-year-old Egyptian doctor thought to be hiding somewhere in Pakistan.

title: 11 Trillion Reasons
description: Heres a good line: [U]nenlightened farm policy  with its massive subsidies for junk food ingredients  has played a pivotal role in shaping our food system over the past century. But that policy can readily be changed.

title: Pilots Switched Controlling Before a Rough Landing
description: WASHINGTON  Seconds before a Southwest Airlines flight hit the runway nose wheel-first at La Guardia Airport on July 22, the captain of the plane took control from the first officer, the National Transportation Safety Board said on Tuesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Venus Williams, Still Not at 100 Percent, Loses in Return
description: TORONTO  Venus Williams made her return from a back injury on Tuesday at the Rogers Cup here, but after a three set defeat to the Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, she admitted she was still not at 100 percent.

title: Elections to Be Easier for Voters With an App
description: The election process can, at times, feel impossibly old-fashioned, as evidenced by the return of mechanical lever voting machines for this years New York City primaries. But this election season, the city will try to make it easier to register to vote, give money and communicate with campaigns, all from the palm of your hand.

title: 2 Senators Visit Egypt With Threat on U.S. Aid
description: CAIRO  On a visit at the request of President Obama, two Republican senators warned Egypt on Tuesday that the United States would cut off aid if the new military-appointed government failed to move rapidly toward democracy, including releasing the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi, and other leaders of his Islamist party from detention.

title: Thorn in Kremlins Side Runs for Mayor
description: Aleksei A. Navalnys campaign has emerged as the most significant test for Russian politics since Vladimir V. Putin returned to the presidency last year.

title: Outrage Over an Antigay Law Does Not Spread to Olympic Officials
description: The Winter Olympics begin six months from today in Sochi, Russia. Athletes find themselves in a risky situation. On the one hand, they face prosecution for advocating for gay rights. On the other, they face banishment by Olympic officials for publicly opposing Russias discriminatory new law.

title: Capping Swipe Fees
Rating Cardiac Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Stone-Throwers Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Breakfast of Champions?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sale of Washington Post
Helping the Poor Go to Good Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 7, 2013
description: Its anarchy, a nonstate. Looting, arson, rape, massacres of the civilian population  they are sowing terrorism.

title: Axel Springers New Focus on Digital Draws Cries of Betrayal
description: BERLIN  The publisher Axel Springers role in Germanys postwar history  from building its high-rise headquarters close to the Berlin Wall to antagonize the Communist authorities on the other side to denouncing the student movement in 1968  has earned it respect and disdain in equal turns.

title: Washington Steps Warily on Housing
description: WASHINGTON  In the seven years since the housing market started to fall apart, politicians of both parties have promised repeatedly to build a better system for financing the American dream of owning a home. There is little sign of progress.

title: Cary Tamarkin
description: Mr. Tamarkin, 55, is the founder of the Tamarkin Company, an architecture and development company based in New York. The firms projects include the condominiums 508 West 24th Street and 456 West 19th Street, both near the High Line.

title: Helping Housing
description: The share of new mortgages guaranteed by the federal government grew to more than 80 percent during the housing crisis and has remained there since, even as the market has begun to improve.

title: Between Players and Doping, a Valet Seen as a Middleman
description: Last year, Everth Cabrera was a promising young infielder hoping to make the San Diego Padres roster, but a nagging shoulder injury threatened to stall his big league career just as it was beginning.

title: Corrections: August 7, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Drink Garnish
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Sometimes not recognizing the theme right away can be a good thing. As frustrating as it can be to not immediately conquer the grid, remember that this is Wednesday, so Will Shortz needs to slow your roll a bit, as it were.

title: Florida: Exhumations Approved at Shuttered Reform School
description: Gov. Rick Scott and his cabinet on Tuesday voted to allow anthropologists from the University of South Florida to begin exhuming the remains of boys who were buried decades ago at the Dozier School for Boys in Marianna. The reform school, now shuttered, had a history of neglecting and abusing the boys in its care. Accusations of abuse spanned decades. A group of elderly White House boys, named for the building where they say they were beaten, have come forward in recent years to speak about the abuse. Anthropologists began identifying the graves in a portion of the school that had been set aside for black boys during segregation. Family members of some of the boys who died at the school have fought for more than a year to have the bodies exhumed, examined and reburied in cemeteries closer to home.

title: George Duke, Keyboardist Who Crossed Genre Boundaries, Dies at 67
description: George Duke, who began his career as a jazz pianist in the 1960s but made his name by crossing musical boundaries, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 67.

title: Robert Bellah, Sociologist of Religion Who Mapped the American Soul, Dies at 86
description: Robert N. Bellah, a distinguished sociologist of religion who sought nothing less than to map the American soul, in both the sacred and secular senses of the word, died on July 30 in Oakland, Calif. He was 86.

title: A Return to Downtown Birmingham
description: Long scarred as the site of brutal civil rights struggles and decades of industrial collapse, downtown Birmingham, Ala., has struggled to attract new business or visitors, even from its own region.

title: Julius Chambers, a Fighter for Civil Rights, Dies at 76
description: Julius L. Chambers, a civil rights lawyer who endured firebombings of his house, office and car in winning case after case against racial segregation, including one that led to a landmark Supreme Court decision allowing forced busing, died on Friday at his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 76.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent Sale

title: Length of Rodriguezs Suspension Was Sticking Point
description: CHICAGO  Michael Weiner, the chief of the baseball players union, said the players association had recommended that Alex Rodriguez accept a suspension from Major League Baseball if it were for a reasonable number of games. That perhaps suggests that evidence uncovered in baseballs investigation into Biogenesis, a defunct South Florida anti-aging clinic, demonstrated Rodriguez was guilty of something.

title: Russia: Tycoons Prison Sentence Is Cut by Two Months
description: Russias Supreme Court on Tuesday reduced by two months the sentence of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon and political opponent of President Vladimir V. Putin, but declined to release him immediately as his lawyers had requested in an appeal. Mr. Khodorkovsky, who was convicted of fraud and tax evasion in 2005 and money laundering and theft in 2010, is now scheduled for release in August 2014.

title: Obama Tells Leno Closure of Embassies Is No Overreaction
description: For a late-night comic Jay Leno certainly covered some serious ground with President Obama on Tuesday evening.

title: Argentina: Gas Leak Causes Deadly Residential Blast
description: Twelve people died and at least 60 more were injured, officials said Tuesday, in an explosion in the center of Rosario, Argentinas third largest city, with 1.2 million people. A gas leak from the ground floor of a residential building caused the blast on Tuesday morning, Mnica Fein, the mayor of Rosario, confirmed. Witnesses said it felt like an earthquake. I woke up and there were no walls, said Franco Jriton, who lived on the seventh floor. News channels showed that the middle block of the building, which was nine stories tall, had collapsed. There are fears that two adjoining blocks, which are badly damaged, will also fall. Fifteen people were missing. Neighbors said they had called the provincial gas company hours before the explosion, warning of a strong gas smell. The company, Litoral Gas, said it had not received any calls.

title: Amity Gardens
description: From the Fountains of Wayne album Utopia Parkway.

title: In Team Meeting, the Yankees Vent and Face Reality

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (BET) LUV (2013) A recent parolee (the rapper Common) dreaming of a better life decides to take his 11-year-old nephew (Michael Rainey Jr., above left, with Common) out of school for a day and teach him how to be a man in this crime thriller from the director Sheldon Candis. But as the boy eats his first oyster, tastes his first beer and learns how to steer a car, he also ends up being an accomplice  and perhaps a hostage  to a man who turns out to be a desperate criminal. Mr. Candis, who wrote the script with Justin Wilson, balances the more sensationalistic aspects of the movie  guns are pointed and fired, blood is shed, and threats are issued with heavy, macho menace  with keen attention to details of character and place, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The landscape of Baltimores African-American neighborhoods may be familiar to fans of The Wire (as will the faces of a few of the actors), but Luv is telling a different kind of tale about drugs, the law and urban life.
