description: SANTA FE, N.M.  The five productions of the Santa Fe Opera season come in two kinds, a distinction made clear last week, when they were presented in quick succession for the benefit of the press and other completists looking to economize. (Good luck with that in Santa Fe.)

title: Lawyer Says Fort Hood Defendants Goal Is Death
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  On the first day of his military trial on Tuesday, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan told jurors that he was the gunman responsible for a shooting rampage at the Fort Hood Army base here in 2009 and that the semiautomatic handgun displayed by prosecutors was in fact his weapon. Major Hasan, who is representing himself after releasing his Army defense lawyers, asked only a handful of questions of the prosecutions 12 witnesses, declining to cross-examine most of them.

title: Veronica Beard, Sketching and Swatching
description: In the second installment of Countdown to Fashion Week, Veronica Miele Beard and Veronica Swanson Beard share their process for sketching and swatching a new collection.

title: A Timeless Love Affair With Leica
description: The Leica has little in the way of bells and whistles, and its photography technology dates back to the mid-1950s. But it allows both amateurs and professionals to take pictures that are truly timeless.

title: Countdown to Fashion Week: At Veronica Beard, Meeting in the Middle
description: The 50 (well, not 50) shades of green tacked to the wall of the Veronica Beard showroom on West 17th Street looked for an instant like the fixings for a leafy garden salad. Minute fabric swatches, they were pinned in tidy rows to a slab of slate-tone fiberboard, where they formed the understated counterpoint to a lineup of nautical stripes, fluorescent-bright daisies and eye-popping leopard spots.

title: Daft Punk Cancels Colbert Show Appearance Because of MTV Conflict
description: Stephen Colbert and his viewers learned the hard way on Tuesday night that MTVs Video Music Awards are still a force in television and the music industry that is not to be trifled with.

title: Searching Big Data for Digital Smoke Signals
description: The office has the look and feel of an Internet start-up. The workers are young, the dress is casual and the computer of choice is an Apple notebook. They inhabit a single open room. The walls have whiteboards for scribbling ideas when inspiration strikes.

title: Florida Wins the Grand National Teams
description: ATLANTA  At the Summer North American Championships here on Sunday, the Grand National Teams was won for the third year in a row by District 9, Florida: Warren Spector of Palm Beach, Michael Becker and David Berkowitz of Boca Raton, Gary Cohler of Miami, and Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach. As they did in last years final, they defeated Jared Lilienstein, Michael Polowan, Brian Glubok, Sam Lev, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, all of New York City, representing District 24, New York City and Long Island.

title: Czech Government Loses Confidence Vote, Extending Instability
description: The new Czech government lost a confidence vote on Wednesday, extending the political instability that has undermined the country since a corruption scandal forced the collapse of the previous government in June.

title: More Flowers for Brussels
description: Fans of the biennial Flower Carpet, the elaborately patterned blooms that form a tapestry covering Brussels central square every other August, will be happy to learn that the capital of Belgium is adding an alternating floral display on odd years.

title: Small Bites, Seasonable and Subtle
description: Though the themes vary in this first of two programs of Summer Shorts at the 59E59 Theaters, a consistent standard is maintained. Its forays into show business rivalry, election year machinations and satirical fantasy dont involve passages of dramatic histrionics or riotous hilarity; rather, they pursue an understated, and effective, path to success.

title: Apps to Send Smartphone Files Into the Cloud
description: I tend to think of the word cloud in terms of cloud-decorated sunsets. Others may think of terrible thunderstorms or even tornadoes. But cloud has also taken on a high-tech meaning over recent years, as a label for online remote-access services.

title: CNN Tweaks Its Lineup Amid Executive Changes
description: One day after revamping its evening program lineup, CNN continued a week of change on Wednesday with announcements affecting the assignments of a range of executives.

title: Petersen Museum Pieces Among Cars Sold at Los Angeles Auction
description: Los Angeles has always been a challenging location for both pro football and collector car auctions. The latter is particularly odd since Southern California has always fancied itself as the epicenter of American car culture. Over the last few years, however, Barrett-Jackson and Russo & Steele have taken another stab at Los Angeles  albeit via Orange County.

title: Confounding a Smoking Ban, and Bouncers
description: Maybe it was the thumping music, the alcohol or the beating sun, or some hallucinatory combination, but for a moment in early July, it appeared as if a waterfront state park in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, had turned into a smokers paradise.

title: For Obamacare, Some Hurdles Still Ahead
description: Like other big employers, in the mid-1990s Harvard University was struggling with the ballooning cost of providing health insurance.

title: Satellite Images Show Destruction in Aleppo
description: A series of satellite images analyzed by the human rights group Amnesty International and the American Association for the Advancement of Science graphically illustrate the devastation wrought upon Aleppo, Syrias largest city, by months of ferocious combat between the government of President Bashar al-Assad and his rebel opponents.

title: The Best Sports Movies: Abdul-Jabbar Tested, Vecsey Approved
description: What is it about so-called best-of lists that riles us up so? Why do we take such offense? They are clearly harmless opinions, compiled by whomever and have no bearing on our own predilections of film, music or whatever. The whole exercise of ranking things flies in the face of art, this idea of quantification and qualification.

title: Fashions Blind Spot
description: Five years ago, the fashion industry faced a reckoning over the startling lack of diversity among the models on major designer runways. Reacting to complaints that many shows and magazines included nothing but white models, Vogue, in its July 2008 issue, featured a substantial article that asked, in its headline, Is Fashion Racist?

title: Magician of Light and Silver, Circa 1860
description: Salman Rushdie, in his novel  The Ground Beneath Her Feet  (1999), described what we see in a photograph as a moral decision taken in one-eighth of a second.In the early days of photography, those moral decisions took longer to process. When Mathew Brady, the Civil War-era photographer, took a portrait, the shutter remained open for 10 to 15 seconds or more, long enough for a bit of wind, or the hint of a smile, to ruin everything. His subjects often had their heads stabilized by an unseen vise.

title: Set of The Drowned Man
description:
The set designer Livi Vaughan describes the dressing room portion of The Drowned Man: A
Hollywood Fable, the new show from the Punchdrunk theater company of London.

title: A London Troupe Thrives With Ambitious Free-Range Theater
description: LONDON  For his final directing project as a student at the University of Exeter, Felix Barrett had the sort of eureka moment that careers are built on.

title: A Whirl of Premieres, From Jookin to Jets
description: VAIL, Colo.  As artistic director of the Vail International Dance Festival, Damian Woetzel has become one of the foremost impresarios of American dance. To cite just one example: Without Mr. Woetzel, the jookin star Charles Riley, known as Lil Buck, might well have remained little known, and Memphis jookin itself would be considerably more obscure. And there are a number of other dancers and choreographers for whom this Vail festival has been an important stage of growth.

title: Lighting, Textiles, Seating and More
description: Lighting, wall art, seating and sculptural room dividers are up to 90 percent off at Aswoon/Susan Woods Studio, while supplies last (a light tapestry, shown, regularly $15,000,

title: Telling Stories, Selling Beauty
description: WEST CHESTER, PA.  Hold on to your panties because Im about to tell you a story, said Mally Roncal, a makeup artist and the founder of the makeup line Mally Beauty, looking straight into the camera at the QVC studio here.

title: Hotel Chelsea by Victoria Cohen
description: In 2011, when the photographer Victoria Cohen heard that the Hotel Chelsea  the talent-suffused West 23rd Street building that housed the likes of Virgil Thomson, Bob Dylan, Janis Joplin, Charles Bukowski, Arthur C. Clarke, Allen Ginsberg and Sid Vicious  was to be sold and gut-renovated, she set out to document the rooms. It became a responsibility, not just an artistic endeavor to capture the essence, she said. I was not photographing empty rooms, I was taking portraits. The images in her new book, Hotel Chelsea (Pointed Leaf Press, $95), are as vivid and haunting as characters in a Fellini film. Shot in natural light, they summon the ghosts of those who lived with blood-red walls, spartan corner sinks or broken-down beds. An exhibition runs from Sept. 17 to Oct. 25 at Third Streaming, 10 Greene Street (Canal Street); pointedleafpress.com.

title: Concealing an Electrical Panel
description: Q. How can I make the electrical panel in my apartment less of an eyesore?

title: The Retro Breadbox Is Stale No More
description: Many baby boomers have fond memories of their parents kitchen gadgets: rotary egg beaters, electric percolators, Salton Hot Trays and various kinds of breadboxes. Countertop containers for baked goods were rife in the 50s and 60s, but they took on a minor role with the rise of commercially produced bread wrapped in plastic and loaded with preservatives. Now, with artisanal bread a staple in many homes, the breadbox is poised for a revival. Wesco, a German company, has reintroduced its Bauhaus-style Grandy model, designed in 1946 by Josef Neuhaus. Made of powder-coated steel, it has ventilation holes in the back, nonslip feet and a metal handle and hinges. The 16-inch-wide box comes in a glossy apple red from the Museum of Modern Art store, for $100. Available on Aug. 15 (orders starting Friday): (800) 851-4509 or momastore.org.

title: Pull Up a Chair, Sandy
description: Jedediah Morfits bas-reliefs have roots that are traditional, though his interpretation is anything but. My work takes inspiration from decorative plates or decorative plasterwork youd see in old houses, said Mr. Morfit, 40, who lives in Collingswood, N.J. But then it takes a sharp detour.

title: An Island for Artists Only
description: Rabbit Island, a secluded artists colony in Lake Superior.

title: An Island for One, With Room to Share
description: RABBIT ISLAND, MICH.  The list of people who own their own islands is small. Exclude royals and Richard Branson, and it is smaller still. Rob Gorski became an unlikely member of the club three years ago, when he bought a 91-acre island off the Keweenaw Peninsula of Michigan after spotting it on Craigslist.

title: Using Baseball History to Teach Children Big Lessons
description: On a recent morning in the Longwood neighborhood of the South Bronx, residents on Fox Street were starting their day. Reggaeton played from a second-story window. A man whistled a nursery rhyme while briskly pushing a toddler in a stroller. A woman stood on the corner with rollers in her hair, smoking a cigarette. And in a room at the end of a hallway on the first floor of 830 Fox Street, about two dozen children, ages 6 to 12, sat before a big-screen TV mounted on the front wall.

title: Mementos, Both Personal and Historical
description: A new exhibit at the Smithsonian features a selection of objects that Americans have saved as historical mementos.

title: Neighborhood Joint: The Lindenwood Diner
description: The Lindenwood Diner in East New York, Brooklyn, has been open since 1967.

title: Toys and Bits From the Attic
description: A curious mishmash is about to go on display in Washington. Among the items: a bagful of chads formerly hanging from Broward County, Fla., presidential election voting ballots; snippets of Rutherford B. Hayess hair; and a chestnut from Mount Vernon embedded with a tiny compass.

title: Empty Nest as Urban Loft
description: A sleek new house in Mill Valley, Calif., home to the cycling Goldsteins.

title: Riding in Tandem
description: Her husband, Ross, calls her Mosquito because thats what she looks like to him  all awkward elbows and determination  when he is riding behind her on bicycle trips here in Marin County, Calif., or, farther afield, on more ambitious tours through the hills of Idaho or Italy.

title: Pentagon Finishing Rules to Curb Sexual Assaults
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel is completing new rules to fight what he has called a scourge of sexual assault in the military, taking steps meant to guarantee high-level attention to accusations of wrongdoing and to offer greater protections to victims, according to Pentagon, administration and Congressional officials.

title: Entry Hall Accessories
description: For the New York designer Suchi Reddy, an entry hall is more than a place to hang your hat. Its an opportunity to be expressive.

title: Shopping for the Entrance Hall
description: The foyer sits on the threshold between public and private realms and signals your sense of style.

title: An Erica Tanov Boutique Opens at ABC Carpet & Home
description: In the 23 years since Erica Tanov first sold Bohemian-inspired lingerie in NoLIta, her company has grown to include ready-to-wear, leather goods and textiles. Last week, Ms. Tanov, now based in Berkeley, Calif., with three Bay Area stores, opened a boutique at ABC Carpet & Home. Paulette Cole, ABCs chief executive, said shes long felt aligned with Ms. Tanovs philosophy, which champions the connection between the self and home. A highlight of the shop: cotton textiles from Ms. Tanovs work with disabled artists from Creative Growth, a nonprofit, like the 18-inch pillow ($95), above left, sitting atop quilts ($202 to $453). There are also beeswax candles ($38), vintage Japanese plates ($35 each) and Indian leather notebooks ($46 each); 888 Broadway (East 19th Street), (212) 473-3000 or ericatanov.com.

title: Your Own Private Idaho
description: The Entering Stanley, Idaho sign seemed more like a friendly warning than a welcome. Population 63, it read, as if to say: Congratulations, youve made it to the middle of nowhere. Stanley is the entry point to the Sawtooth Valley, a time warp of a place with four saloons, five mountain ranges and not much else. My husband, Josh, our two children and I had driven three hours from Boise along an empty, winding two-lane scenic byway for a week of summer adventure. Still, as we strolled down deserted, dusty Wall Street looking for a lunch spot, it was hard not to wonder: Where is everyone?

title: Serenity in the Sawtooths
description: Staggering beauty? Check. Crowds? Not so much.

title: Amid Turmoil, Lebanese Music Festival Presses On
description: BAALBEK, Lebanon  Under the towering columns of the Roman temples here, the Baalbek International Festival over the years has brought the likes of Mstislav Rostropovich, Miles Davis, Sting and the Egyptian singer Umm Kulthum for an annual musical celebration that for many Lebanese symbolizes the openness and cultural richness that coexists with their countrys periodic instability and war.

title: First Impressions: Furnishing the Foyer
description: To hear Suchi Reddy tell it, the entrance hall gets no respect. People just think about their couch, their TV and where theyre going to sleep and eat, said Ms. Reddy, 46, the owner of the New York interiors firm Reddymade Design.

title: The Horticult at Home
description: A San Diego couple known for their gardening blog built almost all their outdoor furniture.

title: Marriage Is Yard Work
description: SAN DIEGO  On a recent Thursday evening, the United States Navy notified Ryan Benoit that instead of tracking the $150 million overhaul of the Essex, an 844-foot-long air and amphibious assault ship, he should probably drink a couple of gin and tonics with his wife and water the drooping lettuce in his planter.

title: On QVC, Beauty and the Tube
description: Selling cosmetics and grooming tools on television shopping networks has become a robust business, online and by phone. Below, a range of product picks from on the air.

title: On the Verge | Uzes, the Hidden Gem of the South of France
description: Oh little town of Uzs! the French novelist Andr Gide wrote affectionately of his fathers hometown in the South of France in his 1924 memoir, Unless the Seed Dies. If you were in Umbria, Parisians would be visiting you in herds! Gide, who was born into a middle-class Protestant family and scandalized France with a blunt but elegant defense of his homosexuality in Corydon, also published in 1924, was a wry and astute observer of Parisian snobberies. So hed surely be amused to learn that today a taste-making coterie of Parisians is falling in love with Uzs and settling there, despite the fact that its not in Umbria.

title: For a Talent Scout, Big-League Space
description: LAST WEEK WAS a busy week in the life of Nevena Borissova, who opened her first Curve boutique in Los Angeles in 1997, when she was just 22, a high school dropout and a part-time assistant to fashion stylists.

description: The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Heres what we noticed today:

title: Video of Veterans Describing Sexual Advances by San Diego Mayor
description: Last Updated | 6:45 a.m. Thursday. Two women who were victims of sexual assault in the military said Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego made unwanted sexual advances toward them after meeting them at a veterans event, my colleague Ian Lovett reports.

title: The Stars Align for The Butler
description: Oprah Winfrey does not have a top-rated daily television show anymore, but that didnt stop photographers from going positively mad on Monday night when she arrived at the Ziegfeld Theater for the premiere of Lee Danielss movie The Butler, in which she stars with Forest Whitaker.

title: Cory Bookers Silicon Valley Friendships Started at Stanford
description: Cory A. Booker has deep ties to Silicon Valley, ties so deep that they have raised questions about money and influence, particularly now that Mr. Booker, the mayor of Newark, is running for Senate.

title: Blackstone Is Expected to Sell Hilton in I.P.O.
description: Updated, 8:10 p.m. | As private equity firms rush to cash in on their investments, the Blackstone Group is moving to sell one of the biggest companies to go private in recent years.

title: Niese Is Set to Rejoin the Mets Rotation
description: Mets starter Jonathon Niese, on the disabled list with a partial tear in his rotator cuff, proclaimed himself ready to go after throwing a pain free minor league rehabilitation start Tuesday. He is scheduled to start Sunday against the Arizona Diamondbacks. Nieses reintroduction into the rotation means the Mets will once again use a six-man staff for the foreseeable future.

title: A Killer Hears About What Could Have Been
description: One by one, the relatives of a young man who was gunned down in Harlem last year while on a trip home from college, stood up in a courtroom to tell the killer that had he chosen a different path, he would have been welcomed into the loving home of his victims family.

title: The Times Isnt for Sale, Its Publisher Declares
description: After a week in which both The Boston Globe and The Washington Post were purchased by new owners, the publisher of The New York Times emphatically declared Wednesday night that the publication was not for sale.

title: Getting a Head Start on Fall Fashion
description: At the risk of sounding springist, isnt fall everyones favorite season for fashion? This time around, the range of trends  rock n roll grunge (yes, still going strong), slick minimalism and lavish decadence  means that fashion has more room for individuality than 16 Handles. To get a jump on the season, look for everyday pieces and build on them. Here, some suggestions.

title: From the Borough of Writerly Types, a Look Inward
description: At around 7 on a recent weekday evening, the days oppressive heat only just beginning to ebb, Adelle Waldman walked out among the picnic tables on the patio of the Hot Bird, a Brooklyn bar repurposed from an old garage, self-consciously carrying her just-published book, The Love Affairs of Nathaniel P.

title: Haiti: Report Blames U.N. Camp for Deadly Cholera Outbreak
description: Adding to assertions that United Nations peacekeepers inadvertently brought a strain of cholera to Haiti, a new Yale University report holds the organization responsible for a recent outbreak and concludes that it should help the victims. Sewage from a United Nations camp contaminated one of Haitis largest rivers, the report said. The United Nations has steadfastly denied causing the epidemic, which has killed more than 8,000 people since it began in 2010, and has resisted paying any compensation. By not holding itself accountable to victims, the report stated, the United Nations is violating its obligations under international law.

title: Special Night for Camping Not Far From Citys Lights
description: Anywhere else it would have been a typical summer scene.

description: Openings and Events

title: A Cold Current
description: DeLisle, Miss.

title: Wal-Mart Settles OSHA Case Over Cleaning Procedures
description: Wal-Mart Stores has agreed to a corporatewide settlement to improve safety conditions related to trash compactors and cleaning chemicals in more than 2,800 of its stores, the United States Department of Labor announced on Wednesday.

title: Venezuelan Court Rejects Challenge to Presidential Election Results
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The Supreme Court on Wednesday rejected a series of legal challenges to the narrow election victory of President Nicols Maduro, closing a chapter in what has been a bitter aftermath of the vote to replace the countrys popular longtime leader, Hugo Chvez.

title: Times Reporter Seeks Subpoenas Withdrawal
description: A lawyer for James Risen, an author and a reporter for The New York Times, has asked Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. to withdraw a subpoena requiring him to testify about a confidential source, in light of the Justice Departments new guidelines for obtaining information from journalists in investigations. On July 19, a federal appeals court ruled that Mr. Risen must testify in the criminal trial of a former C.I.A. official, Jeffrey Sterling, who is charged with leaking classified information. The case involves material published in Mr. Risens 2006 book, State of War. The ruling came a week after Mr. Holder released a report on significant revisions to Justice Department policies intended to strengthen protections for members of the news media. The amended guidelines call for tactics like subpoenas to be treated as extraordinary measures to be used as a last resort, noted David N. Kelley, Mr. Risens lawyer, in a letter to Mr. Holder. We urge you to apply those principles to this case, Mr. Kelley wrote. A spokesman for the Justice Department said it was examiningthe next steps in the prosecution of this case.

title: Owner of Music Schools Charged With Molesting 9-Year-Old
description: The 70-year-old owner of several private music schools for young children in Manhattan has been charged with sexually molesting a 9-year-old girl during lessons over the course of nearly two years.

title: Even if Elected, Hes Just Serving Coffee
description: THE race for mayor of New York City is about to get more crowded, but the latest entrant promises, to borrow a phrase from baseball, to stay only long enough for a cup of coffee.

title: Now Playing at the Womens Tournament: Men
description: TORONTO Three players who lost in the first round of the mens Rogers Cup in Montreal will travel to Toronto to take part in exhibition matches during the womens Rogers Cup event here.

title: JPMorgan Reveals It Faces Criminal and Civil Inquiries
description: JPMorgan Chase disclosed on Wednesday that it faced a criminal and civil investigation into whether it sold shoddy mortgage securities to investors in the run-up to the financial crisis, the latest legal threat to the nations biggest bank.

title: San Diego Mayor Faces New Claims, From Veterans
description: LOS ANGELES  The embattled mayor of San Diego has stepped away from city politics to attend a two-week behavior treatment program, but his absence from City Hall has not stemmed a tide of sexual harassment allegations against him.

title: Boy, 15, Quits Board Tied to Booker Start-Up
description: Andrew Zucker, the 15-year-old son of Jeff Zucker, president of CNN, resigned on Wednesday from a board that advises an Internet start-up founded by Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark.

title: Caustic Light on White Houses Reaction to  a Terrorist Threat
description: WASHINGTON  The gloating among jihadists and their sympathizers began last week, right after the United States shut down almost two dozen diplomatic posts across the Middle East in response to a terrorist threat.

title: Higher Costs Seen for Some in Congress on Health Plans
description: WASHINGTON  Older members of Congress and those who smoke, like Speaker John A. Boehner, could be facing much higher health insurance premiums under a new official interpretation of President Obamas health care law.

title: Too Much Work?
description: Americans have undoubtedly learned more in the past couple of months about the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court and its extensive powers than in the previous 35 years of the courts existence. But it shouldnt have taken the renegade intelligence analyst Edward J. Snowden to let us in on a fact that, while hardly secret, had been little noticed: in establishing the court, Congress gave the authority to name its judges to one individual, the chief justice of the United States.

title: Crazy Pills
description: CHICAGO  ON Oct. 16, 2002, at 4 p.m., I walked out of my apartment in Secunderabad, India, leaving the door wide open, the lights on and my laptop humming. I dont remember doing this. I know I did it because the buildings night watchman saw me leave. I woke up the next day in a train station four miles away, with no idea who I was or why I was in India. A policeman found me, and I ended up strapped down, hallucinating in a mental hospital for three days.

title: From Maoist Criminal to Popular Hero?
description: ANY day now  the authorities wont say precisely when  China will begin one of the most sensational trials in its modern political history, when Bo Xilai, the former rising star in the Politburo and Communist Party boss in the megacity of Chongqing, faces corruption charges.

title: Hollande Vows to Tackle Rising Unemployment, but the French Are Skeptical
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande visited an employment center in Frances heartland this week, armed with promises to reduce record unemployment. That was not enough for Nathalie, a 50-year-old who has long struggled to find work.

title: City Agrees to Expunge Names Collected in Stop-and-Frisk Program
description: The Bloomberg administration has been unmoved by criticism of the stop-and-frisk program, steadfastly declaring that the tactic is necessary to keep crime down.

title: Not Native to N Train, a Shark Hitches a Ride
description: The Mustelus canis shark, often referred to as the smooth dogfish, is known to skulk from the edge of New England to the Gulf of Mexico, off the coast of Brazil and along the shores of northern Argentina.

title: Eli the Rapper Gets a Thumbs Up From Some Big Critics
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The first preseason game is Saturday. There is a roster to trim and a playbook to install, but on Wednesday the monotony of Giants training camp was delightfully interrupted by a rap video.

title: Disclosures From Mr. Booker
description: Mayor Cory Booker of Newark, who wants to be the next senator from New Jersey, has an obligation to give a full and personal accounting of his involvement in an Internet start-up that he formed with the help of several high-powered investors from Silicon Valley.

title: Fast-Food Fight
description: The fast-food workers who have been walking off their jobs illustrate a central fact of contemporary work life in America: As lower-wage occupations have proliferated in the past several years, Americans are increasingly unable to make a living at their jobs. They work harder and are paid less than workers in other advanced countries. And their wages have stagnated even as executive pay has soared.

title: New Yorks Common Core Test Scores
description: Over the last decade or so, most states deceived the public about the dismal quality of public schools by adopting pathetically weak learning standards that made children appear better prepared than they actually were. Not surprisingly, when states like Kentucky dropped the charade and embraced more challenging standards, scores dropped precipitously.

title: A Cafe Where the Spirit of the Arab Spring Lives On
description: TUNIS  In the heat of the afternoon, especially this past month of Ramadan, downtown Tunis plays dead. Offices and shops close at 2 p.m. and life is suspended as everyone, parched and hungry, waits for sunset and the breaking of the fast.

title: Dispute Over Value-Added Tax on Movie Tickets in China Appears Near End
description: LOS ANGELES  A heated Chinese business and political dispute that has stopped about $200 million in box-office payments to Hollywood studios appears near a resolution, just as outlines of the fight were first emerging in public.

description: The United States  and indeed the world  is straining under the weight of an aging population, and that strain is only expected to grow.

description: Hundreds of manatees, pelicans and dolphins have died in the northern section of the Indian River estuary.

description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Gov. Rick Scott of Florida, newly empowered by the United States Supreme Courts ruling in June that struck down the heart of the Voting Rights Act, has ordered state officials to resume a fiercely contested effort to remove noncitizens from voting rolls.

title: A Yankee (Not Rodriguez) Creates Buzz
description: CHICAGO  After the 2000 World Series, when Alex Rodriguez was a free agent and a pipe dream for Mets fans, Bobby Valentine, then the Mets manager, made a more realistic request to the teams assistant general manager, Omar Minaya.

description: ZHONGSHE, China  A moribund coal mine here descends deeply, more than 3,800 feet underground. But the deal in which a Chinese state-owned conglomerate bought it may be even darker and more labyrinthine.

description: CARTAGENA, Colombia  This is a story of two unlikely allies, the wealthy executive/mother and the prostitute/drug smuggler, who rescued each other.

description: Invoking the specter of criminal charges against officials of the State University of New York for obstructing the delivery of emergency room services at Long Island College Hospital, a State Supreme Court judge warned lawyers for SUNY and the state on Wednesday that he might require a week of daylong hearings before deciding whether to dismiss the latest civil actions seeking to keep the hospital open.

title: Deaths of Manatees, Dolphins and Pelicans Point to Estuary at Risk
description: MELBOURNE, Fla.  The first hint that something was amiss here, in the shallow lagoons and brackish streams that buffer inland Florida from the Atlantics salt water, came last summer in the Banana River, just south of Kennedy Space Center. Three manatees  the languid, plant-munching, over-upholstered mammals known as sea cows  died suddenly and inexplicably, one after another, in a spot where deaths were rare.

In the seriess first episode, Brodie struggles to balance the personal and professional as he tries to solve a case involving a girl who went missing 30 years earlier. Case Histories is trying for something lighter (while remaining artfully blood soaked), and some mystery fans might find it a welcome change, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times when the series made its debut in 2011. Mr. Isaacs (above with Millie Innes) is very likable as Brodie, he added. If you can ignore that hes playing a character built on spare parts from Raymond Chandler novels and Willie Nelson songs, that may be enough.

title: Part Ramones Biography, Part Dreamscape
description: In 1979, the Ramones were recording at a studio in Los Angeles with the producer Phil Spector, whose work with the Ronettes, the Righteous Brothers and the Beatles had earned him a reputation as both a musical genius and an exacting, combustible egomaniac. He hadnt produced a hit since John Lennons Imagine in 1971, and the Ramones, who had released four critically acclaimed albums of exuberant punk rock, were still searching for a commercial breakthrough. The sessions for the resulting album, End of the Century, were tumultuous, and the opening pages of the new book, Gabba Gabba Hey!: The Graphic Story of the Ramones, written by Jim McCarthy and illustrated by Brian Williamson, details some of Mr. Spectors more notorious moments: forcing the guitarist Johnny Ramone to play the opening chord to Rock N Roll High School more than 70 times; pointing a gun at the bassist Dee Dee Ramone.

The wraparound chrome siding suggests its an American-style diner, but the place, which opened last month after being shuttered for several years, has a different kind of stateside flavor. The clean palette, vast airiness and abundant flora creates a Palm Springs-by-way-of-Big Sur resort feel. On the main floor, a wealth of natural wood  slatted tables, floors painted with pastel geometric shapes, siding made of reclaimed timber and a polished bar  is complemented by potted succulents and painted white accents. Upstairs, there are hexagonal tables and vintage Modernist daybeds where guests can sip the restaurants agave cocktails and eat its organic burgers.

title: This Blog Has in Fact Published Stuff Other Than the George Saunders Graduation Speech
description: The first rule of going viral is that you should never plan to go viral. And with that rule in no way in mind  thats the point! you cant think about it!  Joel Lovell let a casual e-mail correspondence with George Saunders morph into a blog post that reached a level of Internet popularly normally reserved for Lindsay Lohan and counterintuitive arguments about yoga. His reproduction of Saunderss graduation speech at Syracuse University was by orders of magnitude the most popular thing ever to run on The 6th Floor blog  which has, since its inception, been a strong believer in the first rule of going viral. As the magazines editor, Hugo Lindgren, wrote in his inaugural post in March 2011, This blog is meant as a humble complement to the magazine  a place to let readers listen in on the conversations that happen in the office. We never planned to be the fastest, nor the buzziest, nor to have the most cat GIFs (a staple of the second rule of going viral). We just planned to do the sort of stuff that magazine editors do  allow our curiosity to wander and see where it leads, as Lindgren put it  but do it a little more publicly.

title: Canadian Teenagers Suicide Case Is Back in Spotlight
description: Updated, Friday, 12:43 p.m. | The suicide of a Canadian teenager in April revived outrage that the police did not go far enough to investigate allegations that she was gang-raped in 2011, then bullied after images of the assault were shared and posted online.

title: More on Sequestrations Effects on the Private Sector
description: Back in June I wrote about the private industries whose employment was most dependent on defense funds, and which were therefore most likely to suffer from sequestration.

title: Delta Will Serve Up Some Blue Smoke
description: Delta Air Lines announced an in-flight partnership Thursday with Blue Smoke, a New York City barbecue restaurant that is part of Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group.

title: As Cost of U.K. Rail Project Grows, So Does Resistance
description: ALTOFTS, England  A proposed high-speed railroad known as HS2 is Britains biggest and most controversial transportation plan, a Continental-style grand projet meant to ease crowded trains and congested tracks, reduce automobile traffic and generate economic growth.

title: Grand Jury Decides Not to Charge Officer Who Fatally Shot Unarmed Youth in Bronx
description: Eighteen months after a police officer barged into a private residence and fatally shot an unarmed teenager in the bathroom of the home, the criminal case against the officer has collapsed with a grand jurys decision to not bring charges in the case.

title: Raw Footage: Flooding in the Midwest
description: Floods in Nashville and southern Missouri have shut down roads and forced dozens of residents out of their homes.

title: Market Report | Strappy Flats for Every Type
description: A crop of black, closed-toed, strappy flats  the pointy-toed big sisters to Mary Janes and T-strap sandals  is popping up to carry late-summer wardrobes into cooler fall temperatures. From patent leather (Casadei and Jimmy Choo) to suede (Armani) to lace (Erdem) to studs (Freda Salvador), theres a style for everyone. And for the truly bold, there are even crystals (Tabitha Simmons) for a little extra vamp.

title: Food Rituals
description: Scientists have found that rituals performed around food actually influence the way the food is enjoyed. We all have our food rituals -- from splitting apart the oreo cookie to folding a pizza slice.

title: Taken to Heart
description: When a writer chooses to express something in a particular way, all the other approaches he might have chosen are usually encouraged to disappear in the hope of creating an atmosphere of authority and precision. Javier Maras, the masterly Spanish novelist, follows the opposite policy and, even after he has filled a descriptive vacancy, continues to interview other candidates for the job. The rival formulations turn up one after another, in sub-clauses that offer everything from subtle qualification to flat contradiction. Here is the narrator of The Infatuations, Marass new novel, contemplating the memory of Miguel and Luisa, the husband and wife she grew to think of as the Perfect Couple, if only on the thin basis of observing them have breakfast each morning in the same cafe:

title: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
description: Among the many individual stories of World War I that will doubtless be told and retold for the centenary years between 2014 and 2018, that of T. E. Lawrence stands out from all the rest. As Scott Anderson says at the beginning of Lawrence in Arabia, historians have never quite decided what to make of the young, bashful Oxford scholar who rode into battle at the head of an Arab army and changed history.

title: Elisabeth Maxwell, Expert on Holocaust, Dies at 92
description: Elisabeth Maxwell helped her husband run a multibillion-dollar business and a 53-room manor. Each year she made a scrapbook of press clippings about him; some years it tipped the scales at 60 pounds.

title: Scenes From Italys Heel
description: Take a stroll around Lecce, a historical town in the Puglia region.

title: 36 Hours in Lecce, Italy
description: Thanks to dozens of mostly Baroque-era churches packing its maze of narrow streets, Lecce, the Florence of the South, dazzles with elaborately carved facades and interiors that erupt with symphonies of angels, cherubs, saints, saviors and Madonnas. But this small gem in Italys heel is far from a haven of monkish abstemiousness. A capital of southern Italian cooking, the city brims with rustic restaurants serving the hearty peasant cuisine and robust red wines of the Puglia (Apulia in English) region. Throw in a buzzing bar scene and nearby beaches of sun-bronzed bodies and you have a city fit for holy men and hedonists alike.

title: Near Paris, a City of Flaubert and Joan of Arc
description: Gustave Flaubert reportedly once said that he wrote his novels to resemble a particular color. In Madame Bovary, he remarked, all I was after was to render a special tone, that color of the moldiness of a wood-louses existence. He may well have achieved that with his depiction of illusory love in his novel. But Rouen, France  Flauberts birthplace and the setting for a good portion of Madame Bovary  evokes a different mood altogether.

title: Researchers Suspect That Camels Are Linked to a Middle East Virus
description: Camels may be a carrier of the mysterious virus that has infected at least 94 people in the Middle East and killed half of them, scientists are reporting.

title: Can You Guess What This Is?
description: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

title: Glenn Goldberg: Other Places
description: Jason McCoy Gallery

title: Conspicuous Unusable
description: Miguel Abreu Gallery

title: After the Opt-Out Revolution, Asking: Hows That Working for You?
description: A decade ago, Lisa Belkin (my predecessor here) wrote the article The Opt-Out Revolution, now a classic, for The New York Times Magazine. It spawned both a shorthand for the educated mother who has left a career to stay home and a backlash of complaint (statistically, the revolution was a blip at most, and limited to an economically fortunate few). It also informed thousands of conversations among women across generations about what it meant to choose career or motherhood, and what needed to change in order to allow us to more easily choose both.

title: Nikolay Bakharev
description: Julie Saul Gallery

title: Simon Fujiwara: Studio Piet (King Kong Komplex)
description: Andrea Rosen Gallery

title: Real Estate Q & A
description: Withholding Maintenance Over a Noisy Neighbor

title: Gentlemen at Work
description: Boris Kachkas Hothouse is a big wet kiss to the publishing house Farrar, Straus & Giroux. It does its mightiest to find a Platonic ideal in the very way that Farrar, Straus authors, editors and books put words to paper. Surely this is a house with a longer, grander history and greater commitment to serious literature than some other publishers can claim, but is there no such thing as overkill? It once put out an edition of Courtney Loves diaries that, Mr. Kachka writes, were meant to be purchased by Lord knows whom. The same must be said of Hothouse, thanks to its fanzine breathlessness and tireless fawning.

title: Gee Helps Mets Finish Sweep and Rediscover Optimism
description: In the span of a few days recently, the Mets lost third baseman David Wright, closer Bobby Parnell, reliever Josh Edgin and most of the confidence they had built over the last two months. They seemed to sleepwalk through a series against the Kansas City Royals and appeared to be teetering toward yet another second-half meltdown.

title: A Poll by The Times Finds That Rodriguez Is Alienating Many Yankees Fans
description: Will Alex Rodriguezs return to Yankee Stadium on Friday be met with cheers or jeers?

title: Moscow 57 to Put Down Restaurant Roots
description: Moscow 57, the food and entertainment company started several years ago by Ellen Kaye, has long had a pedigree: Ms. Kayes parents, Faith Stewart-Gordon and Sidney Kaye, owned the Russian Tea Room from 1947 to 1996. But only now has it found itself a home.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, India, Kenya and California.

title: U.S. Cracks Top 20 in FIFA Rankings
description: A run of 11 straight victories, including winning the Concacaf Gold Cup championship, has sent the United States mens national team into the top 20 of the latest FIFA rankings, which were released on Thursday. It is the first time since 2011 the U.S. men have been ranked as high.

title: Going to MoMA to See the Sounds
description: Three summers ago, the Museum of Modern Art installed a 1961 sound art work by Yoko Ono in its atrium. It was called Voice Piece for Soprano  Scream 1. against the wind 2. against the wall 3. against the sky. It consisted of a live standing microphone and some extremely loud amplifiers. Anyone passing through the atrium was invited to stand in front of the mike and follow the instructions in the title: that is, scream.

title: Soundings
description: Images from MoMAs new survey of sound art.

title: S.E.C. Is Said to Press JPMorgan for an Admission of Wrongdoing
description: Updated, 8:56 p.m. | Federal regulators are seeking to level civil charges against JPMorgan Chase and extract a rare admission of wrongdoing from the nations biggest bank as an investigation into a multibillion-dollar trading loss enters its final stage.

title: Top McConnell Aide Holding My Nose to Help Rand Paul
description: Senator Mitch McConnells campaign manager on Thursday confirmed the authenticity of a recording from earlier this year in which he said, quite vividly, that he was reluctantly working for Mr. McConnell to help the presidential prospects of Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky.

title: Meret Oppenheims Works at Martin-Gropius-Bau
description: The Surrealist artist Meret Oppenheim ended up best known for a work that became a kind of burden.

title: Leonardo da Vinci Notebook Coming to Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON  Four centuries before Orville and Wilbur Wright pioneered human flight, Leonardo da Vinci was studying the flight patterns of birds, drawing his observations in a notebook along with descriptions of how humans could learn to fly. The notebook will come to the United States next month at the Smithsonian Institutions National Air and Space Museum in Washington.

title: McConnells Campaign Manager Holding His Nose
description: Anyone whos ever trashed his boss will feel sympathy for Senator Mitch McConnells campaign manager, Jesse Benton. Making the rounds of the Internet today is a phone recording obtained by Economic Policy Journal in which Mr. Benton describes his job-satisfaction as follows: Between you and me, Im sort of holding my nose for two years, cause what were doing here is gonna be a big benefit to Rand in 16.

title: Wheelies: The FARC Tungsten Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Deaf Patrons Suit Accuses Starbucks of Discrimination
description: The Starbucks coffee shop on Astor Place is an airy, communal retreat where the regulars huddle with their laptops, reconnect with friends and exchange water-cooler gossip over foam lattes.

title: Milton Friedman, Unperson
description: David Glasner has been making a series of posts on the legacy of Milton Friedman, some of them in response to Scott Sumner; theyre interesting if you want to delve into the intellectual history. Im not personally big on such things  in general, what people thought Keynes or Friedman meant ends up being more important than what they turn out, on close reading, to (maybe, possibly) actually have meant. For what its worth, I think Glasner makes a good case that Friedman was indeed more or less a Keynesian, or maybe Hicksian  certainly that was the message everyone took from his Monetary Framework, which was disappointingly conventional. And Friedmans attempts to claim that Keynes added little that wasnt already in a Chicago oral tradition dont hold up well either.

title: A Seafood Salad From the Grill
description: This seafood salad, sizzled on a grill (or in a grill pan or under the broiler), delivers lightly smoky swagger and, thanks to radicchio, a welcome edge of bitterness. It is an excellent foil for the earthy-yet-fruity and often-light Sicilian frappato and Cerasuolo di Vittoria wines. A substantial salad, it can be a curtain raiser or part of a buffet for summer dinner at home. It might even be carried to a picnic. But it begs to be served a bit warm, and the wine cool.

title: From Sicily, Reds Worth the Hunt
description: The transformation of the world of wine in the last 20 years has been simply astounding. Consumers have been blessed with a profusion of wonderful wines from sources that few would have predicted as recently as the turn of the century. Case in point: Sicily.

title: Obama Urges Greece to Grow Its Economy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Thursday urged Greece to find ways to grow its economy even as it continues to cut spending in an effort to recover from a debt-driven economic crisis.

title: A Private Tour of the House of Krug
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: New Sign of Stimulants Toll on Young
description: WASHINGTON  The number of young adults who end up in the emergency room after taking Adderall, Ritalin or other such stimulants has quadrupled in recent years, federal health officials said Thursday, fresh evidence of the unexpected consequences that can result from the wide use of medicines for conditions like attention deficit disorder.

title: Excerpt: 'Harbor'
description: Erin Cummings, Paul Anthony Stewart and Randy Harrison in a scene from Chad Beguelin's play at 59E59 Theaters.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Snowdens E-Mail Service Shuts Down and the Future of E-Commerce
description: The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Heres what we noticed today:

title: Quinn Leads Democratic Candidates for Mayor, Poll Finds
description: Christine C. Quinn is leading the crowded field in the Democratic primary race for New York City mayor, lifted by support among Manhattanites and higher-income voters, the latest New York Times/Siena College poll finds.

title: Trying to Be Relevant in the AMC Shadows
description: It cant be easy being the forgotten drama on a channel that has only six dramas, but thats the fate of Hell on Wheels, which begins its third season on AMC on Saturday night.

title: Out There on the Fringe, but Possibly Above the Fray
description: Every year the New York International Fringe Festival descends on the city with a dizzying array of shows. This year, the festival, which runs Friday through Aug. 25, features about 1,100 performances on 20 stages, presented by some 185 companies. (Schedule information: fringenyc.org.) How is a discriminating theatergoer to choose? Below, staff members at The New York Times discuss strategies and pick some productions theyre looking forward to. Of course, there are no sure bets  and half the fun is discovering previously unknown talents  but its worth noting that some shows pop up more than once here.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 20
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: From Balanchine to Lil Buck, a Small Price to Pay
description: VAIL, Colo.  Each year since 2008, the Vail International Dance Festival has had a Dance for $20 evening. The audience is simply told wholl dance, and all seats in the Gerald W. Ford Auditorium are offered at $20 plus the number of cents to match the current year. (Those who sit on the lawn at the back pay in dollars the final two digits of the year  $13 this summer. Nobody knows yet what will happen after 2020.)

title: Vernacular Images
description: Two new exhibitions feature found photography.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Tax-Free Accounts for Homes
description: Tax-free savings accounts help Americans stow away money for health care and college tuition. Why not a tax-exempt account for yet another major expense: the down payment on a mortgage?

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Not for the Family Album
description: Anonymous, found or outsider photographs, taken largely by, and of, people whose identities are long lost, exist in unfathomable numbers, like stars or grains of sand. Not surprisingly, this flood of visual culture, social and personal history and sometime art generates its own connoisseurs and collectors, as well as heated bidding on eBay.

title: Women Inspired to Mix and Match
description: The subjects of Robert Pruitt: Women, his playful solo show at the Studio Museum in Harlem, look as if theyve walked out of a street-style blog from a distant galaxy. One wears a track jacket, a feathered skirt and a Rubix cube perched on her head like a pillbox hat; another sports a tunic emblazoned with stars and planets and a spiraling headdress in the shape of Tatlins Constructivist Monument to the Third International.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 9-15
description: Around Town

title: A Cuzco Hotel Gets a Luxury Upgrade
description: After a $15 million investment, Palacio del Inka in Cuszco, Peru, has opened under Starwoods Luxury Collection banner after 21 months construction.

title: Sweet and Sour
description: We received a save the date card for a fifth birthday party for a boy my daughter knows. It was to be a Superhero Soiree. But shortly before the date, we were uninvited. The party is now just for boys because of its masculine theme, and my daughter was invited to a separate party for him just for girls. I dont want to tell my daughter that she isnt allowed to attend the real party, but she is going to want to know what happened. Something about this feels wrong. Should I mention it to the mother?

title: All Those Voices: Can You Hear Her Now?
description: Reluctantly attending a party at the home of a big-shot voice-over artist, Carol Solomon, an aspiring voice-over artist in her own right, wanders off down a hallway where she discovers a secret door. Behind it is a room full of curious, exotic objects, an eccentric private museum that makes her smile in almost childlike wonder.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 9-15
description: Playdate! With the Little Orchestra Society

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Why Blurred Lines Wont Go Away
description: Robin Thickes Blurred Lines just notched its ninth week at No. 1 on Billboards Hot 100, suggesting not only that its the official summer song of 2013  an argument that was actually settled weeks ago  but also that its dominance might extend well into the fall. What is it thats giving this bouncy but seemingly lightweight track such staying power?

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: A Sister Shows Up, and Stereotypes Settle In
description: Family and children are on the playwright Chad Beguelins mind in Harbor, a comedy about a gay couple and the manipulative sister who came to stay.

title: The Gastro-Pub Movement Sweeps In
description: Were a from-scratch restaurant, said our server as she handed out the menus. We grind our own meat, make our own pastas and have a smoker out back.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 9-15
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Concert App WillCall Gets a $1.2 Million Investment
description: WillCall, a smartphone app that recommends concerts for the hipster crowd, has received a $1.2 million investment from some of the biggest players in the music industry, including Sean Parker, the Spotify board member and former Facebook president, and Coran Capshaw, who manages the Dave Matthews Band and controls a broad empire of concerts and artist management, WillCall announced on Wednesday.

title: This Week's Movies: Aug. 9, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on "Elysium," "Lovelace" and "Prince Avalanche."

title: Killers Who Just Wont Lighten Up
description: Film noir doesnt mean that every scene has to be shot in the dark.

title: Chinese Invest in Queens Real Estate
description: Quick, name a New York neighborhood that has investors from China buying properties. Midtown? TriBeCa? The Upper East Side?

title: A Woman Who Showed It All Yet Hid Everything
description: Lovelace, a movie about the chasm between public perception and private experience, pulls off a sly bait and switch. Its inspired by the autobiography of one Linda Boreman, who when she was young, permed and under the spell of a violent pimp earned her place in hard-core history by suppressing her gag reflex in the 1972 film Deep Throat. With its Boogie Nights typeface and mustachioed dudes as slick and artificial as their Qiana threads, Lovelace promises the down-and-dirty best (or worst) with a snigger and pulsating beats. It delivers just as promised only to do a 180 in order to tell another, uglier story, this one involving beatings, rape and 24/7 terror.

title: Teaching Ballet Language of Pop
description: No one knows where ballet is headed. Onstage, it cant be preserved as if in aspic. Many of us have already seen it change considerably in our lifetimes; its likely that more changes will follow.

title: Take the Janeiac Quiz
description: A panel of Austen experts devised a quiz to separate the Lizzys from the Lydias, the true devotees from the casual admirers.

title: The Cultivation of Belief
description: The Iranian filmmaker Mohsen Makhmalbaf opens The Gardener with the declaration: I am an agnostic filmmaker. From anyone else, this might seem like a simple statement, but not from the complex Mr. Makhmalbaf. In 1974, when he was 17, religious and involved in a guerrilla group, he stabbed a policeman, for which he received a bullet to the stomach and a prison sentence.

title: Mobilizing to Feed Beachgoers
description: Even before Long Beach reopened the first half-mile stretch of its rebuilt boardwalk on July 27, a group of food-truck vendors nearby, calling themselves Shoregasboard, had been helping to keep the spirit of summer alive in the city, which was badly battered by Hurricane Sandy.

title: For a Crop-Duster, Theres More to Life Than Spraying the Fields
description: Not so long ago, if you bought a ticket to an animated childrens movie, you could expect to spend 90 minutes watching a princess slowly fall for a handsome young man, or some variation on that theme. These days, though, the odds are good that you will instead find yourself watching a race. There was Cars in 2006, followed by Cars 2 in 2011. Last years engaging hit Wreck-It Ralph built to a big race, too. And just last month, Turbo brought us a speedy snail.

title: Along the F.D.R. Drive, a Cliffhanger for a Darkly Romantic Wall
description: Rockefeller University, seeking to enlarge its campus, has proposed building a deck over the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive from East 64th to East 68th Street. The project will darken yet another leg of what was once a sunny waterside stretch of twists and turns.

title: Young Canadian Takes Spotlight at Rogers Cup
description: TORONTO  If there was any question about the face of womens tennis in Canada, one only had to look up while entering the main gates at this weeks Rogers Cup. Emblazoned across the top of the Rexall Centre is the youngest entry at this weeks event, the 19-year-old Eugenie Bouchard.

title: Taking the Fast Train to Win a Mob Princess
description: Chennai Express feels like a sumptuous meal with carefully chosen wine and tasty appetizers but a botched main course. Money and visual care have been lavished on this Bollywood action-comedy-romance and glossy stars engaged (Shah Rukh Khan and Deepika Padukone). But the movie chugs along for most of its 2 hours and 20 minutes searching for comedy and characters in a frantically overplotted story.

title: Two Houses, Two Piano Masterworks
description: The Mostly Mozart festival provides shifts of perspective and scale swifter than anything else on New Yorks musical calendar. I began Wednesday evening listening to the pianist Paul Lewis play Mozart with the festivals house orchestra from the last row of Avery Fisher Hall, and two hours later I was just a few feet from him as he played Schubert, solo, in the Kaplan Penthouse.

title: Two Brothers, Fighting Crime With Crime
description: Trying to cram a six-part BBC television series into a 92-minute movie means inevitable narrative tinkering, but Blood feels more damaged than most. Dark, airless and packed with psychological hurt that seems to spring from nowhere, this angry morality play, tucked inside a police procedural, suffers from a crippling lack of back story and characters whose relationships are fraught with unexplained complexity.

title: N.C.A.A. to Quit Selling Memorabilia Online
description: Facing legal and public scrutiny over its business practices, the N.C.A.A. on Thursday said it would stop selling player jerseys and other memorabilia through its Web site.

title: Seafood With a Clam Shack Atmosphere
description: The 79 emblazoned on servers T-shirts at the new waterfront outpost of Lenny and Joes Fish Tale at Long Wharf marks the year that the brothers Lenny and Joe Goldberg opened their first Fish Tale, a roadside clam shack with four picnic tables on Route 1 in Madison.

title: A Hole in the Ground, Worshiped and Feared
description: Shirley Jacksons short story The Lottery has nothing on the grisly compulsory rituals of a backcountry settlement in Chad Crawford Kinkles handily made debut feature, Jug Face. Periodically, a designated potter creates a jug bearing the likeness of an unlucky villager, who is then sacrificed to appease a hallowed pit in the ground. The practice has been going on for ages, which might account for the villages small population, but it takes just one person to jam the process.

title: Jane, Plain No More: A Year of Austen Glamour
description: Oh, Jane. What a summer its been for your insatiable cottage industry  a cottage about the size of Darcys pile at Pemberley, at this point. Here in the 200th birthday year for Pride and Prejudice, it seems as if not a week goes by without new grist. Last month the Bank of England announced that it would feature Jane Austen on the 10 note, making Jane the only woman besides the queen and an obscure prison reformer to be honored on British currency; a Twitter war erupted, with the most extreme position taken by someone who tweeted rape and death threats against the woman whod lobbied the bank to feature a woman.

title: Margaret Pellegrini, 89, Munchkin From Land of Oz
description: Margaret Pellegrini, one of the last three surviving Munchkins from the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz, died on Aug. 7 in Phoenix. She was 89.

title: Woes of Detroit Hurt Borrowing by Its Neighbors
description: The Detroit Effect has rippled all the way to Wall Street.

title: Baring Their Souls in a Film Audition
description: Standing before a concrete wall washed in peeling blue paint, the boy is shy but expectant. What is your biggest dream? the filmmaker Tinatin Gurchiani asks him, her voice gently prodding. The boy would like to be an actor, but the question is a Trojan horse. Answering it, he soon finds that more than dreams come tumbling out.

title: Canada on the Rise
description: MONTREAL  Has American mens tennis now fallen behind Canada?

title: As Foreign Fighters Flood Syria, Fears of a New Extremist Haven
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  As foreign fighters pour into Syria at an increasing clip, extremist groups are carving out pockets of territory that are becoming havens for Islamist militants, posing what United States and Western intelligence officials say may be developing into one of the biggest terrorist threats in the world today.

title: 16 Medal of Freedom Honorees Are Named
description: Bill Clinton, Oprah Winfrey and 14 others will receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom this year. The White House announced Thursday that the president will bestow the nations highest civilian honor on a class that includes activists, athletes, musicians and scientists.

title: Karen Black, Versatile Character Actress, Dies at 74
description: Karen Black, an actress whose roles in several signature films of the late 1960s and 70s included a prostitute who shared an LSD trip with the bikers played by Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda in Easy Rider and a waitress unhappily devoted to the alienated musician played by Jack Nicholson in Five Easy Pieces, died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 74.

title: Judge Denies Ex-Defense Teams Bid to Limit Role in Fort Hood Suspects Trial
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The judge overseeing the military trial of the Army psychiatrist charged in a deadly shooting rampage at the Fort Hood base denied on Thursday his former lawyers request to limit their role in the case. The ruling came a day after the lawyers said they could no longer assist him because he was seeking the same goal as prosecutors  to be sentenced to death.

title: Journey Across a Wide Spectrum
description: The spectrum of autism is wide, as the low-budget documentary The United States of Autism shows. Its host, Richard Everts (also the director and the father of an autistic son), introduces 20 families dealing with the disorder, visited during 40 days of road travel across the country. He meets the highly verbal, troubled only in social situations. He meets the nonverbal, whose physical struggles exhaust financial and emotional resources. He meets parents displaying pain or pride, or both, about their children.

title: Jack Clement, Producer and Country Songwriter, Dies at 82
description: Jack Clement, whose career as a producer, engineer, songwriter and arranger began in the early days of rock n roll and included work with country stars like Johnny Cash, Waylon Jennings and Charley Pride as well as noncountry artists like U2, died on Thursday at his home in Nashville. He was 82.

title: Walking Funny and Fast Puts Russia City on Map
description: SARANSK, Russia  Their hips swinging, their arms pumping, the sports heroes of Saransk set out for their daily workout in a city park, followed by dozens of wide-eyed young admirers.

title: New Jersey's $24 Million Election
description: A breakdown of the costs involved in the special election to choose a replacement for the late Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: 30 Years Later, Reverberations of a Fatal Fight
description: Jesse James Millers moving documentary The Good Son is like a brisk novel with a bigger-than-life protagonist. Boxing fans already know of Ray Mancini, a k a Boom Boom, former World Boxing Association lightweight champion: His 1982 bout against the South Korean fighter Duk-koo Kim ended with Mr. Kim fatally wounded. He died of a subdural hematoma, leaving behind a pregnant fiance. But the film, beautifully shot by Ian Kerr (who evokes the era with photographs, yellowed newspaper clips and fight footage), peels back fresh layers that will captivate nonfans too.

title: Rodriguez Hoping for an Unlikely Reception
description: Alex Rodriguez tried many different ways  denial, platitudes, flattery  to answer persistent questions about what might he might face at Yankee Stadium on Friday night when he makes his 2013 home debut.

title: Dolphin Deaths Off East Coast Worry Federal Wildlife Officials
description: Federal wildlife officials raised a formal alarm on Thursday over the deaths of scores of bottlenose dolphins in waters off the east coast, saying that a fast-spreading infection could be attacking dolphin populations from New York to Virginia.

title: Independent Agencies, Sometimes in Name Only
description: In 1985, President Ronald Reagan had to fill a Democratic slot on the Securities and Exchange Commission. He chose a young lawyer and economist, Joseph A. Grundfest.

title: Opponents in New Jersey Senate Race Struggle to Match Bookers Star Power
description: PATERSON, N.J.  Were this a typical campaign, any of the candidates would be a strong contender to represent New Jersey in the United States Senate. There is the State Assembly speaker who has worked her way up through local politics and would be the first woman as well as the first African-American to represent the state in the Senate. The 13-term congressman endorsed as a workhorse by the family of the senator whose death opened up the seat. The eight-term congressman who has served on the House Intelligence Committee, in addition to being a nuclear physicist and a five-time Jeopardy! champion.

title: Mismatch in Every Possible Way
description: In I Give It a Year, a smutty script and a passel of objectionable characters form an imperfect rom-com union  one that will, with any luck, fade from the mind long before its title suggests.

title: Savory Afghan Fare, and Belly Dancing, Too
description: We knew there was belly dancing, because we entered 3 Olives restaurant through the bar, where a sign announced it. But, distracted by the conversation and the food, we had forgotten about it until the high-volume Arabic music began. The server was apologetic but firm  the dancer needed loud music  but told us it would not last long.

title: Food-Safety Microscope on High-End Kitchens
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Tucked on a leafy street in Leblon, the seaside bastion of this citys elite, Antiquarius ranks among Brazils most exclusive restaurants. Well-heeled regulars frequent Antiquarius, which is decorated in faux-farmhouse style with landscape paintings and porcelain vases, and charges $68 for a stew of codfish in coconut-tomato sauce.

title: Roller Coaster Emotions in Battle Over Amusement Park
description: What goes up didnt have to come down for good, but as Amy Nicholsons Zipper: Coney Islands Last Wild Ride shows, the classic high-flying attractions of Coney Island were no match for politicians and developers. Another in a line of gentrification documentaries, from Foreign Parts to My Brooklyn, Zipper recounts the contraction and conversion of Coney Island through a medley of voices: amusement-park old-schoolers, protesters, New York City officials and one real estate magnate.

title: Witness in Manning Case Says Leaks Could Help Al Qaeda
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  A prosecution witness in the sentencing phase of the court-martial of Pfc. Bradley Manning told a military judge on Thursday that Al Qaeda could have used WikiLeaks disclosures, including classified United States government materials provided by Private Manning, to encourage attacks in the West, in testimony meant to show the harm done by his actions.

title: Low-Key Furyk and Sizzling Scott Tame Oak Hill
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  In a voice as expressive as an air conditioners hum, Jim Furyk said he felt really in control of his game and was pleased with his play Thursday at the P.G.A. Championship. Furyk posted a five-under-par 65 at Oak Hill Country Club on a course softened by a predawn thunderstorm and left defenseless by the disappearance of its bodyguard breezes.

title: Launching Site in Iran Raises Missile Worries
description: Iran has built a previously undisclosed launching site and space center near the northeastern city of Shahrud that could theoretically be used for testing ballistic missiles, according to satellite imagery reported on Thursday by IHS Janes, an authoritative weapons research publication based in London.

title: Irans Plan B for the Bomb
description: TEL AVIV  IS Iran finally ready to talk? Irans new president, Hassan Rouhani, has said hes ready for nuclear negotiations. And in recent weeks, the Iranian government has repeatedly expressed its desire to reach a deal on its uranium enrichment program.

title: In an Airport Fire, Flames of Discord
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  ON one of Kenyas main television networks on Wednesday night, the news announcer wore a funereal expression as she called the fire that destroyed the arrivals terminal of our main airport earlier that morning a national calamity.

title: Lives Defined Daily by Prescription Drugs
description: The overcrowded gallery of prescription-drug veterans in the diffuse documentary Off Label includes at least one actual war veteran, but nearly all seem to suffer from some kind of post-traumatic stress disorder. The source of trauma, as posited by the documentarians Michael Palmieri and Donal Mosher, is pharmaceuticals, here a kind of unyielding behemoth perceivable by the long, indifferent shadow it casts on the afflicted.

title: Polands Opposition Leader Is Poised for a Comeback

title: Amid Grief, Ex-Premier Resurfaces in Polish Race
description: WARSAW  For years, Jaroslaw Kaczynski, Polands blunt and polarizing opposition leader, relished blurting controversial comments that helped earn him the nickname Potato, after a quintessentially Polish staple that apparently embodied his robust populism and rotund shape.

title: Phony Fear Factor
description: We live in a golden age of economic debunkery; fallacious doctrines have been dropping like flies. No, monetary expansion neednt cause hyperinflation. No, budget deficits in a depressed economy dont cause soaring interest rates. No, slashing spending doesnt create jobs. No, economic growth doesnt collapse when debt exceeds 90 percent of G.D.P.

title: The Nudge Debate
description: This has been a great era for the study of error. We know that people can be induced to buy more cans of soup if you put a Limit: 12 per customer sign on the display. We know that if you ask people what movie they want to see next week, theyre likely to mention a classy art film. But, if you ask them what movie they want to see tonight, theyre more likely to mention a mindless blockbuster.

title: On Long Journey Back, Casey Is Among Leaders
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  When Paul Casey reached the final green Thursday, he looked over his right shoulder, craning his neck to peek at a leader board shrouded slightly by a large oak tree.

title: What About Sal?
description: On Tuesday night voters in New York City will be able to watch a live televised debate in the Democratic campaign for mayor. Five candidates were invited: Christine Quinn, Bill de Blasio, William Thompson Jr., John Liu and Anthony Weiner. Sal Albanese was not.

title: Breaking Through Limits on Spying
description: Apparently no espionage tool that Congress gives the National Security Agency is big enough or intrusive enough to satisfy the agencys inexhaustible appetite for delving into the communications of Americans. Time and again, the N.S.A. has pushed past the limits that lawmakers thought they had imposed to prevent it from invading basic privacy, as guaranteed by the Constitution.

title: Apple Pays Dearly for Price-Fixing
description: Last month the Justice Department won an antitrust suit against Apple, convincing Judge Denise Cote of United States District Court that the company had colluded with five major publishers to fix e-book prices. At a hearing on Friday, the department will argue that its plan to remedy Apples misconduct will restore lost competition. In a narrow sense it may, but the problem with this case all along was that the department ignored the potentially bigger anticompetitive force in the e-book market  Amazon  while focusing on Apple.

title: Egypt on the Edge
description: Its hard to imagine things getting worse in Egypt, but they could. The generals who now call the shots in the worlds leading Arab country and their handpicked civilian government have halted efforts to reach a compromise with the Islamist supporters of the man they ousted  Mohamed Morsi, the countrys first democratically elected president. Instead, they have threatened to forcibly disperse tens of thousands of pro-Morsi civilians from two sit-ins in Cairo.

title: Obama Urges Greece to Grow Economy
description: President Obama urged Greece on Thursday to find ways to build its economy even as it continues to cut spending in an effort to recover from a debt-driven economic crisis. In a meeting in the Oval Office, Mr. Obama told Antonis Samaras, the Greek prime minister, that policies focused only on spending reductions would not help Greece return to economic prosperity. Mr. Obama said after the meeting, Its important that we have a plan for fiscal consolidation to manage the debt, but its also important that growth and jobs are a focus. Mr. Samaras echoed Mr. Obamas concerns, noting that youth unemployment in his country had reached 60 percent. He said that Greece must reach for policies for growth and the creation of new jobs.

description: BOSTON  The firehouse near the end of Logan Airports Runway 14 is home to the pride and joy of the airports rescue and firefighting team: Engine 3, a 1,000-horsepower, four-wheel-drive behemoth with thermal imaging and a radar screen, its body painted a special color, Boston Lime Green.

Colored flag streamers hung along the sides of the streets, recycled boxes were circulated through the crowd to collect donations and hundreds of men took their shoes off and stood side by side to pray.

title: Massachusetts: Bombing Suspects Friends Indicted
description: Two 19-year-olds who have been held on a criminal complaint in the investigation of the Boston Marathon bombings were indicted by a federal grand jury on Thursday on obstruction of justice charges. The two, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, attended the University of Massachusetts, Dartmouth, with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who the authorities say worked with his brother, Tamerlan, to set off bombs at the marathon, killing 3 and wounding more than 260. The indictment says the teenagers, friends with Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, removed items including a laptop and a backpack with fireworks from his dormitory room and put them in trash in New Bedford, Mass. The two could face up to 20 years in prison, a $250,000 fine and deportation, as they are both Kazakh nationals. A third friend of Mr. Tsarnaevs, Robel Phillipos, has been charged with lying to investigators.
