How fans will react remains to be seen, but if Rodriguez is loudly jeered, that will fit right in with a tradition of scorching one of your own. Some examples of this phenomenon have been provided by staff writers for The New York Times who, years later, can still hear all those boos or, in one instance, the laughter.

title: S.E.C.s New Tack in JPMorgan Inquiry
description: S.E.C. SAID TO PRESS JPMORGAN FOR ADMISSION OF WRONGDOING |The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking to level civil charges against JPMorgan Chase and extract a rare admission of wrongdoing, as an investigation into last years multibillion-dollar trading loss enters its final stage, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. If JPMorgan concedes to some wrongdoing, such an admission would set an important precedent for the S.E.C., which for decades allowed defendants to neither admit nor deny wrongdoing. An agreement could come as soon as this fall, people briefed on the case said, adding that the agency had not threatened to charge JPMorgan executives.

description: If his life had gone just a bit differently, Curt Boettcher might have been another Brian Wilson. Joseph Gordon-Levitt might be playing him in a modern-day biopic. College students would steal and hoard their parents copies of his records. As it stands, Boettcher  a pop-music producer whose heyday was the late 60s  now survives in rock history mostly as a liner-note credit. He could have been, but never was. Yet he enjoys a godlike status among a select group of music fans, for whom obscurity is more enticing than fame.

title: Who Made That Sippy Cup?
Eternal Bragging Rights
description: Since 1991 Ive competed in a fantasy football league with my college buddies, most of whom hail from the great state of New Jersey. Fantasy football leagues typically draft online, but we still conduct our business face to face, convening once a year, in late August, at a faded South Jersey hotel, thick with cigarette smoke. Its a weekend filled with steaks, beer, Bruce Springsteen bootlegs and affectionately toothless insults; a weird alternate universe where I wash down Cool Ranch Doritos with Mountain Dew and occasionally sleep in my clothes.

title: Harrison Ford on Fanboys and Fat Suits
description: Your new movie, Paranoia, is about corporate espionage and greed. Do you think weve seen the end of the days when Hollywood could make an upbeat movie about corporate life like Working Girl?  I shouldnt think so. I think businesspeople are like every other type of character  they come in all varieties. And Working Girl depended on the glass ceiling for women, and what a pleasure it was to see someone break through. And it was funny. But now, Im sure theres more demand for movies about how corporations are dictating our lives in many ways.

title: I Love Your Work
description: Creators of some of the top dramas on television talk to each other about their series.

title: Help From Evangelicals (Without Evangelizing) Meets the Needs of an Oregon Public School
description: PORTLAND, Ore.  Four summers ago, on her first day as an administrator at Roosevelt High School here, Charlene Williams heard that the Christians were coming. Some members of an evangelical church were supposed to be painting hallways, repairing bleachers, that sort of thing. The prospect of such help, in the fervently liberal and secular microclimate of Portland, did not exactly fill her with joy.

title: Show Runners Roundtable
description: The Times spoke with the people who oversee several top dramas about the challenges of producing television in the Twitter age.

title: Post-Water-Cooler TV
description: LOS ANGELES  For decades, the TV viewing experience was much the same. Tune into your favorite show, week by patient week, all on the networks schedule. Feedback was restricted to faceless Nielsen ratings and perhaps a plaintive letter or phone call to executives complaining about a favorite shows cast change or cancellation.

title: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: This week, Phillip Lopate writes about how authors deal with recognition  or with being ignored. Accepting his Nobel Prize in 1962, John Steinbeck struck a self-effacing note: In my heart there may be doubt that I deserve the Nobel award over other men of letters whom I hold in respect and reverence  but there is no question of my pleasure and pride in having it for myself.

title: Aug. 9: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Seal of Approval
description: It is deeply satisfying to win a prize in front of a lot of people. E. B. White wrote these wise words with a pig in mind, in the closing pages of Charlottes Web. More than a decade earlier, librarians bet that the same principle might apply to illustrators when on June 24, 1937, a committee of the American Library Association met at the Pierre Hotel in New York to lay plans for an annual award honoring the years most distinguished contribution to childrens book illustration by an artist who is an American citizen or resident  the Randolph Caldecott Medal.

title: Midlist Crisis
description: There is nothing more becoming in an author than modesty. Regardless of what egotistic airs they may put on, most writers, I suspect, have a fairly accurate assessment of their own worth and achievement. Still, they  we  are dependent to an uncomfortable extent on the worlds judgment, perhaps hoping that by some fluke the world will rate us higher than we rate ourselves. The problem is not that the world so often ignores literary effort (though that is certainly the case), but that to the degree it breaks its silence it tends to distribute the rewards in a mystifyingly erratic manner.

title: Paperback Row
description: TOBYS ROOM,  by Pat Barker. (Anchor, $15.95.) Barker has traced the psychic reverberations of World War I through a remarkable series of novels: the Regeneration trilogy, Life Class and now Tobys Room. A sequel to Life Class, Tobys Room portrays a group of students at the Slade School of Fine Art in London; at its center is Elinor Brooke, a painter who works as a medical illustrator while unraveling the mystery of what happened to her brother, Toby, a doctor serving at the front.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SOUND OF THINGS FALLING, by Juan Gabriel Vsquez. Translated by Anne McLean. (Riverhead, $27.95.) This gripping Colombian novel, built on the countrys tragic history with the drug trade, meditates on love, fate and death.

title: Trouble Followed
description: Justin St. Germains spectacular memoir, Son of a Gun, calls to mind two others of the past decade: J. R. Moehringers Tender Bar and Nick Flynns Another Bull____ Night in Suck City. All three are about boys becoming men in a broken world. All three feature disappeared fathers. And all three dig into the reality behind the facade of the American dream: namely, that there is no glory in being a blue-collar grunt in this country, that to be working class is to live a tenuous existence, one in which the authors and half the people they know are one misstep away from surfing garage-sale sofas in other peoples living rooms.

title: Through a Lens Darkly
description: In discussing his film The Thin Blue Line, Errol Morris called the claims of cinma vrit  the style of documentary that privileges direct and unobtrusive observation  spurious. Style does not guarantee truth, Morris said. The use of available light and a hand-held camera does not mean that what you are doing is any more truthful than anything else. Truth is a pursuit, its a quest.

title: Patriotic Roar
description: So many histories of the Civil War era have been published that one would think writing another would be pretty much a matter of choosing a major political event  the Compromise of 1850, say, with its controversial Fugitive Slave Act  and then pressing cruise control. We drive on a familiar freeway that takes us through a deepening valley: the growing gulf between the North and the South during the 1850s. We view familiar scenery like the Lincoln-Douglas debates. Then, suddenly, we encounter a multicar pileup: the Civil War.

title: The Ways of Abandonment
description: As the writer Jeanette Winterson says, Men have been writing about women forever. This was in an interview in The Guardian with A. M. Homes, whom Winterson describes as a woman writing dangerously. What Winterson means is that Homes is fearless about writing from a male point of view. (Think of Harry, the narrator of Homess recent novel, May We Be Forgiven.)

title: Today in Small Business: Amys Baking, Again
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: French Lessons
description: Theres an arresting photograph on the cover of the paperback edition of The Storytellers Daughter, Saira Shahs memoir of her adventures in war-torn Afghanistan  an Afghan boy in a turban, regarding the viewer with a shrewdly inquisitive expression. The boy is Shah herself, the daughter of the celebrated Sufi fabulist Idries Shah. Born in England in 1964, she returned at age 21 to her fathers homeland, then under Soviet occupation. Disguised as a young man, braving frostbite and Russian missiles, she reported back to English newspapers and television on the American-backed mujahedeen, who were importing, as she put it, a brand of extremist political Islam that . . . had been almost unknown inside Afghanistan.

title: Adams Rib, van Goghs Ear, Einsteins Brain
description: For a species so pleased with its own brain, we are surprisingly ambivalent about the rest of our body. We tend to admire other peoples bodies, especially if theyre Olympians or shirtless Russian presidents, but most of us are constantly seeking to improve our own by starving or stuffing, injecting, waxing, straightening, piercing, lifting and squeezing. In 2010 in the United States alone, we spent $10 billion on cosmetic surgery, and thats not including Brazilian Blowouts.

title: Running the Asylum
description: A childhood swimming accident has rendered a young woman named Karly mentally impaired, unable to count coins or operate a washing machine. A young man named Mick, who cant remember life before the onset of schizophrenia at age 17, has repeatedly failed to stabilize his medication between ragging and dragging. Their fellow patient Alonsos main occupation is masturbation, while spooky Vex looks likely to bash someones head in at the slightest provocation.

title: The Scene Also Rises
description: In the mid-90s, I told a woman I met at a party that I was moving to Prague.

title: That First Bromance
description: A familiar music beats throughout Brewster, Mark Sloukas intense and elegiac novel about the friendship between two teenage boys during the late 1960s and early 70s. The Beatles and the Stones are on every radio. Every cafeteria conversation finds a way to Muhammad Ali or Charles Manson, Kent State or the draft.

title: Covert Losses
description: Through the heart of Lea Carpenters earnest first novel, Eleven Days, courses the myth of a mother and son: the sea nymph Thetis and her warlike child Achilles. Thetis, so legend runs, submerged Achilles in the River Styx to inoculate him from harm but neglected to dip the back of the ankle by which she held him fast. The prophecy that Achilles would prove a warrior greater than his father, but would also die prematurely in his bid for fame, remained a burden to the vigilant Thetis, who did her utmost to circumvent this destiny.

title: Raw Materials
description: Two of the great pessimistic proclamations of 20th-century literature  Adornos To write a poem after Auschwitz is barbaric and Becketts I cant go on, Ill go on  have at least one thing in common. They both address the inadequacy of language to articulate reality. Better to say nothing, they both say, or at least thats the first half of what they say. If Adorno leaves off the productive half of the equation  Ill go on  other writers have supplied it for him, in the form of a very large body of work concerned with the Holocaust that is not only ethically accountable but also incredibly rich and inventive. In fact it is not too much to claim, of Holocaust literature, that the struggle to say what is unsayable has paradoxically yielded some of the most extraordinary literary works we have.

title: Inside the List
description: PANDORAS ENVELOPE: The Australian writer Liane Moriarty has won a devoted following for her novels chronicling the lives of typical suburban mums, but shes never cracked the New York Times best-seller list. That may change soon, though  The Husbands Secret, Moriartys fifth novel for adults, is hovering at No. 17 on the extended hardcover list after a wave of endorsements and strong reviews. The plot is, essentially, a version of Pandoras box: a happily married woman finds an envelope from her husband with instructions to open it only after his death, and decides to peek ahead of time.

title: In TriBeCa, Squeezing In Some Condo Pizazz
description: At three blocks between Broadway and Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, Park Place is a wisp of a road. But it has shown it can make big news.

title: Unacceptable Prejudices
description: John Holbo asks a very good question inspired by an in-flight magazines feel-good piece about Martin Luther King: how did public expression of racism become unacceptable?

title: Ask Well: Pilates vs. Yoga
description: Question:

title: Lonely in the L.P.G.A.
description: DAVENPORT, Fla.  Chie Arimura, a 25-year-old professional golfer from Japan, sat alone at a table for six in her rented home, her back so straight that her shoulders jutted out. Her fingernails, painted dark pink with sparkly gold on the ring fingers, clicked against the ceramic dishes as she set out a bowl of romaine and ham and a plate of fried salmon.

title: Finding Nemo Sequel Is Altered in Response to Orcas Documentary
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  Blackfish, the orcas-in-captivity documentary that has seared SeaWorld with negative publicity, prompted Pixar Animation Studios to rewrite part of its coming Finding Nemo sequel.

title: Pardon My Spanish
description: RABAT, Morocco  This year, like every year on Throne Day, King Mohamed VI of Morocco handed out royal pardons. With the occasion falling on July 30, during an official visit from King Juan Carlos I of Spain, it was announced that 48 Spanish citizens serving time in Moroccan prisons would be freed.

title: Falcone Adds Defendants in Effort to Keep LightSquared
description: The hedge fund billionaire Philip A. Falcone is in a litigious mood.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
description: This week, Scott Anderson talks about Lawrence in Arabia; Brenda Wineapple discusses Ecstatic Nation; Leonard Marcus on the life and work of Randolph Caldecott; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
description: This week, Scott Anderson, Brenda Wineapple and Leonard Marcus.

title: The Gun Report: August 9, 2013
description: Often we express frustration in this space when a child dies accidentally at the hands of a gun and parents or guardians are not charged with reckless endangerment. So its heartening to see that authorities in Calhoun County, in the Florida panhandle, seem to take this as seriously as we do. But this case has an interesting twist.

title: The Kid-Friendly Brunch Becomes a Kid Takeover
description: I had friends over for brunch a few weeks ago, and to my dismay guess who automatically climbed into the chairs I had placed around the apartment? The kids. I had billed this event as kid-friendly, but it became a kid-takeover.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A seven-bedroom 1870 historic estate in West Orange and six-bedroom 1918 Dutch colonial in Great Neck.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 9
description: Photos include former Gov. Eliot Spitzer in Queens, a campsite on Governors Island, and Playground 52 in the South Bronx.

title: Movie Review: 'Elysium'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Elysium."

title: Book Review Podcast: Who Was T. E. Lawrence?
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Alex von Tunzelmann reviews Lawrence in Arabia: War, Deceit, Imperial Folly and the Making of the Modern Middle East, Scott Andersons new book about T. E. Lawrence. Ms. von Tunzelmann writes:

title: Movie Review 'Prince Avalanche'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Prince Avalanche."

title: A Getaway Apartment, in Your Own Building
description: Freddie Gershon lives with his wife, Myrna, and his dog in a penthouse duplex with a terrace in Midtown East. The space is plenty big, he concedes  6,500 square feet.

title: High Blood Sugar Linked to Dementia
description: People with diabetes face an increased risk of Alzheimers disease and other forms of dementia, a connection scientists and physicians have worried about for years. They still cant explain it.

title: Movie Review: 'Lovelace'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Lovelace."

title: Charges Fly in Feud Over Strategy at Penney
description: William A. Ackman is known as an involved investor. But a public brouhaha with the board of J. C. Penney that sent letters and news releases flying on Thursday and Friday took his activism to new heights.

title: Gallery | Portraits From the Service Window of Montauks Most Famous Food Truck
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Deadly Plane Crash in a Connecticut Neighborhood
description: Bill Henningsgaard took off in his small plane from Teterboro Airport in northern New Jersey with his son Maxwell on Friday morning to make the short hop to Connecticut, the latest leg of their tour of colleges. Maxwell was set to graduate in 2014, and they had flown across the country from the Pacific Northwest visiting campuses. Yale was next on the list.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Utah; Bangor, Me.
description: Moab Music Festival, Utah,Aug. 29 to Sept. 9

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties each have one bedroom. The first is in the West Village and has two fireplaces, the second is in a prewar Chelsea building, and the third, in Prospect Heights, includes a roof deck.

title: Cramming for Stardom at Koreas K-Pop Schools
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Chae-young attends cram school five evenings a week, toiling deep into the night. But unlike most young South Koreans who spend hours at special schools to polish their English and math, she studies slide steps and bubbly lyrics.

title: Sometimes Second-Best Makes a Better Role Model
description: RECENTLY the Yankee third baseman Alex Rodriguez, who was just suspended for 211 games for steroid use, proclaimed that he still wanted to be a role model, despite all the noise.

title: The Washington Post That Was
description: TAKOMA PARK, Md.  WHEN I arrived in 1970, The Washington Post had just achieved escape velocity. The executive editor, Benjamin C. Bradlee, and the publisher, Katharine Graham, had launched a shabby local paper into the orbit of fame, hipness, power and phone-slamming Kennedy-style pugnacity. Watch out, New York.

title: 30-Year Prison Sentence in Plot to Bomb U.S. Bank
description: A Bangladeshi man who tried to blow up the Federal Reserve Bank in New York with what he thought was a 1,000-pound bomb, only to discover that the bomb was a fake and that he had been under constant federal surveillance, was sentenced to 30 years in prisonon Friday.

title: How a Passion for Steam-Powered Cars Led to Love
description: While attending a steam car rally in Maine, Sarah Stanley, the great-granddaughter of Francis Edgar Stanley, co-founder of the Stanley Motor Company, found herself riding next to Donald Davidson, a mechanical engineer who had brought his 1913 Stanley Steamer Model 64 to the tour.

title: The New Gazpachos
description: Gazpacho is a summer soup, incredibly refreshing on a hot day, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health. And with tomato season in full swing, it couldnt be a better time. She writes:

title: More On The Disappearance Of Milton Friedman
description: It seems that many people misunderstood my post on Milton Friedman. It was not intended as Friedman-bashing, as a claim that MF was a bad economist; in fact, Im on record declaring Friedman a great economists economist. His work aimed primarily at a professional audience  the permanent income theory of consumption, the case for flexible exchange rates, the natural rate (even if it does break down at low inflation), the optimum quantity of money  was often, maybe even usually, brilliant, and will live on.

title: What Inspired You to Work in the Visual Arts?
description: This summer, The New York Times is publishing essays by its critics about the moments or works that prompted them to write about the arts, along with stories from readers about their own epiphanies. Previously we heard from readers who work in television, classical music, dance, pop music and video games.

title: Big Ticket | $29 Million on Central Park West
description: A sleekly appointed seven-room condominium at 15 Central Park West, the elaborate and exclusive limestone destination designed by Robert A.M. Stern, sold for $29 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Hollywood Director Takes On Texting While Driving
description: As a toddler, Xzavier Davis-Bilbo loved to scramble around the house and yard. Nicknamed X, the boy imitated plays from his hometown Green Bay Packers. Then tragedy struck.

title: After Post Sale, Spotlight Shines More Intensely on The Times
description: Its surely not just coincidence that great journalism was pioneered, nurtured and celebrated at Americas great family-owned newspapers: The Wall Street Journal under the Bancrofts, The Los Angeles Times under the Chandlers, The Washington Post under the Grahams and The New York Times under the Sulzbergers.

title: Its a Duesie. The First, in Fact.
description: Scotts Valley, Calif.  Nobody would have called the car a beauty. Impossibly high-waisted, cloaked entirely in black, with boxy hips and awkward lines, it stood primly erect on the shop floor, a lonely figure amid seductive shapes.

title: The American Standard-Setter
description: With its DNA in motorsports, its advanced engineering and coachbuilders like Rollston, LeBaron and Murphy, Duesenberg was the most impressive and important American car of its era, said Sandra Button, chairman of Americas premier automotive judged competition, the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: The No. 2 Duesenberg Is Also Pebble-Bound
description: We heard there was an early Model A Duesenberg for sale in Jefferson City, Arnold Schmidt of Valencia, Calif., recalled. So on a whim and a prayer, in 2007 Mike Hogan and I drove to Missouri to try and buy it.

title: Family Adapts to Coachs Nomadic Career
description: CORTLAND, N.Y.  Steve Hagen has coached football in Illinois, Kansas and Arizona. And in Indiana, Nevada and Ohio. And in Iowa, California and North Carolina. And, now, New Jersey, with the Jets, the latest stop in his 30-year odyssey.

title: Ethiopian Plane on Fire
description: Raw video of the scene at Mogadishus international airport, where a Ethiopian military cargo plane missed the runway and crashed, killing four of the six crew members.

title: Toyota Recalls 342,000 Tacomas Over Seat Belt Problem
description: Toyota will recall about 342,000 Tacoma Access Cab pickups from the 2004-11 model years because of a problem with the rear seat belts, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. According to a report on the agencys Web site, Toyota says there is a problem with seat belts mounted to the short rear doors  which Toyota calls access doors  used to reach the rear passenger area.

title: Embracing Technology and Each Other
description: They grew up about 50 miles from each other; left their home state, Ohio, after reaching adulthood; and decades later  after a combined total of five marriages and eight children, a bevy of grandchildren and several lifetimes worth of adventure  landed three blocks apart in Santa Fe, N.M. But only the Internet could bring them together.

title: From a Prominent Divorce in the Affluent Class, Lessons for All
description: IF all goes well, well never hear much about Rupert and Wendi Murdochs divorce. The News Corporation chief executive and his wife will reach a settlement out of court for his third and her second divorce. If talks break down and the divorce goes to trial, however, we could be in for a round of sensational stories.

title: Unemployed? No Food Stamps for You
description: Earlier this year, Eric Cantor, the House majority leader, announced plans to rebrand the Republican Party, improving health, happiness and prosperity for more Americans and their families. In case you took any of that seriously, take a good look at the food stamp proposal Mr. Cantor unveiled a few days ago, one of the more brutal actions Republicans have taken against the poor since they took over the House in 2011.

title: Artists Plan Their Sand Castles, Sponsorships Included
description: Updated, 6:24 p.m. | The drive-through window will be topped by a horseshoe crab, the menu board made of driftwood and the parking lot lined with seashells. Thats the vision that the artist Duke Riley has for his entry into Creative Times sand castle competition, which began on Rockaway Beach on Friday afternoon. If his design, a boxy building with a square turret, seems familiar  or hunger-inducing  thats the point.

title: Placing Products? Try Casting Them
description: The brand managers at Georgia-Pacific were not about to budge. They agreed that Brawny Man, the plaid-shirted character adorning millions of paper-towel rolls, could come to life and share a moment with Mr. Clean. But their Angel Soft Baby, who had sold countless reams of toilet tissue, could never be displaced from her perch in the clouds.

title: On Hot Days, Cold Noodles Are a Welcome Choice
description: Some people just dont get hungry during a heat wave, but Im not one of them. During the last run of hot weather I craved cold Asian noodles; I loved the way they were both cooling and filling, and the way they served as a vehicle for refreshing vegetables like cucumbers and crisp shredded cabbage. Asian noodles dont need to be cooked al dente the way Italian pasta does, so they wont suffer from being cooked ahead, tossed with a little sesame oil or dressing and refrigerated for a day or two. This is really helpful when the weathers hot and youre hungry. You reach into the refrigerator and grab a bowl of noodle salad that is no worse for wear from having been there for a day.

title: When Andrew Johnson Freed His Slaves
description: Eliza Johnson gathered her familys slaves together at their East Tennessee farm on Aug. 8, 1863, to deliver the news. As one slave, William, remembered it, She said we were free to go, or we could stay if we wanted. With the dangers of continued Confederate military occupation and guerrilla war in the region, the slaves opted to stay put for the time being.

title: A Ballerina in a New Realm
description: Wendy Whelan has been a member of New York City Ballet since 1986, so its really no wonder that shes feeling a little fidgety these days. On Wednesday at Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival, Ms. Whelan unveils Restless Creature, a suite of duets choreographed by and performed with Kyle Abraham, Joshua Beamish, Brian Brooks and Alejandro Cerrudo. In the show, which will appear beginning next March in several cities  including New York, at the Joyce Theater  Ms. Whelan, following the path of Mikhail Baryshnikov, is keen to stretch her limits.

title: Sci-Fi Horror Fest With Nod to a Titan
description: Has it really been 17 years since Film Forum last hosted its late-summer extravaganza Son of Summer Sci-Fi, Fantasy & Horror, this year through Sept. 5? Well, its high time that this home of cinematic sophistication got its nerd on once again. And theres no better way to mark the events return than with the family-friendly sub-festival Wild About Harryhausen, double features (for the most part) showcasing the stop-motion-animation giant Ray Harryhausen, through Sept. 8.

title: Being Black in America
description: With the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington coming at the end of the month, and the emotions generated by the trial of George Zimmerman in the killing of Trayvon Martin still crackling, the timing is exactly right for the small, powerful retrospective show of paintings and drawings, In the Tower: Kerry James Marshall, at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Stravinsky Salute at Bard Festival
description: Each summer in the silver-roofed, Gehry-designed Fisher Center, the Bard Music Festival spotlights one composer. The intense weekend lineups feature well-known and obscure repertory performed by rising and established musicians, as well as panels and talks by scholars. Stravinsky, whose Rite of Spring turns 100 this year, is being honored at the festival. Sundays afternoon lineup includes musicians like the pianist Alessio Bax, and works by Stravinsky, Debussy, Schoenberg, Ravel and Satie. That evening, Leon Botstein conducts members of the American Symphony Orchestra and soloists, including the tenor Nicholas Phan, in works by Milhaud, Poulenc, Satie and Stravinsky.

title: The Hunted in Tanzania
description: In his homeland, Josephat Torner is said to be a ghost. Born with albinism, Mr. Torner is among the 170,000 Tanzanians with the congenital disorder  an absence of pigment in the skin, hair and eyes  who have been hunted for their body parts, which are believed by traditional healers to bring riches to those who possess them. Since 2006, more than 100 albinos have been maimed or killed by men who hack off arms, legs, heads and genitals, forcing the government to open boarding schools to protect children and communities to build walled-in camps where families are guarded, making them refugees in their own country.

title: Duesenberg Number One
description: A team of California craftsmen is restoring the first Duesenberg sold to the public to its original 1921 glory. It will compete at this years Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Nashville Singer Finds Her Voice
description: Four years ago, a singer named Margaret Durante tried to have a go at Nashville. She released a tepid country cover of Use Somebody, the desperate Kings of Leon anthem  an uncommitted way to begin a career  and that was that. She kicked around the city for a while, jumping among independent labels, but only this year, remade as Maggie Rose, has she sounded anything like herself.

title: Disorderly Conduct
description: New plays these days tend to come in slimmed-down sizes, the better to accommodate the worrying economics of producing theater, both on Broadway and off, and at the countrys major regional theaters. The Amoralists, an exuberantly iconoclastic Off Off Broadway company known for a raw, aggressive, hypertheatrical style, is, naturally, running off in the opposite direction.

title: The Grime Fighter: Brent Weingard Does Windows
description: The unforgiving pavement of Greenwich Street unspooled half a dozen stories below. But Brent Weingard, who had strapped himself into an olive-green harness and attached himself to a canvas belt that in turn was attached to a hook on the facade of No. 55, seemed oblivious to the fact that gravity was not his friend. Dangling outside the oversize double-hung window, the belt his only protection, Mr. Weingard didnt bat an eye.

title: Man on an Edge
description: Brent Weingard, of Expert Window Cleaners, has battled dirt and grime high above New York City for over 35 years.

title: A New Trail at the Cliffs of Moher
description: Icons of Irelands west, the Cliffs of Moher tower 702 feet above the churning Atlantic, and reign as the countrys most visited natural attraction. Now the intrepid can get even closer to the precipice on a new 12-mile walking trail that skirts the cliffs, linking Doolin in the north and Liscannor in the south.

title: Able to Leap Identities in a Single Show
description: Talk about a bad day: In 24 hours your girlfriend breaks up with you and says she thinks youre gay; you kiss a boy (and decide that maybe shes right); your mother tries to commit suicide; and you wind up moving in with her. All that, and youre not yet 21. So begins Please Like Me, the series conceived by and starring the Australian comedian Josh Thomas on Pivot, a new cable network for millennials.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Stringer and Spitzer Go on Attack in First Debate
description: In their first face-to-face confrontation, Scott M. Stringer attacked Eliot Spitzer on Friday as a wealthy lawbreaker whom the voters should not trust with managing New York Citys money. Mr. Spitzer, in turn, described Mr. Stringer as a career politician who had accomplished little in his 20 years in elected office.

title: Generations Past and Present, Tangled Up in Temptation
description: Washed Out

title: Obama Addresses Surveillance and National Security in News Conference
description: President Obama took questions from the news media on Friday afternoon, and Times reporters are providing live updates and analysis from the news conference.

title: A Game of Catch, or Hot Potato?
description: It started like most, with a call from the wedding D.J. for the unattached to make their way to the dance floor. The group of women gathered slowly, in silk and taffeta, arms ceremoniously outstretched. The bouquet went flying, the California desert sky in the background. Then it fell, bounced and rested squarely at the groups feet.

title: Breaking Free, in Life and on Screen
description: PARIS  Growing up in Iran, Golshifteh Farahani was a rebel. She persuaded her classmates to go on strike because their school had no heat, and she lied to her parents so that her sister could spend time with her boyfriend.

title: Cloaking an Opera in a New Identity
description: Two years ago, a neophyte stage director, unknown among opera cognoscenti and untested in New York, scored a major triumph in his Lincoln Center debut. The opera he directed was a repertory staple, yet paradoxically a work that has stymied seasoned artists recently assigned to stage it at the Metropolitan Opera. This newcomer not only offered a vision unlike any seen previously in New York, but also pulled it off without any sets or props  or, for that matter, an opera house.

title: Adventures in a Sinister Wonderland
description: Eat, the White Queen barks, as you wonder what to do with the waferlike snack she has handed you. In the midst of this tumultuous feast, theres no time for questions. Heaping bowls of fruit and diminutive cocktails materialize from who knows where, as she clambers onto tabletops and chairs, ricochets among cabinets and walls. A creaky lantern hangs from the ceiling; she reaches toward it and, with a brisk shove, sets it swinging on its precarious hinges. When Alice appears, our careening hostess gives her one drink, then another, luring the girlish visitor into a state as wild as her own.

title: Reports See New Roles for Megyn Kelly and Alec Baldwin
description: The Fox News anchor Megyn Kelly and the actor Alec Baldwin were at the center of unconfirmed reports this week about programming changes said to be planned at two of the cable news networks.

title: A Team Player Becomes the Captain
description: Even when David Lowery was a movie-mad teenager in Dallas, he was training himself to be a storyteller. Using the clumsy, now blessedly defunct method of VCR-to-VCR editing  record tape from one machine to the other, stop, rewind, repeat  he learned the basics of cinematic rhythm and narrative. Its just arduous enough that it forces you to think in advance about what youre trying to do  about the big picture, and about how one shot is going to lead to the next, he said. I think a lot of my editorial tendencies were born out of that process.

title: Oprah Winfrey and the Handbag She Couldnt Have
description: When Oprah Winfrey, one of the most famous television personalities and wealthiest women in the United States, walked into a luxury store in Zurich last month, she spied an expensive Tom Ford crocodile handbag in a locked case. The price: 35,000 Swiss francs, or the equivalent of about $38,000.

title: Ethiopian Air Force Plane Crashes in Somalia
description: An Ethiopian air force plane crashed in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Friday, killing four crew members and injuring two others.

title: A Gritty Warsaw Neighborhod Adds to Its Allure
description: The borough of Praga has been repairing its reputation, adding everything from bars and restaurants to a boutique hostel.

title: Hollywoods Biggest Bang for Its Buck
description: Earlier this week Forbes had an article on the return on investment on this summers films, noting that some have still not collected box office grosses that exceed their original production budgets. R.I.P.D., for example, cost $130 million to make, but has earned shy of $50 million at the global box office, according to Box Office Mojo.

title: U.N. Criticizes Vietnams Resumption of Executions
description: GENEVA  The United Nations said Friday that human rights in Vietnam had suffered a major setback after the execution of a 27-year-old convicted murderer in Hanoi this week, ending an 18-month pause in the countrys use of the death penalty.

title: Through the Eyes of the Maasai
description: In the market town of Narok, 90 miles west of Nairobi, I was buying a Kenyan SIM card for my cellphone when I heard someone behind me calling my name. He was wearing a bright red shuka, the traditional shawl of the Maasai people. Colorful beaded jewelry circled his neck, hung from his ears and ringed his wrists. At his waist, a short steel sword was sheathed in red leather. His feet were clad in sandals made from old tires.

title: Portraits From Kenya
description: People and places encountered during a visit to Maasai country in eastern Africa.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Files Legal Challenge to Nullify Presidential Results
description: JOHANNESBURG  The main opponents in Zimbabwes national election filed a legal challenge to the countrys highest court on Friday, citing widespread irregularities and demanding that the election be nullified.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Visualizing Web Activity and Vines Resilience
description: The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Heres what we noticed today:

title: En Garde! Dueling, Drinking and Laughing
description: LOUIS XIII IS NOT as famous as his son Louis XIV (the Sun King) or his descendant Louis XVI (guillotine, Marie Antoinette), but he was quite a character in his day (1601-43). And Michael Borrelli makes him the comic star of the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festivals fun-filled production of The Three Musketeers at Boscobel House and Gardens.

title: Marilyn King, Last of Singing Sisters Group, Dies at 82
description: Marilyn King, the last surviving member of the singing King Sisters, whose performing career began in the early 1930s and continued into the 1980s, died on Wednesday in Laguna Niguel, Calif. She was 82.

title: Harry Reid Hopes Its Not Racism
description: Despite all the politicians who call themselves straight talkers, there is little that makes official Washington queasier than straight talk. And so it was today when Senator Harry Reid, the Majority Leader, dared to suggest that there might just be a racial tinge to the Republicans wild-eyed outrage over just about everything President Obama says and their implacable opposition to just about everything he does or wants to do.

title: Steak With Tomatillo-Pineapple Salsa
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates a grilling equivalent to the one-pot meal using chile-rubbed flank steak and a sweet, spicy tomatillo-pineapple salsa.

title: Obama Discusses Surveillance Programs
description: The president opened his news conference by outlining four steps to move the surveillance debate forward, emphasizing greater transparency and oversight.

title: Italy Gets a Bastianich Restaurant
description: A new restaurant, set in a vineyard in northeastern Italy, serves a contemporary interpretation of Italian food.

title: August Showoffs: Steak and Salsa
description: Ill admit that most of the grilled meals I make are about as basic as it gets. Throw some combination of protein and vegetables on the grill, set the table, open the wine and call it a meal. Sauce is just a drizzle of olive oil and maybe some herbs from the deck. It keeps the kitchen cool, feeds the family and is about as easy as can be.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Walking the Water in the Everglades
description: The immense cypress tree at mile marker 54.5 of the Tamiami Trail  the highway that cuts across the Everglades in southern Florida  looks like it belongs in a fairy tale. Draped in robes of Spanish moss, the tree stands above its mirror image, reflected in a pond.

title: Dying Lawyers Request for Release From Prison Is Turned Down
description: A federal judge in Manhattan declined on Friday to order the release of Lynne F. Stewart, an outspoken former defense lawyer who is dying from cancer in a federal prison in Texas.

title: BMW Brougham?
description: The Gran Coupe is BMWs response to the Mercedes CLS and the Audi A7, but the BMW is not really a coupe.

title: A Lesson Learned About the Intensity of Camera Enthusiasts
description: Anyone who writes about technology has suffered the ire of Apple, Microsoft and Amazon fans, all coming to the defense of their favorite technology companies. Sometimes, these readers can say some pretty mean things to writers and other people who comment on stories; all, strangely, in defense of a corporation.

title: Fashion and Food Collide at Copenhagen Fashion Week
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Organization of Art
description: The curator is a relatively new figure in the art world, but the practice of organizing objects into comprehensive categories for study or display is centuries old. Ben Colman, himself a new curator at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn.  he joined a year ago  has resurrected an 18th-century model for organizing Animal/Vegetable/Mineral: An Artists Guide to the World, an exhibition of 105 artworks.

title: Spitzer and Stringer in First Debate
description: Eliot Spitzer and Scott Stringer, Democrats running for New York City comptroller, faced off Friday in a debate to be broadcast this weekend. The Timess Kate Taylor analyzes their performances.

title: Dr. Google Will See You Now
description: FEELING good today? You are not alone. Were approaching Aug. 11, which is, excluding Christmastime, the happiest day of the year in this country. Or at least the day with the lowest rate of depression, according to our Google searches.

title: Bodies of 3 Chinese Workers Found in a Kabul Apartment
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three Chinese workers were found dead under mysterious circumstances in an apartment in central Kabul on Friday, officials said, prompting the Chinese Embassy to urge the Afghan government to investigate to determine whether its citizens were specifically targeted.

title: Would Daffy Approve? Perhapth
description: You may have known his music all your life without knowing his name. In the 1930s, Raymond Scott was at the forefront of avant-garde jazz. Later, he was an early inventor of electronic music and instruments. But in the 1940s, his compositions, zany yet fastidious, were adopted as the soundtracks for Warner Brothers cartoons. Much as European modernism became the sound of horror films, Scotts experimental music became associated with Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Obama on the Federal Reserves Future
description: President Obama said his pick for the next chairman of the Federal Reserve will be one of the most important economic decisions he will make in the remainder of his presidency.

title: How Wedding Rituals Are Evolving
description: A selection of readers Instagram pictures that illustrate changing traditions.

title: A Duesenberg Reborn
description: The first Duesenberg sold to the public will have its debut at Pebble Beach after the cars three-year restoration.

title: Sifting Through Empires Built of Sand
description: One was known as the nickel empire  a raucous place of thrill rides, sideshow amusements and cooling sea breezes reachable by a 5-cent subway ride.

title: Pictures of the Day: California and Elsewhere
description: Photos from California, Somalia, Russia and China.

title: A Coupelike Sedan Suitable for Caligula
description: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.  Its the screwiest name on any new car, a name that seems swiped from the mid-1970s heyday of the Ford Gran Torino Brougham, the Dodge Royal Monaco Brougham and the Oldsmobile Delta 88 Royale Brougham.

title: M6 Gran Coupe: A Rare Clutch Player in the 6-Figure Field
description: When you cant get a manual transmission on a new Ferrari at any price  the 2012 599 GTB was the last car from Maranello to offer a stick shift  you know times are tough for gear rowers everywhere.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Win a Lottery Jackpot? Not Much Chance of That
description: When those exceedingly lucky people come forward to claim this weeks Powerball lottery jackpot, which swelled to $448 million on Wednesday, its hard not to think: Somebody is winning these things, right? It could be me.

title: Obama on Surveillance Transparency
description: At a news conference on Friday, President Obama used an analogy about washing dishes to help explain how to gain peoples trust about surveillance programs.

title: The Day Jerry Garcia Died
description: We were driving down Knoxville Avenue in Peoria, Ill., on our way to the cleaners to pick up the dress  the wedding was 10 days off. I flipped on the radio, and was greeted with the Grateful Deads Scarlet Begonias, an unusual but much-welcomed selection from a station known more for playing Lynyrd Skynyrd and Bad Company. Nice, I said. A good omen. We were young and in love and getting married, and the sky was yellow and the sun was blue!

title: Track Championships Add Layer of Scrutiny to Russia and Doping
description: MOSCOW  Thirty-three years after the American high jumper Dwight Stones missed the Moscow Olympics because of a United States boycott, he was standing in front of the stadium in which he would have competed and answering questions about another proposed boycott of a Russian Olympics.

title: Their Kind of Town, Always
description: CHICAGO  Even when they leave the city that nurtured them to pursue careers in Hollywood or New York, actors, writers and directors who first tasted success in Chicago tend to return here to work. The citys fertile theater scene seems to inspire a deep-rooted loyalty in artists that never abates.

title: In Germany, Little Appetite to Change Troubled Banks
description: FRANKFURT  One of the most battered banking systems in Europe has a history of mismanagement, corruption and politically connected lending, and it has cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of euros.

title: Sowing a Garden With New Seeds
description: Frank Juliano, executive director of Reeves-Reed Arboretum, has no problem with what he calls passive engagement with nature preserves.

title: Obama on Putin, Snowden and the Olympics
description: President Obama said in his press conference that Edward J. Snowdens asylum offer is only the latest in a long list of actions forcing the administration to question its relationship with Russia.

title: Obama on Embassy Closings and Drones
description: President Obama said that although Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups were weakened, they still posed regional threats against businesses and diplomatic outposts.

title: A Summer Buffet Bursting With Vegetables and Fruit
description: Its not until mid-August that most summer produce is available in magnificent abundance. Take advantage.

title: Wireless Customers Should Thank the Justice Department
description: Two years ago, the American wireless industry was well on its way to becoming a cozy oligopoly, split largely between Verizon and AT&T. The latter was trying to gobble up T-Mobile, and Sprint was doing so poorly some analysts speculated it too would become a takeover target. Thankfully, that scary scenario was averted when the Department of Justice sued to block the AT&T-T-Mobile deal. And now its intervention appears to be paying off for consumers in the way many of us had hoped.

title: The Trip From Bountiful
description: We are led to believe that summer produce is available all summer long, but in truth it arrives piecemeal. Yes, there are early ripening fruits and jump-started zucchini, new garlic and the first green beans that are in the market in June. But its really not until mid-August, at least in this part of the country, that simply everything appears in magnificent abundance.

title: In a Theater Mecca, Fringe Tends to Mean Choosy
description: Elena K. Holy refers to it as the P.U. era, for post-Urinetown, the time after that musical, a breakout success at the 1999 New York International Fringe Festival, went on to Broadway and became a hit there, too.

title: Postal Service Is Still Losing Money, but Not Quite as Much
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service on Friday reported a net loss of $740 million in the third quarter, compared with a $1.9 billion loss in the previous quarter, a better-than-expected performance for the agency, which has been shackled by falling revenues and a Congressional mandate that requires it to annually pay billions of dollars into a health fund for future retirees.

title: Summer North American Championships
description: ATLANTA  At the Summer North American Championships here, several top seeds in the Spingold Knockout Teams were sidelined. On Wednesday, the two-time defending champions, Team Monaco (Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness) lost by 5 international match points to Mitch Dunitz, Ed Davis, Jill Levin, Jenny Wolpert, Ross Grabel and Howard Weinstein.

title: Whistle-Blowers and Gangsters
description: New York Citys numbers-driven anti-crime strategy takes a hit in The NYPD Tapes: A Shocking Story of Cops, Cover-Ups and Courage (Palgrave Macmillan, $27) by Graham A. Rayman of The Village Voice.

title: The Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Trade Commission Orders Ban on Some Samsung Products
description: An American trade agency banned the import of some products made by Samsung Electronics, scoring another victory for Apple in its continuing patent feud with the South Korean company.

title: In This Game of Thrones, Ladies Play Hardball
description: An endless, multisided battle for a throne in a premodern land, but without much actual battling or perversity. That describes The White Queen, a costume-heavy 10-part series that begins on Saturday on Starz. Its as if someone concluded that the world needed a Game of Thrones tasteful enough that women would watch it.

title: Conserving a General and His Horse
description: The reporter David W. Dunlap visits the monument of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, a decorated Civil War hero, at the southeast corner of Central Park.

title: A Tale Told by a Loser, Chock-Full of Failure
description: Clear History, the title of a delicious new HBO film by Larry David, refers to the humiliating steps a loser takes to wipe his billion-dollar belly flop from the worlds memory drive.

title: U.S. Said to Plan to Arrest Pair in Big Bank Loss
description: Updated, 9:30 p.m. | Government authorities are planning to arrest two former JPMorgan Chase employees suspected of masking the size of a multibillion-dollar trading loss, a dramatic turn in a case that tarnished the reputation of the nations biggest bank and spotlighted the perils of Wall Street risk-taking.

title: Eerily Normal, the Real Star of Breaking Bad
description: Any list of great achievements credited to Breaking Bad, the darkly comic AMC series about a chemistry teacher turned meth-cooking gangster, must include the almost mythological resonance it has bestowed on its setting, Albuquerque. The show, whose final season of eight episodes begins on Sunday, has been shot in so many locales around this colorfully tatty city that a visit now seems like a jaunt through a studio backlot. And as mundane as those sites may appear, to a fan, they have acquired the patina of the hallowed.

title: Working-Class Heroes
description: If Made in America:  Building a Nation seems a rather grandiose title for a set of stamps, a glance at the images chosen for the 12 new stamps issued last week by the Postal Service shows it is only fitting.

title: Alex Kapranos of Franz Ferdinand: Where Hes Been; Where Hes Going
description: Things often fail us  a foreseeable outcome, given our expectations that new possessions will transform our lives, or at least perform as advertised. But every so often, something special comes along, doing its job so well that it restores our faith in the material world (or at the very least, in capitalism).

title: Saratogas Social Scene
description: This year is the 150th anniversary of racing at Saratoga, a place that magnetized the 1 percent long before the coinage came into being.

title: The Hamptons on the Hoof
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  The bidders gathered by the back walking ring in the fading gold light of a summer evening. Around dinnertime last Monday, while throngs from the Saratoga Race Course were walking to their cars toting lawn chairs and coolers, another group gathered to indulge a devotion to the sport of kings.

title: Irving Penn Photographs to Bolster Smithsonian Collection
description: On Friday the Smithsonian American Art Museumannouncedthat it had received100 imagesby the 20th-century photographer Irving Penn as a giftfrom theIrving Penn Foundation, significantly broadening its collectionof his work.

title: Learning Outside the Classroom
A Remake So Bad, Its Outright Homage
description: When it came out in 1991, Point Break was a hit. And why not? Under the direction of the action expert Kathryn Bigelow, the film featured the rising star Keanu Reeves as the undercover F.B.I. agent Johnny Utah, on the trail of the beach-based gang leader Bodhi, played by a Patrick Swayze hot off Ghost.

title: Time Moves On, but Blondes Still Get in Trouble
description: Some of the scenes are sort of funny, a few of the songs are a bit catchy, and a couple of the setups are kind of amusing in King Kong, a new musical thats enjoyable enough to watch though not really clever enough to admire.

title: Sex in a Teenagers Room?
description: One of the lovely things about not having children (besides never having to counteract a toddlers propensity for covering all surfaces with what experts call sticky) is that I will probably never need to stare down the barrel of teenage sexuality.

title: Are Teenage Boyfriend-Girlfriend Sleepovers the New Norm?
description: How do parents of teenagers feel about Sex in a Teenagers Room? To borrow a phrase from television: This week, our reporter investigates!

title: Crystals and Persuasion
description: Angel Silva sleeps in a cot-size bed next to a massive homemade shrine in the small room he rents in Astoria, Queens.

title: The Jockey
description: Russell Baze is the winningest jockey in American history. Yet his name is familiar to only the most avid followers of horse racing.

title: The Jockey
description: Coming Soon

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. What is the significance of the different-colored discs, about the size of a casino chip, that are left on the surface of the city streets after repairs are made?

description: The following is a transcript of President Obamas statement and responses to reporters questions at a news conference on Friday, as provided by the White House.

title: Obama Takes Questions From News Media
description: In his first news conference since April, the president discussed surveillance programs, the United States' relationship with Russia, and the Affordable Care Act.

title: Strong Coffee, Weak Hitters
description: Ken Auletta is a prolific author and staff writer at The New Yorker, with an apartment on the Upper East Side and a house in Bridgehampton, N.Y. But what distinguishes Mr. Auletta, 71, in some media circles is that for the last two decades, he has been a team captain in the annual Artists and Writers Softball Game, which will be played on Aug. 17 in East Hampton to raise money for several Long Island organizations. It is not a job for the meek, Mr. Auletta said. Perhaps youve heard of the egos of writers regarding their athletic prowess? Mr. Auletta is married to the literary agent Amanda Urban, who manages egos and looks for home runs all year long. Their daughter, Kate Auletta, and 4-month-old grandson sometimes join them on Sundays.

title: Friday Night Music: Rivers and Roads
description: Ive posted another performance of this song, but for personal reasons it has been on my mind, and I really like this version:

title: Lessons Learned When Its All Over
description: Older Americans are splitting up in record numbers  one quarter of all divorces now involve people over 50. In our new feature, Unhitched, longtime couples tell the story of their relationships, from romance to vows to divorce to life afterward.  Michael Winerip, Booming

title: When Cheatings the Issue, Remorse Helps
description: For a couple faced with overcoming the effects of an extramarital affair, regaining trust is crucial.

title: All-Borough Taxis (Like Yellow Cabs, but Green) Hit the Streets
description: They remain a rare sighting, snaking across the Bronx and Upper Manhattan  the curious spawn of a yellow cab and a for-hire vehicle, cast in a green that is close to the color of wasabi.

title: Doing the Math on a Snack
description: The Kind bar  a gooey slab of dried fruits and nuts, sometimes drizzled in chocolate and wrapped in plastic adorned with yellow, red, green and blue stripes  has been called the Ryan Gosling of energy bars.

title: Week in Pictures for Aug. 9
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include former Gov. Eliot Spitzer in Queens, a campsite on Governors Island, and Playground 52 in the South Bronx.

title: Meet the Aqualillies
description: The Aqualillies, who started in Los Angeles but now have troupes in seven other cities, have performed for a roster of celebrities including Leonardo DiCaprio and the Kardashians.

title: The Aqualillies: In the Pool, Poetry in Motion
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  On a breezy summer night on the rooftop of the Thompson hotel here, four members of the Aqualillies, a synchronized swimming troupe, were rehearsing for a performance.

title: All of Broadways a Stage
description: Whenever I eat at Joe Allen, a mainstay at 326 West 46th Street in the theater district, I cant help being reminded of the attachment I have developed to the area.

title: Byco, a One-Stop Site for Designers? Thats the Plan
description: A FEW MONTHS BACK, I wrote about Byco, a microfinancing site for designers, created by Jesse Finkelstein, a downtown retailer and manufacturer, and his sister, Meredith, a software developer.

title: Museum, All 60 Square Feet of It, Celebrates the Eccentric
description: Zigzagging through Cortlandt Alley, willing your GPS to deliver you to the citys smallest museum, you eventually arrive at a pair of black steel doors. They are, more often than not, shut.

title: A Weak Agenda on Spying Reform
description: President Obama, who seems to think the American people simply need some reassurance that their privacy rights are intact, proposed a series of measures on Friday that only tinker around the edges of the nations abusive surveillance programs.

title: Bill Cunningham | Fluent
description: This summer, young men have created a language of style using familiar items.

title: Sinai Blasts Kill Up to 5 Thought to Be Militants
description: CAIRO  Up to five suspected Islamic militants were killed Friday in two explosions in the restive Sinai Peninsula close to Egypts border with Israel, according to Egypts official state media. The Egyptian military has recently intensified its campaign against Islamic militants operating against Egyptian forces in the region.

title: Bill Lynch, 72, Democratic Strategist in New York, Dies
description: Bill Lynch, the Long Island potato farmers son who became known as the rumpled genius behind David N. Dinkinss victory in 1989 as the first black mayor of New York City, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Seeking to Be Both N.F.L. and ESPN of Video Gaming
description: The must-see match this month on Major League Gaming, North Americas foremost video-gaming league, was the long-awaited face-off between FaZe and Impact, two of the worlds top teams at the military shooting game Call of Duty: Black Ops II.

title: Sallie Mae to Be Accused of Overcharging Military Personnel on Loans
description: Federal regulators plan to accuse Sallie Mae, the giant student lending corporation, of charging military personnel excessive interest on student loans, and the government is looking into similar allegations against other lenders.

title: Ascending Heights of French Power, Trailed by Her Otherness
description: PARIS  CHRISTIANE TAUBIRA was taken aback, she says, though not altogether surprised, at the brutality of the opposition to the same-sex marriage bill she shepherded into French law this year.

title: When Douglass Met Lincoln
description: On Aug. 1, 1863, Frederick Douglass wrote a letter in his newspaper announcing his refusal to continue recruiting black troops for the Union Army. When I plead for recruits, I want to do it with all my heart, he wrote in Douglass Monthly. I cannot do that now, he said, because colored men have much overrated the enlightenment, justice and generosity of our rulers in Washington. Among other things, he said, black soldiers were not being paid as much as whites and were being sent on menial or dangerous missions without adequate support. Even worse, Confederate forces that captured black soldiers often either executed them or sold them into slavery.

title: Japans Debt Looks Like This: 1,000,000,000,000,000 Yen
description: Japans soaring national debt, already more than twice the size of its economy, has reached a new milestone, surpassing one quadrillion yen.

title: The Writing Is on the Walls, and the Signs and the Trees
description: A woman on her bicycle pulled over in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on Thursday to greet a couple of familiar faces. She jumped right into the conversation.

title: Judge Considers Limits on Apples Future E-Book Deals
description: A federal judge proposed on Friday that Apple be required to negotiate future contracts with major publishers separately and at defined intervals as part of its punishment for illegally conspiring to raise the price of e-books.

title: The Maryknoll Sisters, at Work in the World
description: Maryknoll sisters have devoted their lives to missionary work abroad since the orders founding in 1912.

title: Kenyan Inquiries Find No Sign of Explosion in Airport Fire, President Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya said Friday that investigations into the huge fire that razed parts of the international airport here, East Africas largest, had found no evidence of an explosion or an explosive device.

title: Inquiry Focuses on BBC Severance Payments
description: The British police have told news organizations there that they are starting to investigate whether the British Broadcasting Corporation broke the law by handing out large severance payouts to its executives. The scandal has the potential to entangle Mark Thompson, president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, who worked as the BBCs director general before joining The Times last fall.

title: Kerry and Hagel Meet With Their Russian Counterparts
description: WASHINGTON  The American secretaries of state and defense sought Friday to demonstrate that President Obamas decision to cancel a summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia had not disrupted bilateral discussions on nuclear weapons, missile defense and regional issues.

title: Chilean President Apologizes for Census
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  President Sebastin Pieras administration had promised the best census ever.

title: California: Senator Castigates San Diego Mayor
description: Senator Barbara Boxer published an open letter to Mayor Bob Filner of San Diego on Friday, asking him to step down amid more allegations of inappropriate conduct. This week, female veterans, including two women who were victims of sexual assault while in the military, claimed that Mr. Filner tried to use his position in public office to gain dates or intimate contact. Ms. Boxer, along with Californias other senator, Dianne Feinstein, had already called for Mr. Filners resignation, as have many other officials in San Diego and in Washington. In the letter, Ms. Boxer made a direct appeal to the mayor, a fellow Democrat. The latest revelations regarding your behavior toward women recovering from sexual assault  women who desperately need our help  have shaken me to my core, Ms. Boxer wrote in the letter posted on her Web site.

title: Mexican Tied to Killing of D.E.A. Agent Is Freed
description: MEXICO CITY  A drug kingpin convicted of masterminding the murder of an American drug agent in 1985  a killing that helped accelerate the modern drug war and that remains an emotional touchstone for law enforcement agents  was unexpectedly released from prison on Friday after his conviction was overturned.

title: Journalists in Syria Face Dangers of War and Rising Risk of Abduction
description: Abductions of journalists inside Syria have increased sharply this year as the ravages of the conflict have worsened and the insurgency has turned more jihadist and chaotic, making the country one of the most hostile conflict zones for news gatherers in recent memory, according to news media advocacy organizations, rights workers and veteran correspondents.

title: Killing Lions, Buying Bombs
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA and former Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton recently stepped up the fight against poachers, who kill tens of thousands of animals worldwide every year, selling their body parts for enormous profits. As well as bringing much needed political focus to the issue, their efforts include more resources to train and equip anti-poaching forces.

title: Whats the Story?
description: What should a song be about? Its a trick question for songwriters, because lots of amazing songs arent about anything. Or, at least, theyre not about anything thats obvious or logical. But they sound and feel great, and they engage your imagination, so it doesnt matter.

title: Boola (breath) Boola
description: Are you going? Im not sure. Are you?

title: Pollution Economics
description: WITH more than a million people in China dying prematurely each year from breathing its dirty air, and with warming temperatures portending rising sea levels and disruptions to food production, the centrally planned Communist country is experimenting with a capitalist approach to address the problem: it is creating incentives so that the market  and not the government  will force reductions in emissions.

title: Cable Customers as Collateral Damage
description: CBS and Time Warner Cable have been engaged in a contract fight that has left millions of residents in cities like New York, Los Angeles and Dallas without access to the networks programming on their TVs and computers for almost a week.

title: Bad Prison Policy for Women
description: The decision by the Federal Bureau of Prisons to transfer more than 1,100 women from a federal prison in Danbury, Conn., to other locations, including a remote facility in Aliceville, Ala., was rightly denounced as bad policy when it became widely known earlier this summer.

title: Bookers Web Company, Struggling, Sought Buyer as Senate Drive Began
description: Even as Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark continued to promote his year-old Internet start-up, Waywire, the company was racing to find a buyer because it had effectively stalled out, according to people aware of the efforts, and because it feared that his election to the United States Senate this fall would strip the moribund venture of its main asset: Mr. Booker himself.

title: Dufner Slouches to 63 and a Lead at the P.G.A.
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  No golfer has recorded a round lower than 63 in a major championship, but as Jason Dufners ball rolled toward the 18th hole late Friday afternoon, it had a chance to be the 62nd and last stroke of Dufners day. The ball stopped a foot short.

title: At Newtown Starbucks, a Gun Event Is Shut Out
description: The nations gun owners declared Friday Starbucks Appreciation Day, but in Newtown, Conn., not everyone seemed very appreciative.

title: Florida: Officer Put on Leave in Taser Inquiry
description: A Miami Beach police officer has been placed on paid administrative leave while the department investigates the circumstances surrounding the death of Israel Hernandez-Llach, 18, who collapsed on Tuesday when the officer, Jorge Mercado, fired a Taser at his chest after the young man had been spotted tagging a building. A police spokesman, Sgt. Robert Hernandez, said Friday there was definitely no gross negligence on the officers part. You dont die of a Taser, he said. An autopsy was inconclusive, and a toxicology report is pending.

title: Republican Mayoral Debate
description: Three Republican mayoral candidates, Joseph J. Lhota, John A. Catsimatidis and George T. McDonald, faced off in a televised debate Friday. The Times's Thomas Kaplan provides analysis.

title: Bloomberg Finds Fans in G.O.P. Mayoral Field
description: As the Democratic candidates to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg crisscross New York bemoaning police tactics, criticizing widening income inequality and promising to move the city in a different direction, the Republican field offered a starkly different view in a debate on Friday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Protecting the Most Vulnerable
description: Two-and-a-half years ago, The Times reported horrifying abuse of people with developmental disabilities or mental illnesses by state employees, who were rarely punished for it. Gov. Andrew Cuomo promised action. But too little appears to have changed.

title: The Dog Days of a Summer Circus
description: One of the first items on the Yankees promotional schedule this season was a giveaway calendar. Twelve players each had a month to themselves. Alex Rodriguez was not one of them. If only it were that easy to make him disappear.

title: Playing Post Office
description: Today, lets tackle a big national problem. Something thats been going on for so long that everybodys exhausted and has lost all hope of resolution in their lifetimes. (Like the baseball career of Alex Rodriguez.)

title: Mystery From the Grave Beside Oswalds, Solved
description: FORT WORTH  In a corner of the Shannon Rose Hill Cemetery, close to a chain-link fence that separates the living and the dead, a patch of ground has been worn free of grass by all who come to stare at one particular gravestone. With just a surname, the marker says it all: OSWALD.

title: McIlroy and Kaymer Readjust After Life at the Top
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  A few cracks sprouted in the moving wall of people following Martin Kaymer and Rory McIlroy in the second round of the P.G.A. Championship.

title: Sampras Weighs In on the State of U.S. Tennis
description: TORONTO  For the first time in 40 years, there will be no Americans in the top 20 of the A.T.P. rankings when theyre released on Monday. This after No. 20 John Isner lost to the Canadian Vasek Pospisil in the first round of the Rogers Cup on Tuesday.

title: In Cairo Camps, Protesters Dig in and Live On
description: CAIRO  Reaching the heavily sandbagged entrance to the sprawling protest camp in the northeast of this city requires navigating past makeshift brick walls and stepping around circles of stone marking the places where martyrs shot by the government fell dead.
