title: Dry Brush and Winds Feed Blazes in California
description: LOS ANGELES  Fueled by dry brush, shifting winds and droughtlike conditions, several wildfires continued to burn across Southern California on Friday as thousands of firefighters worked to quell the flames and protect homes.

title: Dominicans on A-Rod
description: Dominicans remain supportive of Alex Rodriguez, who faces a 211-game suspension for violating Major League Baseballs antidoping rules.

title: Public Unions Fight New Yorks Effort to Curb Health Costs
description: In his final months in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg set himself an ambitious goal: tackling New Yorks rapidly rising health care costs by finding cheaper insurance for the citys nearly 300,000 employees, 200,000 retirees and their families.

title: Two Firms Accused of Using Political Ties to Bilk Medicaid
description: A Congressional committee released letters on Friday alleging that a pharmacy and a nutrition company in New York State got away with inappropriately billing the Medicaid program by millions of dollars by using political connections in the Democratic Party, including Edward G. Rendell, the former governor of Pennsylvania, to influence the Cuomo administration.

title: Sheryl Sandberg Sells $91 Million of Facebook Stock
description: With Facebooks shares finally trading above their initial public offering price of $38 a share, Sheryl Sandberg is taking some money off the table.

title: Winged It
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  You have to be impressed with a puzzle that opens with GDEL, ESCHER, BACH, the revolutionary book by Douglas Hofstadter about self and patterns that lead to the self. Its a book I am still learning from, even on the 20th anniversary of my having opened it. And yet there are people who say that crossword puzzles are not the intellectual pursuits they once were.

title: Fox May Produce Clinton Biopic Reviled by G.O.P.
description: The script for the proposed mini-series on the life of the possible presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton hasnt even been written but we may already have a plot twist.

title: Threats Test Obamas Balancing Act on Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has said he wants eventually to scale back drone strikes and steer the country away from a single-minded focus on counterterrorism. But in response to a vague yet ominous terror warning in recent days, his administration shut down nearly two dozen American embassies and consulates and waged an intense drone campaign in Yemen.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: A gun maker prepares to move from Connecticut, bee colonies pollinate some rooftops in Midtown Manhattan and a newspaper announces its sale.

title: Amid Domestic Deadlines and Global Crises, Obama Begins a Shorter Break
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama headed off to Marthas Vineyard on Saturday for his familys almost-annual August vacation, toting the usual baggage of unrelenting global crises but stealing a weeks break before dealing with looming deadlines for the budget, his health care law and the appointment of a new Federal Reserve chairman.

title: Madison Returns to Giants, but Dont Call Him Coach
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There is obvious familiarity for Sam Madison this summer. He is back as part of the Giants defensive secondary in training camp, five years after he left.

title: Top Catching Prospect Is Poised to Join Mets
description: PHOENIX  Before catcher John Buck and the Mets embarked on a four-city, 11-game tour of the West and Minnesota, he offered his wife, Brooke, a collection of home remedies to induce her overdue pregnancy  everything from a stroll through Central Park to an entree of spicy foods.

title: Regina Resnik, Metropolitan Opera Star, Dies at 90
description: Regina Resnik, a Bronx-born opera star who sang more than 300 performances at the Metropolitan Opera and who made the shift from soprano to mezzo-soprano in the middle of her career, died on Thursday in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Two Sit-Ins Tested New Egyptian Leadership
description: Supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, massed in two sit-ins in Cairo for more than a month.

title: A Town Without Pity
description: America was once the land of Lady Liberty, beckoning the world: Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free, the wretched refuse of your teeming shore. Send these, the homeless, tempest-tossed to me. I lift my lamp beside the golden door!

title: Sanchez Throws for Two Touchdowns, One for Each Team
description: DETROIT  In evaluating Mark Sanchez, Rex Ryan has vowed that he is capable of ignoring the recent past  all the turnovers and the bewildering mistakes  and focusing squarely on the present. If so, there couldnt have been any way, none at all, that Ryan endured any flashbacks Friday on the Jets fourth offensive play of the preseason, a screen that Sanchez would have executed perfectly had the man who caught it, Ezekiel Ansah, not played for the Detroit Lions.

title: Hopefuls Connections Jolt Bitter Virginia Race
description: McLEAN, Va.  Frustrated by government red tape slowing his electric car company, Terry McAuliffe repeatedly sought a meeting at the Department of Homeland Security.

title: Highly Anticipated Return of Rodriguez Is Met With Mixture of Boos and Cheers
description: In some instances, the boos would come first, boiling up from within the Yankee Stadium stands, eliciting an immediate rejoinder of cheers and applause. Other times, the order was flipped  cheers first, then boos. Whatever the exact sequence or proportion, the visceral responses to Alex Rodriguez on Friday were always loud, the dissonant noises intermingling.

title: In Iowa, Hopes That a Clinton Can Close a Gap
description: DES MOINES  Iowa has never exactly been a place that feels like home for the Clintons.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Within Cairo, Impromptu Cities of Dissent
description: Camps of protesters in Cairo are the front lines in Egypts stalemate between a military-installed government and supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

title: Boos and Cheers Yield to a Triumphant Final Roar for Yankees
description: Sometimes, the boos would come first, boiling up from within the Yankee Stadium stands, eliciting an immediate rejoinder of cheers and applause. Other times, the order was flipped  cheers, then boos. Whatever the exact sequence or proportion, the visceral responses to Alex Rodriguez on Friday were always loud, the dissonant noises intermingling.

title: Mavericks Owner Chides Baseball
description: Mark Cuban, the Dallas Mavericks owner, delivered sharp comments about Major League Baseball and its stance toward Alex Rodriguez during an interview shown Thursday on The Tonight Show.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (CUNY) SPIES (1928) Fritz Lang: Silent to Sound, a five-film series, continues with this silent thriller, set to musical accompaniment, about a government agent (Willy Fritsch) trying to get the goods on a master criminal (Rudolf Klein-Rogge, above, with Gerda Maurus) with a vast network of spies. Throughout the bewildering mass of scenes in the German production Spies, there is always something to intrigue the eye, despite the fact that it is impossible to make head or tail of the story, Mordaunt Hall wrote in The New York Times. Its principal attributes are its excellent photography and its cleverly designed scenic effects. Its episodes are like a nightmare. Still, Mr. Lang handles his camera like a wizard. Afterward Jerry Carlson, the host of City Cinematheque, interviews Geoffrey OBrien, editor in chief of the Library of America.

title: A Limping Cabrera Leaves Rivera Staggered
description: The worlds greatest hitter stepped to the plate against the worlds greatest closer with two outs in the ninth inning Friday at Yankee Stadium. The Detroit Tigers Miguel Cabrera had never gotten a hit off Mariano Rivera in six prior at-bats, postseason included, and on the first pitch, he lofted a pop-up toward the first-base dugout.

title: 24 Hours at a Pro-Morsi Sit-In
description: Time-lapse video of supporters of the ousted Egyptian president, Mohamed Morsi, who have been occupying the area surrounding the Rabaa al-Adawiya mosque for more than a month.

title: Learning to Write and Let Live
description: We asked Tony Gervino, author of this weeks Lives essay, to share with us the most helpful piece of writing advice he ever received.

title: Death Panels and the Apparatchik Mindset
description: Aaron Carroll reads the Wall Street Journal, which is outraged, outraged, at the prospect that Oregons Medicaid system might seek to limit spending on treatments with low effectiveness and/or patients who arent going to live much longer in any case. Death panels!

title: Italian Style at the Top of the Rock
description: It was an opportunity the accomplished Italian photographer Fabrizio Ferri, who now spends much of his time in New York, could not ignore.

title: Globalization and Keynesianism
description: Looking at some of the comments on yesterdays column, I see that a fair number of readers believe that Keynes is no longer valid because any increase in domestic demand will simply leak abroad. This is a widespread view, but its wrong. Globalization has been impressive, but it has not proceeded far enough to make Keynesian analysis irrelevant.

title: Two Gaffes on Bases Loom Large in Mets Close Loss
description: PHOENIX  In a one-run loss, hindsight tends to magnify the opportunities that fizzled.

title: For Iraqis, Some Relief Amid Violence: Its Only 108
description: BAGHDAD  For many of the weary residents of this city, who have faced a bloody summer of explosions at soccer fields, cafes and open markets resulting in Iraqs highest death toll in five years, there are only small things for which to be grateful. Like the weather.

title: Variety: A Peaceful Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  The subject of peace and its broad application across all walks of human life is a complex one, requiring open and frank discussion among greater minds than mine, so you can imagine how surprised I was to see it covered here in the [Not peace. PEAS. Ed.]

title: Witnesses Relive Horror of Fort Hood Attack
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. First Class Maria Guerra crouched down on the floor of her office, put her back to the double doors and propped her feet on her desk, using her body to block the doors from swinging open. She told the two women she shared the office with to stay down and not stand up. She could hear screams beyond the doors.

title: Century-Old Boat, and a Mostly Teenage Crew
description: LONDON  Jolie Brise needs no introduction in a Fastnet Race, but its skipper, Toby Marris, still makes a good one.

title: Sisters for Life
description: In October, a woman you havent heard of who died in 1955 will be inducted into the National Womens Hall of Fame in Seneca Falls, N.Y., along with Betty Ford, Nancy Pelosi, Kate Millett and Julie Krone, the great jockey. She is Mary Josephine Rogers, also known as Mollie, also known as Mother Mary Joseph, founder of the Congregation of the Maryknoll Sisters of St. Dominic.

title: Aug. 10: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Punishments to Ponder
description: Major League Baseball recently suspended 14 players, including the stars Ryan Braun and Alex Rodriguez, for at least 50 games for violating its antidoping code. Only the Yankees Rodriguez has appealed his ban  his is for 211 games  and continues to play. Other players and many readers of The New York Times reacted to the penalties and their effect on the integrity of the game.

title: Fresh Start for Chiefs Leaders on Team With Lingering Pain
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mo.  They came to Kansas City to start over. Alex Smith, the quarterback who lost his job the way no quarterback thinks he should, and Andy Reid, the successful coach who experienced personal and professional loss, are now relying on each other for redemption.

title: Losing Games, but Not His Calm
description: When Robin Ventura first joined the Chicago White Sox, in 1989, the team finished last in its division. For the rest of his 16-year playing career, Ventura never finished in last place again, and as a rookie manager for the White Sox last season, he spent more days in first place than any other spot.

title: Books to Have and to Hold
description: I finish reading a book on my iPad  one by Ed McBain, for instance  and I shelve it in the cloud. It vanishes from my device and from my consciousness too. Its very odd.

title: Marxs Lesson for the Muslim Brothers
description: KARL MARX wrote that history repeats itself, first as tragedy, then as farce. He had in mind the Revolution of 1848, when a democratic uprising against the French monarchy collapsed into a Bonapartist dictatorship just as the French Revolution had six decades earlier.

title: When Doctors Discriminate
description: THE first time it was an ear, nose and throat doctor. I had an emergency visit for an ear infection, which was causing a level of pain I hadnt experienced since giving birth. He looked at the list of drugs I was taking for my bipolar disorder and closed my chart.

title: Thomas Lewis
description: Thomas Lewis is a psychiatrist who is best known as an author of A General Theory of Love, which was published in 2001 and has been reissued twice and translated into eight languages. READING Harlots Ghost by Norman Mailer is tremendous, more than 1,000 pages, beautifully written and in a setting youd think no one could ever use as a basis for literature. It tracks the career of a C.I.A. agent from 1955 to 1965. Also, The Ocean at the End of the Lane by Neil Gaiman. Hes kind of a macabre fantasist. Ive only gotten to the part where the person actually gets to the ocean at the end of the lane, so I dont know what happens after that.

title: Changing Attitudes on Labor Color Bay Area Transit Dispute
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  With the threat of a railroad shutdown looming, Alice Jorgensen was at the Bay Area Rapid Transits MacArthur Station here on a recent morning, waiting for the service she uses 8 to 10 times a week to run errands and go to the library. A strike, she said, would be a real inconvenience.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Sell Masterpieces to Help Save a City?
description: Readers discuss the value of art museums as Detroit weighs how to solve its financial crisis.

title: Good Charity, Bad Charity
description: YOU are thinking of donating to a worthy cause. Good. But to which cause should you give?

title: Lawless Sinai Shows Risks Rising in Fractured Egypt
description: SHEIKH ZWAYD, Egypt  Every night at dusk, the streets of this desert town near the Israeli border empty out, and the chatter and thump of gunfire and explosives begin. Morning reveals the results: another dead soldier, another police checkpoint riddled with bullets, another kidnapping. In mid-July, the body of a local Christian shop owner was found near the town cemetery, his head severed, his torso in chains.

title: What if Novelists Took Steroids?
description: COLUMBUS, Miss.  WELL, Major League Baseball, youre making me depressed. I cant even revel in the satisfaction of the Braves having their longest winning streak since 2000 because every time I turn on SportsCenter, youre there with your performance-enhancing drugs, with your suspensions, with A-Rod, Ryan Braun and then some more A-Rod.

title: Better to Have Won Only Once ...
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  The footsteps of champions are not erased when the tide goes out, which Rich Beem pointed out to Shaun Micheel on a rainy Friday the way one might call attention to a rainbow.

title: Another Twist in the Saga of Henrietta Lacks
description: When Henrietta Lacks was stricken with an aggressive cancer more than 60 years ago, doctors who treated her at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore took cells from her tumor without her permission or knowledge, as was common practice at the time. They soon learned that the cells were just as aggressive in a laboratory dish. Instead of dying quickly as previous cell lines had, they kept replicating at an astonishing rate, earning them the label immortal and making them immensely valuable to any scientist who wanted a stable base for experiments.

title: A Clean-Car Boom
description: In a welcome development for the planet, the cars on American streets are becoming much more climate-friendly much sooner than many had expected. Consumers are increasingly buying fuel-efficient hybrid and electric vehicles thanks to breakthrough innovations and supportive government policies.

title: Californias Continuing Prison Crisis
description: California has long been held up as the land of innovation and fresh starts, but on criminal justice and incarceration, the Golden State remains stubbornly behind the curve.

title: Men of Few Words Are Talk of the Tournament
description: PITTSFORD, N.Y.  At the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, the weather stopped fluctuating and the leader board began to rock back and forth. The third round at Oak Hill Country Club, played in abundant sunshine, low humidity and gentle breezes, turned into a seesaw ride with Jason Dufner and Jim Furyk taking turns going up and down.

title: I Flirt and Tweet. Follow Me at #Socialbot.
description: FROM the earliest days of the Internet, robotic programs, or bots, have been trying to pass themselves off as human. Chatbots greet users when they enter an online chat room, for example, or kick them out when they get obnoxious. More insidiously, spambots indiscriminately churn out e-mails advertising miracle stocks and unattended bank accounts in Nigeria. Bimbots deploy photos of gorgeous women to hawk work-from-home job ploys and illegal pharmaceuticals.

title: After Guantnamo, Another Injustice
description: ABOUT two months ago I learned that some of my books had been banned at Guantnamo Bay. Apparently detainees were requesting them, and their lawyers were delivering them to the prison, but they were not being allowed in because of impermissible content.

title: When Leaning In Doesnt Pay Off
description: WHY do women not have as many leadership roles in the workplace as men do? Some have pointed to internal barriers, suggesting that the problem is partly attributable to something about women themselves  they are not ambitious enough at work (while pursuing meaningful family goals), or are deeply committed to work but too hesitant to climb leadership ladders in organizations. Others cite structural or institutional barriers, like bias, discrimination or inadequate work-family flexibility. Sheryl Sandberg, in her now famous phrase, would have women lean in, to be more assertive at work and not let biases keep them from pushing forward. By leaning in, women would obtain more authority.

title: How to Read Afghanistan
description: ON a sunny, crisp November day in 2008, three American civilians joined a platoon of United States soldiers on a foot patrol in Maiwand District, a flat, yellow patch of earth crowned by black-rock mountains in southern Afghanistan. The civilians were part of the Human Terrain System, an ambitious, troubled Army program that sends social scientists into conflict zones to help soldiers understand local culture, politics and economics.

title: Rays Try to Promote Way Out of Attendance Skid
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  In their endless quest to get more people to show up for their games, the Tampa Bay Rays recently announced that they were revisiting one of their most popular fan giveaways: a figurine of Manager Joe Maddon dressed as a gnome.

title: Edgy Is the Crown of the Hit Kings
description: If one word can describe the members of baseballs 4,000-hit club, it is determination. A close second is anger.

title: High Culture Goes Hands-On
description: THE quest for an experience has taken over giant portions of our lives. Everywhere, we are assaulted by endless opportunities and activities. We text and get texts wherever we are, even behind the wheel. We constantly post what were doing and where we are, letting friends know how active we are. We take part in ever more extreme sports. We work not on our own, but in teams and in social spaces, bullpens for offices, coffee shops for self-employed free agents. And when we go on vacation, we spend our time shopping, eating and seeking adventure. Even in Europes old cities of culture, some people might stop in at the Louvre or the Uffizi, but often just to snap a few pictures on their cellphones to prove they were there.

title: Fatal Mercies
description: FEW of us get anything approaching the degree of control wed like over our lives. Must we also be denied a reasonable measure over our deaths?

title: Help Thy Neighbor and Go Straight to Prison
description: IF you want to understand all that is wrong with Americas criminal justice system, take a look at the nightmare experienced by Edward Young.

title: Kansas and Al Qaeda
description: SALINA, Kan.  IVE spent the last few months filming a Showtime documentary about how climate and environmental stresses helped trigger the Arab awakening. Its been a fascinating journey because it forced me to look at the Middle East through the lens of Arab environmentalists instead of politicians. When you do that, you see the problems and solutions very differently. Environmentalists always start by thinking about the health of the commons  the shared air, soil, forests and water  that are the basis of all life, which, if not preserved, will undermine the whole society. The notion that securing the interests of any single group  Shiite or Sunni, Christian or Muslim, secular or Islamist  over the health of the commons is nuts to them. Its as laughable as pictures of gun-toting fighters strutting on the rubble of broken buildings in Aleppo or Benghazi, claiming victory, only to discover that theyve won a country with eroding soil, degrading forests, scarce water, shrinking jobs  a deteriorating commons.

title: Madam President
description: WASHINGTON  PRESIDENT OBAMA proved himself a great segue artistFriday, as he smoothly glided from his previously unassailable position on the matter of surveillance to his new unassailable position on the matter of surveillance.

title: How the Post Was Lost
description: MANY American newspapers were doomed to decline from the moment the Internet arrived on personal computers. But The Washington Post, just sold off unexpectedly to Amazons Jeff Bezos, was never really one of them.

title: Hugh Martin, on the Importance of  Commitments
description: This interview with  Hugh Martin, chief executive of Sensity Systems, an LED lighting company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Measuring the Sycamore
description: PERHAPS it is a search for order, for scale, for the rules of proportion, some impulse to keep track, but human beings seem hard-wired to take measure of the world around them. Its why we record everything from rainfall and ice melt to temperature and bird arrival dates. Its also why I found myself one morning, not long ago, in the meadow of my friends Alex and Blair, in Wallkill, N.Y., along with George Profous, a senior forester with the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. He was there to measure the old sycamore tree.

description: Dear Workologist:

description: To the Editor:

title: Rodriguez Has Day Off but Talks to Reporters
description: Alex Rodriguez was not in the lineup for the Yankees Saturday afternoon game because Manager Joe Girardi decided to rest him after the late finish of Fridays game, a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers in 10 innings.

title: Car Bombings Kill Scores Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  As Iraqis flooded the streets of their capital and other cities on Saturday to celebrate Id al-Fitr, the holiday that marks the end of the holy month of Ramadan, a string of car bombs struck in mostly Shiite neighborhoods, killing more than 60 people, officials said.

title: Roy Rubin, Who Led Record-Losing 76ers, Dies at 87
description: The Philadelphia 76ers were pleading for help. In the spring of 1972, they ran advertisements in The Philadelphia Inquirer seeking applicants for their head coaching job. They had been N.B.A. champions in 1967, but poor trades and terrible draft choices had sent them plummeting, and they could not find anybody to fix things.

title: This Ironman Market Is Still Lacking Respect
description: UNLESS you know theyre taking place, amazing feats of endurance and longevity are invisible in their early stages.

title: The Housing Market Is Still Missing a Backbone
description: IN a speech in Phoenix last Tuesday, President Obama finally entered the debate over the future of United States housing policy. But his talking points offered few details about how to reduce the governments giant footprint in the mortgage market.

title: When a Co-Pay Gets in the Way of Health
description: ECONOMISTS specialize in pointing out unpleasant trade-offs  a skill that is on full display in the health care debate.

title: Skip the Romance; Shes Going to Court
description: IN our last episode, a woman unhappy with the dating service Its Just Lunch was offered a partial refund of her $1,000 membership. The catch was that to receive the check, she had to sign a contract in which she agreed to not disparage the company, ever.

title: A Responsibility to Give Back
description: MY grandfather was a Methodist minister. When I was growing up in Washington, his sermons at the Park Road Community Church, which he helped to found, had a powerful impact on me. He made sure I understood that I had a responsibility to give back and help make life better for others.

title: The Pigou Effect (Double-super-special-wonkish)
description: Via Brad DeLong, Robert Waldmann weighs in on the contributions or lack thereof of Milton Friedman, arguing that much of what he said was already there in Samuelson and Solow 1960. Actually, Id give him more credit than that; the S-S paper  very unusually for both men, and for Bob Solow in particular  is one of those pieces sometimes described as rich, with many points alluded to but not many takeaway lines; to the extent that people did take something away, it was the crude notion of a usable downward-sloping Phillips curve, which turned out to be wrong.

title: Amid Pipeline Debate, Two Costly Cleanups Forever Change Towns
description: MARSHALL, Mich.  As the Obama administration inches closer to a decision on whether to approve construction of the much-debated Keystone XL pipeline, costly cleanup efforts in two communities stricken by oil spills portend the potential hazards of transporting heavy Canadian crude.

title: Microsatellites: What Big Eyes They Have
description: PEOPLE already worried about the candid cameras on Google Glass and low-flying drones can add a new potential snooper to the list: cameras on inexpensive, low-orbiting microsatellites that will soon be sending back frequent, low-cost snapshots of most of Earths populated regions from space.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 11
description: Tensions between the United States and Russia came to a head last week after Russia granted temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden, the National Security Agency leaker,with the White House announcing President Obama would not meet with President Vladimir V. Putin next month.

title: The Pirate Bay Offers Web Browser to Avoid Censorship
description: ThePirate Bay, one of the largest and most famous piracy sites on the Web for illegally downloading copyrighted material, has been in a constant game of cat and mouse with legal authorities from around the globe for the past decade. Government agencies have often tried to shut the site down, or thwart people from reaching it because people use it to download movies, music, digital books and other intellectual property  only to see the site retaliate with new doorways for people to access its wares.

title: A Victim of Mass Incarceration
description: My Sunday column looks at Americas failed policy of mass incarceration, through the case of a man who was recently sentenced to a mandatory minimum of 15 years in federal prison as an ex-felon in possession of seven shotgun shells. To me, it just seemed nutty. If he had burglarized storage containers, then state authorities should have prosecuted him for that. But 15 years in federal prison, at a cost of more than $400,000, for innocent possession of seven shotgun shells with no gun to go with them?

title: Texting and Driving, the Aftermath in a Movie
description: Corporate videos are not often noted for their searing emotional content. But From One Second to the Next, a short documentary about texting and driving commissioned by AT&T from the acclaimed director Werner Herzog, tells four deeply harrowing tales of lives altered by a drivers focus on a phone rather than on the road.

title: In Story of My People, Recalling an Industry (and Way of Life)
description: EDOARDO NESI has written a short memoir of great charm, for all its sadness a pleasure to read. A born writer, Mr. Nesi was also by birthright a manufacturer of fine woolens. He was bred from an early age to take over the Tuscan textile business that his grandfather and great-uncle began in the 1920s.

title: The Chatter for August 11, 2013
description: In Switzerland, the banks are so organized that they are able to circumvent new rules and laws to continue to enable tax evasion.

title: At Chekhovs Estate, a Pastoral Literary Shrine Belies a Turbulent Century
description: MELIKHOVO, Russia  In a country as big and brash as modern Russia, it is always something of a surprise to discover a modest jewel of the culture that many Russians value so highly.

title: Boy, 5, Is Killed in Hit-and-Run on Staten Island
description: A 5-year-old boy was killed and his mother and a sister were injured on Friday night when they were struck by a black Mercedes-Benz sedan as they were crossing a street on Staten Island after a prayer meeting, relatives said. The driver left the scene and was arrested on Saturday, according to the police.

title: Rodriguez Rests, but Its Hughes and Yanks Who Seem to Need a Break
description: Less than 24 hours earlier, Alex Rodriguezs mere presence turned the Yankee Stadium crowd into a buzzing, inharmonious chorus. On Saturday afternoon, the Yankees were being blown out, Rodriguez spent the day on the bench, and the fans resorted to doing the wave for amusement.

title: Added Satisfaction

title: Obama Assures Disabled Veterans They Will Get Aid

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (AMC) LOW WINTER SUN Frank Agnew (Mark Strong), a Detroit homicide detective with a tragic past, is persuaded by a colleague, Joe Geddes (Lennie James, above), to help him kill another cop, who he claims murdered a loved one of Franks. But as holes surface in Joes story, Frank starts to worry that he has been played in this new series, based on a 2006 British mini-series of the same title. Ruben Santiago-Hudson portrays the precinct commander, who assigns Frank to lead the investigation into the cops death. David Costabile is an Internal Affairs detective delving into corruption. And James Ransone is a thug who, with his wife (Sprague Grayden), and a police officer on his payroll, looks to set up a drug and prostitution business. Its a deadly serious drama, but some of the early scenes are so overwrought that they are almost laughable, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. The series, she said, doesnt need to overreach. It has an intriguing story, an aptly sinister setting and an excellent cast. She added: Its inevitable for viewers to yearn for the kind of odyssey that series like The Wire and Breaking Bad provided. Low Winter Sun isnt that, but its an entertaining way station. The fifth, and final, season premiere of Breaking Bad leads in at 9. Talking Bad, a companion show hosted by Chris Hardwick that analyzes the seriess last eight episodes, follows at 11.

For just over an hour the soprano Tony Arnold, the closest this experimental work has to an actual character, walks atop a small platform stage amid white lace curtains, sometimes humming chants but mostly whispering cryptic sentence fragments and phrases. She was accompanied by four instrumentalists playing cello, percussion, various flutes and clarinets, all members of the International Contemporary Ensemble, known as ICE. And accompanied is the right word, since the musicians actually follow Ms. Arnold, stationing themselves in different corners of the platform, also whispering incomplete sentences and unanswered questions.

Thompson is, in his demeanor and his approach to public service, the anti-Weiner  even-keeled, not self-aggrandizing, careful, decent. His favorite adjective seems to be balanced. His oratory rarely rises above a simmer. (No one will ever accuse him of being inflammatory, Chris Smith dryly observed in New York magazine.) It is easy to forget that in 2009 he ran a close challenge to the seemingly invincible Michael Bloomberg despite being outspent 14 to 1.

title: Born Again in Mississippi
description: Adjutant Gen. Lorenzo Thomas had assumed that General Ulysses S. Grant had lost his way. For two days, his small party of officers and orderlies had ridden around and across the same pair of bayous, making use of bridges and fords and sometimes swimming their horses. Caught in a terrific storm, they had spent a night on the ground  notwithstanding the distinguished guests in the company, General Thomas himself, on special assignment from Washington, and Congressman Elihu Washburne, Grants friend and patron from his home state of Illinois. Washburne later recalled with admiration how the commander traveled six days in May of 63 with nothing more than a toothbrush, an example to his troops of military grit and mobility [1] .

title: Diversification Isnt Broken, It Just Takes a While
description: Its a classic moment in sports history. With less than 20 seconds left in Game 6 of the 1998 N.B.A. finals and the Chicago Bulls down by one, Michael Jordan goes one-on-one with Bryon Russell of the Utah Jazz. He pushes off (clearly!), Russell stumbles and the ball hits nothing but net. Game over. Bulls win.

description: In our July 17 post about Austins start-up scene, we wrote that there were at least 15 incubators and accelerators in the region. A reader in Austin questioned the effectiveness of incubators at creating successful companies in the long term. He compiled a list of the top 150 publicly traded software companies by top-line sales  his measure of success  and found that not one on his list had come out of an incubator.

title: On View | The Hilarious, Poignant Humanity of eBay Auction Listings
description: Clothing is an overlooked way of telling stories, said Emily Spivack, a 35-year-old curator, editor, writer and social entrepreneur. Sentimental Value, her Internet found-art project (on display at the Philadelphia Art Alliance through Aug. 23), is all about sartorial narratives. It gathers some 40 of the more than 60 garments she has purchased on eBay and pairs them with revealing tales the sellers shared when they listed them.

He had most recently been executive director for strategy at Cheil USA, New York, part of Cheil Worldwide. Publicis Dallas is part of the Publicis Worldwide in the USA division of Publicis Worldwide, which is owned by the Publicis Groupe.

When I was with another brand, I used to oversee 23 countries, and was traveling to five or six countries a month. One time I had to go to six countries in three days. Fortunately, I dont have to do those kinds of whirlwind trips anymore, but Im still flying all the time.

title: Listen Up | Teenage Folk-Singing Sisters Hit the Big Time
description: The Indianapolis-based sister folk duo Lily and Madeleine recorded their debut EP, Weight of the Globe (which came out in January), entirely on the weekends. Thats because on weekdays, they were too busy with high-school homework. Its weird that were, like, business partners now, said Madeleine Jurkiewicz, 18, the older sister. Not long ago, she and 16-year-old Lily were anonymous bedroom singers; now theyre signed to Sufjan Stevens Asthmatic Kitty Records, with a namesake debut album on the way (on Oct. 29). Devil We Know, which makes its world premiere here, is the centerpiece of the record, an appealing back-country portrait comprised of a slow-rolling piano melody, deftly plucked acoustic guitar and the teens tender, swirling voices.

The dish can include chicken or meat, or it can be vegetarian, as this version is, with tofu standing in for chicken. It can also be vegan if you omit the boiled eggs. Make the broth a day ahead so that it will be nice and cold.

title: On the Verge | Yang Lis Deliberately Imperfect Style

For someone so young, Li has accomplished quite a lot: after dropping out of Central Saint Martins, he interned for Raf Simons, and by the tender age of 23 had already caught the eye of Michle Montagne, the in-demand French publicist and stylist who helped shape the careers of Ann Demeulemeester and Haider Ackermann. Lis clothes are made in Italy, and finished with absolute precision  except when they arent. He loves an element of spontaneity, like slashing the two front pockets of a slim-cut classic boucl jacket. Art is not all clean lines, but has a human touch, he said. Same with fashion.

title: Kennedy, and What Might Have Been
description: As the 50th anniversary this November of the assassination of John F. Kennedy looms on the horizon, the debates over his legacy and presidency continue: a procession of what ifs and might have beens, accompanied by contradictory arguments, and informed and not-so-informed speculation. Would Kennedy have avoided Lyndon B. Johnsons tragic escalation of the war in Vietnam? Would he have found a way to propel his stalled tax-cut bill and civil rights legislation through Congress and start a war on poverty, or was Johnson able to achieve these historic goals only through a combination of his bare-knuckled, tactical knowledge of Congress; his personal relationships on Capitol Hill; and his ability to use the momentum of sentiment generated by Kennedys death?

description: A surge of brain activity in dying rats may hold an explanation for the vivid, realistic visions experienced by some human victims of cardiac arrest, researchers say.

title: Mother Says Son Is Messiah; Judge Says No
description: Updated, 6:14 p.m. | Asked to settle a dispute between a mother and a father over what their childs last name should be, Martin or McCullough, a magistrate judge in Tennessee in search of a Solomonic compromise decreed last week that the boy should be known as Martin McCullough. The childs mother, Jaleesa Martin, told the NBC News affiliate WBIR-Knoxville that she would appeal the ruling, mainly because the court order meant scrapping the first name she had given her son, Messiah.

title: Intense and Dramatic Tango, Up Close and Sensual
description: On Sept. 25 and 26, the Argentine dancers Gabriel Miss and Anala Centurin will appear in City Centers Fall for Dance opening program. Since they are among the worlds most wonderful dancers today, I look forward to it, just as I cheered them recently when they performed at the Vail International Dance Festival. Yet, although I have loved Argentine tango as a theatrical form since the 1980s, I increasingly have learned that tango is best seen at close quarters. Yes, tango is inherently dramatic and scintillatingly musical, but its whole emphasis can be distorted by rendering it theatrical or exhibitionistic.

At night, for instance, we often watch an episode of some series thats available on Netflix: Kingdom, George Gently, Sherlock. Its always a mistake, though, because all I do is judge the characters, wonder what will happen next, ask questions and solicit my husbands opinion about whether he thinks most men behave the way the ones on TV do.

title: The Olympics Leadership Mess
description: ON Sept. 10, members of the International Olympic Committee will vote for a new president for the first time in 12 years. The campaign for the I.O.C. presidency is a quiet event that does not attract much news coverage (how many of the six candidates can you name?), but if you care about human rights, the stakes are high. This may be the last chance for many years to reform the committees approach to repressive governments that seek to host the games. It is imperative that the committee elect a president willing to lead, not cave in, on this issue.

title: Tackling the Roots of Rape
description: Steubenville. The Naval Academy. Vanderbilt University. The stories of young men sexually assaulting young women seem never to stop, despite all the education weve had and all the progress weve supposedly made, and there are times when I find myself darkly wondering if theres some ineradicable predatory streak in the male subset of our species.

Now, as President Obama has observed, the nation is divided by  a different threat: widening income inequality. He could respond much as Mr. Johnson did  with an executive order aimed, this time, at raising the pay of millions of poorly paid employees of government contractors.

title: Shortsighted Thinking on Israeli Settlements
description: There was a certain internal political logic to two announcements made by the Israeli government, just days before Wednesdays scheduled resumption of peace talks with the Palestinians. Early Monday, the government released a list of 26 Palestinian prisoners to be released Tuesday, most serving sentences for murder and other violent crimes. A few hours before that, the government published bids for the construction of more than 1,000 new housing units in East Jerusalem and existing West Bank settlements  a move apparently designed to mollify right-wingers who would oppose the prisoner release.

title: Racial Discrimination in Stop-and-Frisk
description: Judge Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court in New York upheld the bedrock principle of individual liberty on Monday when she ruled that the tactics underlying New York Citys stop-and-frisk program violated the constitutional rights of minority citizens. She found that the city had been deliberately indifferent to police officers illegally detaining and frisking minority residents on the streets over many years.

title: Texas: After Illnesses, Compounded Drugs Are Recalled
description: A pharmacy has recalled all of its compounded sterile products after 15 patients in two Texas hospitals fell ill from what federal health officials said were tainted sterile infusions. The patients developed bacterial infections in their bloodstreams from infusions of calcium gluconate made by Specialty Compounding of Cedar Park, the Food and Drug Administration said. The substance is used to treat conditions related to low calcium levels. No patients died. Lawmakers are developing legislation that would toughen rules for pharmacy compounding, the practice of custom-mixing medicines, after a Massachusetts pharmacy caused a deadly meningitis outbreak last year.

Jerry Brown signed legislation on Monday that guarantees transgender students access to interscholastic sports, gym classes, locker rooms and bathrooms based on their gender identity, irrespective of their biological sex. Interscholastic athletic commissions in several states, including California, have policies that allow students to compete on teams that correspond with their gender identities rather than the sex listed on their school records. California will be the first state to write access for transgender students to sex-segregated activities into law.

title: Myanmar: U.N. Envoy Visits Troubled State
description: A United Nations human rights envoy on Monday visited the state of Rakhine just days after the police opened fire on protesters seeking access to the body of a Rohingya Muslim fisherman. One person was killed and 10 others were wounded in the confrontation on Friday, said a government spokesman, Win Myaing. Over the past year more than 250 people have been killed in religious violence, most of them minority Muslims, and 140,000 have been forced to flee their homes. A United Nations special rapporteur on human rights, Toms Ojea Quintana, is on an 11-day visit, including a stop in Rakhine, scene of some of the worst bloodshed. After the battered body of a fisherman washed ashore on Friday in Sittwe, rumors spread among Rohingya Muslims that he had been killed by the police. Mr. Win Myaing said the police fired into the air when 500 Rohingyas who were demanding access to the body attacked a police checkpoint. After more protesters gathered, the officers shot into the crowd, wounding at least 10, he said. One of the men died of his wounds, he said. (AP)

But the Suffolk County police said the preliminary results gave them no reason to believe that the death was anything other than an accident.

In 1976 leg stress fractures kept her out of the Montreal Games. And in 1980 the United States boycott prevented her from competing in Moscow. In this Nine for IX documentary, Shola Lynch tells the story of Ms. Decker (above, in 1984) as she prepared to make her Olympic debut in the 3,000 meters at the Games in Los Angeles  and the collision with Zola Budd, an 18-year-old barefooted South African running for Britain, that derailed her dreams.

title: Is It Nuts to Give to the Poor Without Strings Attached?
description: Bernard Omondi lives in a small Kenyan village in a rural district called Siaya that sits right on the Equator and is almost impossible to get to. He has spent years working on and off as a day laborer, moving stones on construction sites, and commuting long distances over rough dirt roads. When he could find work, he made about $2 a day. When he couldnt, his two sons sometimes went hungry. Then one morning last year, Omondi woke up to an unusual text message. When I saw the message, I jumped up, he recalled. My wife said, Bernard, what is it?  He told her he had just been given $500 with no strings attached.  Its here!  he said.

title: How Laura Poitras Helped Snowden Spill His Secrets

She replied to this one and sent her public key  allowing him or her to send an encrypted e-mail that only Poitras could open, with her private key  but she didnt think much would come of it.

title: A Conversation With Katrina Lantos Swett, on Religious Freedom in India

Mr. Modi is the de facto prime ministerial candidate for Indias leading opposition party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, in the 2014 parliamentary elections. Mr. Modi has been remodeling himself as a pro-business, pro-development leader who can bring about economic growth and make difficult decisions. Yet the ghosts of the 2002 sectarian violence, in which more than 1,000 Muslims were killed and tens of thousands displaced from their homes under his watch in Gujarat, along with his continuing use of derogatory language to refer to Indias Muslims, has raised concerns about his political rise.

title: New Jersey Jitney Drivers Squeezed Between Competition and Demands for More Safety
description: WEST NEW YORK, N.J.  From behind the wheel of his 21-seat minibus, Joseph Cruz sees things with exceptional clarity. He has divided the world  at least, the helter-skelter world of commercial minibuses in which he has made his living for 11 years  into two camps: the safe drivers and everyone else.

title: Aug. 13: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Appointment of 19 Generals as Provincial Governors Raises Fears in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Egypts new military-appointed government on Tuesday named a roster of generals as provincial governors, raising fears of a return to the authoritarianism of former President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Mount Fuji, So Popular It Hurts
description: The words printed on the buses that drive through Kawaguchiko, a scenic town in the foothills of Japans tallest and most sacred mountain, were as reassuring as they were disconcerting: Preserve the Nature of Mt. Fuji.

title: U.S., Filing Suit, Moves to Block Airline Merger
description: Updated, 8:44 p.m. |After a decade of rapid consolidation in the nations airline industry, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Tuesday to block the proposed merger between American Airlines and US Airways, which would create the worlds largest airline.

title: N.H.T.S.A. Servers Restored After They Were Hacked
description: About 10 days after a few of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administrations servers were hacked and taken offline, service has been restored. The servers were used to store and make available to the public documents like reports from automakers about plans for recalls, as well as communications between automakers and agency officials regarding investigations.

title: A Rating With a High Return: NC-17
description: Updated, 10:32 p.m. | with comment from Michael Cieply.

title: 'Believe'
description: The first television ad from the Thompson campaign focuses broadly on his platform and his background.

title: A Tale of Two Flat Countries
description: Simon Wren-Lewis writes about the rise of extremist parties in the UK and the Netherlands. As he notes, in a way this shouldnt be surprising. The Netherlands, in particular, has the kind of Grand Bargain the Washington Post editorial page dreams of  a government of national unity committed to fiscal austerity. Its as if Harry Reid, John Boehner, and President Obama had all agreed to implement Simpson-Bowles, with some extra front-loaded cuts thrown into the bargain too. And heres the thing: its not working. So what you have is a frustrated populace, finding no respectable politicians willing to challenge a failing orthodoxy:

title: A Wall St. Brawlers Winning Qualities Also Play Out in Defeat
description: Updated, 9:27 p.m. |  The hedge fund titan William A. Ackman is not an investor known to make small bets. Yet one of his gambles, on turning around a dowdy department store chain, has blown up, leading him to make an embarrassing retreat.

title: The Gun Report: August 13, 2013
description: Two months after the deadly shooting at Santa Monica Community College, guns have been banned at all nine community college campuses in Los Angeles. The unanimously approved resolution passed by the Board of Trustees last week cited repeated, serious occurrences of campus-based shootings. It also stated the presence of firearms, even when nonoperational and in the instructional setting, lends itself to the potential for panic and fear.

title: John Lewis on Race and Voting Rights
description: Ahead of the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, Congressman and civil rights leader John Lewis discusses race relations and voting rights with reporter Sheryl Gay Stolberg.

title: Still Marching on Washington, 50 Years Later
description: WASHINGTON  John Lewis was the 23-year-old son of Alabama sharecroppers and already a veteran of the civil rights movement when he came to the capital 50 years ago this month to deliver a fiery call for justice on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Today in Small Business: Walmart Vs. Amazon
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: John Lewis 50 Years After the March on Washington
description: The sole surviving speaker from the 1963 march, Mr. Lewis is taking on the Supreme Courts decision on voting rights.

title: Into the Gyre
description: A team of artists and scientists traveled to Alaska to document water pollution. Carl Safina, an ecologist and Mark Dion, an artist, talk about their observations from the trip.

title: 'Manny's Law'
description: A new ad from the Quinn campaign focuses on the creation and passing of Manny's Law.

title: Herbalife Safety Issue Draws Scrutiny
description: Updated, 9:15 p.m. |  After Herbalife, the nutritional supplement company, began producing its best-selling drink mix at a plant in California, anxious executives had to scramble in early 2011 as they faced a potentially serious product safety threat.

title: Booker Coasts in Primary; Make Me Your Senator, He Tells New Jersey
description: Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, who rose to prominence with his efforts to remake a notoriously troubled city and then used that perch to build a national reputation as a charismatic and media-savvy star in the Democratic Party, easily won the Democratic nomination for United States Senate on Tuesday night.

title: Lady Gaga Releases a New Song After It Leaks Online
description: Lady Gaga has released the first single off her forthcoming album a week early because the song was circulating on the Internet, the BBC reports.

title: The Civil War and Hawaii
description: Almost 5,000 miles and half an ocean away from the killing fields of Gettysburg, Chickamauga, or Spotsylvania, Hawaii and Hawaiians might be assumed to have not played a role in the Civil War. Yet regardless of proud protestations of neutrality by the Hawaiian monarchy  the islands were not American territory at the time  many of the islands residents participated in the conflict, on both sides. And for good reason: though they lived on one of the most geographically isolated island chains in the world, Hawaiians kept abreast of international events, knowing that the outcome of the war could greatly affect Hawaii as well.

title: Discord in an Intergenerational Home
description: Mother Daughter Me, Katie Hafners new memoir about her attempt to form a multigenerational household, reminds me of those horror movies where the heroine (its always a heroine) is about to plunge heedlessly into a darkened basement/attic/forest instead of sensibly dialing 911. You want to yell, Nooooo!

title: Costata
description: Inside Michael Whites steakhouse on Spring Street.

title: Image of the Day: August 13
An Old Flame, Whispering Steak
description: So this is where he decides to bring us: back to the same place on Spring Street where it all started. The year was 2002, the restaurant was called Fiamma, and he was just another hungry 29-year-old chef from the Midwest. We didnt know yet that his name was Michael White. We just knew that when he cooked Italian food, he could make us forget about all the others for a while.

title: Wines to Accompany Grilled Flank Steak
description: A fine piece of grilled flank steak is an open invitation to a world of red wines to show their stuff. But what happens when you add chiles heat, to say nothing of nomadic travelers in the wine world like tomatillo and pineapple? Not to worry. The char of the meat will still be the dominant flavor, though amplified and augmented by the additions. I recommend a dry Loire red, like one of the less-structured Chinons, Bourgueils or Saumur-Champignys. Unless they are too tannic, they seem to have an affinity for chiles. Whats more, their fruit, spice and acidity will take naturally to the fruitiness of the tomatillo, pineapple and, indeed, the chile. Other options: cru Beaujolais and West Coast gamays, if you can find them; lighter-bodied Ribeira Sacra and Bierzos, made from the menca grape; and Austrian blaufrnkisches and zweigelts.

title: Avivos Custom Cellphone Cases, Pretty but Tricky
description: For ease of use, most cellphone cases typically have a single, integrated design. To change the look, you have to change the entire case. Avivo thinks owners should be able to swap a few parts instead.

title: Brolly Umbrella Frees Thumbs for Texting
description: Umbrellas are decidedly low-tech devices. They really serve only to keep our gadgets, and heads, dry. Unfortunately, holding an umbrella usually precludes the use of said gadgets, but Brollytime, a company based in Chicago, has come up with an innovation to change that.

title: Pacific Northwest Car Collectors Celebrate 60 Years of Corvette History
description: It was a no-brainer for LeMayAmericas Car Museum to open an exhibition honoring Americas sports car, the Chevrolet Corvette. As David Madeira, president and chief executive of the Tacoma, Wash., museum said at the opening of 60 Years of Vette on Friday, Sixty years of continuous production speaks to the importance of this car in our culture.

title: Hillary Clinton Returns to Political Life
description: Hillary Clinton seized upon exactly the right issues in her return to political life this week, issuing a firm defense of voting rights Monday in a speech to the American Bar Association. The danger is that she will see this as a box thats been checked, an obligation addressed, and will then move on to other subjects in a policy parade.

title: For Sports Fans, Before the Internet, There Were the Complete Handbooks
description: Zander Hollander sat silently on his couch. Rows of books  a large portion of them ones he created, edited and nurtured  hovered above him, dominating a wall in his Manhattan apartment.

title: Blacked Out in 3 Cities, CBS Still Wins Ratings Race
description: The 11-day old blackout of CBS on Time Warner Cable systems seems to be having a minimal effect on the networks ratings.

title: A Challenge to Industry in Small-Town Australia
description: A ruling in a Rio Tinto case could upend a system that favors the mining industry.

title: Coal Mine Fight Embodies an Economic Struggle in Rural Australia
description: BULGA, Australia  Bulga, a hamlet nestled in the verdant hills of the wine country north of Sydney, is at the center of a legal dispute that could reshape the regulatory environment of a national economy heavily dependent on natural resource extraction.

title: Conan the Barbarian Rampages Into Prestigious Archive
description: Conan the Barbarian, the pulp fiction action hero introduced in 1932 by Robert E. Howard, will soon be rubbing shoulders with the spindlier literary characters of David Foster Wallace, Don DeLillo and Norman Mailer, thanks to the recent acquisition of a large Howard collection by the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: Great Story, Compelling and Rich: Anchorman Ron Burgundy to Write Memoir
description: In his time as a television broadcaster Ron Burgundy has boasted that he discovered the wheel and built the Eiffel Tower out of metal and brawn. And while he may have accomplished neither of those things, he will soon be the author of a memoir.

title: Hiring to Carry Out Tasks Vs. Hiring to Achieve Goals
description: At the most recent She Owns It business group meeting, the owners talked about hiring employees who could grow along with their companies. Susan Parker, who owns Bari Jay, said she initially doubted that her most recent customer service hire was right for the job because she seemed overqualified and interested in doing more than customer service. Still, Ms. Parkers sister, Bari Jays co-owner, persuaded her to choose this candidate over another with a more typical customer service background.

title: New Novel by Dave Eggers Due in October
description: Dave Eggers is perfecting the art of sneaking onto bookshelves. His new novel, The Circle, will be published in October, according to the Web site of his publisher Alfred A. Knopf. Like his last book, A Hologram for the King, which was published less than a month after its existence was announced, The Circle will appear without much lead time.

title: The Ad Campaign: Quinn Supporters Testimonial of Her Effectiveness
description: First aired: August 13, 2013

title: Toto Koopman, Model Spy
description: All but forgotten today, in her time Toto Koopman shocked the world. As the first famous biracial model (she was half-Javanese, half-Dutch), Koopman posed for Chanel in Paris and appeared on the cover of French Vogue in the 1930s. She was fluent in six languages, which served her well when she later became a spy for the Italian resistance during World War II  until she was thrown in a Nazi concentration camp. In his new biography, The Many Lives of Miss K., Jean-Nol Liaut likens the secretive Koopman to a squid hiding behind its cloud of ink. Though she was never monogamous  she took lovers into her 70s, including the actress Tallulah Bankhead, Winston Churchills son Randolph and the press baron Lord Beaverbrook  she devoted the second half of her life to Erica Brausen, the visionary art dealer, who, with Koopmans help, launched Francis Bacons career from her Hanover Gallery in London. The couple never concealed their relationship, even though homosexuality was a criminal offense in Britain at the time. Being around them, a friend recalled, I really came to understand the meaning of freedom.

title: Capture, a Camera Strap Attachment, Gets an Update
description: The Capture, a device from Peak Design that attaches a camera to any belt or strap, has become a bit smarter. A refined version, called the Capture Pro, is now being shipped to some Kickstarter investors, and will be available to the public in September.

title: Pain and Gain:  50 Shades Author Tops Earnings List
description: The publishing phenomenon Fifty Shades of Grey has made its author, E. L. James the No. 1 writer in the world in terms of earnings over the last year with an estimated $95 million, according to anannual list released by Forbes of the top-earning book writers.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: Perceval
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.Poor Perceval apparently didnt have as good a publicist as some other Knights of the Round Table did, but he gets title-character treatment from a troupe called the Immediate Family in this spunky, stripped-down show.

description: And just like that, American Airlines easy path out of Chapter 11 has hit a dead end.

description: First aired: August 13, 2013

title: Delta to Offer Shuttle Between Los Angeles and San Francisco
description: Delta Air Lines will begin hourly nonstop shuttle service between Los Angeles International and San Francisco International airports on Sept. 3, tailored to business travelers while adding a California perspective, the carrier said earlier this month.

title: Sudsing Up, Memorably
description: Instead of treating showers as utilitarian afterthoughts or relying on the old trend of rain-forest showerheads, some hotels are getting creative when it comes to getting wet.

title: Lewis Says He Will Back Hillary Clinton for President if She Runs
description: Representative John Lewis, the Georgia Democrat and elder statesman of the civil rights movement, said in an interview that he would support Hillary Rodham Clinton if she sought the White House in 2016, and called her the most qualified person in America to be president.

title: Recipe Lab: Blueberry Jam
description: Julia Moskin makes blueberry jam with lime from Kevin Wests canning cookbook Saving the Season.

description: The activist hedge fund boss William A. Ackman is always ready for a fight  just maybe not so many at once.

title: Art Dealer Suspected of Selling Fake Paintings Is Released on Bail
description: Glafira Rosales, the Long Island art dealer who was arrested this past spring on charges that she laundered money and evaded taxes as part of a scheme to sell multimillion-dollar forgeries, was released on bail Monday.

title: Jackery Air Auxiliary Battery Has Power to Spare
description: Batteries may sometimes pose vexing problems for the automotive and aircraft industries, but for mobile devices they seem to be improving.

title: Getting Started With Blueberry Jam
description: Recipe Lab, a monthly feature, invites you to cook with the Dining section. Well publish a standout recipe from a cookbook for you to try; the next week, the books author will join Julia Moskin and readers in a live video chat.  If youre interested in participating in the chat, please fill out this form. You can watch this months chat on Wednesday, Aug. 21, at 2 p.m. Eastern time, at nytimes.com/dining.

title: Subsidized Child Care: For the Poor, By the Poor
description: For a parent with a minimum-wage job in retail or fast food, finding a really good in-home child-care provider is like choosing the Auntie or Gramma of your dreams: loving, secure and available for emergencies. Find the right woman (and it is almost invariably a woman) and shes got your back. If Dunkin Donuts calls with a shift change, or the painful tooth you couldnt afford to have the dentist treat turns into a trip to the E.R., you have one less thing to worry about.

title: U.S. Accounting Regulator Proposes More In-Depth Reports From Auditors
description: The federal regulator that polices accounting firms is proposing a major overhaul of how company audits are reported to the public, a move that could provide investors with deeper insight into the health of corporations.

title: Afraid to Get Tested? Slow Down and Think About It
description: Many patients are eager to search bottomless troves of health information on the Internet. But when it comes to learning whether they are at risk for certain diseases by getting a medical test, millions would rather just not know.

title: In Bangkok, Chefs Look Beyond Thailand
description: Bangkoks renowned local food scene established the city long ago as one of the most exciting, well-priced and diverse culinary capitals in Southeast Asia. These days some heavyweight chefs, both foreign and homegrown, have gone from showcasing a more highbrow take on Thai classics to looking at other, more far-flung menus for inspiration.

title: Restaurant Report: &Samhoud Places in Amsterdam
description: Its been a busy last 12 months or so for Amsterdam: a royal coronation, the reopening of the Van Gogh Museum and the Rijksmuseum, the 400th anniversary of the citys emblematic canals. So its not surprising that a delicious development has gotten a bit lost in the shuffle: the opening of a serious and strikingly original restaurant. The curiously named &Samhoud Places made its debut last August in the modern and redeveloping Oosterdokseiland district, and was awarded two Michelin stars in November.

title: Veterans Bare Their Souls in Literary Events
description: Veterans live in the world in between. Never fully civilians culturally, no longer service members by profession, we do our best to find a balance, to create comfortable zones.

title: From Outsiders to Innkeepers in Chinas Sleepy Countryside
description: XIZHOU, China  Brian Linden welcomed the guests to his boutique hotel in one of its courtyards at the end of a cobblestone alley here, surrounded by old stone walls and polished wood balconies.

title: Tracks New Power Couple Prove It With Medals
description: MOSCOW  One month after their marriage, Ashton Eaton and Brianne Theisen-Eaton have two shiny new wedding presents.

description: Chuck Close is honored by Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Icahn Says He Has Large Stake in Apple
description: For an old-school investor, Carl C. Icahn has quickly become a force in technology stocks.

title: How to Charm: Remember Their Names
description: Along with Oliver Sacks, Jane Goodall and Brad Pitt, Chuck Close has prosopagnosia, which is commonly known as face blindness.

title: New Poll Suggests That de Blasio Is Now First Among Voters
description: In a jolt to the Democratic campaign for mayor, a new poll suggests that Bill de Blasio, the most liberal of the leading candidates, has vaulted into first place among likely voters.

title: U.S. Faces Obstacles in Bid to Arrest 2 in Big Trading Loss at JPMorgan
description: Federal investigators, seeking to bring criminal charges against two former JPMorgan Chase employees at the center of the banks multibillion-dollar trading loss in London last year, are facing logistical hurdles in planning arrests.

title: Family Transcends a Wall Between East and West
description: Suffused with the odors of coal fire and hot bockwurst; resonant with the clanks of Lada and Trabant automobiles; replete with references to Trotsky, Gorbachev, Erich Honecker, Sputnik and the gulag, Eugen Ruges In Times of Fading Light might sound like an edifying but ultimately dour Eastern Bloc affair. Yet one of the most remarkable things about this multigenerational saga of an East German family before and after the demise of Communism is how contemporary and, well, Western it seems.

title: Officers Are Wistful as Crown Vic, Long a Fleet Staple, Nears Retirement
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The greatest muscle car that ever wore a uniform is now racing toward retirement. After more than a decade as the most widely used law enforcement vehicle in the nation, the Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptor  the Crown Vic, as it has become known  went out of production in 2011.

title: Lawyers Hint at Possible Recovery of Stolen Art
description: BRUSSELS  Paintings worth tens of millions of dollars that were stolen last October from an art museum in the Netherlands have not been burned, and a Romanian gang behind the theft wants to cut an unspecified deal with the authorities so the artwork can be returned, lawyers for the defendants said on Tuesday as they went on trial in Romania.

title: Farmer Chic in Farm Country
description: New restaurants are bringing urban chefs ideas of farm-to-table back to the land.

title: An Upriver Current
description: HUDSON, N.Y.  In 2011, the New York City restaurateurs Zak Pelaccio and Mark Firth bumped into each other at a friends house near here, two hours north and a world away from the city.

title: One-Upmanship Continues After Publicis-Omnicom Deal
description: TOKYO  For years, the two highest-profile chief executives in the advertising business  Sir Martin Sorrell of WPP in London and Maurice Lvy of Publicis Groupe in Paris  had engaged in one-upmanship across the English Channel as they jousted for industry dominance.

title: Beijing Orders Demolition of Rooftop Art
description: BEIJING  In a city brimming with look-at-me architecture, the sprawling addition that Zhang Biqing, a health care magnate, built atop his 26th-floor apartment is a showstopper.

title: Order That Police Wear Cameras Stirs Unexpected Reactions
description: In more than a decade in office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has often championed the use of cutting-edge technology to help solve age-old problems in New York.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Bahrain, Egypt, Afghanistan and South Korea.

title: Living South of West Fourth Street
description: By turns raffish and intimate, boisterous and quaint.

title: South of West Fourth Street: Tracking the Ghosts of Bohemia
description: By turns raffish and intimate, boisterous and quaint, Greenwich Village below Washington Square Park and West Fourth Street has such a distinct local feel that it might best be described with one self-referential word: Villagey.

title: A Thriving Financial Product, Despite a Record of Failure
description: On Wall Street, strange financial products sometimes exist not because they are good for investors or companies, but because they offer their promoters a way to profit.

title: Stringer and Spitzer Slug it Out
description: Eliot Spitzer and Scott Stringer battled through their second New York City comptroller debate on Monday evening. It was an ugly, uninspiring event.

title: An Irish Pubs Toast to Women
description: Danny McDonald, an owner of several New York bars, including Swift Hibernian Lounge and Ulysses, had been nursing the idea of opening a place that honored the more feminine side of the Irish pub for years. But when he thought of his partners (Peter Poulakakos, Paul Lamas and Michael Jewell), he realized something was missing: women.

title: As Marchs 50th Anniversary Nears, King Memorial Repairs May Be Delayed
description: WASHINGTON  A contractor repairing the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial was not insured to use the sculptors preferred method for part of the work, putting in doubt whether the repairs will be finished before the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

title: Counselor and Ex-Con, Adjusting to New Worlds
description: In Chad Hartigans resolutely low-key film, the Martin of the title, a fresh transplant from the East, is starting over as an outreach counselor at a Reno, Nev., penitentiary after a crisis of belief. He meets Travis, who is newly sprung after years in prison, and takes him under his wing. The slightly bewildered new ex-con sees freedom stretched out before him and immediately worries that hell blow his chances.

title: Gift Bolsters Denver Museums Collection of Western American Art
description: The Denver Art Museum, which has been steadily establishing itself as a center for Western American art for more than a decade, announced that it would receive the bulk of one of the most important private collections of 19th- and 20th-century Western art in private hands.

title: New York and U.S. Open Investigations Into Bitcoins
description: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | State and federal officials are starting broad investigations into shortcomings in the oversight of upstart virtual currencies like bitcoin.

title: Hospital Reverses Decision and Adds Teenager to Heart Transplant List
description: Last Updated | 9:21 p.m. An Atlanta childrens hospital reversed course on Tuesday and decided to list a 15-year-old boy for a heart transplant, only days after refusing to do so because of concerns that he would not follow medical advice, including taking medication, after surgery.

title: AOL Chief Apologizes Over Firing of Worker
description: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, issued an unusual apology on Tuesday to his entire staff for the public manner in which he fired an employee during an internal conference call last Friday.

title: Mapping the Brain Circuitry That Spots Movement, in Flies
description: Building on decades of prior research, scientists have mapped the precise circuit in the fruit fly brain that enables the tiny gnat to detect movement in its visual field  an impulse essential to its skill at avoiding swatting hands and other existential threats.

title: As She Tends, a Wife Starts to Find Herself
description: Life and death circle each other restlessly and then furiously in the Afghan-set movie The Patience Stone. Life takes the form of an unnamed beautiful young woman (the fine Iranian actress Golshifteh Farahani) who, when the story opens, is caring for her wounded, much older husband, also unnamed (Hamidrez Javdan), an immobilized Mujahedeen fighter with a bullet in his neck and the slender tube of a medical drip bag snaked into his mouth. Theyre simply two people inside an austere room. Yet, as bombs shake the walls and she places a bloodied compress on his head, they are quickly transformed into a time-tested, outwardly reassuring vision of a woman heroically ministering to a wounded, possibly dying man.

title: Front Burner: Nourish in Greenwich Village, Tomato Soup, Potato Chips and More
description: To Shop: Wholesome, Yes, but Tasty, Too

description: As surprised researchers have discovered, some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.
