title: Underground Idol
description: The true believers come out at night. They meet in condemned buildings marked by the symbol of a stylized eye to watch a night film  one of the psychologically punishing horror pictures of Stanislas Cordova, a master filmmaker who has shunned publicity with a zeal that makes Thomas Pynchon look like a shameless attention hog. Adding to the mystique is a sense that Cordova might have retreated because he has something unsavory to hide. Bad things happen to those who try to pick his locked closet for a look at the skeletons. Consider the star reporter Scott McGrath, who plunged into disgrace after a preliminary investigation into Cordovas secrets blew up in his face. McGrath has a score to settle, so when Cordovas achingly gifted daughter turns up dead in a Manhattan ruin, its Take 2 for the unemployed journalist. Nor is McGrath the only one who wants to know whats been going on behind the camera; in short order hes joined by a shabby but smoldering drug dealer named Hopper and a breathless ingnue, Nora Halliday. Together, the three make an adorably awkward family of misfits, who will be even more appealing should George Clooney, Ryan Gosling and Alison Brie be cast for the movie adaptation.

title: Digging Up Family Roots in Sicily
description: As a writer Ive always tended to seek out origins. My first book, about the search for the historical Jesus, was an attempt to get at the real story behind my Catholic upbringing. After living in Manhattan for several years, I wrote The Island at the Center of the World, a book about the Dutch settlement of New Amsterdam, the seed from which New York City grew.

title: On Foreign Shores
description: A number of remarkable short novels have emerged in the recent past: Tinkers, by Paul Harding; Train Dreams, by Denis Johnson; The Sojourn, by Andrew Krivak; The Buddha in the Attic, by Julie Otsuka. Far from slight, they all deal with large themes and subjects that could easily fill 500-page books, yet have been compressed into poemlike works. Page count is one of the most prosaic ways to categorize a book, but it points to the fact that one approaches these works differently  the experience more akin to reading poetry or short fiction, where what is left out is at least as important as what remains. With Snow Hunters, Paul Yoon proves himself well suited to the short form.

title: Service Jobs
description: In his beguiling 2009 memoir, When Skateboards Will Be Free, Sad Sayrafiezadeh recounted being raised by devout members of the Socialist Workers Party. His Jewish mother did the actual raising; his Iranian-born father abandoned the family for the cause. Both believed a workers revolution was imminent. It was a childhood, Sayrafiezadeh observed, devoted to a peculiar set of rules that were both ethically impeccable and entirely at odds with the dominant culture.

title: In Istanbul, Seeing Art Through Two Lenses
description: The art scene in Istanbul has gradually shifted from a heavily traditional one that celebrates the citys history to a contemporary one that prizes its upstarts. Less than a decade ago, the citys Museum of Modern Art was inaugurated. Last year the contemporary art space SALT opened. This year a number of Istanbul galleries will be on hand at Londons Frieze (as they were at the Randalls Island New York version and at Art Basel in Basel and Hong Kong).

title: Political Journalism Chronicle
description: THE CENTER HOLDS  Obama and His Enemies  By Jonathan Alter  Simon & Schuster, $30.

title: Fruit of Knowledge
description: Rebecca Solnits latest book, a series of essays loosely about storytelling, has a table of contents that sits on the page like a mountain tipped on its side. The essays titles mirror or refract one another, imparting symmetry. The summit, a chapter titled Knot, evokes another of the books metaphors, the bringing together of narrative threads. The tipped mountain shape resembles the traditional rise and fall of story structure. But this isnt the only visual conceit. Imagine all the sentences in this book as a single thread around the spool that is a book, Solnit writes. You neednt imagine it, though: One unspooled essay runs like a news ticker along the base of every page.

title: Witness to War
description: Long before I could locate the peninsula of Gallipoli on a map, as a Briton I knew it as a place where we did something awful to the Australians. Down Under they have a clearer memory. Having fought bravely and loyally for king and empire in two world wars, they have never shaken the belief that they were used as cannon fodder when Britain (and France) launched a disastrous attack on this strategic outpost of the Ottoman Empire in 1915.

title: King of the Jean Pool
description: Thirty-five years ago, Renzo Rosso co-founded Diesel, the company that almost single-handedly incited the premium denim craze. Now 57 and worth an estimated $3 billion, the farmers son who created his first pair of jeans on his mothers sewing machine has expanded his empire to include fashion brands like Maison Martin Margiela, Marni and Viktor & Rolf, all under the umbrella of his parent company OTB (short for his personal motto, Only the Brave). Despite these successes, Rossos life is in many ways very small. Case in point: the Italian businessman owns only one home, an 18th-century Palladian villa just an hour drive from his hometown of Brugine. Of course when he wants to go further, theres always the private jet.

title: Movie Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'
description: A. O. Scotts review of Lee Daniels The Butler.

title: Paperback Row
description: IRON CURTAIN: The Crushing of Eastern Europe, 1944-1956,  by Anne Applebaum. (Anchor, $17.95.) In her Pulitzer Prize-winning Gulag (2003), Applebaum documented the horror of Stalins Soviet terror machine. Now this remarkable sequel, drawn from newly opened archives and survivor interviews, shows how the Soviet Union imposed its totalitarian will upon Eastern European nations ravaged by World War II.

title: Movie Review: 'Kick-Ass 2'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Kick-Ass 2."

title: Deep Cuts at Patch, AOLs Local News Sites
description: AOL on Friday moved to cut losses at Patch, its struggling local news service, eliminating as many as 500 positions and closing or consolidating many of its sites across the country.

title: In Gods Name, or Baby Messiah, Competing Claims of Religious Freedom
description: Last week, when a Tennessee judge forcibly changed an infants name from Messiah to Martin, it was hard to decide which was more noteworthy, the parents grandiosity in naming their child for the one they consider their Savior or the judges religious zealotry in prohibiting the name.

title: Movie Review: 'Jobs'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Jobs.

title: Across the Cumberlands
description: On Aug. 16, 1863, Henry Campbell recorded in his diary how his unit, the 18th Indiana Battery, had just climbed the front range of the Cumberland Mountains, which separate the fertile Cumberland Basin of middle Tennessee from the eastern part of the state. A rainstorm impeded their ascent, making the road exceedingly steep, slippery, and winding. As they labored upward, the soldiers were enveloped by a dense fog. Suddenly, as they approached the top of the mountain, they found themselves entirely above the clouds, looking down, Campbell wrote, on one of the grandest sights I ever witnessed. Bright sunlight poured through the rain, creating hundreds of rain bows on the sides of the mountains beneath us. The 18-year-old Hoosier struggled to convey in words a sublime spectacle that no pen could describe.

title: Bombing in Beirut
description: Video shows the aftermath of a car bomb that tore through a southern suburb of Beirut on Thursday, killing at least 18 people and wounding nearly 300.

title: Image of the Day: August 16
Calendar: Coming Events in Trinidad and Tobago; Lucas, Ohio; Charlottesville, Va.
description: The Biswas House,Trinidad and TobagoThe childhood home of V. S. Naipaul, above, the Nobel Prize-winning author, which is at the center of one of his best-known novels, A House for Mr. Biswas, has been converted into a literary museum that will open in October. Some sections of the property, in Trinidad and Tobago in the Port of Spain suburb of St. James, resemble how it would have looked in the late 1940s, when it was acquired by the Naipaul family. Many original furnishings and items, some described in the 1961 novel, will be on display.

title: Fund Set Up for UBS Bailout Repays Loan
description: LONDON  The Swiss National Bank said Friday that a fund set up as part of UBSs bailout five years ago had fully repaid a loan it received as part the rescue.

title: Good Deeds Gone Bad
description: ON your way to work today you may have paused to let another car merge into your lane. Or you stopped to give a dollar to a subway artist. A minute later, another chance to do the same may have appeared. Did your first act make the second more tempting? Or did you decide you had done your good deed for the day?

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Nightmare Dream
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Witness Accounts of Sectarian Attacks Across Egypt
description: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick in Cairo reported, supporters of the ousted Islamist president, Mohamed Morsi, have lashed out across Egypt since two pro-Morsi sit-ins were violently dispersed by the armed forces, blocking bridges and highways, storming government buildings and attacking churches of the countrys Christian minority.

title: Lee Miller: Light on Her Fashion
description: Id rather take a picture than be one, Lee Miller remarked to a New York newspaperman in October 1932, as she stepped off a ship from Europe and was recognized among the cargo of celebrities on board.

title: Learn Campus, Meet Dorm Neighbors, Get Ready to Vote
description: In the back-to-school rush of choosing courses and decorating dorm rooms, college students might be tempted to tune out the citys coming elections.

title: A Pact to Make the Heart Grow Fonder?
description: When Andrew and I left our Vermont college town, we thought we were so incredibly in love, we tried an experiment. He flew home to Canada to work, I drove to San Francisco, and we agreed not to have sex for almost a year. Not with each other during visits. Not with anyone.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 16
description: Subjects include graffiti in Greenpoint, Brooklyn; swimming lessons in Far Rockaway, Queens; and a protest march on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Roosevelt Island Tramway, 12:05 P.M.
The Eagles' Elephant in the Room
description: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.

title: Surfs Up
description: The amount of Internet traffic zooms ever upward, but economic indicators have risen at a vastly slower pace.

title: Voter Fraud! Wait, No.
description: Weve written before on allegations of voter fraud that, upon close or even cursory examination, turn out not to hold water. Like when South Carolinas Republican Attorney General, Alan Wilson, claimed 900 dead people had voted in recent elections (spoiler alert: there were no zombies, but click the link for the whole story).

title: A Mayor Who Puts Wall Street First
description: On March 15 of last year, at a moment when many New Yorkers found themselves increasingly disturbed by revelations that the Police Department had conducted constitutionally suspect surveillance of Muslim communities, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made an unplanned visit to the offices of Goldman Sachs.

title: Still Tingling Spines, 50 Years Later
description: Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys estimates that hes heard Be My Baby, by the Ronettes, more than 1,000 times. The very first listen, 50 years ago this month, still haunts him.

title: American Hurdler Puts Her Potential on the Starting Line
description: MOSCOW  A young woman who has handled the day-in-day-out pandemonium of having six younger brothers is not likely to panic at the prospect of facing seven other hurdlers.

title: Wait Ends for a Yiddish Version of Godot
description: Waiting for Godot, Samuel Becketts signature, absurdist play, has a new twist: the New Yiddish Rep and the Castillo Theater are presenting what they bill as the first-ever production in Yiddish. The play, to run Sept. 20 to Oct. 13 at the Castillo Theater, presents the characters as Holocaust survivors. The boy who is Godots messenger is played by a young African-American actor.

title: Video: The Eagles Elephant in the Room
description: Eagles players should take a stand against using the kind of language that Riley Cooper used that caused a recent controversy regarding race.

title: The Fig Now Yields Its Charms
description: Theres a magnificent century-old fig tree on the farm my friend Bob Cannard has near Sonoma, Calif. It keeps giving fruit year after year. Its a mammoth of a tree, with thick, gnarled, low branches that span outward, then twist to form a natural gazebo 20 feet in diameter. You dont climb up the tree so much as step into it to find a place to perch.

title: Judges Ruling Removes Hurdles to a Dell Takeover Bid
description: Updated, 6:03 p.m. | A Delaware judge on Friday denied a bid by Carl C. Icahn to derail a vote on a nearly $25 billion takeover bid for Dell Inc., dealing a blow to his fight against the buyout offer.

title: Earl Sweatshirt and ASAP Ferg Step Up
description: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss new records by two hip-hop lieutenants who are making a move.

title: A Gumdrop Shape, Good and Plenty
description: Ask 5-year-olds to draw you a tree and they will unwittingly sketch you a pin oak.

title: Before Saying I Do, Define Just What You Mean
description: Writing your own vows, Lois Kellerman says, is like making homemade cookies.

title: Popcast: Earl Sweatshirt and ASAP Ferg Step Up
description: This week: two hip-hop lieutenants make a move.

title: Every Cat Has Its Day: Hermitage Museums Mouse Catchers Are Immortalized in Portraits
description: MOSCOW  While it might seem risky to keep dozens of cats near some of the worlds most precious pieces of art, cats are regarded as treasured guardians of the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, patrolling the basement for mice and rats and treated like furry royalty by doting staff members.

title: Hotel Drinking Gets Specialized
description: Bartenders are a mainstay at most upscale hotels, but some properties today have staff members who are specialists in just one type of alcohol.

title: Theyve Come Back for One Last Pint
description: The Worlds End, a new comedy directed by Edgar Wright and written by Mr. Wright and Simon Pegg, is a reunion movie in the most literal sense: it tells the story of a burned-out and reckless middle-aged man (Mr. Pegg) who reunites a gang of reluctant childhood friends (Nick Frost, Martin Freeman, Paddy Considine and Eddie Marsan) to complete the hometown pub crawl they couldnt quite finish in their youth  only to discover some very sinister developments are afoot in their former stamping grounds.

title: Stagflation, Stagnation, and Intellectual Asymmetry
description: Brad DeLong weighs in on the Friedman legacy, and notes that there have been two big successful sort of meta-predictions in macroeconomics over the past half-century. In the late 60s, Friedman and Phelps warned of the risk of stagflation, and were vindicated in the 1970s. In the late 1990s, some economists warned of the risk of Depression-type liquidity traps, and were vindicated in the Naughties. The first success led to Friedmams promotion to demigod status; the second success has not produced any comparable elevation.

title: Despite Fears, King Memorial Is Ready for Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON  Repairs to the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial have been completed, erasing doubts about whether the site would be ready for the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington and Dr. Kings I Have a Dream speech on Aug. 28.

title: What Happens When the N.S.A. Gets Sloppy
description: All institutions make mistakes, but when an organization as vast and unsupervised as the National Security Agency gets sloppy, the mistakes quickly amount to a serious abuse of government authority. Barton Gellmans article today in the Washington Post was remarkable not just because it showed widespread incompetence by the agency, but because it showed the real dangers in allowing the N.S.A. to exercise overly broad power with almost no oversight.

title: A Kung Fu That Maims and Romances
description: Wong Kar-wai was recounting his research for The Grandmaster, the tale of the kung fu innovator who trained Bruce Lee. As he described crisscrossing the mainland to talk to aging martial artists, he could have been setting the scene for a movie.

title: Closing the Proficiency Gap in New York Schools
description: As befits a tech mogul, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been a resolute supporter of digital initiatives in New York City, from hiring the citys first chief digital officer, Rachel Sterne Haot, to strong patronage of the thriving Silicon Alley start-up community.

title: Schroedingers Price Index
description: Apparently Republicans are trying, once again, to extract chain-linking of Social Security benefits as the price of some kind of deal. I have no idea whether this will go anywhere; my guess, or maybe just my hope, is that Obama the Grand Bargainer has vanished from the scene.

title: The Gun Report: August 16, 2013
description: The Gun Report began seven months ago, after I wrote a column that simply grabbed examples of gun violence from the weeks news. Since then, we have tried to document the awful range and scope of daily gun violence, from accidents involving small children who get their hands on guns, to drive-by shootings, to killings that transpire in a flash of anger. Now, however, the Gun Report is going to take a short break. We will be back after Labor Day.

title: Artists on Artists | Chris Johanson on the Apocalyptic Machines of Kal Spelletich
description: After a two-year hiatus, the skateboarder-turned-art Chris Johanson is back in a major way, with his first comprehensive museum solo show, Within the River of Time Is My Mind, at the Museum of Contemporary Art Los Angeles (through Oct. 13) and a self-titled new monograph from Phaidon.

title: A Prayer Before the Complaints Roll In
description: Sherone Lewis works for the City of New York and loves her job  a common enough sentiment, you might say, but consider this: For the last 11 years, Ms. Lewis, 46, has worked for the citys 311 line, managing the complaints and dissatisfactions of a populace that approaches them as Olympic events. Ms. Lewis started as a call center representative, or C.C.R., in December 2002, just as the Bloomberg administration was consolidating the citys help lines into 311, and is now a call center manager. Sundays often find her working the evening shift downtown, commuting from her apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, which she shares with her 25-year-old daughter.

title: Can a Child Be Too Young for Shared Custody?
description: A reader finds herself abruptly getting divorced, with two small children: 15 months and 5 years old. The circumstances of the divorce arent happy ones, and she is angry and upset, but writes that she is trying to protect the relationship my children have with their father while still providing them with the necessary stability for them to thrive.

title: Boop-Boop-a-Doo on Blu-ray
description: Betty Boop began her life as a floppy-eared dog and ended it as a happy homemaker dressed in an apron. But at her peak  roughly from 1931 to 1934  she was a major figure in American movies, despite being, as her theme song put it, made of pen and ink.

title: Gabriel Kreuther Will Leave the Modern
description: Gabriel Kreuther is stepping down as executive chef at the Modern, where he has been since 2004. Its the dream of most of the chefs to open their own place someday and for me the moment is now, he said. He probably will not leave before the end of the year, he said. In announcing the news, Union Square Hospitality Group, which runs the high-end restaurant at the Museum of Modern Art along with its cafe and private dining room, said it wished him the best and was beginning a search for out next executive chef.

title: Bank of America May Merge Merrill Lynch With Parent
description: Bank of America is still trying to get its arms around the big acquisitions it did amid the financial crisis.

title: A Love Embraced, Some 35 Years Later
description: Anyone who has ever had one knows there is nothing quite like a perfect summer beach romance in the spring of life. But, like a great bottle of wine, once it is done it is done, its pleasures left only to memory.

title: Duet for Composition and Software
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  On a recent Tuesday afternoon, Tod Machover, a professor of music and media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technologys Media Lab and head of the Opera of the Future group there, assembled his students in his glass-walled lab. The space was cluttered with computers, triangular-headed robots, colorful fabric-covered childrens toys and digital control tables. A large metal chandelier hung suspended from the ceiling, its swooping curves and fanned-out spokes giving it the look of a mathematically minded jellyfish.

title: No Rest in Peace for the Wicked
description: America loves a serial killer, the detective Jane Rizzoli (Angie Harmon) says in Tuesdays episode of Rizzoli & Isles, at 9 p.m. on TNT. So why not bring one back from the dead? The episode, No One Mourns the Wicked, gives fans of this reliable series another look at Charles Hoyt, one of the most memorable recurring characters the show has had since its debut in 2010. Hoyt was Rizzolis archnemesis until he was killed off in Season 2. Or was he?

title: Release the Hounds of Memory
description: This is not a comparison that any playwright wants to have to live up to, but Anne Washburn has always struck me as the American author most like Caryl Churchill. Like that justly hailed British playwright, Ms. Washburn (The Internationalist) writes formally daring, ominous and prickly dramas that urgently address topical issues while creating worlds that seem very foreign. In her new work, Mr. Burns, a Post-Electric Play, which drew raves in its run in Washington, she tackles global disaster, adaptation and the peculiar power of stories passed down over generations.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Viand Cafe
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has made Viand, just around the corner from his townhouse, a place for power breakfasts.

title: Spirit of Parker, Freely Inhaled
description: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival, now in its 21st year, doesnt always genuflect directly to its namesake, the alto saxophonist and bebop paragon commonly known as Bird. But this year the lineage is clear. Two anchors of the lineup are Jimmy Heath, who earned the sobriquet Little Bird early in his career, and Lee Konitz, who became known in the same era for his stubborn independence from the Parker style. Mr. Heath, 86, will lead his big band in the premiere of a suite called Bird Is the Word on Friday night; Mr. Konitz, 85, will work with a quartet on Sunday afternoon.

title: M.I.T.s Opera of the Future
description: The professor Tod Machover and his students work on building better sounds.

title: In the Jungle, Eccentric at Work
description: The title of the Film Society of Lincoln Centers Werner Herzog series, Parables of Folly and Madness, perfectly describes Fitzcarraldo (1982), a work of many-splendored obsession. Fitzcarraldo  a conquistador of the useless  has a quixotic dream: to build an opera house in the middle of the Peruvian jungle.

title: Rodriguez Denies Implicating Others
description: BOSTON  Alex Rodriguez arrived at Fenway Park on Friday to begin a three-game series against the Red Sox, bracing for an extended chorus of derision from Red Sox fans getting their first crack at him since baseball suspended him for 211 games. The punishment came after he was linked to a South Florida clinic that supplied players with performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Fresh Pieces, Crisp Players
description: Among the many changes that the Mostly Mozart Festival has instituted in recent years to shore up intrigue and innovation, few have stood out as sharply as this seasons residency by the International Contemporary Ensemble. A reliably persuasive new-music group, the ensemble opens the week with fresh pieces by Felipe Lara and Tyshawn Sorey on Sunday, and by Maria Stankova and Nathan Davis on Monday.On Tuesday, the ensemble celebrates the 80thbirthday of the maverick composer Pauline Oliveros, collaborating with her in a range of chamber works. A final offeringon Thursdaypairs a premiere by George Lewis with Beethovens Septet in E flat.

title: A Photographers Tender Ardor
description: In 1863, when Julia Margaret Cameron was 48, her daughter and son-in-law gave her a camera for Christmas. The British-born Cameron was a mother of six and religious. She was also a friend of many Victorian artists, poets and thinkers, many of whom she photographed in a dreamy, soft-focused manner that was often condemned by her contemporaries for its lack of craftsmanship. From the first moment I handled my lens with a tender ardor, she wrote, and it has become to me as a living thing, with voice and memory and creative vigor.

title: A Classic, Outrageous Still
description: This year marks a century of ominous springtime shudders. Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rite of Spring), Stravinskys disquieting ballet about an ancient tribes spring sacrifice of a young woman to appease the gods, had its premiere in 1913. Many choreographers have tackled this score, among them Martha Graham, whose 1984 version is being revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company.

title: Fords Big Payout on the C-Max Hybrid
description: Dominic Franchella, owner of Stamford Ford Lincoln in Connecticut, has some satisfied C-Max hybrid customers. We havent had one customer complain to us about not getting the mileage, he said in a telephone interview.

title: Costly Rents Push Brooklynites to Queens
description: It was only a matter of time, after Bushwick was given a featured role in the HBO show Girls, that the young creative types who established this gritty Brooklyn neighborhood as an artists enclave began to be priced out.

title: A Divide Between Two Neighborhoods
description: Bushwick and Ridgewood are close on the map, but monthly rents are a different story.

title: Hard-Swinging Sounds, With the Help of Friends
description: Warren Wolf WOLFGANG

title: No Reservations at the Mayors Table
description: Angel Pelengaris led the way to Table 14, saying it was the booth to sit in if you want to be mayor for five minutes.

title: One Dip Into a 401(k) Often Leads to Another
description: Some people cant seem to stop at just one.

title: Brazilian Fund, Under Fire, Has a Defender
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  GP Investments, one of Latin Americas largest private equity funds, has come under fire over its executives compensation while its stock price languishes, but the fund is receiving some support from Wall Street.

title: Hot Days, Cold Noodles
description: For a light but satisfying meal during the last days of summer, consider cold Asian noodles, suggests Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health. She writes:

title: Fantasy Football: Walking Through a 12-Team Draft
description: The following 12 team, 15 round draft primer is not an all-inclusive draft guide. Rather, it offers a couple of different approaches depending on where you are drafting from. It also contains a summary of opinions I have come to form over the years, and over the course of a very active mock draft season. The rules and the level of competitiveness will vary greatly from one persons fantasy league to the next, and ultimately you will need to form your own draft day game plan as they relate to these deciding factors.

title: The Petermann Glacier
description: Late July and early August, 2012: NASA satellites observed a giant chunk of Greenlands Petermann Glacier gradually break off and then drift towards the open sea.

title: Smog Over China
description: Oct. 20, 2012: A dense smog covered most of China.

title: Fires in Sumatra
description: June 2013: Dense clouds of smoke from fires set on the Indonesian island of Sumatra choked neighboring Singapore.

title: Sandstorm Over the Mediterranean
description: May 29, 2013: Following the course of an immense sandstorm across the Sahara Desert in a northerly direction over the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Blackberry Crumb Muffins
description: When there are are so many fresh summer berries available, why not fold some into your muffin batter?

title: Muffins With Blackberries and a Buttery Crumb Topping
description: There are muffins that aspire to be healthful, filled with the likes of whole grains, wheat germ and fruit pure. Then there are rich, chocolate chip-laden muffins that are more like cupcakes in disguise.

title: The Rupees Decline
description: The economies of many emerging markets are struggling, as Nathaniel Popper pointed out in The Times earlier this week. In China, for example, credit has dried up so much that all but one of the car dealers in the once booming city of Shenmu in the northwest have failed. Perhaps the country the world should be most worried about is India. The countrys currency, the rupee, fell sharply against the dollar on Friday, briefly passing 62 to the dollar; it was at 55 to the dollar as recently as May. Inflation remains high even as growth is slowing.

title: Week in Review: Failed Trades in London Add to Inquiry in New York
description: Criminal cases against two former JPMorgan Chase traders who worked in an office building near the Thames River spotlighted federal authorities inquiry of bank executives on Park Avenue.

title: Allyson Felix Tears Hamstring in 200 Meters
description: MOSCOW  On one side of the track in Luzhniki Stadium, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce was celebrating her first major 200-meter victory with the Jamaican flag in hand and the Bob Marley song Three Little Birds playing over the loudspeakers.

title: Killing of Strikers Alters South Africa Politics
description: MARIKANA, South Africa  Had the memorial held on an outcropping of rock here on Friday taken place two decades ago, the African National Congress almost certainly would have led it.

title: Near Seat of Government, Seats of Power
description: At City Hall, the power-lunch spot that opened near you-know-where in the late Giuliani years, sometimes the challenge is keeping the planets out of one anothers orbits, said Henry Meer, the chef and owner. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg favors Table 41, a booth along the western wall  as do Raymond W. Kelly, the police commissioner, and Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney. Representative Gregory W. Meeks typically takes Table 21, and the mayoral candidate Joseph J. Lhotas regular spot is Table 23. Judges, lobbyists and officials have their turf. Though Mr. Meer tries to keep regulars at their regular tables, sometimes the powers lunch needs overlap. In that case, I usually give the table to whoever called first, Mr. Meer said.

title: Libertarian Populism and Its Critics
description: Let me assume, one more time, the mantle of libertarian populisms friendliest critic, and say something about the ongoing arguments that the concept has inspired. (The latest round-up includes Ben Domenech vs. Ezra Klein, Conn Carrollvs. Brian Beutler, Jonathan Chait vs. Will Wilkinson  and I could easily go on.) In particular, Id like to address what seems like the core critique of the lib-pop idea, common to its left-wing, centrist and conservative critics alike, which is that it might call itself populist but its too, well, libertarian to ever be truly popular.

title: G.M. Recalls 293,000 Chevrolet Cruze Models Over Braking Problem
description: Almost 293,000 Chevrolet Cruzes from the2011-12 model years will be recalled for a braking problem, General Motors has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. In a news release Friday, the automaker said it was aware of 27 low-speed crashes related to the problem, but it was not aware of any related injuries.

title: The Impossible Mayor of the Possible
description: The question was a trap, put to a novice politician who had only just been elected mayor and had no government experience whatsoever.

title: Israel Keeps a Wary Eye on Turmoil in Egypt
description: JERUSALEM  Before the violence this week in Cairo, the Israeli government was quietly pleased with the overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi and the crackdown on the Muslim Brotherhood, which has always been hostile to Israel. But now the mass killings have left Israel in the uncomfortable position of being a spectator to the crisis unfolding in Egypt, though one with a huge stake in the outcome.

title: Feeling For | Postcards With a Graphic Pop
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Trying to Make Google Glass Fashionable
description: In the 2006 movie The Devil Wears Prada, with a high-end fashion magazines office as its backdrop, theres a memorable scene when the characterMiranda Priestly, played byMeryl Streep, is picking between two belts for a photo shoot that look almost identical. As she surveys them in her hand, her assistant,Andy Sachs, played byAnne Hathaway, starts to laugh quietly.

title: Ivete Sangalo, a Brazilian Belter, Extends Her Reach
description: If Ivete Sangalo were an American singer, rather than the most popular female vocalist in Brazil, she would undoubtedly be described as a belter. Onstage, she is bold, brassy and boisterous, part of a lineage that includes Tina Turner, Janis Joplin and Bette Midler, and on her records she has often favored songs that allow her to emote loudly and dramatically.

title: A Marriage of Economy and Serenity
description: TESTED 2013 Lincoln MKZ Hybrid

title: Chevrolets Cheap Minicar, the Spark, Is a Surprisingly Strong Seller
description: The tiny Chevrolet Spark from General Motors is about as bare bones as cars come these days, with no floor mats and one of the smallest engines of any car. But to the surprise of even G.M. itself, which has traditionally struggled to sell small cars, the Spark has become an unlikely hit as many American buyers warm to a car that is cheap to buy and to operate.

title: Plugging an Outbreak of Leaks
description: Audis with coolant drips and Nissans that shudder at moderate speeds are among the mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Move Over, CB Radio: Trucker Apps Are Helping to Haul the Load
description: STRASBURG, VA.  If youre old enough to remember 1970s trucker films like Smokey and the Bandit, Convoy and White Line Fever, you may think of truck drivers as free-spirited individuals tethered to the world by nothing more than citizens band airwaves. That depiction was a stretch even then, but todays truckers are often as Web-connected as the technophiles occupying the local Starbucks. Even on the loneliest stretches of the Interstates, smartphones and tablet apps provide diversions and lend a helping hand.

title: She Brings Out His Soft Side, but Its Bad for Business
description: In Once Upon a Time in Mumbai Dobaara, Shoaib (an effective Akshay Kumar) is a gangster to his core: he looks the part  sunglasses, slicked-back hair, sleek suits  and has a firm grip on Mumbais underworld. The characters rise was told in the action-packed 2010 movie Once Upon a Time in Mumbai, but for this sequel, Milan Luthria, who directed both, wanted to show that his villain has a heart.

title: The Bane of Four Mayors
description: Just a few more months with the devil, Rafael Martnez Alequin announced, standing in the middle of City Halls Blue Room, which was packed with journalists on Monday waiting for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to arrive.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

description: Of all the new careers one might expect for a 55-year-old former publishing executive, part-time record producer is not the most likely.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Fox Decides Not to Produce Hillary Clinton Mini-Series
description: An outlet of Fox Entertainment said on Friday that it would not be involved with the hotly debated Hillary Rodham Clinton mini-series on NBC, after all.

title: A Big, Blingy Indian Love Song for a Brandy-Swigging Elephant
description: In Sundays magazine, I write about the lives of famous elephants in the Indian state of Kerala  animals who have their own fan clubs, appear in movies and get trucked around the state for half the year to appear as the main attraction at temple festivals. One of the foremost chroniclers of Keralas elephant craze is a filmmaker named Sreekumar Arookutty, who was the creator, director, writer and host of a popular local TV show called E4 Elephant. Earlier this year, Arookutty wrote the lyrics to a pop song, The Lord of Beauty, in tribute to a star elephant named Thiruvambadi Shivasundar. He is a jewel, the pearlstone of Kerala, the song goes. As beautiful as a poem carved in stone. Arookutty also directed the music video below, starring Shivasundar himself, which provides about as vivid a taste of Keralas elephant-fan culture as could be hoped for.

title: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Leaving Eden
description: A little plain and simple beauty to end the week:

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Lebanon, Syria and South Africa.

title: Veiled Group Shows Ease of Using Web for Attack Ads
description: The ad popped up on YouTube over a week ago, a slickly produced, sneering attack against Bill de Blasio, run by a mysterious group identified only by its account name, Citizen Truth.

title: Sergeant Who Confronted Fort Hood Gunman Faces Him in Court
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  The last time Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley faced Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, they stood about eight feet apart, and each of them was holding a gun. It was shortly after 1 p.m. on Nov. 5, 2009, outside the building on the Fort Hood Army base where Major Hasan had waged a brief but deadly shooting rampage with a laser-equipped semiautomatic pistol.

title: The Corrupt World of Then, So Similar to Now
description: Last Tango in Berlin, the title of Ute Lempers, dense, fiery new show at 54 Below, refers to the disappearance of European cabaret traditions under the relentless onslaught of pop. Berlin may be the cultural capital of Europe, observed Ms. Lemper, who was born in Germany in 1963, but today it is almost without any memory. Genres like the caustic, cynical cabaret of Germanys Weimar period and the more romantic French chanson are all but forgotten.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: A Review of Jobs and Marissa Mayer in Vogue
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Big Ticket | $12 Million for a Luxury Co-op at the Pierre Hotel
description: A luxury co-op with Central Park frontage at the Pierre Hotel, the 1930 white-glove landmark that underwent a $100 million renovation in 2005, sold for $12 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Winners of the Roth Open Swiss Teams
description: ATLANTA  One other major national championship was decided here on Sunday evening, the Roth Open Swiss Teams.

title: A Former Madoff Penthouse Goes Back on the Market
description: It would be criminal to tarnish an elegant 87-year-old New York City penthouse with guilt by association, unfair to imply that it is haunted by the ghosts of white-collar crooks or burdened by bad karma and negative vibes. But the classically proportioned seven-room duplex at 133 East 64th Street where the serial swindler Bernard L. Madoff once lived is poised to enter the marketplace yet again. He bought it for a song in 1984 compared with what his fellow financiers were spending on tonier Park and Fifth Avenues, and had lived there until 2009, when he traded his final weeks of high-end house arrest for a 150-year prison term in bucolic North Carolina.

title: Inside the Former Madoff Duplex
description: The three-bedroom four-and-a-half-bath penthouse is back on the market.

title: Squeezebox and Strings as Charmers, Coaxing New Magic From Beethoven
description: Beethoven is hardly lacking for attention. So, amid many fresh programming initiatives at this summers Mostly Mozart festival, its Celebrate Beethoven project stands out as a dull idea.

title: Plan to Ban Oil Drilling in Amazon Is Dropped
description: Six years ago, President Rafael Correa of Ecuador offered the world what he considered an enticing deal: donate $3.6 billion to a trust fund intended to protect nearly 4,000 square miles of the Amazon jungle and his country would refrain from oil drilling in the rain forest.

title: By Design | The Kitchen Apron Gets a Stylish Upgrade
description: If you ate only at the Los Angeles restaurants whose chefs sport Hedley & Bennett aprons, youd be eating at some of the finest places the city has to offer. Jon Shook, Vinny Dotolo and Ludo Lefebvre use them at Trois Mec, the toughest reservation in town. Michael Voltaggio places a new order every week for Ink. Nancy Silverton sells a version of the one she uses at Mozza. And Michael Cimarusti proudly sports them at Providence, where Ellen Bennett, the aprons creator, works two days a week. (I shucked 85 oysters yesterday! she says.)

title: Spider-Man Resumes Shows After Injury
description: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark is once again facing questions about safety.

title: Luke Bryan, the Leading Gentleman of Country
description: The most uncomfortable Luke Bryan sounds on Crash My Party, his fourth album, is at the beginning of the second song. Its called Beer in the Headlights, and its about a familiar kind of romantic infatuation. Mr. Bryan begins the ode by sketching out a magical rural night: Honeysuckle in the air/Breeze blowing through your hair.

title: A Rare Auction Consignment: A Reigning Pebble Beach Winner
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  A year ago, a one-of-a-kind 1928 Mercedes-Benz 680S Torpedo Roadster pulled up on the lawn at the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance to be crowned Best of Show. This week, its here again, although this time its headed for the auction block.

title: A Haven for Wit and Whimsy Dusts Off Its Welcome Mat
description: SHELBURNE, Vt.  Dont get the wrong idea when you encounter Manets Grand Canal, Venice (1875) at the inaugural exhibition of the new visitors center at the Shelburne Museum. Dont get the wrong idea, either, from the solemn name of the 18,000-square-foot building: the Pizzagalli Center for Art and Education. Despite signs of aesthetic ambition, increased professionalization and expanded educational goals, this quirky, astonishing institution is not jettisoning its distinctive oddities.

title: For the Met, Opera History Lives in a Newark Parking Lot
description: NEWARK  The costumes were all wrong for Andrea Chnier. At the center of the action were men in white protective suits, not tailcoats and breeches, and they were aiming high-pressure hoses at pieces of the set. Not one of them sang a note.

title: Invoking the Divine in Tiny Gestures
description: Every year, the Downtown Dance Festival devotes one of its open-air lunchtime performances solely to Indian dance. This, organized by the Indo-American Arts Council as part of its Erasing Borders festival, serves as a rich sampler of the various Indian dance forms and has become one of the highlights of New Yorks dance year.

title: Modern Mothers Turn to Scratch an Itch
description: On a rainy August night when it seemed that most people in Manhattan had fled town, Jes Wade, a fashion designer and married mother of two, was lying in a 97-degree salted bath called a Flotarium, at Aire Ancient Baths in TriBeCa. Eyes closed, hands splayed by her side, in a crocheted black bikini, she seemed impermeable to stress. This must be what it feels like to be in the womb, she said.

title: Judge Blocks State Voter ID Law
description: A state judge in Pennsylvania on Friday prohibited enforcement of a strongly contested law requiring voters to show state-approved identification.

title: As Berlusconis Party Supports Embattled Chief, Critics Retaliate
description: Posters in support of Silvio Berlusconi, the embattled former prime minister, are appearing on billboards and bus stops in major Italian cities and along highways. An aerial advertising blitz along Italys coastline was timed to coincide with Ferragosto, the sacrosanct mid-August holiday that sends Italians to the seaside.

title: Stacey Bendet Eisner: Suited for Friends, Staff and Daughters
description: Raised in Manhattan and Chappaqua, N.Y., Stacey Bendet Eisner, 34, is the founder of the clothing line Alice & Olivia. She lives in the West Village with her husband Eric Eisner, 39, a producer, and their two daughters, Eloise, 4, and Scarlet, 2.

title: Hollywoods New Stars: Pedestrians
description: Everyone in Los Angeles has a ridiculous story about driving somewhere when two feet would have worked just as well. Mine features a celebrity. I once interviewed John Travolta at Paramount Pictures for an entertainment magazine, and when it came time for us to move from his trailer to the shooting location, a limo was summoned. Estimated distance of our chauffeured, temperature-controlled, Evian-sipping road trip: less than 25 yards.

title: As Worries Over the Power Grid Rise, a Drill Will Simulate a Knockout Blow
description: WASHINGTON  The electric grid, as government and private experts describe it, is the glass jaw of American industry. If an adversary lands a knockout blow, they fear, it could black out vast areas of the continent for weeks; interrupt supplies of water, gasoline, diesel fuel and fresh food; shut down communications; and create disruptions of a scale that was only hinted at by Hurricane Sandy and the attacks of Sept. 11.

title: Bill Cunningham | Tea by the Sea
description: Guests at Victorian Weekend in Nahant, Mass., spent the next day at a musical and tea dance at the Historical Society, in fashions from the 1870s to the Ragtime era.

description: LONDON  A weary familiarity hangs over the latest clashes between India and Pakistan, whose armies have traded artillery and accusations in recent days, jeopardizing new efforts to normalize relations between the two countries.

title: Philippines: 24 Killed as Cargo Ship and Passenger Ferry Collide Off Coast
description: At least 24 people were killed when a passenger ferry carrying nearly 700 people collided with a cargo ship and sank in the central Philippines on Friday night, officials said. About 575 people were rescued by government vessels and small fishing boats by early Saturday, Petty Officer Joy Villegas of the Philippine Coast Guard said in a phone interview. Hundreds of people were still thought to be missing. The ferry, St. Thomas of Aquinas, was not far from shore off the island of Cebu when it collided with the cargo boat Sulpicio Express 7. The incident was visible from the shoreline, so it was easier to respond and conduct search and rescue, Petty Officer Villegas said. Survivors interviewed on local television said that when the ferry began listing, panicked passengers raced to the deck and leapt into the ocean as it sank.

title: Automatic System Warned Pilots Before Alabama Crash
description: WASHINGTON  Sixteen seconds before a U.P.S. cargo plane crashed on approach to the airport in Birmingham, Ala., on Wednesday morning, an automated system in the cockpit warned that the aircraft, an Airbus A300, was descending too fast, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday.

title: My Job Isnt So Bad
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio  GOOD news: unemployment fell to 7.4 percent in July  the lowest level since the end of 2008. But theres bad news, too: most of the new jobs were low-wage, in retail and restaurants. Theyre not the jobs that people want. I should know. No one wants my job, either. At least, nobody in my family.

description: A Glen Cove contemporary and a Bronxville Tudor.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Gramercy Park area condo, an East Village co-op and a Brooklyn two-family house.

title: Democracy in Egypt Can Wait
description: WASHINGTON  THE Egyptian militarys bloody crackdown on supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood is yet another sign of the dark side of the Arab awakening. Across the Middle East, glimmerings of democracy are being snuffed out by political turmoil and violence.

title: Little Leaguers, Dreaming in Extra Large
description: Four new metal street signs are on order in Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich., but Mayor Robert Novitke is not sure what they will say.

title: N.S.A. Calls Violations of Privacy Minuscule
description: WASHINGTON  The top National Security Agency official charged with making sure analysts comply with rules protecting the privacy of Americans pushed back on Friday against reports that the N.S.A. had frequently violated privacy rules, after the publication of a leaked internal audit showing that there had been 2,776 such incidents in a one-year period.

title: Sizing Up Small Cars
description: With fuel prices high, many Americans are turning to smaller cars that are cheap to buy and operate.

title: Under Scrutiny, Baby App Maker Amends Learning Claims
description: A childrens advocacy group has withdrawn a complaint of deceptive marketing against the maker of eight mobile apps for babies, now that the company has amended its claims about the products.

title: Ties With Egypt Army Constrain Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Most nations, including many close allies of the United States, require up to a weeks notice before American warplanes are allowed to cross their territory. Not Egypt, which offers near-automatic approval for military overflights, to resupply the war effort in Afghanistan or to carry out counterterrorism operations in the Middle East, Southwest Asia or the Horn of Africa.

title: Bewilderment in Wake of Arrest of A.A.U. Coach
description: WASHINGTON  Sonny Vaccaro, a former sports marketing executive, said he was well aware of Curtis Malones checkered past when the two reached a sponsorship deal in 1993.

title: Christie Amends Medical Marijuana Restrictions
description: Trying to straddle a potentially dangerous social issue, Gov. Chris Christie agreed on Friday to expand New Jerseys medical marijuana program, but stopped short of what parents of children with life-threatening diseases say is necessary to improve their access to treatment.

title: Bill Clinton Defends Familys Charity
description: Former President Bill Clinton defended his familys charity and its finances on Friday amid reports that the group  recently renamed the Bill, Hillary and Chelsea Clinton Foundation  had run up deficits in some years and been mismanaged.

title: Two English Cities Battle in Court to Acquire Remains of King Richard III
description: LONDON  As if 500 years of ignominy lying in a grave hastily dug after his defeat in battle were not enough, King Richard III now faces a new battle in the English courts over which of two cities, Leicester or York, will be his final resting place.

title: Songwriters Sue to Defend a Summer Hit
description: Robin Thickes Blurred Lines is the song of the summer, spending 10 weeks at No. 1 on Billboards charts and still blaring out of cars and bars from sea to shining sea. Marvin Gayes 1977 hit Got to Give It Up was a clear inspiration for it, but were Mr. Thicke and his songwriting partners merely inspired by Gaye, or did they infringe on the copyright of the earlier song?

title: Pebble Beach Weekend: Concorso Italiano Best of Show Announced
description: The winner at this years Concorso Italiano, in Monterey, Calif., is a lime green 1969 Lamborghini Miura P400S, owned by Mark Jansen of Brisbane, Australia.

title: Headstone for an Apocalypse
description: SHROUDED by foliage and separated from the city by the Hudson River, the looming cliffs of the Palisades mean little more to most New Yorkers than a pleasant view from the West Side Highway. But these titanic ramparts of ancient basalt are also monuments to an apocalypse.

title: Sharapova and Connors Part Ways, Quickly
description: MASON, Ohio  One of the unlikeliest coach-player pairings in tennis history has ended after just one month  and one match.

title: Weekend Wheels Calendar
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

title: Hezbollah Makes Vow to Step Up Syria Fight
description: AITA AL SHAAB, Lebanon  Thousands of men, women and children gathered in this village near the border with Israel, jumped to their feet, pumped their fists and cheered as Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, vowed on Friday to step up the fight against the radical Sunni Muslims whom he accused of a car bombing on Thursday in one of the groups strongholds in Beirut.

title: City Slows Plan for Market-Rate Units on Public Housing Land
description: Facing fierce opposition from tenants in public housing projects, the administration of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is slowing down plans to lease land in some developments for market-rate apartments.

title: The Warm Thrill of Confusion
description: I used to carry around a little blue transistor radio at my grandmothers house in Douglassville, Pa., holding it tight against my ear for Brandy by Looking Glass and Go All the Way by the Raspberries. I had no idea what either of those songs meant. I might have known there was a drink called brandy and I thought Eric Carmen was singing go away. I was 5, and thats probably my earliest memory of being transfixed by music. In the way children understand these things, I guess I thought it was magic. No part of my brain could hear the different instruments as distinct from one another, nor did it cross my mind that someone sat down and decided to write about something.

title: Thrust Into Nonstop Turmoil, an Obama Adviser Counsels Pragmatism
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  Each morning this week, Susan E. Rice has called or come to a secluded contemporary house here, intelligence reports at hand, to brief President Obama about the chaotic world that has followed him on vacation.

title: Merge Is What Airlines Do
description: Hey, wait a minute. Wasnt airline deregulation supposed to bring lower prices and increased competition?

title: LeanIn.org Offers Paid Internship After Uproar Over Volunteer Position
description: LeanIn.org  the organization started by Sheryl Sandberg, Facebooks chief operating officer, to promote womens career empowerment  is paying a heavy price for an unpaid internship.

title: As Investors Jump Ship, SAC Looks to Cut Back
description: The wildly successful hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors typically heads into the end of the year in a position of strength, promising market-beating returns for its investors and outsize paydays for its owner, Steven A. Cohen.

title: For the Giants, a Full-Gear Operation
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Victor Cruz needed new cleats this week at Giants training camp, so he asked Joe Skiba, the teams equipment director, for a pair.

title: Rodriguez Offers Support, but Finds Little in Return
description: BOSTON  This is where it all began for Alex Rodriguez, on a Friday night at Fenway Park in July 1994. He started at shortstop for the Seattle Mariners, batting ninth against the Boston Red Sox and going 0 for 3 in a loss. It was so long ago that Goose Gossage pitched in the game.

title: Quinn Seeks Distance From Mayor on Police Stop-and-Frisk Strategy
description: Confronting a new political reality, Christine C. Quinn moved aggressively on Friday to put distance between herself and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, as she sought to fend off a strong challenge from a mayoral rival, Bill de Blasio, who has tapped into voters frustration with the Bloomberg era of government.

title: Attacks on Protesters in Cairo Were Calculated to Provoke, Some Say
description: The ferocity of the attacks by security forces on Islamist protesters in Cairo this week appears to have been a deliberate calculation of the military-appointed government to provoke violence from the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies, a number of Arab and Western historians of Middle East politics said Friday.

title: Brown Cheered in Second Act, at Least So Far
description: LOS ANGELES  When Jerry Brown became governor of California again, three years ago, this state was on a steep decline, crushed by budget deficits, deep spending cuts, governmental paralysis, high unemployment and a collapsing housing market. California, a place that once symbolized promise and opportunity, seemed caught in an intractable reversal of fortune.

title: No Nike Deal for Pole-Vaulter After He Puts Tape Over Logo
description: Nike withdrew its offer to sponsor a top American pole-vaulter this week after he placed tape over the companys swoosh logo on his shoes during a recent competition.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: The Justice Department moved to block an airline merger, the global economy began to tilt in favor of familiar powerhouses and Chinas economy showed new signs of a crisis.

title: Layoffs Taboo, Japan Workers Are Sent to the Boredom Room
description: TAGAJO, Japan  Shusaku Tani is employed at the Sony plant here, but he doesnt really work.

title: Hanging Out at the E-Mall
description: Shopping online is easier than shopping in a mall  as long as you know exactly what you want to buy. The problem comes when you dont know what you want.

title: Widen Main St.? Community Had Other Ideas, and Thrived
description: HAMBURG, N.Y.  How did this Rust Belt village of 10,000 people resurrect itself from a 30-year slide? It started with a road.

title: One Chase Manhattan Plaza for Sale
description: One Chase Manhattan Plaza, the silvery, sky-scraping symbol of Lower Manhattans emergence into the modern era of architecture and finance, is being offered for sale by JPMorgan Chase & Company. It might become a luxury apartment building and will almost surely get a new name.

title: Compliments to the Chef
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Wow, I had to work for this one, and I am so glad I did. The cluing on this one was fabulous. Its not so much that the entries were tough, but there were a lot of brain benders in this grid by Ed Sessa.

title: For New York City Comptroller
description: Scott Stringer has done an outstanding job as Manhattan borough president and would make a fine New York City comptroller. He is not a flashy candidate and he has no measurable notoriety. But in this turbulent election season, we dont need another celebrity office seeker.

title: Handicapping Dopers at the Racetrack
description: It turns out that the destructive and widespread doping of racehorses has become as much a concern for the $2 bettor as it is for the Jockey Club, the sports most influential group, which is urging far stronger safeguards to repair racings credibility. The clubs new opinion poll finds that as bettors handicap their choices, nearly four out of five ponder the possibility of illegal drug use, much the way they factor in a muddy track. Bettors are also making smaller wagers because of their suspicions. This a red flag from the sports customer base.

title: GPS Tracking and Secret Policies
description: This week brought fresh revelations about the National Security Agencys sloppy and invasive collection of phone data on Americans and others, as reported first by The Washington Post. In another realm of surveillance  the governments broad use of location tracking devices  the Justice Department was in federal court on Thursday defending its refusal to release memos containing information about its policies governing the use of GPS and other potentially invasive technologies.

title: Cheers Calm Nerves as Europe Takes Lead in the Solheim Cup
description: PARKER, Colo.  Before she hit her first shot in her Solheim Cup debut, the teenager Lexi Thompson glanced up in the stands behind the tee box and made eye contact with her teammate Morgan Pressel. They exchanged nods, and shortly after  as Thompson prepared to hit  Pressel exhorted the crowd to make more noise.

title: A New Danger to Campaign Law
description: Republican operatives are charging forward with their efforts to sabotage the Federal Election Commission in its lawful obligation to police campaign abuses. The six-member commission is evenly divided between the two parties, but the Republican vice chairman, Donald McGahn, has spent his tenure as a partisan obstructionist, adroitly engineering 3-to-3 standoff votes to block penalties and other recommendations by staff investigators who uncover abuses by big-money campaigners.

title: Scenes of Renewed Clashes in Egypt
description: Dozens of people were killed across Egypt on Friday as supporters of the ousted President Mohamed Morsi clashed with police.

description: NATIONAL

title: Thriving in Cape Cods Waters, Gray Seals Draw Fans and Foes
description: CHATHAM, Mass.  Ted Ligenza, a fisherman here for nearly 40 years, was intrigued when he first started seeing gray seals bobbing in the harbor for the very first time about three decades ago. We thought they were kind of pretty looking, he said.

title: The Return of the Gray Seal
description: Gray seals are popular with tourists, but Cape Cod fishermen say the growing population is competition for fish.

title: Lottery Numbers
With Buck on Paternity Leave, dArnaud Will Make Debut at Catcher for Mets
description: SAN DIEGO  One minute, John Buck was putting on his workout clothes, getting ready to play catcher in the Mets game against the San Diego Padres on Friday night. The next, he was packing his bags and getting ready to fly back to New York, where his wife was preparing to give birth.

title: Former Fund-Raiser for Grimm Pleads Guilty to Visa Fraud
description: A former fund-raiser for Representative Michael G. Grimm, whose campaign finances are under investigation by federal prosecutors, pleaded guilty on Friday to visa fraud.

title: Victims Dilemma: 911 Calls Can Bring Eviction
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa.  The police had warned Lakisha Briggs: one more altercation at her rented row house here, one more call to 911, and they would force her landlord to evict her.

title: New Charge for Durst as F.B.I. Sifts His Past
description: In 2006, it looked like the longstanding acrimony between Robert A. Durst, the real estate scion, and his family was coming to an end, with one final separation. Just a few years after being acquitted of murder despite admitting to dismembering a neighbor in Texas, Mr. Durst agreed to cash out his stake in the family skyscrapers for about $65 million.

title: With Another Yankee Win, Echoes of a Classic Comeback
description: BOSTON  Aside from the loud, visceral booing directed at Alex Rodriguez in each of his four at-bats, a pervasive, nervous silence hung over Fenway Park on Friday like a threatening thunderstorm. Somewhere dotted throughout the largest crowd of the season were fans who remembered epic collapses, including the Red Sox free fall in 1978, when the Yankees overcame a 14-game deficit to beat Boston in a one-game playoff.

title: He Used to Be on Police Dramas, Then He Met a Bad Guy in Real Life
description: A 72-year-old man stretched his tall, thick, worn self onto the little bed in his Greenwich Village apartment for an afternoon nap. It was Aug. 1, hot outside.

title: Brain Changers: A Response
description: I would like to thank the readers of The Stone for their insightful feedback on my recent post, Bursting the Neuro-Utopian Bubble. There seemed to be a few questions about my basic argument, which I will do my best to clarify here.

title: Back for Dinner at Housing Project
description: Last month, the leading Democratic candidates for mayor expressed shock at some of the conditions at Lincoln Houses, a public housing complex in Harlem, after staying there overnight with residents at the invitation of the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: Djokovic and Murray Fall at the Western & Southern Open Quarterfinals
description: John Isner defeated No. 1 Novak Djokovic, 7-6 (5), 3-6, 7-5, on Friday, finally converting a break point on his 10th opportunity to seal the victory in the Western & Southern Open quarterfinals in Mason, Ohio. After his win, Isner pretended to tear open his shirt to reveal a Superman logo, a celebration move he has borrowed from Cam Newton, the quarterback of the Carolina Panthers.

title: Struggling Immigrant Artist Tied to $80 Million New York Fraud
description: Pei-Shen Qians neighbors on 95th Street in Woodhaven, Queens, knew he scratched out a living as an artist: he often dried his paintings in the sun, propping them up on the weathered white siding of his modest house.

title: Federer Is Inspired, but Nadal Gets the Victory
description: MASON, Ohio  In the 31st edition of their storied rivalry, it was again Rafael Nadal who had the answers, even with Roger Federer turning in one of his most inspired efforts of the season.

title: Back at Fenway, Rodriguez Is Met With Fervent Booing
description: BOSTON  As Alex Rodriguez stepped into the batters box Friday night, he seemed unfazed by the crowds jeers. The boos were low-pitched and from the gut, as if the louder the crowd booed, the more it would hurt.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 7:30 P.M. (HBO) ANNA KARENINA (2012) Keira Knightley, above, stars as Anna, the bored wife of a virtuous government official (Jude Law) in mid-19th-century Imperial Russia, who travels from St. Petersburg to Moscow to calm a marital storm in the household of her philandering brother (Matthew Macfadyen) in Joe Wrights stagy adaptation of the Tolstoy novel. Aaron Taylor-Johnson plays the man who captures her heart: Count Vronsky, a young military officer with the eyes of a poet and a domineering mother (Olivia Williams). And Alicia Vikander is Kitty, a lovely young woman adored by Levin, the gloomy rural landowner (Domhnall Gleeson) widely understood to be Tolstoys alter ego, with his idea of love  an ennobling union of souls  serving as a rebuke to the amorality festering in cities. I assume you know that it ends badly, but Mr. Wrights real interest, like Tolstoys, is in everything that happens in between Annas first meeting with Vronsky and her final encounter with the wheels of a train, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. And while Mr. Wrights screen versions of Jane Austens Pride and Prejudice and Ian McEwans Atonement remain trapped in literariness, he added, Mr. Wrights Anna Karenina is different. It is risky and ambitious enough to count as an act of artistic hubris, and confident enough to triumph on its own slightly  wonderfully  crazy terms. Pious Tolstoyans may knit their brows about the stylistic liberties Mr. Wright and the screenwriter, Tom Stoppard, have taken, but surely Tolstoy can withstand (and may indeed benefit from) their playful, passionate rendering of his masterpiece. Jacqueline Durran won an Oscar for costume design.

title: The Name of War
description: In 1881 the United States government published the first of many volumes of the official records of its war with the Confederate States of America. That massive resource has been a first port of call for historians, amateur and professional, since the moment of its publication; today digitization has made it even more widely accessible. Its shorthand nickname is the O.R., for Official Records. It can come as a surprise, then, to see that its full title is The War of the Rebellion: A Compilation of the Official Records of the Union and Confederate Armies. It was called that because the rebellion was what the people who actually fought the war, especially but not only on the Union side, were most likely to call it. Understanding why helps us to better understand how the wars participants understood the conflict, and how they remembered it.

title: Not All Industrial Food Is Evil
description: IVE long wondered how producing a decent ingredient, one that you can buy in any supermarket, really happens. Take canned tomatoes, of which I probably use 100 pounds a year. It costs $2 to $3 a pound to buy hard, tasteless, fresh plum tomatoes, but only half that for almost two pounds of canned tomatoes that taste much better. How is that possible?

But increasingly, middle- and upper-middle-class parents are finding that day care is hard to find or access and that even when it is available it is startlingly costly. Among the mothers I spoke to, one sent her daughter to a day care proprietor where the owner secretly had another woman mind all eight babies all day long; another signed up for a slot at a local day care when she was newly pregnant. Her daughter is now 5, and she is still on the wait list.

title: Bodies on the Border
description: This summer, as discussions have advanced around a comprehensive immigration reform bill, I traveled to Arizona to film some people who have a unique perspective on border security. I followed Dr. Bruce Anderson, a forensic anthropologist with the Pima County Office of the Medical Examiner, who has worked to identify the remains of some 2,200 people found dead in the Arizona desert since 1990  undocumented migrants who attempted to cross illicitly from Central America and Mexico into the United States. His essay is an excellent critique of libertarians; but most conservatives are not libertarians, even if they like to use libertarian rhetoric now and then.
