On Aug. 24, Yair Narvaez, a friend of the grooms family, is to lead a nondenominational ceremony in Venezuela at Ranchos de Chana on Isla de Margarita. Both ceremonies incorporated Jewish elements.

title: Rebecca Ginsberg, Robert Rutkoff
description: Rebecca Michelle Ginsberg and Robert Nathaniel Rutkoff were married Saturday evening at the home of the brides maternal grandparents, Shirley Talbot and Eugene Talbot, in Stockbridge, Mass. Rabbi Israel Zoberman, a cousin of the groom, officiated.

title: Once Is an Accident; Twice Is Good Luck
description: Catherine Amorous Moore and Nicholas Brookhart Anderson were married Friday by the Rev. Bruce Comiskey, a Congregational minister, at the Stowe Community Church in Stowe, Vt.

title: Elizabeth Bierut, Francis Marisco III
description: Elizabeth Ann Bierut and Francis Anthony Marsico III were married Saturday at Transfiguration Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Msgr. Anthony M. Hernandez performed the ceremony.

title: Diana Kamin and Gary Carrion-Murayari
description: Diana Tracy Kamin and Gary Luis Carrion-Murayari were married Saturday by Karen Bray, a Universal Life minister, at the Down Town Association, a private club in New York.

title: Alicia Beyer, David Zeman
description: Alicia Courtney Beyer and David Roy Zeman were married Saturday at the Joseph Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago. The Rev. Richard D. Sloan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sara Aviel and Martin DiMarzio
description: Sara Margalit Aviel and Martin Joseph DiMarzio are to be married Sunday at the Timber Cove Inn in Timber Cove, Calif. Rebecca J. Aviel, the brides sister, who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the event, is to perform the ceremony, incorporating Jewish and Catholic traditions.

title: Sarah Kaminetsky, Isaac Jonas
description: Sarah Anne Kaminetsky is to be married in Boca Raton, Fla., Sunday evening to Isaac Saul Jonas. Rabbi Joseph Dweck is to officiate at the Boca Raton Resort and Club.

title: Stringed Instruments, Including the Heart
description: Megan Ruth Levin, a daughter of Ronda Jones Levin of Buda, Tex., and Daniel D. Levin of Austin, Tex., was married Saturday to Shawn Christopher Conley, the son of Nancy E. Conley and Herbert N. Conley of Honolulu. The brides father, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the home of the grooms parents.

title: Drew Carver-Peterson, Zachary Fein
description: Drew Patricia Carver-Peterson and Zachary Scott Fein were married Friday evening at the St. Regis resort in Princeville, Hawaii. Kelvin Ho, a minister of the Church of Revelation, performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Hutchins, Eugene Peroni III
description: Emily Dunn Hutchins, a daughter of Teresa Dunn Hutchins and Michael T. Hutchins of Ridgewood, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Eugene Everett Peroni III, a son of Mercedes Miller Peroni of Malvern, Pa., and Mr. Peroni Jr. of Conshohocken, Pa. The Rev. James J. Balija, a priest of the Catholic Apostolic Church of North America, officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Elizabeth Berylson, Robert Katz
description: Elizabeth Sara Berylson, a daughter of Amy Smith Berylson and John G. Berylson of Wellesley Hills, Mass., was married Saturday evening to Robert Benjamin Katz, the son of Dr. Gabriela Goldstein and Lewis Katz of Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Ronne Friedman performed the ceremony at the Boston Public Library.

title: Lilly Haberl and Caleb Nannes
description: Elisabeth Bridget Haberl, a daughter of Kate M. OBrian and Robert J. Haberl, both of New York, was married Saturday to Dr. Caleb Everett Nannes, a son of Nancy Everett and Michael Nannes of Bethesda, Md. Louis Pressman, a justice of the peace for the town of Salisbury, Conn., officiated at the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn., at a ceremony that was led by the brides stepfather, Robert W. Etherington III.

title: Kelly Martens, Michael Murray
description: Dr. Kelly Anne Martens and Dr. Michael Richard Murray were married Saturday at St. Peters Church in New York. The Rev. Joseph Tyrell, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Having the Stamina to Go the Distance
description: Katharine Ann Hagler and Douglas Steven Coppola Jr. were married Saturday at St. Luke the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Dahlonega, Ga. Msgr. Thomas J. Mullelly performed the ceremony.

title: Caitlin Powell, Nathan Gimpel
description: Caitlin Antoinette Rose Powell, a daughter of Mary Lynn R. Powell and William H. Powell Jr. of Boonton, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Nathan Scott Gimpel, a son of Tracy S. Gimpel and Christopher J. Gimpel of Marietta, Ohio. The Rev. Martha R. Jacobs, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to officiate at Riverside Church in New York.

title: Margot Hill, Colin Kirby
description: Margot Langdon Hill, a daughter of Janine W. Hill and J. Tomilson Hill of New York, was married Friday to Colin James Kirby, the son of Joan Driscoll Kirby and C. John Kirby of Kentfield, Calif. The Rev. Jonathan Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Church in Telluride, Colo. On Saturday, the Rev. Morris led a second religious ceremony that included a homily on Last Dollar Mountain in Telluride.

title: Misty Wright, Robert Yoskowitz
description: Misty Nicole Wright, the daughter of Jean Kiefer Wright of Louisville, Ky., was married in Washington Saturday to Robert Jeffrey Yoskowitz, a son of Carol Magil Yoskowitz and Irving B. Yoskowitz of Potomac, Md. Stephen M. Yoskowitz, the brother of the groom, who was ordained by Open Ministry for the event, led a ceremony at the Andrew W. Mellon Auditorium that incorporated Jewish and Catholic traditions.

title: Shauna Southerland, Kristoffer Strauss
description: Shauna Marie Southerland, the daughter of Muriel A. O. Southerland and Daniel R. Southerland of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday evening to Kristoffer Calvert Strauss, a son of Jean A. Strauss and Jon C. Strauss of Purchase, N.Y. Matthew O. Southerland, the brides brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the OByrne Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase.

title: Audrey McFadden, Daniel OBrien
description: Audrey Elizabeth McFadden and Daniel Joseph OBrien were married Friday by Peter H. Slutsky, a Universal Life minister, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Sarah Agor, Lane Nussbaum
description: Sarah Danielle Agor and Lane Michael Nussbaum are to be married Sunday at the Bnai Tikvah temple in North Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi Shea Hecht is to officiate.

title: Kate Iezzoni, John Martinez
description: Kate Anne Iezzoni and John Anthony Martinez were married Friday at the First Unitarian Congregational Society in Brooklyn. The Rev. Jude Geiger, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Jay Stowsky, David Kerr
description: Jay Samuel Stowsky and David Allen Kerr were married Wednesday morning at City Hall in San Francisco. Gabriel Breitzke-Rivera, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated.

title: Mets Mejia Is Injured in Loss to Padres
description: SAN DIEGO  The Mets 8-2 loss to the San Diego Padres on Saturday night at Petco Park was compounded by an injury to the right-hander Jenrry Mejia, who left the game during the fourth inning while feeling discomfort in his elbow.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THE LADY VANISHES In this Masterpiece Mystery! movie, based on Ethel Lina Whites 1936 novel, The Wheel Spins, from which Alfred Hitchcock adapted his 1938 thriller, The Lady Vanishes, Iris Carr (Tuppence Middleton, above, with Tom Hughes), a beautiful young socialite, is befriended on a train by an older Englishwoman named Miss Froy (Selina Cadell), who then disappears  after which Iriss fellow passengers deny she ever existed. Only Max Hare (Mr. Hughes), the infatuated engineer, pays heed to Iriss conviction. Is it fair to compare this film with Hitchcocks? Mike Hale asked in The New York Times. It doesnt really matter, because if youve seen the original, its impossible to do otherwise, he decided. This new Lady Vanishes, directed by Diarmuid Lawrence (South Riding) from a screenplay by Fiona Seres, is a perfectly adequate television mystery of the week. But it forgoes the crackling pace, light touch and surprisingly sophisticated sexual banter of the original, opting for melancholy, ominousness and sentimentality.

title: Sothebys to Auction Rare Blue Diamond
description: HONG KONG  Chinas economy is cooling, and Asias once-rosy prospects look less shiny than they did two years ago, but this has not deterred Sothebys from choosing Hong Kong as the place to sell a rare multimillion-dollar diamond in October.

title: North Korea Agrees to Talk About Reunions for Families
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea on Sunday accepted a South Korean proposal to discuss the reunions of elderly relatives who had been separated from their parents, siblings and children since the Korean War six decades ago.

title: China Answers One Question About Trial: A Date
description: HONG KONG  Bo Xilai, an ambitious and divisive Chinese politician whose downfall shook the Communist Party elite, will stand trial on Thursday on charges of corruption, taking bribes and abusing power, state-run news media announced Sunday.

title: 42 Heavy-Metal Bands, 2,000 Fans, My Son and Me
description: When my son Dylan was 18, he asked me to accompany him on a Royal Caribbean cruise. But this wasnt your normal cruise. This one was called 70,000 Tons of Metal, and it featured 42 heavy-metal bands and 2,000 metal fans. I did not like heavy-metal music, and I did not particularly like my son very much those days, either.

title: Yes, We Can (Tomatoes)
description: Mark Bittman offers something different and really interesting  a qualified paean to the tomato-canning industry. As he describes it, the whole process  including, yes, the infamous square tomatoes, suitable for mechanical harvesting  produces a pretty good product, with less environmental damage and better working conditions than you might think.

title: The Dynamo and Big Data
description: James Glanz relays skepticism about the economic impact of Big Data, with

title: Disruptions: Texting Your Feelings, Symbol by Symbol
description: I recently had to sit my friend down for a modern-day digital intervention. It wasnt that he was using his phone at dinner, or that he was hitting reply all on e-mail threads, or leaving unnecessary voice mail messages. No, this was much worse.

title: A Stylish Taverns Unlikely Origins, and Location
description: Every so often, along this industrial strip of Hicks Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, you could make out a man  a tall, thin figure moving behind the fogged-up, heirloom-tomato-brimmed windows of the storefront at the corner of Degraw Street.

title: Islamists Killed While in Custody, Egypt Confirms
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government acknowledged that its security forces had killed 36 Islamists in its custody on Sunday, as the countrys military leaders and Islamists vowed to keep up their fight over Egypts future.

title: Aug. 18: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Samsung Said to Be Preparing to Unveil Smart Watch
description: Samsung Electronics plans to introduce a wristwatch in September that can make phone calls, play video games and send e-mails, potentially beating Apple to market with a piece of technology that moves mobile communications beyond the smartphone.

title: Pebble Beach Weekend: Ferrari 275 GTB/4 Spider Brings $27.5 Million
description: Amidst a host of other multimillion-dollar sales on the Monterey Peninsula of California this weekend, the 1967 Ferrari 275 GTB/4 N.A.R.T. Spider sold by RM Auctions for $27.5 million has become, according to RM, the second most expensive car ever to be sold at auction  and the most expensive Ferrari ever to cross the block.

title: A Strong Start for Lee Daniels The Butler
description: Oprah Winfrey served up a surprise No. 1 finish for Lee Daniels The Butler at the weekend box office, while the superhero sequel Kick-Ass 2 tripped on its cape. The Butler (the Weinstein Company) took in about $25 million in North American theaters, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. A biographical drama that cost roughly $30 million to make, The Butler was aggressively promoted by Ms. Winfrey, who plays an alcoholic wife in the film. Pent-up demand for more serious cinema also helped sales, as did enthusiastic reviews and a tempest-in-a-teapot fight over the films title.

title: Stringer Gets Endorsements of Three City Newspapers
description: Three major daily newspapers in New York City made it bluntly clear this weekend whom they did not want to see as the next comptroller: Eliot Spitzer.

title: At the Printer, Living Tissue
description: SAN DIEGO  Someday, perhaps, printers will revolutionize the world of medicine, churning out hearts, livers and other organs to ease transplantation shortages. For now, though, Darryl DLima would settle for a little bit of knee cartilage.

title: Most of U.S. Is Wired, but Millions Arent Plugged In
description: The Obama administration has poured billions of dollars into expanding the reach of the Internet, and nearly 98 percent of American homes now have access to some form of high-speed broadband. But tens of millions of people are still on the sidelines of the digital revolution.

title: Public Funds Take Control of Assets, Dodging Wall Street
description: Investors responsible for more than $2 trillion recently gathered at a resort in the Canadian Rockies, far from the news media and, more important, far from Wall Street.

title: Printing Out a Biological Machine
description: URBANA-CHAMPAIGN, Ill.  Not all bioengineers who are using printers in the lab are trying to create tissues or organs. Some are intent on making biological machines.

title: Communicating Economics
description: A somewhat belated response to Roger Farmer, who accused me of cribbing from his writings. The truth is sadder; I havent read any of his stuff. Ive tried, a couple of times, but found it very hard to penetrate and gave up  and several other economists Ive talked to had the same reaction.

title: Firefighters Survivor Benefits Value Some Lives Over Others
description: DENVER  As a wilderness firefighter, Caleb Renno hiked over mountains until his heels bled, living out of tents and eating packaged food for weeks at a time in rugged corners of the burning West. He did not love the work, but like many young adults in southern Oregon, he knew he could always find steady pay fighting fires.

title: The New Growth Fizzle
description: A sort of side-thought inspired by Brad DeLong on the end of Malthusian economics and all that, plus what looks like deja vu all over again on the payoff or lack thereof to Big Data: whatever happened to New Growth Theory?

title: Another Gold for Bolt as World Championships End
description: MOSCOW  Usain Bolt, as is now customary in track and field, had the last word Sunday at the world championships.

title: Britain Detains the Partner of a Reporter Tied to Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  The partner of Glenn Greenwald, the journalist for The Guardian who has been publishing information leaked by the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden, was detained for nine hours by the British authorities under a counterterrorism law while on a stop in Londons Heathrow Airport during a trip from Germany to Brazil, Mr. Greenwald said Sunday.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Spider
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Selfless Star, Ultimate Sacrifice
description: CUMMING, Ga.  Before her husbands funeral a year ago this month, Bernadine Roundfield recalled another one they had attended together. After the eulogies, on the way home, he told her, bluntly, When I go, make sure no one tells any lies or makes me out to be something I wasnt.

title: A Television Unit Flourishes in an Often Overlooked Corner of Sony
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Next month, the broadcast networks will introduce more than 20 new series, and four of the most ambitious will be supplied by Sony.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 19
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Postal Service Applies Old Promise to New Priority
description: THE Postal Service is identified with a promise that neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night would stay its couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds. But the Internet? Dont ask.

title: Baidu Deal May Reduce App Piracy in China
description: TOKYO  The biggest Internet takeover to date in China has already sharpened a rivalry among the countrys digital powerhouses, but the deal could also bring more order to Chinas messy world of mobile apps.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Upon a Sylvan Riverside Lawn, Woeful Darkness Settles
description: GARRISON, N.Y.  Been thinking of taking early retirement? Before making that decision, you might want to hear about this guy I met up in Putnam County on the gorgeous grounds of a Hudson River mansion. He looked to be no more than, say, 50-something.

title: Unloading the Weightiness of Brahms With a Few Flicks
description: Sprezzatura is not a term usually associated with Brahms. Coined in 16th-century Urbino by Baldassare Castiglione, the author of the Renaissance blockbuster guide to courtly manners, the Italian word denotes an elegant lightness of bearing that masks the effort behind the composure. The music of Brahms? The opposite, surely, with quill-chewing, meticulous labor audible in every earnestly created bar.

title: This Artificial Intelligence Is Ruining My Commute
description: Machines have been proving themselves to be our enemies for years, at least in the science-fiction world. The danged things keep becoming sentient and turning against us. They do it again in Delete, a television movie that has its debut on Reelz on Monday night.

title: Knocking the Crowns Off Pageant Winners
description: At the start of Francesca Harpers Art Prototype 2013, a dance-theater production using beauty pageants as its point of departure, a woman slowly crossed the stage while trailing two long strips of white fabric. Another performer passed the other way, marking the stage with an X. The dancer Eriko Iisaku, her body both lissome and punctuated, dashed across and underneath the pieces of the fabric before landing on her rear; gradually, her legs splayed. Then, like much of what happened throughout this congested work, the moment was abandoned; it trailed off, leading to nowhere.

title: Quinns Wife Edges Onto the Political Stage
description: Kim M. Catullo does not like giving interviews or getting behind a microphone. At political events, she tends to hover in the background, so much so that she is sometimes mistaken for a member of her wifes security detail.

title: Off to a Good Start
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  In todays puzzle, constructor Jean OConor riffs on the many meanings of one common English word by demonstrating the myriad ways it can be used. For a single four-letter word with only three unique letters, its got plenty of versatility  my edition of Websters spouts off 51 definitions  and the six examples that Jean uses show its diverse denotations in action. After all, its not readily apparent that theres a verbal link between POPPY SEEDS and WALLPAPER.

title: Theft Charges Reverberate in Connecticut Art World
description: For 16 years, William Morrison has watched the passing parade at his airy, contemporary Morrison Gallery in Kent, in northwestern Connecticut, where luminaries like Meryl Streep, Sam Waterston, Kevin Bacon and Kate Winslet, and far-flung artists great and small live the understated good life of the Litchfield Hills.

title: Students Trip Ends; A Mystery Just Begins
description: Gone Home, the first game from the Fullbright Company, is the greatest video game love story ever told and proof, in case any more were needed, that video games do not require shooting or punching or jumping or action of any kind to create gripping fiction.

title: Ballerina Leaves Her Comfort Zone
description: BECKET, Mass.  Entering the world of modern dance, as she does in her program Restless Creature, Wendy Whelan exhibits the same qualities of temperament she has shown for years as a principal dancer of New York City Ballet: Shes uncompromising, generous, bold, enthusiastic, adult, at the same time decisive and investigative. Few dancers in any genre show better that a work should be a process of self-discovery.

title: John Hollander, Poet at Ease With Intellectualism and Wit, Dies at 83
description: John Hollander, a virtuosic poet who breathed new life into traditional verse forms and whose later work achieved a visionary, mythic sweep, died on Saturday in Branford, Conn. He was 83.

title: A Heavy-Metal Narrative That Speaks in the Many Dialects of Music
description: Phil Anselmo started his remarkable set on Friday night atGramercy Theater by tenderizing the crowd on the subject of his new group, Philip H. Anselmo & the Illegals, bragging and downplaying, joking and turning serious. I apologize ahead of time, he said. His voice has lost most of its melody after three decades of nicotine and grandiose yelling, but it still works; even his apologies sound like commands.

title: Resisting the Siren Call of the Screen
description: My house may be like your house.

title: Manifesta Curator Named
description: Kasper Konig, a Berlin curator who has defended art against censorship by conservatives, has been named chief curator of the 10th edition of Manifesta, the roving European contemporary art biennial. This year the event is to be held in Russia for the first time, just as the countrys treatment of gay men and women is being criticized internationally. Manifesta 10 is to be held in St. Petersburg from June 28 to Oct. 31, 2014, with activities centered in the restored contemporary art wing of the State Hermitage, Russias most important museum, which is in the former Winter Palace of the czars. The museum will be celebrating its 250th anniversary, and Manifesta will be recognizing its 20th as a post-cold-war platform for cultural dialogue.

title: Project in Moscow Loses Norman Foster
description: The British architect Norman Foster has resigned from a proposed expansion of the Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow. The plan was to expand and modernize the 101-year-old institution and had an estimated cost of $670 million. The project was approved by the Russian government in 2009, but it stalled over disputes between Russian officials and preservationists, according to The Art Newspaper. The architecture firm Foster & Partners released a statement last week that said Mr. Foster, above, had sent a resignation letter in June to Irina Antonova, the former director of the Pushkin. Foster & Partners took this action because the museum, for the last three years, has not involved us in the development of the project, which was being carried out by others, the statement said. Ms. Antonova resigned in July as museum director, a post she held for more than 50 years. She was said to have supported Mr. Fosters involvement.

title: Mark Itabashi Wins Fishbein Trophy in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA  The Fishbein Trophy is presented to the player who wins the most master points at the Summer North American Championships. This years was awarded to Mark Itabashi of Murrieta, Calif. He won two major national championships, the von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs and the Truscott/United States Playing Card Senior Swiss Teams to finish 45.69 points head of Jacek Kalita and Michal Nowosadzki from Poland.

title: Azarenka Upsets Williams; Nadal Tops Isner for Title
description: MASON, Ohio  Losses have been rare in this chapter of Serena Williamss career: her established power is now paired with consistency, making her perhaps an even more reliable favorite.

title: A Summer of Troubles Saps Indias Sense of Confidence
description: NEW DELHI  For the last 10 years, India seemed poised to take its place alongside China as one of the dominant economic and strategic powerhouses of Asia. Its economy was surging, its military was strengthening, and its leaders were striding across the world stage.

title: Economic Reports for the Week of Aug. 19
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes minutes from the Federal Reserves meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in July, and the National Association of Realtors sales of existing homes for July (Wednesday); the Conference Boards index of leading indicators and the Labor Departments initial weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Commerce Departments new home sales for July (Friday).

title: Death Row Improvises, Lacking Lethal Mix
description: The decision by the Missouri Supreme Court to allow propofol, the same powerful anesthetic that caused the death of Michael Jackson, to be used in executions  coming at a time when Texas, Ohio, Arkansas and other states are scrambling to come up with a new drug for their own lethal injections  is raising new questions about how the death penalty will be carried out.

title: Top Presidential Candidates Barred From Election in Madagascar
description: JOHANNESBURG  A court in Madagascar has removed several prominent political leaders from a list of presidential candidates eligible to run in the countrys election, scheduled for Friday, which many in the region hope will settle the island nations long-running political crisis.

title: Braced to Remake Itself, Detroit First Awaits Challenges to Bankruptcy Eligibility
description: Before Detroit can start remaking itself in bankruptcy court, there is a basic question that stands in its way: Does it even qualify?

title: Spanish Fishermen Protest Restrictions Off Gibraltar
description: MADRID  About 40 Spanish fishing boats confronted British police vessels on Sunday in a dispute over access to the waters off Gibraltar, a British territory at the tip of the Iberian Peninsula that has long been a political sore point between Spain and Britain.

title: Stringers Claim of Money Laundering by Spitzer Starts a Legal Debate
description: Among the accusations that political candidates sling at one another during debates, money laundering does not usually come up.

title: Mets Get Glimpse of Bright Future and Dim Present
description: SAN DIEGO  Matt Harvey, the Mets ace, and Travis dArnaud, the organizations promising young catcher, played together for the first time Sunday afternoon during the Mets 4-3 loss to the San Diego Padres, doing their small part to stoke hope for the clubs outlook.

title: Feminists Ask for Protection After Attack in Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Leaders of Femen, the Ukrainian womens rights group known for staging bare-breasted political protests, demanded government protection on Sunday after two of them and a male associate were assaulted while on vacation in the Black Sea port city of Odessa.

title: A Call for Aid, Not Laws, to Help Women in Italy
description: ROME  Responding to the persistent problem of violence against women, Prime Minister Enrico Letta this month announced very harsh, very tough measures to counter domestic abuse and what he called femicide, the killing of women because they are women, often at the hands of current or former husbands or boyfriends.

title: Again Away From Delaware, but Finally at Home
description: ROSEMONT, Ill.  Chicago trailed the Minnesota Lynx by 3 points late in the fourth quarter on Aug. 11. The game clock ticked under 10 seconds. Elena Delle Donne, a 6-foot-5 do-it-all rookie for the Sky, rose and fired a 3-point shot over two pairs of outstretched hands. Swish.

title: McCain Takes His Work Home to Arizona, Promoting an Immigration Bill
description: TUCSON  For Senator John McCain, the Congressional summer recess has turned into a race against the clock, and against other Republicans. As the most senior member of the bipartisan Senate group that drafted the omnibus immigration bill pending in the House, he has spent his days prodding constituents to pressure Arizonas Congressional delegation to support it.

title: U.N. Team Arrives in Syria to Assess Possible Chemical Arms Use
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A United Nations team arrived in Damascus on Sunday to begin a long-awaited investigation into the alleged use of chemical weapons in the civil war in Syria.

title: Doctors Who Profit From Radiation Prescribe It More Often, Study Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Doctors who have a financial interest in radiation treatment centers are much more likely to prescribe such treatments for patients with prostate cancer, Congressional investigators say in a new report.

title: Second Act for the Temple of the Stars
description: LOS ANGELES  It was known as the Temple of the Stars: a soaring sanctuary capped by a 100-foot-wide Byzantine dome, built by Hollywood moguls on the eve of the Depression and splashed with the kind of pizazz one might expect at a movie palace rather than a synagogue.

title: An Afghan Poet Shapes Metal and Hard Words
description: KHOST, Afghanistan  The poet guided a strip of sheet metal into the ancient steel clippers, cutting shimmering triangles that fell with a dull clang on the shop floor.

title: David Howard, Revered Teacher of Dancers, Dies at 76
description: David Howard, who for nearly half a century was one of the most sought-after ballet teachers in the United States and far beyond, with a student roster that included Gelsey Kirkland, Patricia McBride and Mikhail Baryshnikov, died on Aug. 11 in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Al Jazeera America Promises a More Sober Look at the News
description: Fourteen hours of straight news every day. Hard-hitting documentaries. Correspondents in oft-overlooked corners of the country. And fewer commercials than any other news channel.

title: The Core of Mind and Cosmos
description: This is a brief statement of positions defended more fully in my book Mind and Cosmos: Why the Materialist Neo-Darwinian Conception of Nature Is Almost Certainly False, which was published by Oxford University Press last year. Since then the book has attracted a good deal of critical attention, which is not surprising, given the entrenchment of the world view that it attacks. It seemed useful to offer a short summary of the central argument.

title: Learn to Talk in Beggars Cant
description: RULERS have long kept certain powers hidden from their subjects. But this summers disclosures concerning the surveillance practices of the National Security Agency have made it clear that todays freedom of expression comes at the price of a new power: the states ability to burrow ever deeper, by technological means, into the private language of ordinary citizens.

title: Misrule of Law
description: XU ZHIYONG, a lawyer for the underprivileged, knew he risked his freedom by challenging the Chinese Communist Party to fulfill its vows to fight corruption and promote the rule of law.

title: A Flawed Background-Check System
description: The Federal Trade Commission has rightly intensified scrutiny of the companies that provide the criminal background checks used by most firms and corporations to screen job applicants. In too many cases, the reports are out of date and incomplete, causing job seekers who may have been arrested but never charged  or who have had their cases expunged or even dismissed  to be unfairly locked out of the job market.

title: Bangladeshs Workers Deserve Better
description: Four months after a building collapse killed more than 1,100 factory workers in Bangladesh, their families are still waiting for adequate  and in some cases, any  compensation. This is a shocking lapse by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and her government.

title: Wanted: Another Green Mayor
description: New York has been a dirty, gritty city practically forever, but it has also had farsighted leaders who qualify as green visionaries, going back to the 19th century. They preserved valuable real estate as irreplaceable public parkland; dreamed up an astonishing system of aqueducts to carry clean mountain water, unpumped and unfiltered, to city taps; and built a walkable, ridable, electric-train metropolis generations before smart growth and transit-oriented development were buzzwords.

title: Lottery Numbers
Graying Prisoners
description: MORE and more United States prisons resemble nursing homes with bars, where the elderly and infirm eke out shrunken lives. Prison isnt easy for anyone, but it is especially punishing for those afflicted by the burdens of old age. Yet the old and the very old make up the fastest-growing segment of the prison population.

title: More Friction Between Yankees and Rodriguez
description: BOSTON  Feeling betrayed and disappointed by his star player, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman sat in the visitors dugout at Fenway Park on Sunday, calling Alex Rodriguez a liar and saying he no longer trusted Rodriguez enough to discuss any substantive matters with him. Yet when Rodriguez is in the batters box, Cashman roots hard for him to succeed.

title: Questions on the Dual Role of a Clinton Aide Persist
description: WASHINGTON  When news surfaced in May that the State Department had approved an arrangement that allowed Huma Abedin, a top adviser to Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, to take on work for private clients, officials at the department described it as nothing unusual.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 5:10 P.M. (MoreMax) JANE EYRE (2011) Mia Wasikowska, above, portrays Charlotte Bronts beleaguered governess, in flight from her employer and soul mate, Edward Rochester (Michael Fassbender), in this adaptation of the novel, set at Thornfield Hall on the misty moors of England. Jamie Bell is St. John Rivers, the clergyman who helps nurse Jane back to health; Judi Dench, the gossipy housekeeper; Sally Hawkins, the nasty aunt; and Imogen Poots, the rich girl who almost derails Janes chances at love. This Jane Eyre, energetically directed by Cary Joji Fukunaga (Sin Nombre) from a smart, trim script by Moira Buffini (Tamara Drewe), is a splendid example of how to tackle the daunting duty of turning a beloved work of classic literature into a movie, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Neither a radical updating nor a stiff exercise in middlebrow cultural respectability, Mr. Fukunagas film tells its venerable tale with lively vigor and an astute sense of emotional detail.

title: 21st Century Birding
description: Andrew Farnsworth, the project leader of BirdCast, discusses new methods to aggregate data from birders with the help of modern technology.

title: Business Meetings Move Poolside (Dont Overdress)
description: The contract negotiations were progressing well until the woman in the tiny bikini interrupted to ask Mitchell Stevenson and his client if they wanted drinks.

title: Crowdsourcing, for the Birds
description: HELENA, Mont.  On a warm morning not long ago on the shore of a small prairie lake outside this state capital, Bob Martinka trained his spotting scope on a towering cottonwood tree heavy with blue heron nests. He counted a dozen of the tall, graceful birds and got out his smartphone, not to make a call but to type the number of birds and the species into an app that sent the information to researchers in New York.

title: Birding as Big Data, Inkjet Cartilage, Our Chemical Lives
description: A Web site called eBird pulls together hundreds of thousands of birders observations from around the globe; making clumps of human cells using a desktop printer; we debut a new column called Poison Pen.

title: China Takes Aim at Western Ideas
description: HONG KONG  Communist Party cadres have filled meeting halls around China to hear a somber, secretive warning issued by senior leaders. Power could escape their grip, they have been told, unless the party eradicates seven subversive currents coursing through Chinese society.

title: Street Style: Summer White
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Aug. 12.

title: Detroit Institute of Arts Wont File Objection in Citys Bankruptcy Proceeding
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class art collection has become a potential target for the citys creditors in Detroits federal bankruptcy case, announced on Monday that it would not file an objection in court to the citys eligibility for relief under Chapter 9. Monday was the deadline for objections to the city seeking bankruptcy protection.

title: Being Printed, Living Tissue
description: At labs around the world, researchers have been experimenting with bioprinting, but there are many formidable obstacles to overcome.

title: A Trophy Owner Also Familiar With Turmoil
description: Jeff Bezoss purchase of The Washington Post raises the possibility that he acquired the paper as a trophy to celebrate his success as the founder and chief executive of Amazon.com. The acquisition comes after the purchase of The Boston Globe by John W. Henry, the owner of the Boston Red Sox and a trading firm billionaire. The purchases are part of a broader trend toward private ownership of media companies.

title: Software That Exposes Faked Photos
description: Using algorithms designed to sniff out suspicious shadows, computer scientists from Dartmouth and the University of California, Berkeley, say they have developed software that can reliably detect fake or altered photos.

title: New York Fringe Festival Report: The Unfortunates
description: Reviews of shows from the New York International Fringe Festival will appear on ArtsBeat through the festivals close on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: Indoor Tanning Remains Popular, Despite Risks
description: Despite warnings aboutskin cancer, about a third of the young and adult white women in a new study said they used tanning beds, and many were using them frequently. Tanning beds are widely believed to have played a large role in the increasing rates of skin cancer in recent decades. The most serious type,melanoma, has risen sharply among young white women in particular.

title: Egyptians Share Gruesome Images of Dead Prisoners and Soldiers
description: Last Updated, 5:38 p.m. | As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Rod Nordland report from Cairo, Egypt has seen two grisly mass killings in the last 24 hours. The government has acknowledged killing 36 Islamist prisoners in its custody under circumstances that remain unclear, and an attack by suspected militants in a remote corner of the Sinai peninsula left at least 24 police officers dead and 3 injured.

title: A Dry Pipeline for Psychiatric Drugs
description: Fully 1 in 5 Americans take at least one psychiatric medication. Yet when it comes to mental health, we are facing a crisis in drug innovation.

title: At Home at Animal Farm: An Orwell Collection
description: In a life that was relatively brief but exceedingly active, George Orwell was, among other things, a police officer in Burma, a dishwasher in France, a tramp in England, a combatant in Spain, a war correspondent in Germany and a farmer in the Hebrides. Like many people of his era  he was born in 1903 and died in 1950  he was also a prolific letter writer, and a particularly captivating and thoughtful one at that, thanks partly to the wealth of experience he had acquired.

title: Only Essential Travelers Remain, Warily, in Egypt
description: THEYVE been through the drill there before, but global security and medical response companies say that deteriorating security conditions throughout Egypt have reduced the number of foreign business travelers there to workers who are deemed necessary.

title: Pill Can Prevent Fatal TB in H.I.V. Patients
description: An inexpensive daily pill can often fend off a lethal bout of tuberculosis in people with H.I.V., according to a large new study.

title: European Union Sets Emergency Session on Suspending Aid to Egypt
description: LONDON  European Union foreign ministers will meet in an emergency session on Wednesday to discuss suspending aid to Egypt, but the continuing military crackdown there has been a devastating blow to European efforts to negotiate a political solution and fill a vacuum left by Washington.

title: Progress in Quest for a Reusable Rocket, and Teleporting Data
description: Our theme this week is things that move in unexpected ways. In Texas, a rocket flew 800 feet in the air, then traveled sideways for 300 feet before returning to Earth. Elsewhere, two teams of researchers devised a method for teleporting small bits of information. And a wounded $600 million telescope is like a shopping cart with a broken wheel, says NASA. Onward and upward.

title: G.O.P. Purity Control
description: After losing the 2012 election the G.O.P. engaged in a bit of soul-searching, and talked publicly about changing their image, if not their policies. That phase is definitively over. The Republicans are back to denouncing every utterance that strays from an absolutely rigid right-wing orthodoxy, and even ones that really dont.

title: Hagel on Egypt at the Pentagon
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel speaks about the United States relationship with Egypt after days of intense violence there.

title: At Sentencing Hearing, Lawyers for Manning Urge Leniency
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  Pfc. Bradley Mannings defense lawyers on Monday made a last-minute personal plea to the military judge hearing his court-martial, asking her to be lenient in sentencing and to allow Private Manning a chance to rehabilitate himself. A prosecutor in the case urged a 60-year sentence for disclosing hundreds of thousands of documents to WikiLeaks.

title: Pregnant, and Disputing the Doctor
description: During herpregnancy, Emily Oster didnt appreciate her doctors habit of issuing blanket rules: Dont gain more than 35 pounds. No need to discuss amniocentesis  youre not 35. No eating in the delivery room.

title: Beers Implicated in Emergency Room Visits
description: Nationwide, roughly a third of all visits to emergency rooms for injuries are alcohol related. Now a new study suggests that certain beverages may be more likely to be involved than others.

title: College Prep, This Time for Health
description: To me, the strangest thing about my sons college health forms was that they did not require my signature.

title: Simon & Schuster and Barnes & Noble Reach a Deal
description: After a dispute over terms that stretched for most of the year, Simon & Schuster and Barnes & Noble said in a joint statement on Monday that they had resolved their outstanding business issues. Both parties look forward to promoting great books by Simon & Schuster authors, they said.

title: Petersen Automotive Museum Announces Exterior Redesign
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Not long after it began liquidating nearly a third of the 400 cars in its collection, the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles announced a major exterior redesign of the museum Sunday at a news conference held here at the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Thompson Tries to Turn Caribbean Ties Into Votes
description: A steel drum band welcoming the guest of honor? Check. The flags of Grenada, Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago, and other Caribbean island nations adorning the mirrored walls? Check.

title: 4 Officials Convicted of Negligence Over Russia Flooding
description: MOSCOW  A court in southern Russia convicted four local officials of criminal negligence on Monday for failing to alert residents to flash flooding in the city of Krymsk last summer that killed more than 170 people. The verdict came as Russia was coping with disastrous flooding again, this time in the countrys Far East.

title: Listen Up | All Is Not Lost for the Civil Wars
description: The Civil Wars self-titled sophomore album, which was No. 1 on the Billboard 200 chart last week, tells the story of a duo in turmoil. Recorded earlier this year amid building tension between the bandmates Joy Williams and John Paul White (they abruptly halted a European tour last November because of internal discord and irreconcilable differences of ambition), the album is rife with allusions to heartache and regret, providing subtext for the two singer-songwriters own conflict.

title: Harley-Davidson Unveils Project Rushmore Bikes
description: Harley-Davidson unveiled eight new 2014 motorcycles on Monday that were developed under Project Rushmore, an initiative to bring a new level of sophistication to the brands biggest motorcycles.

title: Part Gel, Part Muscle
description: Researchers at the University of Illinois have created tiny biological machines called "biobots" using heart cells from a rat and gel, merged by a 3-D printer.

title: In Performance: Soul Doctor
description: Eric Anderson and Amber Iman sing the number Always With You from the new Broadway musical about the life of Shlomo Carlebach, the folk-singing rabbi. The show is at the Circle in the Square.

title: The Sources of Christies Campaign Cash
description: Jonathan Martins story about Gov. Chris Christies re-election efforts noted that more than a third of the Christie campaigns $8.3 million intake has come from outside New Jersey. But where are those out-of-state donors from, and how much have they given?

title: Falcone to Admit to Wrongdoing as S.E.C. Takes a Harder Line
description: Wall Streets regulator sent a message on Monday that it was now taking a more aggressive stance on securities settlements as it extracted its first admission of wrongdoing under a new policy.

title: 160-Million-Year-Old Fossil of an Omnivore
description: Researchers have discovered a 160-million-year-old fossil of a fast-running, agile omnivore that resembled the modern-day African dormouse.

title: Monday Motorsports: Logano Wins Michigan 400; Former BMW and Fiat Executive Is Killed in Vintage Bike Race
description: Joey Logano took the lead with three laps remaining Sunday, holding off Kevin Harvick to win the 400-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, India, the Philippines and Egypt.

title: The Bulls of the Camargue
description: These bovines, raised only in Southern France, are a delicacy in the restaurants of the region.

title: In Southern France, the Braising of the Bulls
description: ARLES, France  I was finishing the first course at the one-star Michelin restaurant La Chassagnette when Armand Arnal, the chef and owner, rushed into the dining room and ordered me to follow him. He led me out the door and into his five-acre fruit, vegetable and herb garden.

title: Samsung Offers Up Another Jumbo Phone
description: Samsung Electronics on Monday introduced a mobile device in the United States with a 6.3-inch screen  large enough to blur the lines between a tablet and smartphone. Its another example of how the South Korean manufacturer is willing to make just about anything in any size to see what sticks with consumers.

title: Fitting More on a DVD
description: Fitting More

title: Travel Is Great, but Theres No Place Like Home
description: AFTER I finished interviewing roughly 200 women and men about their successes, failures and regrets for a book I was writing, the one thing I repeatedly heard was that most people wished they had traveled more.

title: A Newcomer Asks Questions and Sketches Some Fresh Answers
description: In The Impulse Wants Company, a new ballet by Troy Schumacher, the young dancer Harrison Coll, in profile, steps into arabesque. One arm stretches forward into space, one leg continues the line behind him  whereupon first his colleague Kaitlyn Gilliland, tall and mature, goes to support him, keeping him in that position. Next, other companions cluster around, partnering him, sharing and amplifying the gesture. This image coalesces before our eyes like a rapid coral formation. Its a collective moment, and the company that performs it is called BalletCollective.

title: Oversight Board Faults Broker-Dealer Audits
description: Auditors performed complete and correct audits of at least three brokerage firms last year, the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board said Monday.

title: The Results of the Baby-Llama Naming Contest
description: When youve raised as many llamas as Richard Snyder has  hundreds, over several decades  naming the new babies can be a chore. This year Mr. Snyder, who was featured in a recent article about llama enthusiasts, invited Times readers to help name the three crias, or baby llamas, born on his farm in Milford, Pa., in May. There were two males and a female, and their parents names were given as inspiration.

title: In Rome, a Melodic Nero Burns With Love
description: It did not take long for the medium of opera, as it coalesced in Italy in the first half of the 17th century, to discover the heady combination of glorious music put to the service of venality and vice. Monteverdi, a founding father, certainly had it down by the time of his final opera, LIncoronazione di Poppea, which appeared in Venice in 1643.

title: Our Egyptian Unrealpolitik
description: In a column on Egypt written while Hosni Mubaraks regime was teetering that is, two and a half years and an eternity ago I closed with the following observation about ideology and foreign policy:

title: Former C.E.O. of Willis Group Joins K.K.R. as Senior Adviser
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Monday that it had hired a former chairman and chief executive of the Willis Group as a senior adviser, adding another veteran corporate boss to its roster of outside experts.

title: Still Tough Mothers, if a Bit Warmer
description: LENOX, Mass.  Though theyre marginal improvements on Mrs. Bates, the lady who sent little Norman around the bend in Psycho, these are not mothers you could bring anyone home to meet. One is a conniving, endlessly itinerant businesswoman so hard-bitten that shell haggle over the price of her childs life.

title: A Surplus of Good TV? Try Depression Economics
description: Eighty years ago, President Franklin D. Roosevelt taught us what to do when confronted by a surplus of something: Pay people not to make any more of it. And what we have a surplus of right now is good television.

title: In Fashion | Candylike Pastel Coats to Brighten Up Fall
description: Falls sugary pastels  lavender, pistachio, pale rose, butter cream  are a romantic respite from so much hard-working black and white.

title: Romes Start to Architectural Hubris
description: Granted that Rome was not built in a day, the unresolved question among scholars has been just how long did it take. How early, before Julius Caesar came, saw and conquered, did Romans begin adopting a monumental architecture reflecting the grandeur of their ambitions?

title: Oklahoma Judge Blocks Law Limiting Morning-After Birth Control
description: A judge in Oklahoma on Monday blocked an attempt by the states Legislature to restrict access to morning-after birth control pills.

title: Stravinskys Many Rites of Passage Are Distilled
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  While Igor Stravinsky successfully cultivated the air of a rootless cosmopolitan during his long stretch as the 20th centurys most renowned composer, modern scholarship has firmly established his links to a broader tradition of Russian music and the debt many of his works owe to his culture and forebears. But with that facet of his multifarious career having been summarily addressed during the first weekend of this years Bard Music Festival, there was plenty more to cover during three more jam-packed days and nights.

title: Even Ocean Dwellers Decorate for Company
description: For years, scientists were baffled by large circular patterns on the ocean floor. These crop circles of the ocean floor are created by male puffer fish in order to attract females.

title: Pebble Beach Weekend: Spyker Reveals B6 Venator Spyder
description: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif.  The sparkling sunshine and mild breezes demanded an open-top car at Pebble Beach this weekend. Spyker, the tiny Dutch automaker, obliged on Friday by introducing the B6 Venator Spyder at the 2013 Quail Motorsports Gathering.

title: A Daughters Visit Turns Into a Family Stress Test
description: Old Cats takes place almost entirely in an apartment in Santiago, Chile, occupied by Isadora (Blgica Castro); her second husband, Enrique (Alejandro Sieveking); and the felines of the title, a pair of roly-poly tabbies described by Isadora as the kings of the house. The enclosed space and the age of the couple  as well as Isadoras increasingly frequent lapses of lucidity  may remind you, at first, of Amour, Michael Hanekes unsparing end-of-life excursion. But Old Cats, written and directed by Sebastin Silva and Pedro Peirano (originally released in Chile in 2010, long before Amour), is less concerned with the austere reality of death than with the stress and mess of living.

title: Where Words Mean as Much as Objects
description: Four years ago, the American Museum of Natural History agreed to return to the Apaches 77 objects from its collection, including headwear, feathers, bows and arrows, medicine rings and satchels containing crystals and charms.

title: Christie Signs Bill Outlawing a Gay Cure
description: BELLEVILLE, N.J.  Gov. Chris Christie signed a bill Monday outlawing therapy that aims to convert gay children to heterosexuals, making New Jersey the second state to ban the controversial practice.

title: Superchunk and Tedeschi Trucks Band Release Albums
description: SUPERCHUNK

title: Petition Wants Met Gala Dedicated to Gay Rights
description: The furor over Russias new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality has spread to the world of classical music, with some opera fans calling on the Metropolitan Opera to dedicate its opening-night gala performance of Tchaikovskys Eugene Onegin to the support of gay people.

title: Pebble Beach Weekend: Galpin Unveils 1,024-Horsepower Ford GTR1
description: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif.  Road-testing began Sunday for the Galpin Ford GTR1  a modern-day interpretation of the classic Ford GT40  that was revealed on Friday at the Quail Motorsports Gathering.

title: Mets Give Rookie Catcher an Extended Stay
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Shortly after learning the Mets planned to keep him for the rest of the season, the rookie catcher Travis dArnaud returned to his locker and found the veteran reliever LaTroy Hawkins standing in front of it talking to a reporter. Protocol and humility are vital for someone with only three days in the major leagues, so dArnaud, 24, asked Hawkins if he could slip by, careful not to offend his 40-year-old teammate.

title: Web Site Down? How Dare You!
description: SEATTLE  On occasion, I visit a small store in my neighborhood only to find a sign saying the store is closed for an hour or so. Its mildly irritating, but it has never occurred to me that those moments are worth freaking out over.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Zuckerbergs Facebook Page Hacked and McAfees Regrets
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items. Earlier in the afternoon, Amazon.com went down. It came, as Nick Wingfield noted, after a week in which several of the Internets biggest companies went dark for a time.

title: Prime Minister of Pakistan Open to Talks With Taliban
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In his first televised policy speech to the country since assuming office in June, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Monday hinted at his governments inclination to hold talks with Taliban militants even while maintaining the option of military action against them.

title: Germany: Police Foil Hostage Taker
description: Chancellor Angela Merkel canceled a campaign appearance in the northern Bavarian town of Ingolstadt on Monday after a 24-year-old man armed with a knife and a realistic plastic replica of a pistol took three hostages in the local city hall. The police later stormed the building, freeing the hostages and wounding the suspect. It was unclear whether the episode had any connection with Ms. Merkels plans for an appearance in a nearby square. She was to proceed with a planned appearance in the nearby city of Regensburg later Monday. Ms. Merkel is seeking a third term in federal elections onSept. 22. All three hostages were unharmed, said Gnther Beck, a police spokesman. The suspect suffered a gunshot wound and was being treated by doctors, but he was expected to appear in a local court on Tuesday, Mr. Beck said.

title: Seized Guns Offer Look at Pipeline From South
description: The guns often arrived by Chinatown bus, packed into patterned bags and destined for sale in a Brooklyn rap studio or in the backs of cars on the Lower East Side.

title: Syria: Thousands Flee to Iraq
description: At least 29,000 Syrians have flooded into northern Iraq since Thursday, the United Nations refugee agency said Monday, calling it one of the largest cross-border migrations since the Syrian conflict began in 2011. Officials said 20,000 crossed over on Thursday alone. More than 1.9 million Syrians have already sought refuge in neighboring countries; more than 180,000 are now in Iraq.

title: South Korea: U.S. Joins War Drills
description: South Korea and the United States began another round of military drills on Monday. In the past, North Korea denounced the drills as a rehearsal for an invasion, but on Tuesday its criticism was less harsh, which analysts said was a sign of the Norths interest in continuing diplomacy. The drills, which continue until Aug. 30, involve 30,000 American and 50,000 South Korean troops in computer-simulated war exercises.

title: Prosecutor in Enron Case Expected to Be Named to Justice Dept. Post
description: The Justice Department is expected to name Leslie R. Caldwell, the former lead prosecutor in the Enron case, as the next head of its criminal division, according to people briefed on the decision.

title: At U.N., Labor Tensions Mar 10th Anniversary of Bombing
description: The United Nations commemorated the 10th anniversary of the single deadliest assault in the organizations history on Monday, the bombing of its Baghdad offices that killed 22 people, with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon warning in a speech that since then the attackers who target us have grown more sophisticated, more brazen and better armed.

title: Michigan: Many Object to Bankruptcy
description: About 100 objections to Detroits eligibility for bankruptcy were filed in federal court before amidnight deadline on Monday. The challenges, most from individual city retirees or residents, contend that city officials did not prove insolvency or negotiate enough with creditors before seeking Chapter 9 protection last month. Unions also argued that the case should be dismissed because it will violate pension protections under the State Constitution. The state attorney general, Bill Schuette, who will defend pensioners in later bankruptcy proceedings, did not protest the citys eligibility.

title: As a Boom Slows, Peru Grows Uneasy
description: LIMA, Peru  From his office window, Henrik Kristensen, the chief executive of the company that runs Perus main port, can still look out at rows of newly arrived, shiny Kia automobiles from South Korea and shipping containers stacked four high, full of imported items like television sets and brand-name clothing bound for the growing number of malls that serve this countrys burgeoning middle class.

title: Smith Feels Pressure as Sanchez Finds Comfort
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As much as Jets Coach Rex Ryan insists the quarterback competition is not over, the demeanor and words of the incumbent Mark Sanchez and the rookie Geno Smith on Monday appeared to hint at the more likely outcome.

title: Obama Presses for Action on Bank Rules
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged the nations top financial regulators on Monday to move faster on new rules for Wall Street, telling them in a private White House meeting that they must work to prevent a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis.

title: Uncertainty Over a Palace of Parking
description: BERLIN  The preservation of a sooty parking garage covered with graffiti is a tough sell in a city whose landmarks include fragments of the wall that for decades defined the cold war, a jagged church tower that stands as testament to the ravages of World War II and elegant Prussian palaces where German leaders host visiting dignitaries.

title: Using U.S. Golf System to Help Defeat U.S.
description: PARKER, Colo.  The Solheim Cup victory was another plume in what has become a tribal headdress for golfers from the other side of the Atlantic. A European team led by Charley Hull, an irrepressible 17-year-old from England, put the finishing touches on its record 18-10 drubbing of the Americans hours after another British teenager, Matthew Fitzpatrick, 18, became the first Englishman in more than a century to win the United States Amateur.

title: Prime Lot, Empty for Years (Yes, This Is Manhattan)
description: This hole in the ground is the length of three city blocks. It is a carpet of sand, weeds and prairie grass sloping down to the river, interrupted only by a low ridge of broken bedrock. Around it, a black chain-link fence catches the plastic cups, paper and other debris that roll along like tumbleweeds.

title: Baas Is in Doubt for Giants Opener
description: A knee injury to the Giants starting center, David Baas, will jeopardize his chances of being available for the teams season-opening game Sept. 8, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin said Monday.

title: Deaf Student, Denied Interpreter by Medical School, Draws Focus of Advocates
description: Speaking with the parents of a sick infant, Michael Argenyi, a medical student, could not understand why the child was hospitalized. During another clinical training session, he missed most of what a patient with a broken jaw was trying to convey about his condition.

title: Egypts Media Cheers on Army Crackdown
description: Updated, Tuesday, 5:32 p.m. | As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, criticism of the deadly crackdown on Islamist protesters by security forces there has all but disappeared from the Egyptian media since channels that supported the Muslim Brotherhood were shut down last month.

title: With a Little Help From My Friends
description: My new technique was born of laziness and lack of imagination. I was trying to come up with a name for a character in my latest novel, Swann Dives In. He was a disbarred lawyer, a friend of the protagonist, Henry Swann, himself a money-obsessed skip tracer unafraid to cut a few corners. Rather than waste too much time, which as it happens is a specialty of many writers when it comes to writing, I slipped in the name of my friend Mark Goldblatt, as a place holder. He had no special significance to the story or the character. I would just use it, I thought, until I came up with something more appropriate.

title: N.C.A.A. Restores Marines Eligibility to Play Football
description: Early this summer, Steven Rhodes sent tapes of himself playing football to college coaches around the country, hoping to be invited to join their practices. The tapes included footage from some games Rhodes participated in while at Air Station Miramar, the Marine Corps base in San Diego.

title: Bo Guaguas Statement
description: Following is the statement that Bo Guagua released to The New York Times on Monday. Mr. Bos father, Bo Xilai, a former Chinese Communist Party official, is scheduled to go on trial on Thursday on charges of taking bribes, corruption and abuse of power.

title: Fallen Chinese Officials Son Is Denied Contact With Parents
description: BEIJING  Bo Guagua, the younger son of a fallen Communist Party leader scheduled to go on trial this week, made a rare public comment on the case on Monday, saying in a statement that he had been unable to communicate with his father or mother for a year and a half and drawing attention to their clandestine detention.

title: America Has No Leverage in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  EGYPT has entered a dark tunnel, and it is difficult to say when, and in what condition, it will emerge.

title: The Real Costs of Policing the Police
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  SETTING aside the legal wisdom of the recent decision by a federal judge against the New York Police Department and its stop-and-frisk policy, one thing seems clear: the judges remedy will be enormously expensive and time-consuming to implement, and at a time when the number of stops is falling dramatically.

title: Riding and Raging on the Rail Road
description: Starting my morning off right with the commute from hell, courtesy of the ever-reliable & always punctual LIRR.

title: Provocative Proposals for New York, Missing From the Campaign Trail
description: Weve hit the bell lap, in which our mayoral candidates calibrate, recalibrate and yap until they are ready to plotz.

title: Hiring the Well-Connected Isnt Always a Scandal
description: When is a new hire on Wall Street scrutinized over possible bribery?

title: Rodriguezs Lawyer Calls Baseballs Offer a Trap
description: The Yankees were off on Monday, but there was no letup in an increasingly contentious battle between the teams highest-paid player, Alex Rodriguez, and seemingly the rest of the baseball world.

title: False Choices on Egypt
description: A surprising number of world leaders and foreign policy experts have effectively acquiesced in the continued brutality of Egypts generals, arguing that support for the military is the only way to restore stability in the Arab worlds most populous state and limit wider regional turmoil. But this is just one of several false choices misinforming the debate and one that is certain to ensure more unrest, not less.

title: Trifling With the Arts and Humanities
description: More than eight months ago, the high-wattage Broadway producer Rocco Landesman announced his departure as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. Mr. Landesman, who took the job in 2009, will be hard to replace but not impossible. The White House has taken too long to nominate a successor. It also needs a new leader for the National Endowment for the Humanities, which has been missing a permanent chief since May.

title: Carwash Managers Held in Immigration Raids
description: PHOENIX  Federal agents arrested 11 managers and supervisors of a local car-washing chain on immigration fraud and other charges in weekend raids that brought in more than 200 people, setting off fear among immigrants already on edge by years of relentless enforcement in a state at the core of the debate over illegal immigration.

title: Back to the Future on Wall Street
description: It has been about a year since the JOBS Act sailed through Congress with the support of bipartisan majorities, President Obama and the banking industry  despite warnings that it would harm investors by weakening the standards and procedures that companies and their bankers must follow when they seek to raise money from the public.

title: Saudi Arabia Promises to Aid Egypts Regime
description: CAIRO  Saudi Arabia has emerged as the foremost supporter of Egypts military rulers, explicitly backing the violent crackdown on Islamists and using its oil wealth and diplomatic muscle to help defy growing pressure from the West to end the bloodshed in search of a political solution.

title: Girardi Stands, and Jumps Up, for Whats Right
description: If Joe Girardi detests cheating in baseball as much as he says, then some part of him must disapprove of his third baseman. Alex Rodriguez has a long rap sheet that would appear to read as the antithesis of the values Girardi stands for.

title: Lottery Numbers
Indictment in Immigration Raids at Arizona Carwashes
description: Federal agents raided 16 carwashes in Arizona and accused managers of intentionally hiring immigrants in the United States illegally.

title: How Not to Stay on Top
description: In the late 1970s and early 1980s, the dominant computing device used in corporate America was a word processor made by Wang Laboratories. The companys founder and chief executive was An Wang, a brilliant Chinese immigrant who was widely hailed as a visionary entrepreneur and philanthropist.

title: A Sons Heartfelt Campaign
description: Youd be hard pressed to find a political consultant who couldnt perform a convincing swoon for the candidate he or she is promoting. But when Josh Isay talks about Christine Quinn and the chance of her becoming the next mayor of New York, you see something else, something more. His eyes actually mist.

title: Time to Read, Then Vote
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Musics Generation Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Grass-Roots Campaigns
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Free Speech and Internet Filters Co-Exist?
The Struggle for Power in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: In Charitable Giving, No Hierarchy of Goodness
description: To the Editor:

title: With Proposed Rail Expansion, Northwest Confronts Its Clean Image
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The Pacific Northwests sense of itself can sometimes seem green to the point of parody: a medium-roast blend of piney peaks and urban cool, populated by residents who look descended from lumberjacks or fishermen.

title: Man Slaps Two Supporters at Quinn Event
description: Almost wherever she goes, Christine C. Quinn encounters hostility from a small group of protesters critical of her record as City Council speaker. On Monday, that rancor erupted, when the publisher of a community newspaper slapped a state senator and an intern who were supporting Ms. Quinn.

title: Whats On Tuesday

(Sundance) THE PLAYER (1992) In this film directed by Robert Altman, Griffin Mill (Tim Robbins), the head of production at a large Hollywood studio, tries to fend off a young genius (Peter Gallagher) rumored to have been hired as his replacement while figuring out who is writing him poison-pen postcards. When the hate mails author  a screenwriter (Vincent DOnofrio) Griffin failed to get back to  turns up dead, he becomes a suspect, partly for falling in love with the writers girlfriend (Greta Scacchi, above, with Mr. Robbins). Whoopi Goldberg and Lyle Lovett play the detectives who make Griffin squirm. As a satire, The Player tickles, Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. It doesnt draw blood. Mr. Altmans most subversive message, he added, is not that its possible to get away with murder in Hollywood, but that the most grievous sin, in Hollywood terms anyway, is to make a film that flops. In Short Cuts (1993), at 10:15, Mr. Altman intertwines the experiences of Los Angelenos in adaptations of Raymond Carver stories. Mr. Robbins reappears as a philandering motorcycle cop who cant be faithful to the woman (Frances McDormand) with whom hes cheating on his wife (Madeleine Stowe). Lily Tomlin is a diner cook who hits a small boy with her car. Bruce Davison and Andie MacDowell are his parents; Mr. Lovett is the baker who makes his birthday cake. Fred Ward, Buck Henry and Huey Lewis are three pals who find a dead woman while fishing. And Jennifer Jason Leigh is a mother who supports her family by doing phone sex, sometimes while washing dishes or changing diapers. The lives are often desperate and the characters inarticulate, but the group portrait is as grandly, sometimes as hilariously, realized as anything the director has ever done, Mr. Canby wrote. When future social historians want to know what the temper of life was like in one corner of America in 1993, Short Cuts will be a mother lode of information. Its also a terrific movie.

title: Crespu
description: Crespu is a traditional Provenal dish consisting of several frittatas layered one on top of the other. On my summer trips to Provence over the last few years Ive noticed that the dish has become popular in charcuteries, baked in breadpan-shaped terrines and sold by the slice. These usually consist of three or four different types of frittata and they are different from the stack of thin frittatas that I learned to make years ago. Traditionally you would make these simply by making the frittatas, leaving them a little runny on the top and stacking them, then finishing the stack in the oven or just weighting it with a plate and chilling. But its easier and faster (though still quite time consuming) if youre making the crespu in a breadpan or tureen to cook the eggs and filling like runny scrambled eggs and layer each batch in a breadpan, then bake in a water bath. You can use 3 eggs in each batch instead of 4, but the layers will be thinner.

Directors willing to play by the governments strict rules can see their films screened on Chinese television or at a small number of officially sanctioned independent film festivals. Others can walk away with generous state support.

title: With Waves and Turns, a Soloist Tells the Story of Two Indian Saints
description: Drive East at La MaMa  accurately subtitled a Journey Through South Asian Music and Dance  is an extraordinary feat, covering more ground than many other festivals. In seven days, it presents 26 performances, none repeated, of music and dance. Six of Indias classical dance forms  Bharata Natyam, Odissi, Kathak, Kuchipudi, Mohiniattam and Kathakali  will be represented. The music includes Carnatic and Hindustani vocals and individual performances devoted to the tabla, sitar, flute and other instruments. Few of us in the West know nearly enough about these rich and compelling genres; I hope this festival recurs in years to come.

Or retire to the Roosevelt Spa to soak in the healing mineral waters as Diamond Jim Brady, J. P. Morgan, Lillian Russell and a roll call of celebrities from a century past once did.

But nearly as disturbing was footage from last week showing an Egyptian police vehicle toppling off the 6th of October Bridge, which spans the Nile in central Cairo. News accounts differed over whether the vehicle was pushed over by protesters or, in a panic, the driver burst through the bridge railing and plunged into the river. Either way, the bridge was badly damaged, the car was lost, the fate of its passengers unknown.

The commission engaged in some questionable maneuvers aimed at preventing the Yucca site from ever opening, thus carrying out pledges to scuttle the facility made by President Obama, while campaigning for the presidency in 2008, and Senator Harry Reid, a Democrat of Nevada and the majority leader, who has ferociously opposed the site for years.

That sounds impressive, but the fact is these reforms should have been in place a long time ago. The challenge at this late date is not simply to move faster  which could imply a slipshod effort  but to issue strong rules without further delay.

title: South Sudan: Commander Arrested

James Otong was relieved of his command in Jonglei State and flown by helicopter back to the capital, Juba, on Monday, said the spokesman, Col. Philip Aguer. There are allegations of human rights violations, said Colonel Aguer, as well as violations of the military rules of engagement. He referred specifically to killings of civilians by soldiers in Pibor, where General Otong was based. Jonglei was the scene of clashes in July after thousands of fighters from the Lou Nuer ethnic group raided towns and villages belonging to members of the Murle group. More than 300 people died.

title: Whats on Wednesday
description: 12:50 P.M. (TMC) COOL RUNNINGS (1993) Three Jamaican sprinters  played by Leon, Malik Yoba and Rawle D. Lewis  fail to qualify for the Olympics in track and field but earn a second chance at a gold medal when they enlist a pushcart racer (Doug E. Doug, above, far left, with, from left, Mr. Yoba, Mr. Lewis, John Candy and Leon) and a disgraced former bobsled champion (Mr. Candy) as their coach to become Jamaicas first bobsled team. Writing in The New York Times, Janet Maslin described the film, very loosely based on events at the 1988 Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, as a cute, buoyant sports fantasy, jolted along by a reggae soundtrack and playfully acted by an appealing cast. She added: This new Disney comedy is slick, funny and warmhearted, very much in the old-fashioned Disney mode. The merits of Yellen versus Summers aside, it sounds as if the WH wants Summers, and doesnt want Yellen, for all the wrong reasons. They want a team player  and consider Yellens somewhat independent stance as a liability, even though she has been consistently right. They consider Yellen diminished because she wasnt part of the team making policy in 2009  when most people outside the WH dont consider 2009 anything like a policy triumph.

title: Image of the Day: August 21
In Store | At Prada, a Provocative Mural by Santi Moix

title: Laws of Attraction
description: I was at a party with the actor James Gandolfini about two weeks before he died. It was a wedding in Hollywood, and around midnight he was pouring shots of tequila for a group of men who would have laughed  slamming another Don Julio  to learn that the major preoccupation of our time is whether one is beautiful or not. Gandolfini himself was 51: he was grizzled, overweight, red in the face and complex in the soul, but to many people, men and women, he had never looked better in his life. (I would, a woman back at my table said.) In this not entirely fair world of ours, men, as they grow older, get to look distinguished, while women often feel they disappear. The actor toasted the stars and drank as if the only thing that told on you was your experience. He was near the end, God bless him, but he didnt go out wishing he was somebody else.

title: 36 Hours in Izmir, Turkey
description: Infidel Izmir. Thats the nickname that was long ago bestowed on Turkeys third-largest metropolis. Known for most of its history as Smyrna, this port city was, in Ottoman times, a melting pot that included Greeks, Armenians, Jews, French and Italians. Todays Izmir is largely Turkish, but the moniker lingers. For religious Turks, the label seems appropriate for this sunny, palm-fringed seaside city, with its relaxed attitudes and many nonobservant Muslims. For most residents, though, the nickname is proof of Izmirs progressiveness. Reverential images of Ataturk, the founder of modern secular Turkey, are everywhere, and in June many in the city protested against Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan after his Islamist-inspired government cracked down on peaceful demonstrators in Istanbul who had mobilized to save a city park from developers. Izmir  which is among four international cities that are vying to hold the World Expo in 2020  has much to offer visitors: a renovated waterfront, an ever-evolving night-life district and slick new design hotels. Meanwhile, a vast traditional bazaar and the spectacular nearby ruins of Ephesus bear witness to a rich past.
