title: Whats On Thursday
description: 1 P.M. (IFC) THE CABLE GUY (1996) Jim Carrey plays Chip Douglas, a sociopathic cable television installer who first invades the home and then the personal and professional life of Steven M. Kovacs (Matthew Broderick, above left, with Mr. Carrey) in this dark comedy directed by Ben Stiller. Jack Black is the friend who warns Steven that Chip is not as harmless he initially appears. Mr. Carrey, who won legions of fans just by speaking from his buttocks, now tries the creepy gambit of talking with a lisp, sneering at strangers, behaving like a deranged stalker and wallowing in sad, stale references to ancient television shows, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. His character is a pure creature of the television age, and the film suggests he is to be both pitied and tuned out.

title: Comments by de Blasios Wife Lead to Dispute With Quinn
description: Two Democratic front-runners, Bill de Blasio and Christine C. Quinn, on Wednesday got into an ugly dispute over whether Mr. de Blasios wife had suggested that Ms. Quinn could not understand the problems of parents because she did not have children herself.

title: Trailing in Polls, Stringer Woos Black Voters

title: Riding Away From a Bar Crawl With Citi Bikes
description: It started as a normal date night: Shawn, a bearded graduate student who favors lumberjack plaid, went to Williamsburg for dinner and drinks with his girlfriend. But instead of taking the L train from their Chelsea apartment, they decided to ride Citi Bikes there and back.

title: A Quartet, a Quarter of It New, Plays On
description: First of all, for those who were wondering: Theyre still standing. The podium is the same, too, only theres a different man sitting on it. On Monday evening, the Emerson String Quartet made its first New York City appearance with its new cellist, Paul Watkins, who took over the seat vacated by David Finckel early this summer. Playing to a packed Alice Tully Hall in its customary manner  the cellist sitting on a raised platform, the other three standing  the new Emerson Quartet sounded and looked enthused, at ease and passionately engaged with the music.

title: Hazare Embarks on His Next Movement
description: Two years ago, public disgust over the depth of corruption in India boiled over into huge protests led by the longtime social activist Anna Hazare. His nearly two-week hunger strike brought out hundreds of thousands of people and forced lawmakers to support his legislative proposal to create an independent anticorruption agency, known as Lokpal.

title: Elmore Leonard: A Man of Few, Yet Perfect, Words
description: When Freaky Deaky came out in 1988, Elmore Leonards writing credo hadnt quite kicked in yet. Though he would later deliver 10 great rules for writing with streamlined tough-guy elegance, the dedication for Freaky Deaky thanked his wife for giving him a certain look when I write too many words.

title: In Store | Illesteva Totes Out New Line of Handbags
description: Handbags are the latest offering from Illesteva, the accessories brand that first drew a celebrity following with eyewear in 2009 and has since added umbrellas and collaborations with the likes of Zac Posen and Dasha Zhukova to its repertory. Alina Silberman, who founded the line along with her brother Daniel Silberman and their friend Justin Salguero, came up with the idea. It wasnt planned, to be honest, she said. I just really wanted to do it. I thought it was too expensive, what was out there, and I thought we could do it better. The collection, which includes chic clutches and round purses, isnt just for women. Daniel said he has been traveling the past month with the backpack, one of the four designs that are available at illesteva.com, some of which will be for sale at Barneys New York early next month. Since the team often flies between New York, where the boys live, and Germany, Italy and France, where their glasses are manufactured, travel was a big inspiration for the project.

title: Marketers Invade Montauk This Summer
description: It was a balmy afternoon at the Montauk Beach House, and the English pop singer Natalia Kills was performing before 500 fans. Made of walnut wrapped in Danish cord, it was his homage to American rush seating. I wanted to create a fairly iconic chair where all the complications came from the geometries of the cord, he said.

The boutique, which features the work of Japanese artists, was hosting a pop-up shop for Stussy Livin General Store, the lifestyle offshoot of the California surfwear brand, and between the two it was a feast of Pacific design.

title: Please Pet the Geranium
description: Next month, the Dallas Arboretum will open the Rory Meyers Childrens Adventure Garden, an eight-acre, $62 million, mostly open-air learning center. The 150 interactive exhibits include an edible garden, a treetop walkway, a native wetlands ecosystem, and a lab for solving nature mysteries CSI-style. Designed to teach children the life and earth sciences, the garden has been a 17-year project of Maria Conroy, the arboretums vice president for education and a former elementary school teacher.

The 30-year-old, from Oneida, N.Y., introduced a collection of tables, chairs and lamps two years ago, and found himself with a pile of leftover wood pieces. Those scraps of white ash, walnut, maple, sycamore and catalpa have now found life as rolling pins.

There was far too much lacquer and Art Deco for her traditional Southern taste. And yet she tingled at the thought of waking up every day in such a whimsically conjured space.

title: Fix the Census Archaic Racial Categories
description: STARTING in 1790, and every 10 years since, the census has sorted the American population into distinct racial groups. Remarkably, a discredited relic of 18th-century science, the five races of mankind, lives on in the 21st century. Today, the census calls these five races white; black; American Indian or Alaska Native; Asian; and Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander.

description: Its unlikely that the Supreme Court will get its hands on Federal District Judge Shira A. The Democratic candidates running to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is appealing the decision, have vowed to overhaul the stop-and-frisk approach and end the citys appeal. Because the plaintiffs in the lawsuit, Floyd v. City of New York, requested only an injunction and not monetary damages, in all likelihood there will be no case left after Inauguration Day.

description: The New York state ethics commission voted behind closed doors last June to exempt a leading abortion-rights group, Naral Pro-Choice New York, from a new ethics law requiring tax-exempt organizations to disclose their major donors as they lobby in public forums. The action is causing understandable controversy and cries of liberal bias. It should be reconsidered  out in the open and in the spirit of the laws goal to shed more sunshine, not less, on the entwined workings of government and political lobbying.

title: Bradley Mannings Excessive Sentence
description: The 35-year sentence a military judge imposed on Pfc. Bradley Manning Wednesday morning was in some sense a vindication of his defense: following his conviction last month on charges of violating the Espionage Act, Private Manning faced up to 90 years in prison. He had previously pleaded guilty to lesser versions of those crimes that exposed him to 20 years behind bars. For a defense lawyer, a sentence of one-third the potential maximum is usually not a bad outcome. But from where we sit, it is still too much, given his stated desire not to betray his country but to encourage debate on American aims and shed light on the day to day realities of the American war effort.

title: Pardon Rates Remain Low

In all his 4,000 words on Americas broken legal system  and particularly on its outlandishly harsh and ineffective sentencing laws  there was not one mention of executive clemency.

description: The man accused of exchanging gunfire with the police at a Decatur elementary school was held without bond Wednesday on charges that included aggravated assault on a police officer and terroristic threats. Investigators were trying to determine whether the man, Michael B. Hill, 20, had stolen the AK-47 they say he used in trying to seize control of the Ronald E. title: Iran: Another Nuclear Official to Be Replaced
description: Irans longtime ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency will leave in September, news agencies reported Wednesday, making him the third senior Iranian nuclear official to be replaced under the new administration of President Hassan Rouhani. The ambassador, Ali Asghar Soltanieh, frequently criticized the agency, the nuclear monitoring arm of the United Nations, as well as what he views as Western bias against Iran. Mr. Rouhani, who took office this month, has vowed to pursue a more flexible approach toward resolving the dispute over Irans nuclear program, which many countries suspect is aimed at giving it the capability to produce nuclear weapons, despite Iranian denials. Last Friday Mr. Rouhani replaced the head of Irans Atomic Energy Organization, which runs the countrys nuclear facilities. On Tuesday state news media signaled that negotiations over the nuclear program would now be handled by Mr. Rouhanis foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, an American-educated diplomat.

description: In the latest border clash, a Pakistani Army officer died Tuesday night in Indian shelling near Skardu on the Line of Control, the disputed border between Pakistan and India, according to a Pakistani military official. The Pakistani military said that Indian troops resorted to unprovoked shelling late Tuesday that resulted in the killing of a captain, identified by only one name, Sarfraz. A soldier was also seriously wounded.

title: England: Queens Swan Is Barbecued and Eaten
description: The charred carcass of one of Queen Elizabeths own swans was found on a riverbank near Windsor Castle after having been barbecued and eaten, according to the police and a charity called Swan Lifeline. The swan was one of about 200 that live on Baths Island and belong to the queen. Until 1998, under a law dating to the 12th century, killing or injuring a swan was classified as treason, and the crown retains ownership of all unmarked mute swans in areas along the River Thames. Wild swans are also protected under a 1981 act, and to injure or kill a swan  let alone eat one  is against the law. Wendy Hermon of Swan Lifeline said that the whole breast had been removed, and it looked like it had been eaten for lunch. There was just a swan skeleton left, she said. Its absolutely disgusting, I cant imagine the kind of people that would do this. She said the carcass, with its feathers still attached, was taken by her group to be cremated.

description: An impressionistic video portrait of the actress, shot by the photographer David Sims.

title: Paper Gallery: Dreamscapes, Abysses and Radiation
description: Abelardo Morell and Elena Dorfman present unsettling, layered images in their photographs, while the painter Forrest Bass put his nightmares on canvas.

title: Escaping the Heat in Arts Fortress
description: CHANEL BALDWINS eyes sipped on that painting and only that painting, because it was what was available to her on this side of the money line.

title: Ardent Victorian at the Lens
description: Julia Margaret Cameron took up the camera rather late in her life, at 48, but very early in the life of photography. And, as much as anyone of her time, this 19th-century British woman (1815-1879) helped the nascent medium grow into a viable art form.

title: Thats Why They Call Them Gems
description: Go ahead and put your hands in those stones, Brogan Wikarek said, gesturing toward the bins of colorful, polished quartz. Then ask yourself, does anything resonate?

title: On an Aegean Island, an Ugly Past Rolls in With the Tide
description: Whats a writer to do after his debut novel lands him in the hot seat for hewing uncomfortably close to the unsavory details of his life? Heres one strategy: offer the world a protagonist whose personal history is just about as far from his own as is possible in the age of globalization.

title: Take Root
description: Inside the restaurant in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, that doubles as a daytime yoga studio.

title: Satisfying the Body and the Mind
description: It is an intimate thing to be cooked for by someone who loves to cook, and does so with skill, ardor and imagination, alone in a kitchen, knowing that at the end of the night, she will have to scrape off the dishes and scrub down the counters herself.

title: President and Soldier: 3 Meetings, and a Lesson in Resilience
description: WASHINGTON  Three times, mainly by chance and in very different circumstances, Sgt. First Class Cory Remsburg has met President Obama.

title: Songs and Snow
description: Photos from Irving Berlins White Christmas on Broadway.

title: Jury Begins Work on Fort Hood Shooting
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Choosing small details to underscore the governments larger murder case against Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, a prosecutor on Thursday told a jury of senior Army officers that on the day the major went on a deadly rampage in 2009, he had stuffed paper towels into the cargo pants of his combat fatigues to muffle the metallic clanging of 16 magazines as he walked  a total of 420 rounds for his laser-sighted semiautomatic pistol.

title: Can You Guess What This Is?
description: RULES1. Player has not seen the photo beforehand.

title: Tchaikovskys Showpiece, Performed by a Showman
description: Familiarity, they say, breeds contempt. But that maxim, however hoary, is not unassailable. Audiences for concerts of mainstream orchestral repertory have not yet grown tired of Tchaikovskys showy, songful Violin Concerto in D, composed in 1878 and now almost surely played somewhere on the planet every week of the year. New evidence came on Wednesday night in the boisterous applause that followed the works first movement, as the violinist Joshua Bell played the concerto with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Employer Mandate, Delayed by Paperwork (and Efforts to Reduce It)
description: Over the last several weeks, weve taken a close look at the Affordable Care Acts employer mandate, which requires companies with at least 50 employees to provide affordable health insurance to workers or pay a penalty. Weve examined, among other issues, how the mandate defines affordable, how it treats workers whose hours vary  even whether it could be used as catalyst for hiring formerly undocumented immigrants.

title: A Salad With Farm-Stand Allure
description: The calendar is leaning into Labor Day, but that does not mean summer is over. There is still much at the greenmarket to recommend for a bottle of dry German riesling. Consider leafy herbs, the whisper of sweetness in fresh corn and summer squash and a ripe tomato, all brought together with a splash of lemon.

title: The Summer I Discovered Suburbia
description: One preteen summer, I was sent by my parents to Kent, Ohio, to spend a few days with my cousins, Jessica and Anna. They were close to my age and looked like me: Norwegian, with blond hair and blue eyes. They, and their parents, a dental hygienist and geographer, were warm and easygoing. And yet, when I arrived at their cozy two-story house, it felt like touching down on an alien planet.

title: Seasonal Variety in a Homey Setting
description: That Trattoria 632 looks like someones expanded residence is not surprising. This roomy restaurant, bar and lounge was cobbled together from two adjoining homes. Although the many walls that sheltered a few generations have been removed and the space repurposed for the buildings new life, this merging wasnt a redo, it was a make-do, on what might have been a limited budget. The resulting layout is a tad awkward, and homey touches remain, but the mismatching sets the tone for informality and adds a bit of country charm.

title: Oh, Yes, Saturday TV Is Ladies Night
description: There were television movies before Sharknado, and there continue to be television movies after Sharknado. Witness this Saturday night, when Lifetime offers a topical drama, Escape From Polygamy; Hallmark Channel provides a frothy romantic mystery, After All These Years; and Nickelodeon kicks in Swindle, a childrens caper movie modeled on the Oceans films.

title: Yahoo Surpasses Google in Web Traffic, Somehow
description: Without question, it has been a good month for Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo. She was featured in a fancy fashion spread in Vogue magazine, Yahoos stock has continued to climb, and now, like a big cherry on top, the company beat Google to become the most visited Web property in America.

title: Fools Rush In, With Camera
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: Its Wagners Birthday, but We Get the Gifts
description: Love his music or hate his personality, the one thing you cant do with Wagner is ignore him, especially this year, as the music world celebrates his bicentenary. However petty and malicious the man could be, his artistic achievement was huge, not only in sheer physical bulk but also in ambition, imagination and invention.

title: When Its All About the Timing
description: A conventional way to describe Kate and Lukes relationship would be to say theyre just friends. But just hardly captures the intensity of the bond between them. Co-workers at a thriving Chicago microbrewery, Kate (Olivia Wilde) and Luke (Jake Johnson) have an effortless, comfortable intimacy. They get each others jokes and never tire of each others company. Daily lunch companions, they often extend the nightly busmans holiday of after-work beer-drinking until closing time. They snuggle up in booths and couches, sometimes dozing off, but more like puppies in a box than lovers in bed.

title: Council Reverses Bloomberg Veto of Policing Bills
description: The City Council voted Thursday to greatly increase oversight of the New York Police Department and of its widespread use of stop-and-frisk tactics.

title: Triple Play: Make Your Picks for Week 22
description: The Bats blog again tests our readers predictive skills with three questions about the coming week. Feel free to lean on research, tea leaves, your gut instinct or maybe just dumb luck.

title: Privileged, but Wired Not to Find Comfort
description: The rich are different from you and me, as F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote, sometimes nowhere more so than in French movies. In the United States, a Viking stove in the kitchen and a BMW in the driveway may be mere background noise in a sleek thriller; in France, such emblems of class privilege can be grounds for a date with the Widow (a k a the guillotine), metaphorically speaking. In Thrse, a 1920s woman is driven to commit a terrible crime, for all sorts of nominal reasons, though, in truth, her paramount motive is the accident of her birth: shes bourgeois.

title: Q. & A. | Edgar Wright on the Autobiographical Inspirations Behind His Boozy Film
description: Edgar Wrights latest gleefully genre-fusing meditation on English small-town life, The Worlds End, in theaters tomorrow, charts an epic pub crawl led by the character of Gary King (played by Wrights co-writer Simon Pegg), a roguish, charismatic drunk. King reunites a disbanded group of friends from his teen years to finally complete The Golden Mile, in which a stop is made at all 12 pubs in their hometown, a task they had conspicuously failed at 20 years before. As the group makes its way toward an apocalyptic climax, old wounds are reopened, lost loves are reunited, an alien invasion is uncovered, and many, many pints are consumed. Here, the writer and director talks about real-life inspiration for the film.

title: Last Call for Friends to Grow Up
description: On a summer evening in 1990, five British teenagers attempted a heroic pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, a feat of herculean imbibing known as the Golden Mile. Along the way, there were vomiting, fighting and drunken sex, but amid all that fun, the group failed to make it through the requisite 12 watering holes, the last of which was called the Worlds End. Their second try, more than 20 years later, is the subject of Edgar Wrights new movie.

title: Still Keeping Time, Staying True to the Past While Living in the Present
description: The urge toward retrospection runs strong among jazz musicians of a certain age, and to resist it requires stern commitment. But theres also a way to be stubborn about honoring the past and its pull, making no disclaimers and leaving nothing to conjecture.

title: Germanys Rieslings on the Tip of the Tongue
description: The topic today is German rieslings, and since I already know the first question, let me start with the answer: No, not all German rieslings are sweet. In fact, sweet German rieslings may soon be an endangered species.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Syria, Zimbabwe and the Philippines.

title: Brooke Astors Son Is Paroled
description: New York States parole board ruled on Thursday that Anthony D. Marshall, the 89-year-old son of the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor, had grown so sick and frail that he would be granted immediate parole after serving just eight weeks of his one- to three-year prison sentence.

title: A Return to Nature
description: There is an elusive quality to the natural light in Iceland, where long, white days of hazy luminosity dont start and end so much as they seem to surreptitiously appear and, eventually, disappear. A similarly evanescent quality can be found in the music of Julianna Barwick, a singer and composer whose third album, Nepenthe, was issued by the Dead Oceans label on Tuesday. Ms. Barwicks songs  chiefly wordless vocals, electronically looped  materialize out of ether, saturate a sonorous atmosphere, then dissolve. Environment trumps event.

title: Egyptian Police Failed to Defend Churches, Rights Group Says
description: As my colleague Kareem Fahim reported from Nazla, Egypt, dozens of churches and other facilities connected to Egypts Christian minority have been attacked and burned in the last seven days by Islamists seeking revenge for the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and a violent government crackdown that has left hundreds of his supporters dead.

title: A Well-Traveled Table in a Majestic Setting
description: The owners of Mediterraneo, which opened in April at the new Hotel Zero Degrees in Norwalk, want diners to imagine that they have stepped into the dining salon of a large, majestic yacht. That explains the beautiful teak-and-holly floor that resembles a deck and the three enormous columns that punctuate the room.

title: Havana Fantasies, Biology and Geography
description: A bright red sports car, a stripper and knee-length 24-karat gold chains: those accouterments define the sweet life in Miami in the feverish fantasies of Ral (Dariel Arrechaga), a hotheaded, hormonally overcharged Havana teenager in Una Noche. With his best friend, Elio (Javier Nez Florin), and Elios twin sister, Lila (Anailn de la Ra de la Torre), Ral hopes to follow countless others and navigate the straits of Florida to America on a homemade raft.

title: The Desert Foils Friendly Scheming
description: It isnt easy to drum up sympathy for the two 30-ish buddies of Scenic Route, childhood friends who reunite for a road trip to hell. Through their own shortsightedness, they find themselves stranded in Death Valley on a nearly deserted road with only jelly beans to eat, a few swigs of water and no cellphone service.

title: Style and Kinetics Triumph in a Turbulent China
description: The Grandmaster, a hypnotically beautiful dream from the Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai, opens with curls of smoke, eddies of water and men soaring and flying across the frame as effortlessly as silk ribbons. The men are warriors, street fighters with furious fists and winged feet, who have massed together on a dark, rainy night to take on Ip Man (Tony Leung), a still figure in a long coat and an elegant white hat. Even amid the violent whirlpools of rain and bodies, that hat never leaves his head. Its as unyielding as its owner.

title: A Surgical Center for Older Patients
description: How well will a particular patient withstand the stresses of surgery? To make that determination, surgeons typically order cardiovascular tests. Is his heart pumping efficiently? Are her lungs providing enough oxygen? But Dr. Mark Katlic never found that sufficient for older patients.

title: One of His Biggest Fights Was Outside of the Ring
description: Muhammad Ali, born Cassius Clay, was not the only American to refuse to serve during the Vietnam War, but he was, by some measures, the most famous, the loudest and the baddest. Tracing the road to Mr. Alis act of defiance in 1967, Bill Siegels film The Trials of Muhammad Ali tries to recover the cultural clat of the moment after decades of pop-history shorthand have reduced it to sound bites about the Vietcong.

title: Clocks That Have Been Ticking Since Before the Revolution
description: TICKING SINCE BEFORE

title: Comedy Listings for Aug. 22-29
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Aug. 22-26
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: How BlackBerry Handled Past Wealth
description: It started in an unlikely place, far from the headquarters of more established technology companies, and grew to become a dominant player. Along the way, investors piled in, undeterred by the companys policy of never paying a dividend.

title: Picking Up the Scent on the Road to Bliss
description: One of my first boyfriends announced after our fourth date that he would never consider marrying or even living with a woman who smoked. I was devastated (although I didnt smoke).

title: What Happens When Youre Repeatedly Hit in the Head
description: Would I allow my son to play football? is the question that the sports journalist Sean Pamphilon positions at the center of The United States of Football, his documentary on the dangers of head injuries in that sport. He follows the stories of several retired N.F.L. players, living and dead, who had the degenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, which has been linked to repetitive blows to the head. Extreme dementia and depression set in before the disease slowly destroys the body. What do you do with a 300-pound, 45-year-old person whos out of control and is only going to get worse? asks Lisa McHale, the widow of the Tampa Bay lineman Tom McHale.

title: Jazz Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: They Probably Should Have Skipped This Dinner Party
description: Injecting the home-invasion thriller with fresh DNA, Adam Wingards Youre Next strays just enough from formula to tweak our jaded appetites. That it does so without spraying the gore to geyserlike excess says a great deal about Mr. Wingards sensibility. Never one to linger ghoulishly over violence  or to rely on bloodletting to plug a weak script  he prefers to strike and move on.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Fun Begins With the Name
description: Olive Lucys Kitchen Table is a pleasant place at which to pass a sultry summer evening. It has comfortable white-backed, tufted booths, pitchers of fresh fruit sangria and music that ranges from lively salsa to mellower Sinatra. Look around the room: people have fun here. A table piled with gift bags suggests a birthday or an engagement; Alan Valenti, the owner, in a phone conversation after my visits, said the restaurant, which opened last Valentines Day, was also a popular place for bachelorette parties.

title: Lightness of Being
description: Playful sculptures abound in a group show at City Hall Park.

title: Dance Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Caretakers Needing Some Care Themselves
description: A delicate intensity of feeling shapes Short Term 12, a drama about young, lost people hoping to be found. These arent like the strays who anxiously drift through other contemporary American movies  whose lack of purpose is reflected both in the groping camerawork and the uncertainty of a budding filmmaker behind the camera. The young director of Short Term 12, Destin Daniel Cretton, may have adapted some of the techniques of low-budget independent features, including a suggestion of tentativeness in the hand-held cinematography. But hes clearly thought through his choices and found a subject that has earned its heartache.

title: People as the Big Game in an Alaskan Hunt
description: Does that worried look on the face of Nicolas Cage in The Frozen Ground signal his realization that he is trapped in a police procedural that is not as good as an average episode of Law and Order: Special Victims Unit? Could be, although the movie, the directorial feature debut of Scott Walker, is at least watchable, unlike recent debacles starring Mr. Cage, including Stolen, Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, Trespass, Seeking Justice and Season of the Witch.

title: Pop Music Videos? I Want My YouTube!
description: A LOT has changed since 1984, when MTV first televised the Video Music Awards. Thirty years ago, record labels often spent millions of dollars on videos by top directors to promote the sale of albums. Then label executives would submit the videos to MTV and pray that the network would put them in its rotation.

title: That Fractious Couple, Sex and Religion
description: Grotesquerie is in the eye of the beholder. Thats one lesson to be taken from the cinematic provocations of the Austrian filmmaker Ulrich Seidl, who, by presenting his characters as exotic specimens under a microscope, dares you to recoil.

title: A Feast of the Eyes, Then a Treat for the Ears
description: Drive East, a festival focusing on South Asian music and dance, continued on Wednesday with separate presentations exploring two dance forms: first, Odissi with Sonali Mishra, and later, Kathak featuring Shambhavi Dandekar. Even though La MaMas first-floor theater has the look of a grim church basement, there is a bright side to seeing classical Indian dance here. Details are given jewel-box prominence: the gaze, the subtle shift of a neck, the way fingers stretch and curve are as arresting as a stomp on the floor.

title: American Modern: Hopper to OKeeffe
description: MoMAs show includes paintings, drawings, prints, photographs and sculptures by more than 50 artists, bringing together some of the museums most celebrated masterworks.

title: Theater Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Theater

title: A Medal Harvest for the Top Winery
description: Long Island producers won in nine of 32 classes of wines made from grapes in the New York Wine and Food Classic this month.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Aug. 23-29
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Market Report | Blue Gets the Black and Gray Treatment
description: Designers have embraced Yves Kleins iconic shade of blue in standout pieces for early fall. From tops (Victoria Beckhams prim calf-hair coat and Jil Sanders artistic turtleneck sweater) to bottoms (Roger Viviers flocked leather bootie and Manolo Blahniks signature stiletto) and everything in between (Christopher Kanes color-blocked velvet dress and a calf-hair bag from Michael Kors), this deep indigo hue is being paired, accented and trimmed with black and gray to prove that the similar shades can, and should, be worn together. The pice de rsistance: Diors ladylike watch with baguette sapphires and bright diamonds.

title: A Plumber Lends a Sympathetic Ear
description: To describe the setup of Sparrows Dance, Noah Buschels disarmingly offbeat romance, is to risk alienating audiences fatigued by too-quirky characters and low-budget contrivance. In one corner, we have an unnamed, severely agoraphobic actress (Marin Ireland); in the other, a saxophone-playing, poetry-writing plumber (Paul Sparks). Between them lies a tiny New York City apartment and a mental-health problem as vast as a football field.

title: An Urban Park Dotted With Gardens of Whimsy
description: A certain pants-making company promoted its denim three years ago with the imperative Be stupid. This was an attempt at irony. It really meant, If you are smart, you will buy our jeans. Variations on that tag line explained: Stupid might fail. Smart doesnt even try; and Stupid creates. Smart critiques. In other words, to be original and creative, you might have to be willfully ignorant of what passes for conventional intelligence  or, at least, appear to be so. Think of the seemingly nave TV detective Columbo.

title: When Fringes Became Fashion
description: BOSTON  DOES anyone else remember that early episode of All in the Family? The one in which Archie Bunker, wearing a tie at his daughters urging, meets her boyfriend, Mike Stivic, who arrives in tie-dyed T-shirt and ripped bluejeans.

title: Spare Times for Children for Aug. 23-29
description: iLuminate: Artist of Light

title: The Pentagon as Silicon Valleys Incubator
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In the ranks of technology incubator programs, there is AngelPad here in San Francisco and Y Combinator about 40 miles south in Mountain View. And then there is the Pentagon.

title: Comfortable Old Friends
description: Its sad. When the Museum of Modern Art isnt jumping the shark with celebrity-performance art featuring the likes of Tilda Swinton, it can often be found paddling about in the lukewarm waters of the shallow end.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 23-29
description: Battle of Brooklyn Commemoration (Sunday) It was a Revolutionary War battle that George Washington and his troops would probably have liked to forget  they lost  but the Battle of Brooklyn, on Aug. 27, 1776, was the colonists first major confrontation with the British after declaring independence, giving the occasion a special place in history. Its 237th anniversary will be celebrated on Sunday, from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., with events at one of the sites involved, what is now Green-Wood Cemetery, Fifth Avenue and 25th Street, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Drunk, Ornery and With a Gun in His Hands
description: Savannah, a picturesque film based on a true story from the early-20th-century South, has a tone that leaves you expecting an outsize character to emerge and carry you to an ending that is the stuff of legends. But the man at the center of the story, Ward Allen (Jim Caviezel), turns out to be something less than that. Hes an interesting fellow but not particularly larger than life, at least as portrayed here.

title: How the Daughter of an Ancient Race Made It Out of the Australian Outback
description: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 29, 1971, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Arthur Ashe Has to Be Aware That He Is a Pioneer in Short White Pants
description: This article originally appeared in print on Jan. 2, 1966, and is excerpted, along withother tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Apology, but No Explanation, for Massacre of Afghans
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  Staff Sgt. Robert Bales offered a tearful apology on Thursday for gunning down 16 unarmed Afghan civilians inside their homes, but said he still could not explain why he had carried out one of the worst American war crimes in years.

title: Borg vs. Tilden
description: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 24, 1980, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Helen Wills Is Queen of Her Tennis World
description: This article originally appeared in print on Sep. 9, 1928, and is excerpted, along withother tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: The Little Girl With the Big Racquet
description: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 23, 1953, and is excerpted, along withother tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Wheelies: The Hot Wheels Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Former Windows Boss Goes to Andreessen, and Dear Miss Disruption
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: Fiery Mayoral Debate Drew Few Viewers, Nielsen Says
description: The Democratic mayoral debate televised on Wednesday night was filled with fireworks. But it turns out that relatively few voters actually saw them.

title: This Weeks Movies: Aug. 23, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on The Worlds End, The Grandmaster, and Drinking Buddies.

title: Surprise! No Rent Increases!
description: A friend recently told me, breathless with excitement, that she was renewing her lease at 8 Spruce Street, the Frank Gehry-designed 76-story skyscraper, without any rent increase.

title: Icahn Tweets Dinner Plans With Apples Chief, and Investors Applaud
description: Despite the hullabaloo over the Nasdaq stock markets failure on Thursday afternoon, traders remained fixated squarely on Apples then-frozen stock price.

title: For Borrowers, Many Questions
description: In this risk-averse lending climate, mortgage lenders are unabashed in their demands for detailed documentation of a loan applicants financial situation.

title: Lone Star Flavor in New York
description: Those looking for a little Lone Star soul can feel plenty at home in New York. Between the thriving scenes at Hill Country, the West 26th Street outpost dedicated to Austin-style brisket and live music, and the long-running Rodeo Bar, a Tex-Mex-flavored roadhouse pretty much directly across town, that old saw from westerns about this town isnt big enough for the two of us doesnt seem to apply here.

title: Sturgis Biker Reunion
description: Seth Kugel's summer road trip takes him to Sturgis, S.D., during an annual gathering of thousands of motorcyclists.

title: Motorcycles, Memorials and the Middle of Nowhere
description: It turns out Ive been using the phrase in the middle of nowhere incorrectly my whole life. I used to mean it as a put-down, but Ive discovered that its actually a good thing. And now that Ive found the middle of nowhere, it turns out to be more remote than I could have imagined: on a rural mail route way outside of Philip, S.D., population 750.

title: Walking and Talking Bed-Stuy
description: Bedford-Stuyvesant has not quite peaked on the been-there, done-that gentrification bucket list, but it already has its own Boswell recording every permutation of the landscape. His name is Morgan Munsey, or for those more familiar with his comments on the blog Brownstoner, he is Amzi Hill, a sobriquet taken from an architect who built Italianate brownstones and Neo-Grec town houses in Brooklyn from 1860 to 1892 and dabbled, as does Mr. Munsey, in real estate.

title: The Siren Call of the Adjustable-Rate Loan
description: As if first-time home buyers were not having enough trouble getting into the market, now they have to contend with rising interest rates.

title: Peak-Hour Pursuit
description: I am a daily commuter from suburban Connecticut to New York City. I have ridden the same train car with the same people for months (and sometimes years). I have grown enamored of a particular man I see most mornings, but I am not sure how to start a conversation with him  or whether to try. Any advice?

title: Enter a Turkish Newcomer
description: Mavi Grill and Deli, a Turkish newcomer to Mount Sinai, is surprising, first for its location in a mostly residential area, and then for its setting, not the more typical storefront but an airy, spacious, converted house.

title: American Tells of Odyssey as Prisoner of Syrian Rebels
description: Matthew Schrier was helpless. An American photographer held in a rebel-controlled prison in the Syrian city of Aleppo, he and a fellow prisoner had been caught trying to gouge a hole in their cells wooden door. The captors took his cellmate, he said, beat him, and brought him back with blood-streaked ankles and feet.

title: Now, You Can Follow Government Intelligence Agencies Back
description: If surveillance from government intelligence agencies has you concerned, now you can at least follow them back  if only on Tumblr.

title: Why Is Obama Caving on Tobacco?
description: LAST year I endorsed President Obama for re-election largely because of his commitment to putting science and public health before politics. But now the Obama administration appears to be on the verge of bowing to pressure from a powerful special-interest group, the tobacco industry, in a move that would be a colossal public health mistake and potentially contribute to the deaths of tens of millions of people around the world.

title: New Claims in U.S. Case Against SAC Ex-Trader
description: Federal prosecutors filed an updated indictment in the criminal insider trading case against a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, adding a claim that he received secret information about drug trials from a second doctor.

title: Kochs No Longer Interested in Buying Tribune Papers
description: Charles and David Koch are no longer contemplating a purchase of the Tribune Companys chain of newspapers, a spokeswoman for the billionaire industrialists said on Thursday.

title: A Silicon Valley for Ad Agencies, Only in the Mountains
description: AN agency holding group with ambitious growth plans is setting up shop in a growing market for agencies.

title: Yanks Add Some Luck to Their Streak, With Two Bad Calls on One Play
description: When luck is on your side, even the most absurd calls can go your way.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Ad Revenue From Mobile for Pandora Increases
description: Pandora Media, the company behind the popular Internet radio service about to face major competition from Apple, reported on Thursday a loss of $7.8 million, or about 4 cents a share, for the second quarter but the company continues to experience rapid growth.

title: Many Young El Pasoans Find They Can Go Home Again
description: EL PASO  In 2009, Xochitl Rodriguez, a multitalented performer from a middle-class El Paso neighborhood, was Bhutans first-ever invited artist in residence. After leaving South Asia, she served another residency in Kansas City.

title: Shortage of Doctors Tough to Fix
description: Texas lawmakers invested millions of additional dollars in the 2013 legislative session to address a looming physician shortage. Voters and university regents have rubber-stamped plans to open two new medical schools, in Austin and the Rio Grande Valley. But those moves have not placated the medical community, which remains concerned that Texas has no long-term solution to produce enough physicians, particularly in primary care, to support the surging population.

title: These Walls Speak, Recalling Victims of Violence
description: MEXICO CITY  The memorial to Mexicos victims of violence looks like it has been dropped from the sky by an angry God. Welcoming it is not, with its rusted slabs the size of movie screens standing next to a busy intersection.

title: Law Updated to Protect Some Who Do Roadwork
description: In 2003, Gov. Rick Perry signed the Move Over Act. It gave Texas drivers a new rule of the road when they came across a police car or other emergency vehicle parked on a shoulder with its lights flashing: slow down or move one lane over while passing.

title: Gingrich Will Be Back in the Crossfire on CNN

title: Quarterback? Jets Have Yet to Decide

title: Jimmy Connors, Ladies Man
description: Technically, Jimmy Connors wasnt the most overwhelming player. He was on the slight side; his serve was so-so, his forehand questionable. His only truly great stroke was his two-handed backhand. That he managed to win eight Grand Slam events (five U.S. Opens, two Wimbledons and one Australian Open), spend 160 consecutive weeks at No. 1 (1974-77) and rack up a record 109 career singles titles (John McEnroe and Roger Federer each have 77; Rafael Nadal has 58) is a testament, in large part, to a relentless and, at times, all-consuming will. This trait goes a long way toward explaining Connorss most quietly astounding feat: for 16 years, he held a Top 10 ranking. In an era when tennis careers can flame out over a half-dozen seasons, Connors  who on his 39th birthday won a fourth-round U.S. Open match against the 24-year-old Aaron Krickstein in 4 hours 41 minutes  looks, in retrospect, more and more like a freak of nature or nurture or both.

They make the trip solely for the free gambling and meal vouchers they receive when they arrive, coupons they sell on the black market. A half-day trip to the Sands can net around $40.
