title: 8.11.13 Issue
Who Made That Picnic?
description: Its part of our DNA, says Walter Levy, author of The Picnic: A History, who points out that picniclike events appear in the writings of Ovid, Plutarch and Seneca. The word picnic, however, is of more recent vintage. An early mention can be traced to a 1649 satirical French poem, which features the Frres Pique-nicques, known for visiting friends armed with bottles and dishes. In 1802, the term made a hop to Britain after a group of Francophiles in London formed a Pic-Nic Society to gorge, guzzle and perform amateur theatricals. Participants drew lots to determine who would supply which dish  from calfs-foot jelly to blancmange. Depending on your luck, Levy says, you might have to bring something expensive, like pie made from truffles.

title: Tennis Stages Another Vivid Spectacle
description: This article originally appeared in print on Sep. 1, 1935, and is excerpted, along with other tennis writing from the archives, in the August 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Plays Tennis Like a Man, Speaks Out Like  Billie Jean King
description: This article originally appeared in print on Aug. 27, 1967, and is excerpted, along withother tennis writing from the archives, in the Aug. 25, 2013, issue of the magazine.

title: Twice Was Not a Charm for Bars Run by Stringer
description: As a young man, Scott M. Stringer tried and failed to turn a ramshackle Manhattan saloon into a thriving establishment, eventually abandoning the effort in the wake of disputed bills and a displeased landlord.

title: Inside the List
description: COOL RUNNINGS: In The Sports Gene, David Epstein, a senior writer at Sports Illustrated, investigates whether there are natural-born athletes among us, just biologically built for speed and endurance. Its a topic hes been thinking about since he ran track in high school and college and was handily outpaced by Jamaican and Kenyan runners.

title: Singapore Is The New Chile
description: Remember the 2005 Social Security debate? George W. Bush had just been returned to office; his campaign was focused on national security and social issues  as I like to say, he ran as Americas defender against gay married terrorists  but as soon as the returns were in, he declared that he had a mandate to  privatize Social Security.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE GOOD LORD BIRD,  by James McBride (Riverhead, $27.95.) McBrides romp of a novel, narrated by a freed slave boy who passes as a girl, is a risky portrait of the radical abolitionist John Brown in which irreverence becomes a new form of homage.

title: Beyond Windows XP
description: Q. I keep reading warnings about Windows XP getting retired next year with no more security updates. I dont like the look of Windows 8, but if I upgrade to Windows 7, how long will that system be supported?

title: Thriving on Chaos, Manziel Shocks a Traditional System
description: AS BIG-TIME COLLEGE FOOTBALL has grown into a multisponsored, million-footed behemoth, the urge to reduce each season to a few personalities has become ever more absurd, and more necessary. You have to believe there are some actual people under all those piles of money.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review:  The Smartest Kids in the World by Amanda Ripley
description: This week, Annie Murphy Paul on The Smartest Kids in the World by Amanda Ripley, and Cris Beam discusses To the End of June, her book about Americas foster care system. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Ben Affleck to Play Batman in Man of Steel Sequel
description: The fanboy corner of the Internet collectively fainted late Thursday when Warner Brothers put an end to wild casting rumors and said that Ben Affleck would play Batman in a Man of Steel sequel.

title: Book Review Podcast: Amanda Ripleys The Smartest Kids in the World
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Annie Murphy Paul reviews The Smartest Kids in the World, Amanda Ripleys investigation into the educational experience in Finland, South Korea and Poland, and how it compares with its American counterpart. Ms. Paul writes:

title: Cherish Is the Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Ubiquitous Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Trouble in Mind
description: On the morning Leonard Peacock, the high school narrator of Matthew Quicks young adult novel, prepares a murder-suicide, he packs the Nazi pistol his grandfather brought back from the war and starts his school day with a plan. It is his 18th birthday. He is targeting his onetime best friend. Creeping through the morning with this secret knowledge, he attempts to reconcile the lives that have gone wrong around him, and to savor the freedom that comes from his imminent demise.

title: Hidden Truths
description: When Leo Strauss died in 1973 he was virtually unknown outside the tiny academic circle that he inhabited. Forty years later his name and influence are known almost everywhere. His books and articles have been translated into nearly every European language and several Asian ones. Web sites  both pro and con  are devoted to him. International conferences debate his thought and legacy.

title: Russia, With Love
description: When I lived in Moscow in my 20s, Id often pass nervous young men standing in the metro station, holding flowers and waiting for their dates to show up. Meeting in the metro was a Russian tradition, and like Russia itself it seemed exotic, romantic and rife with drama. I arrived in tears to several of my own rendezvous because of confusion over the Cyrillic-only metro signs, and I missed others entirely.

title: The Art of Fitting In
description: Like the lead characters in two new books about navigating the dynamics of high school society  Caprice Cranes Confessions of a Hater and Bridie Clarks Snap Decision: Maybe Tonight?  I was a bit of a fish out of water as a teenager. But theres something about those uncomfortable years that draws me, like many adults, back to them  at least as a reader. The perspective of these novels is subtle enough to be engrossing for both teenagers and adults for whom high schools intense friendships and antipathies still resonate. And how could they not?

title: What the Dickens
description: To the Editor:

title: Elusive Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle: Memoirs by Women
description: BLUE PLATE SPECIAL  An Autobiography of My Appetites  By Kate Christensen  Doubleday, $26.95.

title: Dreaming With Van Gogh
description: Art and art history are two subject areas in which certain electronic textbooks are not only convenient, but sometimes more effective as learning tools. Who wants merely to read about pigment-mixing without trying it, or to squint at a tiny printed reproduction of a still life by Pieter Claesz  an artist who was sharing pictures of food centuries before Instagram was invented  instead of popping open a full-screen version to better study the composition?

title: Paperback Row
description: EVERY LOVE STORY IS A GHOST STORY: A Life of David Foster Wallace,  by D. T. Max. (Penguin, $17.) Wallace, who committed suicide in 2008 at age 46, compiled a vibrant body of work: short fiction and novels  including the magnum opus Infinite Jest  as well as long-form journalism about subjects ranging from tennis to politics to lobsters. Maxs biography offers a deeply sympathetic appraisal, tracing Wallaces success as a writer and his battles against depression and addiction.

title: Away From Home
description: Early in Cris Beams remarkable new book, she outlines what she calls the core questions at the heart of Americas foster care system: Who decides the correct way to raise a child? Who makes the moves on the moral chessboard where a familys right to privacy opposes a childs right to protection from harm? And who should get to keep a child: the parents who nurse and tend to him, or the parents who brought him into this world?

title: Voice of the Voiceless
description: Autism is an endless mystery, largely unknowable by its nature, yet there are dozens of books by or about autistic people determined to explain the lives of those affected. The newest is The Reason I Jump, popular in Japan since it was published in 2007. The author, Naoki Higashida, was 13 years old at the time he wrote the memoir, and nonverbal. He wrote by spelling out words on a Japanese alphabet letter board.

title: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
description: New picture books, including David Ezra Steins Dinosaur Kisses.

title: Poetic Virtues
description: The audience for poetry is like a vastly reduced version of the audience for college football  superstitious, gossipy and divided into factions no less fervent for having only an occasional idea of whats going on outside their own campuses. Its a hard crowd to write for, and the critic who sets himself up as a color commentator inevitably struggles to find a style that can please Peter without needlessly riling up Paul.

title: Outside the Lines
description: Ask a group of kindergartners how many of them are artists and every child will enthusiastically raise a hand. Ask that same question to progressively older groups of kids and the numbers of artists will diminish with each advancing grade, until in high school only a few ink-stained hands rise from the fringes.

title: Bookshelf: Dinosaurs
description: DINOSAUR KISSES  Written and illustrated by David Ezra Stein. 32 pp. Candlewick Press. $15.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: Solitary Creatures
description: The first illustrations in the Canadian author Fanny Britts graphic novel, Jane, the Fox and Me, are of a schools large campus, with buildings, stairways, paths, shadows, scattered trees, even a far-off forest and this line: There was no possibility of hiding anywhere today.

title: Bookshelf: Sleep
description: Lenas Sleep Sheep, by Anita Lobel, and more.

title: Bait and Switch
description: The term thriller usually triggers an image of some drooling serial killer who does unspeakable things to the women he holds captive on his pig farm. Or some mad hacker who has programmed a computer virus to reroute all your e-mails to WikiLeaks. Less likely to come to mind is a small town where high school seniors selling booze to underage juniors constitutes a crime wave. Thats the context of Linwood Barclays new mystery, A TAP ON THE WINDOW (New American Library, $25.95), and, yes, its a killer of a thriller.

title: Bookshelf: Sleep
description: LENAS SLEEP SHEEP  A Going-to-Bed Book  By Anita Lobel.  24 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: Bookshelf: Issues
description: Noni Is Nervous, by Heather Hartt-Sussman, and more.

title: Bad Behavior
description: No child (except yours and mine) is nice all the time. But we dont look the other way anymore when children are mean. Four new picture books about bullying substitute animals for children. This charming menagerie lightens things up, allows us to laugh, and sometimes sneaks in  or rams through  a valuable lesson.

title: Alpha Dogs, Underdogs
description: The movie Mean Girls is nearly a decade old, but the burn book at the center of Tina Feys screenplay remains an evergreen plot device. Mostly written by the popular girls, these burn books are public logs of carefully calculated insults lobbed at social rivals and undesirables. Like everything else in the past 10 years, the burn book has moved online, and Facebook and Tumblr are littered with hateful messages written by aggressive tweens.

title: Meryl as Mary
description: The Testament of Mary, Colm Toibins novel and play about the mother of Jesus, has been blessed in its interpreters. When Fiona Shaw played the role on Broadway, Toibin praised her commitment to theater at its most pure and risky and dangerous. Now Meryl Streep has narrated the audiobook, due out Sept. 10. No word yet on whether Toibins work will also make it to the big screen or whether Shaw and Streep will compete for the part.

title: Gifted and Talented
description: I wanted to hate this book. After all, this was a book for children, and I dont do childrens books. I was totally lost by Page 2 of the preface  wondering what a Zilchbot was (12 dozen of them were attacking Captain Marvelous and his friends) and why I should care about Kid Caliber or the Diamond Dame (heroes trapped in the Nulzone). As for Captain Marvelous, he seemed like a vanilla remake  a rip-off, really  of Superman, from the big red M on his chest to his ruby red cape and captaincy of the Legion of Justice. I am an authority on the Man of Steel, having written a full-fledged biography of him. I know Superman, Superman is a friend of mine, I was tempted to write to the author, John David Anderson, and Mr. Anderson, Captain Marvelous is no Superman!

title: Family Stories
description: What parent wasnt thrilled to hear about the Emory University study suggesting that children who are told stories about their families pasts may develop a greater ability to cope with the vicissitudes of life? But most childrens books that convey a sense of family history and tradition  All-of-a-Kind Family, Little House in the Big Woods  are written with the older child in mind. Younger children are more likely to learn the day-to-day habits of rabbits, monkeys and bears. So its refreshing to find three new picture books that take as their subject the stories of human families, illuminating the ways certain rituals  along with sayings, jokes, pastimes and world views  get passed down through the generations.

title: Escaping the Past
description: Can the literary novel ever really get its arms around the problem of human evil? It keeps trying  a difficult assignment for the poor beast. In any case, an undaunted Alexander Maksik has brought his skills to this very problem. His second novel, A Marker to Measure Drift, recounts a season of homeless exile in the life of a 24-year-old Liberian woman fleeing an episode of gruesome violence incidental to the overthrow of the tyrant Charles Ghankay Taylor, in 2003. Maksik has produced a bold book, and an instructive one.

title: Bookshelf: Issues
description: NONI IS NERVOUS  By Heather Hartt-Sussman.Illustrated by Genevive Ct. 24 pp. Tundra Books. $17.95. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5)

title: A Nose for Words
description: The day John Lennon was shot, just across the park from where I attended high school, was also the day my P.S.A.T. scores came in. The news wasnt good. The problem was my vocabulary; I didnt know enough words. And so, while the rest of the world was laying flowers at the Dakota, I found myself at the Stanley H. Kaplan Educational Center, where, for 10 Sundays, I was enrolled in reform school.

title: Constant Acquisition at Microsoft, and One Deal That Didnt Close
description: With his impending departure as Microsofts chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer has put an expiration date on one of the most prolific deal-making streaks in technology over the last two decades.

title: March on Washington Original Coverage
description: Read The New York Timess original coverage of the March on Washington and its implications in August 1963, headlined 200,000 March for Civil Rights in Orderly Washington Rally.

title: From the Fire Hose: Obamas Bus Stop in Gas Country, Al Gores Category 6, an Unplugging Climate Blogger
description: Updated, 12:23 p.m. | Heres another end-of-the-week roundup of noteworthy news and analysis on issues relevant to Dot Earth grabbed from the 24/7 fire-hose flow:

title: Study Suggests Shift in Fed Bond-Buying
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  A new study finds that the Federal Reserve should keep buying mortgage-backed securities even as it stops buying Treasury securities, and even as it sells off its existing holding of Treasuries and mortgage bonds.

title: Dutch Bank ABN Amro Takes Step Toward an I.P.O.
description: LONDON  The nationalized bank ABN Amro moved a step closer to the public markets on Friday after the Dutch government said it would seek an initial public offering for the bank.

title: Outcry Grows Against British Housing Plan
description: LONDON  Depending on where one stands in the debate on the rising cost of housing in Britain, Paul Thomas and Abigail Walker, first-time home buyers, are either part of the solution or part of the problem.

title: Witnesses to History, 50 Years Later
description: The New York Times asked readers who attended the March on Washington to recall their experiences and reflect on the legacy of that day.

title: A Guessing Game for Taxpayers on What They Owe
description: WHEN it comes to income taxes, my wife and I try to pay exactly what we owe. And by this I mean we try to calculate what we need to pay during the year so we do not overpay. We would rather owe a bit more in April than find out we are getting a refund.

title: 50 Years After March, Views of Fitful Progress
description: WASHINGTON  When Daniel R. Smith was born dirt poor more than three-quarters of a century ago, there were only about 20 other blacks in his small Connecticut town. His own father had been born a slave in Virginia in 1862. Mr. Smith served as a medic in Korea in the years just after the Army had been desegregated.

title: Second Term Playbook: Impeach
description: The G.O.P. failed to unseat President Obama in last Novembers election, and birther fantasies of invalidating his presidency on technical grounds have gone nowhere. So the Republicans have pulled out their second-term playbook from the Clinton years, and are now gossiping about impeachment.

title: A New Benjamin Franklin Museum
description: The new Benjamin Franklin Museum opens on Saturday in Independence National Historical Park in Philadelphia, with 21st-century hands-on exhibits and computer simulations designed to animate the character and wisdom of the 18th-century sage.

title: 2013 U.S. Open: Players to Watch
description: Among the players to watch at this years United States Open are John Isner, Jelena Jankovic, Juan Martin del Potro, Dominika Cibulkova, Grigor Dimitrov and Sloane Stephens.

title: U.S. Open Players to Watch: Not the Usual Suspects
description: Juan Martn del Potro

title: The Impala Regains Its Swagger
description: Chevys latest Impala harks back to the nameplates 60s heyday, when it was the quintessential big, stylish American family car.

title: For Americas Sedan, a Great Leap Forward
description: My wife used to work as a sales representative for Johnson & Johnson. Like many sales reps, she was provided a nondescript, inexpensive company car  in her case, a Chevrolet Impala. At some point, the a fell off the trunk badge and we began calling it the Impal. The Impals chief virtue was its huge trunk, which could conceal many cases of sample products  typically, Tylenol PM and K-Y jelly. Say what you want about the old Impala, but it sure could haul some K-Y jelly. General Motors should have made a bigger deal of that.

title: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Impala
description: Chevrolet aims to rid the Impala of its rental-car reputation with distinctive new styling. Tom Voelk drives the 2014 model to see if the changes to this full-size sedan are more than skin deep.

title: For Two Female News Anchors, Morning Has Spoken
description: When you wake up at 3:30 a.m. to go to a job that starts in the predawn hours, lunch comes early. So, on a recent weekday morning at 10:45, Gayle King, one of the hosts of CBS This Morning, and Mika Brzezinski, the sparring partner of Joe Scarborough on Morning Joe on MSNBC, came together at Gotham Lounge at the Peninsula Hotel, dressed in near-matching green sheathes and very high heels, to share a midday meal (burrata and chicken Caesar salad for Ms. King; burrata and hot-and-sour soup for Ms. Brzezinski; freshly squeezed orange juice for both) and to talk about the demands of morning television, the roles of male and female anchors and not knowing who Russell Brand is.

title: The Jazzman With a Debt to Nashville
description: SOUTH YARMOUTH, Mass.  Theres a moment in Learning to Listen: The Jazz Journey of Gary Burton, an autobiography due out on Sept. 3 from Berklee Press, that depicts the authors earliest encounter with Miles Davis. It happened at a summer jazz festival in Mr. Burtons home state, Indiana, and probably could have gone a little better.

title: Gary Burton, Resurgent Jazz Outsider
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the Grammy-winning jazz vibraphonist, who has a new autobiography and a new album.

title: Images of Bomb Blast and Aftermath in Lebanon
description: Videos from a security camera and  from witnesses in the northern city of Tripoli in Lebanon on Friday captured the moment a bomb exploded at a Sunni mosque and the aftermath of a blast at another mosque, in attacks that killed more than two dozen people and wounded hundreds.

title: Jeep Grand Cherokees Investigated for Ceiling Fires
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is investigating whether 146,000 Jeep Grand Cherokees from the 2012 model year should be recalled after reports of fires in the headliners of three vehicles, according to a report posted on the agencys Web site.

title: Faster Assistance for Medicare Patients
description: Just over a year ago, Medicare quality improvement organizations (Q.I.O.s) across the country began a practice known as immediate advocacy.

title: Four Frittatas and a Terrine
description: For a taste of Provence in the summer, start with eggs. Thats what Martha Rose Shulman did as she recreated some of her favorite Provenal dishes to escape the summer. She writes:

title: Exhibition of Sicilian Antiquities Will Proceed at Cleveland Museum
description: An exhibition of ancient treasures from Sicily that had been abruptly canceled last month is back on the fall schedule of the Cleveland Museum of Art after the museum and Sicilian officials ironed out a dispute over money.

title: Off the Charts: Emerging Markets Submerge
description: Stock markets in emerging markets have fallen sharply this year, while most developed markets are up significantly.

title: Carmelo Anthonys Friends and Family Celebrate His Latest Award
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Lockdown by Government Smothers Day of Planned Protest in Egypt
description: CAIRO  A tight lockdown on Cairo by Egyptian security forces on Friday all but squelched a planned day of protests by the Muslim Brotherhood and its allies, suggesting that the new military government had gained a decisive edge in its battle against supporters of the ousted president, Mohamed Morsi.

title: Mets or Yankees?
description: The candidates in the New York mayoral race sound off on their baseball allegiances.

title: Taking an Invention From Idea to the Store Shelf
description: EVERY once in a while, my family will toss around ideas for potential inventions. Like my sons ultimate alarm clock, which wakes you up, tells you the weather and makes tea and toast.

title: Whether R&B, Techno, Jazz or Metal, Dont Pin Them Down
description: SZA

title: '3 Things'
description: The Catsimatidis campaign has released its first attack ad against Joe Lhota.

title: I Love You, Mom, but Hear My Record
description: Its pretty easy to spot Ty Segalls influences. This singer-songwriter, raised in Laguna Beach, Calif., has Neil Youngs name tattooed on his right arm and the logo from Black Sabbaths 1972 album Vol. 4 inked on his left. His music is likewise a recognizable combination of disparate sources, displaying a remarkable ability to synthesize different elements of pre-1980s rock  heavy 60s garage-rock riffs, harmonies that evoke the Beatles or early Tyrannosaurus Rex, and a punk velocity  into fresh and catchy pop nuggets.

title: 10 Weeks, 5,446 Entries: Reflections on the 2013 Summer Reading Contest
description: We knew it was shaping up to be the most successful year yet for the New York Times Summer Reading Contest, but until we closed the final post and did the math, we didnt realize just how successful.

title: Citys Annual Cost Per Inmate Is $168,000, Study Finds
description: New York City is an expensive place to live for just about everyone, including prisoners.

title: Image of the Day: August 23
How Fights Over Fixtures Can Derail a Closing
description: Even at their smoothest, residential real estate closings are not for the faint of heart. At stake is nothing less than the roof over the buyers head, but the repercussions can be primal when, just before the culmination of a deal worth hundreds of thousands or, in many instances, millions of dollars, weeks of negotiations unravel when the buyer and seller suddenly squabble over who gets custody of something as inconsequential as a $150 ceiling fan.

title: New York Citys Jail Population: Whos There and Why?
description: The New York City Independent Budget Office released findings on the prison population.

title: Runaways Find Homes on the Screen
description: LOS ANGELES  Early on in the new movie Short Term 12, teenagers living in a group home gather, as Nate, a neatly dressed young counselor with a nervous smile, introduces himself.

title: Hey, Ludwig, Theres an App for You
description: At the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, as at many schools around the United States, students will flock to classes this fall to begin a new academic year. Though flock may not be the right word for Curtis, with its minuscule current student body of 171.

title: Roger Federer Can Still Get His Game Face On
description: On the first Wednesday of Wimbledon this June, under a bright early-evening sky, Roger Federer trailed two sets to one in his second-round match against Sergiy Stakhovsky, a Ukrainian ranked 116th in the world and best known until that point for pulling out his cellphone during a match to take a photograph of a disputed ball mark. But Stakhovsky had played imposing serve-and-volley tennis, a style seldom seen nowadays, and as the fourth set unfolded on Center Court, it became clear that he was not going to succumb to nerves. Federer, 31 and seeking a record eighth Wimbledon title, would have to contrive an escape.

title: When You Cant Forget the Gifts You Didnt Get
description: Lisa Kaas Boyle, an environmental lawyer in Los Angeles, knows exactly who gave her what for her February 1994 wedding. The silver serving utensils? Courtesy of Uncle Michael. The magnificent Waterford vase with the doors of Ireland etched into the crystal? That came from Jimmy Murakami, the Oscar-nominated animator.

title: Recommended Reading
description: NYT developers share their recommendations from around the web.

title: Not Much to Matsuzakas Mystery Pitch
description: We were promised gyroballs.

title: Hustlers Returns
description: A look back at Philip-Lorca diCorcias photographs of male prostitutes.

title: Real People, Contrived Settings
description: In the early 1990s, the photographer Philip-Lorca diCorcia made five trips to Los Angeles to pick up male prostitutes in Hollywood. Cruising down a seedy stretch of Santa Monica Boulevard, where young men loitered suggestively by the curb, he would slow down in his rental car when he saw a likely prospect.

title: Fantasy Football: Answers to Reader Questions
description: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the 2013 season. Follow them on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

title: Nixons Political Wisdom, Caught on Tape
description: Our long audio nightmare is over. The final batch of Richard Nixons secret and self-incriminating White House tape recordings have been released. As in the 3,700 hours previously made public across the past 17 years, Nixon as president is there in all his cunning and self-pity Hamlet without the Prince, in the description of Stanley Kutler, the historian who fought mightily to block Nixon and his loyalists from burying the tapes forever. They can be tedious listening, and its hard to judge what younger generations addicted to on-screen bursts of brevity will make of the 37th presidents schemes and maunderings amid the scandal known as Watergate. But they still offer an unparalleled voyeuristic fix, which had citizens lining up for hours to hear the initial batches played endlessly on 32 audio machines in Washington.

title: Law School Applications Decline, Especially From Graduates of Elite Colleges
description: Weve written before about the declining interest in law school, as evidenced by the number of people taking the Law School Admission Test and the number applying to law schools. Over at the Associates Mind blog, Keith Lee notes that the number of applicants is down across the board, but the drop-off is particularly sharp among people who went to elite schools for their bachelors degrees.

title: Popcast: Gary Burton, Resurgent Jazz Outsider
description: If youre only a casual listener to jazz, and not a vibraphonist, Gary Burton may not be a big name to you. But hes probably had more to do with the development of jazz over the last 50 years than you think as a player (he developed the widely used four-mallet Burton Grip for the vibraphone); a mentor (to Pat Metheny, for starters); a conceptual inspiration (to Bill Frisell, among others, through the way he incorporated country and rock into his music during the late 60s); and a longtime teacher and administrator at Berklee College of Music.

title: Required U.S. Open Reading, Old and New
description: There is much to dread about late August: the heat, the humidity, those people who leave work at like 1 every Friday while you work normal hours. But there is at least one thing to look forward to: the magazines annual U.S. Open issue. You probably remember previous Open coverage from the magazine. There was John Jeremiah Sullivans article on Venus and Serena Williams, Andy Sambergs re-enactments of iconic mens championships and Dewey Nickss video gallery of womens tennis stars. And then theres the older stuff. Who could forget Harry Gordon on Arthur Ashe; Hal Higdon on Billie Jean King; or Allison Danzig on Helen Wills? Wait, did you forget them? Did you never know about them? Maybe thats because those pieces, dating to 1928, do not exist on the Internet.

title: Military Jury Convicts Army Psychiatrist on All 45 Counts in Fort Hood Rampage
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  A military jury on Friday found Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan guilty of carrying out the largest mass murder at a military installation in American history.

title: Some Stops on the March
description: In this 50th anniversary of a pivotal summer for racial equality, the Brooklyn Academy of Music has been offering A Time for Burning: Cinema of the Civil Rights Movement, a series that wraps up with a well-known Hollywood movie and some less known historical offerings.

title: Jacobs Pillow, Ready for Rest
description: Dance lovers, you have one last chance, on Sunday, to catch a performance at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., where the Martha Graham Dance Company and Kyle Abrahams Abraham.In.Motion  both well worth a pilgrimage  close the season there.

title: Bassoon Solos on the Water
description: The floating concert hall Bargemusic is possibly the cutest place in New York to hear music, and it is also one of the most adventurous; its Here and Now series is among the citys most valuable homes of new and recent work. The programs are varied, the tickets reasonably priced, and the mood low key. The series gets a big showcase this week with its annual Labor Day festival, a motley assortment of sounds with an element of surprise. While a list of works has been published on the barges Web site, the program and performers will differ slightly for each of the four performances (Wednesday, Friday, Saturday at 8 p.m. and next Sunday at 2 p.m.).

title: Sharp Lawyers, Willing to Cut
description: Its called taking silk: the merit-based appointment of a British lawyer as Queens Counsel, which confers the right to wear a specially designed silk gown in court (and, for ceremonial occasions, an even bigger wig). And in Silk, a Masterpiece Mystery! series beginningSundaynight on PBS, Martha Costello, a sharp-witted defense barrister in London portrayed by a crackling Maxine Peake, wants to take silk  badly. Already stretched thin, she strategically overloads on cases that could bolster her reputation and tutors an ambitious if occasionally bumbling pupil (Tom Hughes).

title: Living Large at Yale Gallery
description: For such a populist, accessible and at times interactive artist, Red Grooms doesnt get much respect or exposure these days. His place in history rests mostly on his role in the invention of Happenings, less on his contribution as deviant, satirical Pop artist and latter-day American (art) Scene painter. StartingFriday, Red Grooms: Larger Than Life at the Yale University Art Gallery will feature Mr. Groomss forays into the history of modernism with a group of oversize paintings and drawings.

title: Microcultures on the Island
description: Dance music is often depicted as some kind of monolith, and from a distance, Electric Zoo  a multistage festival held on Randalls Island every Labor Day weekend, now in its fifth year  submits to the prevailing stereotype.

title: In a Room to Talk
description: In times of crisis, it is perhaps better to listen to walls than climb them. Lauren Yee gives new and literal life to the hoary speculation if only these walls could talk in The Hatmakers Wife, which begins previews on Tuesday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. In it, a loquacious wall speaks up to offer advice and an, uh, ear to a commitment-challenged woman named Voice.

title: A Conservative Catholic Now Backs Same-Sex Marriage
description: HOT SPRINGS, S.D.  In the past couple of years, conservative opposition to same-sex marriage has clearly started to erode. Prominent Republicans like Senators Rob Portman and Lisa Murkowski and former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell have come out in support of gay marriage. Even David Blankenhorn, the expert witness in the Proposition 8 trial in California and a Democrat, announced that he had changed his mind.

title: Confused by How YouTube Assigns Dates, Russians Cite False Claim on Syria Videos
description: Citing reports circulating on the Internet, a spokesman for Russias foreign ministry claimed on Friday that video posted online by opposition activists in Syria, said to show victims suffering from a chemical weapons strike outside Damascus on Wednesday, was fake.

title: Two Market Operators, BATS and Direct Edge, Said to Be in Talks to Merge
description: BATS Global Markets and Direct Edge are in talks to merge, potentially creating one of the biggest stock market operators in the country, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: Serendipity and Tradition Meet in Wallpaper Design
description: Alpha Workshops trains New Yorkers with H.I.V. for jobs in artistic fields. A new wallpaper design, called Astral, shows just how spontaneous Alphas students can be. Artisans at the workshop fold 15-foot-long sheets of paper, then unfold them, spread them out, and apply paint with a sponge. The paint is caught in the peaks and valleys, and no two sheets are exactly alike.

title: The Ad Campaign: Catsimatidis Goes on the Attack
description: Thanks to his considerable fortune, John A. Catsimatidis has been a steady presence on television as he seeks the Republican nomination for mayor. His advertisements so far have touted his rags-to-riches biography and his commitment to public safety. Now, three weeks before the primary, he is going on the attack against his main Republican rival, Joseph J. Lhota. Mr. Lhota is the focus of a 30-second commercial, 3 Things, that began airing Friday. A second new commercial, Cares About Us, also criticizes Mr. Lhota.

title: Play Misty for Me
description: When designing Casamista, a portable humidifier produced by Umbra, Alan Wisniewski said he began with the idea of things that smoke: tugboat funnels, automobile tailpipes and rooftop chimneys. He settled on the last. I thought that a traveling house with a functional chimney was a little reminder of a home away from home, he said. The humidifier, made of molded satin-textured plastic, has a purifying filter and will fit on top of any water bottle or glass. It can also be used with water-soluble essential oils. The device comes with a USB cable and can run on AAA batteries, which are not included. Available in avocado or black for $25. Information: (800) 387-5122 or umbra.com.

title: Museum for African Art Broadens Its Mandate
description: Soon after construction began in 2007 on the Museum for African Arts new headquarters, engineers discovered a quicksand-like layer of sediment under the site, at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. The structural problems were surmounted, but in other ways, the museum has had trouble finding stable ground since.

title: Soldier Sentenced to Life Without Parole for Killing 16 Afghans
description: JOINT BASE LEWIS-McCHORD, Wash.  Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who pleaded guilty to slaughtering 16 Afghan civilians inside their homes, will spend the rest of his life in prison, a military jury decided on Friday.

His 5-year-old grandson and namesake, however, moved a whole lot quicker, allowing his grandfather to catch up only when he stopped to pet the nose of a racehorse.

title: Screenwriter Questions Whether Tchaikovsky Was Gay, Sparking Furor in Russia
description: MOSCOW  A prominent Russian screenwriter working on a film about Tchaikovskys life that has just received state financing set off a firestorm this week by saying that the biopic would not focus on the composers sexuality because it is far from a fact that Tchaikovsky was a homosexual.

title: Getting Tesla From Here to There
description: Whether Tesla Motors can meet its ambitious growth targets  not to mention support its high-flying stock price  may well depend on people like Jason Berkley.

title: The Rise and Fall of Windows Mobile, Under Ballmer
description: Microsofts Windows Phone operating system is hardly as influential as its desktop counterpart. And now that Steven A. Ballmer has announced plans to retire, it is easy to point fingers at the Microsoft chief executive for the lackluster success the company has had in mobile computing.

description: A different take on a Rosh Hashana favorite: Melissa Clark prepares a honey cake with olive oil, red wine and plenty of spices.

Driven by an explorers voracious desire to do what has never been done, and frankly obsessive about mental and physical preparation, she has completed scores of pioneering swims, most famously the frigid Bering Strait in just a suit, cap and goggles.

title: A Homecoming for Honey Cakes

description: A magisterial floor-through residence at 640 Park Avenue, an opulent limestone building designed by J. E. R. Carpenter as a luxury rental oasis for the millionaires of 1914, sold for $23 million and was the weeks most expensive residential transaction, according to city records. The building, at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and 66th Street, went co-op in 1946; the monthly maintenance fee for the simplex, No. 8, is $15,981.

title: Does Media Violence Lead to the Real Thing?
description: EARLIER this summer the actor Jim Carrey, a star of the new superhero movie Kick-Ass 2, tweeted that he was distancing himself from the film because, in the wake of the Sandy Hook massacre, in all good conscience I cannot support the movies extensive and graphically violent scenes.

But the very best plays usually come from writers who dont necessarily have all the answers, who dont insist on telling us what to think about the developments onstage and who dont offer neat solutions to their characters problems.

title: Movie Night, Hamptons Style
description: The Hamptons home theater is more than ready for its close-up. Twenty years ago it was a rare indulgence; these days its a mandatory amenity, more coveted than wine cellars and a source of exponentially greater entertainment than, say, the ubiquitous home gym or tennis court.

description: The New York International Fringe Festival concludes on Aug. 25. For more information, go to fringenyc.org.

title: We Blew the Funeral Money on an iPad, So Sing!
description: The nuns seem to be everywhere at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport. A few show up in the aisles even before the show begins, chatting up members of the audience. At intermission, nuns mill about in the lobby and the auditorium, engaging patrons in light conversation. During the musical itself  that would be Nunsense, which made its Off Broadway debut nearly 28 years ago  the nuns occasionally move off the stage to sing and award prizes, although thankfully not to the point of forced audience participation.

title: Carpaccio at Its Beefy Best
description: These days, on restaurant menus, you are likely to encounter carpaccio dishes made with anything but meat. There is octopus carpaccio, zucchini carpaccio or heirloom tomato carpaccio, not to mention dessert carpaccios like pineapple or mango.

title: The Diary of Mrs. Tependris | Complicated Coats and Cabinets of Curiosities at Paris Couture, Part Two
description: The Greek-born artist Konstantin Kakanias is known for his drawings of eccentric characters, the most enduring of whom is a big-haired, beak-nosed, fashion-crazed woman-of-a-certain-age named Mrs. Tependris. This summer, at Ts invitation, Kakanias took Mrs. Tependris to the couture shows in Paris, where she was scandalized by latex-clad, masked models at Maison Martin Margiela, seated amid an audience of Qatari princesses at Armani Priv and encased in one of the artist Marina Abramovics space-age jumpsuits for Net-a-Porter at the Palais de Tokyo. Mrs. Tependris, who last attended the Paris shows in the mid-90s, has kept herself busy with a different type of global affair in the intervening years. She had to join a lot of revolutions, do a lot of political acts, Kakanias said. She just couldnt do couture for a while. Immediately following the shows last month, Kakanias shared Part One of his heroines adventure. Here, he fills us in on the rest of what Mrs. Tependris saw and did.

title: Three Decades of Conversations With Fire
description: The ceramist Akira Satake is not used to playing the role of foreman, but you wouldnt know it from the relaxed demeanor he displayed recently while leading a crew wearing protective face shields and fire-retardant gloves at Peters Valley School of Craft in Layton, in Sussex County.

description: The drumbeat for Fashion Week started a month ago in my in-box, and now its up to oblivion level, white noise in the black season.

title: Not at First Sight, or Even the First Dozen
description: It was not as if they hadnt had every chance to fall in love. For three years, Adrian Zackheim, the publisher and president of three imprints at Penguin Random House, and Elizabeth Lunney, co-founder of ABC Languages, a foreign language school, fled Manhattan for weekends to the same house owned by Nancy Winston in Westport, Conn.

title: Head-Turners
description: Rob Sass takes a look at some trend-setting models from this years Monterey auctions.

title: A Well-Traveled Concours Winner
description: PEBBLE BEACH, CALIF.  A dark green 1934 Packard 1108 Twelve Convertible Victoria with a custom body by Dietrich became the first Packard in 36 years to win the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance.

title: Pebble Beach Gallery
description: A photographic tour of the Pebble Beach Concours dlgance, with a side trip to the cheeky Concours dLemons, courtesy of Jerry Garrett.

description: Brazils central bank announced a $60 billion program on Thursday aimed at halting the slide of the Brazilian real, making Brazil the latest emerging economy to seek to prop up its sagging currency.

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Hawaii; Kentucky; Munich
description: Aloha Festivals, Oahu, HawaiiA celebration of Hawaiian culture and history through music, dance, cuisine and art will take place at various locations on Oahu during the 2013 Aloha Festivals from Sept. 12 to 28. Highlights include an opening ceremony featuring traditional chants and hula dancing, concerts, demonstrations, activities, displays of crafts, food booths, block parties and a parade with marching bands, floats with cascades of Hawaiian flowers, and pau riders (women on horseback), above. Many of this years events pay tribute to the ocean-voyaging culture of the islands ancestors. All events are free and open to the public.

title: Betony Vernons Guardian Angel
description: Success is, of course, a beautiful thing, a gift of affirmation from the world that comes in a neat little box. The only problem is that if you want to keep this gift, you usually have to get into the box and stay there. In other words, the good news is that you get a niche. Thats also the bad news. If you dont fit easily in your assigned compartment, you may get uncomfortable.

title: London Lawyers Measure Themselves for New Robes
description: Stories by lawyers about lawyers are often guilty of grandstanding for the jury (thats us), and early in the first episode of Silk the barrister heroine is told, apropos of not much: Fifteen years youve been doing this and you still believe, dont you? Innocent until proven guilty. Just in case we missed the point, its repeated by her a few minutes later: Innocent until proven guilty. Four words to live by.

title: Go East Old Man: Off The Reservation
description: Dexter Ford is traveling from Southern California to upstate New York along mostly obscure roads, on a motorcycle that, by American standards, is quite tiny. This is the fourth of his occasional reports from the paths less traveled.

title: Untangling a Mesh of Identities
description: Its tough enough to be a teenager in New York City. Try this formula for confusion: I am a Palestinian-Lebanese-American Christian woman, but I grew up as a Jew in New York City. I began my life, however, as a WASP.

title: Playing Spy, Sans Violence
description: If you want to keep your hands, I want names, an American spy growls at one point in the new video game Tom Clancys Splinter Cell: Blacklist. The man he is yelling at is on the ground, arms stretched, wrists trapped between the nearly closed legs of a folding chair. Our hero, the spy, whom we control in most of the game, is torturing this other man for information. Hes worried about another terrorist attack in the United States, which would be the second one in Blacklist.

title: Car Bombs Kill Dozens in Lebanon
description: Two deadly explosions killed dozens and wounded hundreds in the largely Sunni Muslim city of Tripoli in northern Lebanon.

title: Stopped Cold: Mercedes Sales Blocked in France
description: BERLIN  Even as showrooms in Europe prepare for the arrival of 2014 vehicles, authorities in France have sparked controversy with a drastic action: blocking the registration  effectively shutting down sales  of some popular new Mercedes-Benz cars, including the A-Class, B-Class, CLA and SL models.

title: Your Earrings Remind Me of Grandmas Gran Torino
description: DETROIT  With its layers of colors and psychedelic swirls, fordite resembles jasper or Mexican crazy lace. And though fordite is crafted into eye-catching jewelry, it is not a gemstone  rather, it is dried paint that built up, layer upon layer, in factories that built automobiles long ago.

title: Wood That Proudly Wears the Marks of Previous Use
description: VENICE  Those poles look so old, my companion said, pointing to the striped barber poles lining the canals. I wonder how long they last in that salt water?

title: Taking Beethoven on a Mashed-Up Quirky Adventure
description: We have come almost automatically to associate Beethoven with impressions of fist-shaking temperament and eternity-pondering quest. But during his lifetime, one popular work cast him in a different light not particularly to his liking. His Septet in E-flat (Op. 20), introduced in 1800 when he was 29, reportedly caused strangers to ask why he didnt write more in its sunny, vivacious and genteel style.

title: Richard Simmons, Internet Star?
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Richard, honey, youve got lipstick on your teeth.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking: Aug. 23, 2013
description: How vulnerable are financial markets to computer glitches? The Nasdaq stock exchange was paralyzed for more than three hours this week because of technical problem and Goldman Sachs reportedly lost $100 million after erroneous algorithmic trades. Joe Nocera of The New York Times and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine spoke with Heidi Moore of the Guardian on WNYCs Money Talking about the real impact of software malfunctions on financial markets and what regulators can do about it.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, Egypt, Japan and Syria.

title: A Jazz Host Remembered as Inspiration
description: Marian McPartland, who died on Tuesday at 95, was an erudite jazz pianist whose career stretched back to the heyday of 52nd Street. But she will be best remembered for Marian McPartlands Piano Jazz, the public radio show she hosted for more than 30 years, featuring duets and conversation with an array of musicians.

title: Making the Rounds at Boxing and Brunch
description: The composer and lyricist William Finn lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and spends his summers at Wasabi Gables. Thats what he and his longtime partner, Arthur Salvadore, call their corner Victorian house in Pittsfield, Mass., for its exterior hue. Mr. Finn, 61, a two-time Tony Award winner, has been the artistic director since 2006 of the Musical Theater Lab at the Barrington Stage Company, up the block. There he was part of the team that developed and premiered The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee before its Off Broadway and Broadway success. After two years of revision, Little Miss Sunshine, by Mr. Finn and the librettist James Lapine, will open off Broadway this fall at Second Stage. On the last summer Sundays, Mr. Finn will socialize with Barrington Stages director, Julianne Boyd, and go to productions, when not serving as M.C. for Mr. Finns Cabaret at the theater. Rather than seeking rest, he looks for the joy in work and play.

title: A Surprising Reversal for Emerging Stock Markets
description: FOR more than a decade, investors loved emerging markets. Now many seem to fear them.

title: Syrian Kurds Flee to Northern Iraq

When Isabelle Olsson, the lead industrial designer for Google Glass, arrived at Diane von Furstenbergs New York studio to fit models for the new device, she wasnt concerned about how the models would look strutting along the runway wearing tiny screens and computers on their faces.

title: Thai Officials Play Down Effects of Oil Spill
description: KOH SAMET, Thailand  Two rescue operations were set in motion last month when a burst pipeline sent tons of crude oil gushing into the sea near this idyllic resort island. One was cleaning up the spill. The other was defending the image of Thailands tourism industry, crucial to the countrys increasingly fragile economy.

title: Strolling and Playing, but No More Saluting
description: On a map, New Yorks biggest summer playground looks just like an ice cream cone, shaped for the citys enjoyment. Governors Island was an Army base until 1966, then used by the Coast Guard through the mid-1990s. It opened to the public in 2004, with guests first arriving in small numbers. But times change: on a recent weekend, 12,000 visitors took a free ferry from Brooklyn Bridge Park or the Beaux-Arts Battery Maritime Building in Lower Manhattan to enjoy the 172-acre islands lawns, historic buildings, food carts and arts programs  all open Saturdays, Sundays and holiday Mondays through Sept. 29.

title: Dancing Erotically, With Knives
description: HUDSON, N.Y.  The knives are always out. They hang, in a neat and gleaming row of nine, above the sink of the fashionable London home that is the setting for Stockholm, Bryony Laverys sharp and twisting liebestod of a play, which has been given a smashing American premiere at Stageworks/Hudson here.

title: The Fine Print of Dvoraks Contract
description: The contract that brought Antonin Dvorak to New York to lead the National Conservatory of Music of America allowed him to earn more than 25 times what he had been earning in Prague, and opened a very fruitful period of his career in which he wrote some of his best-loved works, including the New World Symphony and the Cello Concerto. While its details have long been known to scholars, one of the original signed contracts  discovered recently by the great-grandson of the conservatorys founder, Jeannette Thurber, and purchased by the Dvorak American Heritage Association  will be displayed publicly for the first time on Sept. 8 at the Bohemian National Hall at 321 East 73rd Street in Manhattan.

title: The Deal That Brought Dvorak to New York
description: It was an audacious act of Gilded Age New York. Jeannette Thurber, a wealthy patron trying to create not just a new American music school but, more broadly, a new American school of music, decided in 1891 to hire one of the greatest composers of the day: Antonin Dvorak.

title: Styles Reach Beyond Appearances
description: On Thursday evening at Drive East, the festival of South Asian music and dance running at La MaMa, an exuberant South Korean dancer took center stage. Jin Won, that dancer and a resident of India for 15 years, specializes in Kathak, a form of classical Indian dance. But as a skilled tabla player, shes also as much a musician as a dancer.

description: This year, a study administered by researchers at Harvard and Stanford drew significant attention for what it revealed about how inadequately low-income students are represented at selective colleges and universities. Only 34 percent of the highest-achieving high-school seniors whose families fell in the bottom quarter of income distribution  versus 78 percent in the top quarter  attended one of the countrys most selective colleges, based on a list of nearly 250 schools compiled by Barrons.

On the rough edge of the Fort Peck Indian Reservation, with a graduating high school class of just 40 students, it offers the kind of small town life many young men join the military to flee from, never to return.

title: Editors Letter
description: As this is a fashion issue, and there is plenty of alluring fashion in these pages, I thought Id start the issue off with a short note about books. Well, about physical objects really. We photographed writers with forthcoming books  Jonathan Lethem, Edwidge Danticat, Richard Dawkins, Jhumpa Lahiri and Julian Barnes  at home in their work spaces. Quite frankly, none of the spaces look that remarkable; there are no bursts of design genius or eccentric collections. Just what one might expect: wood tables, crowded bookshelves, laptops, messy desks. But as you read each writers essay about their space, you understand the resonance these ordinary, simple things convey to each of them. Value is something we bestow upon objects  whether a picture tacked on the wall, a mess of papers, an old typewriter. We animate the inanimate through our memories, associations and desires.
