title: T Fall Womens Issue
description: Ts fall Womens Fashion issue is all about the ladies: Rooney Maras visceral performances in complex films (David Amsden gets to her core), Victoria Beckhams injection of chic sophistication into her ready-to-wear line, and this centurys greatest botanical artists stunning, otherworldly creations. Suzy Menkes investigates where the fashion industry has broken down and why its so impossible to get our hands on a retail coat in winter, while Howie Kahn immerses us in the sights and smells of Shanghais exploding culinary scene. You will also find photographs of where modern writers work and where the Milanese designers of Dimore Studio live. Plus, the photographer Glen Luchford captures the seasons bold, graphic prints amid the cacophony of New York City; Amy Schumer and Aerin Lauder test-drive a snood; the artist Ranee Palone Flynn shares the process behind shooting total strangers; and velvet returns to its place atop the high-fashion throne. See all stories from the issue >>

title: War on Egypts Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Christie and Gay Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Operator Raises Alarm on Crisis
description: TOKYO  The operator of Japans tsunami-hit nuclear power plant sounded the alarm on the gravity of the deepening crisis of containment at the coastal site on Friday, saying that there are more than 200,000 tons of radioactive water in makeshift tanks vulnerable to leaks, with no reliable way to check on them or anywhere to transfer the water.

title: Biggest Sale of Year in Europe Appears to Be Near Finish
description: The Gareth Bale transfer drama appeared Friday to be reaching its merciful, and seemingly inevitable, end. Tottenham Hotspur worked to complete a deal to move Bale, its talented Welsh wing, to Real Madrid for a price that would almost certainly top the world-record fee that Madrid paid to acquire Cristiano Ronaldo in 2009.

title: New Rules Would Cut Silica Dust Exposure
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration proposed long-awaited rules on Friday to limit crystalline silica, a move it said would prevent nearly 700 deaths a year by reducing exposure to these very small particles that can cause lung cancer and other diseases.

title: The Ugly American Telegram
description: BOSTON  ON Aug. 24, 1963, the American ambassador to South Vietnam, Henry Cabot Lodge, received a top-secret message with the bureaucratically anodyne title Deptel 243. But the content of the message was anything but routine. Hastily drafted and cleared over the course of a single day, with most of official Washington on vacation, Deptel 243, also known as the Hilsman telegram, signaled a major shift in American policy. A few days later Mr. Lodge remarked, We are launched on a course from which there is no respectable turning back.

title: Qualifying Chronicles: Answering Reader Questions
description: Irina Falconi, a 23-year-old American, who lost in the first round of qualifying, is writing posts for Straight Sets from the United States Open this year. You can also follow her on tumblr and Twitter.

title: I Have a Character Issue
description: LOS ANGELES  PLAYING Skyler White on the television show Breaking Bad for the past five seasons has been one of the most rewarding creative journeys Ive embarked on as an actor. But the role has also taken me on another kind of journey  one I never would have imagined.

title: A Blunt Chief Justice Unafraid to Upset Brazils Status Quo
description: BRASLIA  Brazils highest court has long viewed itself as a bastion of manners and formality. Justices call one another Your Excellency, dress in billowing robes and wrap each utterance in grandiloquence, as if little had changed from the era when marquises and dukes held sway from their vast plantations.

title: Settlement in Lawsuit Against Paula Deen
description: The legal battle that led to the near-instant collapse of Paula Deens multimillion-dollar food empire ended on Friday when the last pieces of a lawsuit, filed by a former manager at one of her restaurants, were resolved in a settlement agreement.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: A few months ago, a saleswoman at Macys tried to wheedle me into renewing my expired store credit card by offering a deep discount on the towels I was buying. So I dug it out of my wallet, where it was nestled between an expired press pass to the Texas State Capitol and an expired library card from Manchester, N.H., and happily handed it over.

title: A Dream Examined
description: A half-century after the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, disparities in education, employment, housing and wages still exist.

title: Apple and Microsoft, Then and Now
description: If you picked up The New York Times in December 2000, you would have seen very different headlines than exist today. Microsoft was projected to generate revenue of $6.4 billion for the last fiscal quarter of 2000, whereas Apple, the companys almost-lifeless competitor, was clawing to reach $1 billion in revenue.

title: At a Fed Conference, Views Differ Sharply on Stimuluss Effect
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  There is still plenty of skepticism about the stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and other central banks, and there is plenty of concern about the consequences. But for the first time in several years, there was also a general sense of optimism among the policy makers gathered here for an annual meeting at the foot of the Grand Tetons that things are going reasonably well.

title: The Next Hurricane, and the Next
description: Hurricane Sandy, the monster storm that hit the Atlantic Seaboard on Oct. 29, left at least 159 dead and caused $65 billion in damages. But as a presidential task force made clear this week, Sandy cannot be considered a seasonal disaster or regional fluke but as yet another harbinger of the calamities that await in an era of climate change. With that in mind, the report says that individuals, local governments and states that expect federal help cannot simply restore what was there but must adopt new standards and harden community structures to withstand the next flood or hurricane.

title: A Good Deal Gone Bad
description: In 2007, the president of Ecuador, Rafael Correa, offered the world a deal: find $3.6 billion and he would institute a permanent moratorium on oil drilling in the Amazons Yasuni National Park, one of the most biologically diverse places on the planet.

title: Finding Lessons in Stumbles, American Aims for the Top Again
description: When the draw for the United States Open was made Thursday, Ryan Harrisons name again appeared next to that of one of the biggest stars in the sport. This time, it was Rafael Nadal, the No. 2 seed, who comes to New York with a 10-match winning streak and a 15-0 record on hardcourts.

title: Air War in Kosovo Seen as Precedent in Possible Response to Syria Chemical Attack
description: WASHINGTON  As President Obama weighs options for responding to a suspected chemical weapons attack in Syria, his national security aides are studying the NATO air war in Kosovo as a possible blueprint for acting without a mandate from the United Nations.

title: Hedge Funds Win Ruling in Argentina Bond Case
description: A dogged group of hedge funds secured a significant victory in a federal appeals court on Friday in a case that is likely to have far-reaching effects on international bond markets, parts of the banking system and the struggling nation of Argentina.

title: Dean Meminger, Who Helped Knicks to a Title, Dies at 65
description: Dean Meminger, a speedy guard and tenacious defender who honed his basketball style in Harlem playgrounds and went on to play for the Knicks 1973 N.B.A. title team, was pronounced dead on Friday in a hotel room in Upper Manhattan. He was 65.

title: In Paper War, Flood of Liens Is the Weapon
description: MINNEAPOLIS  One of the first inklings Sheriff Richard Stanek had that something was wrong came with a call from the mortgage company handling his refinancing.

title: After Mishaps, Nasdaq Loses Standing to Rivals
description: Nasdaq was once the upstart of the financial world, set to take over the American stock market. Now, the company is looking more like a vulnerable also-ran.

title: Questions for Microsoft as It Nears a Crossroad
description: Microsofts plan, announced Friday, to replace Steven A. Ballmer as its chief executive does not exactly follow  at least to people outside the company  the way they draft these things in business school.

title: Tom Christian, Descendant of Bounty Mutineer, Dies at 77
description: Tom Christian, known as the Voice of Pitcairn for his half-century-long role in keeping his tiny South Pacific island, famed as the refuge of the Bounty mutineers, connected to the world, died at his home there on July 7. Mr. Christian, Pitcairns chief radio officer and a great-great-great-grandson of Fletcher Christian, the mutinys leader, was 77.

title: Second Day of Barclays Is Another Marathon, This One in Fair Weather
description: JERSEY CITY  Phil Mickelsons day began at 7:02 a.m., and when it finally ended, 31 holes later, he was on the ninth green, more than a mile away from the Liberty National Golf Course clubhouse. A white van stood ready to whisk him back, the same van that delivered him out onto the course four and a half hours earlier.

title: N.S.A. Said to Have Paid E-Mail Providers Millions to Cover Costs From Court Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The National Security Agency apparently compensated e-mail service providers millions of dollars for costs they incurred in the fallout from an October 2011 court ruling that an unrelated aspect of the agencys surveillance operations violated the Constitution, according to a newly disclosed document.

title: A Troubled Teenager at Odds With Life in the Bronx
description: To those who did not know him, Shaaliver Douse was an example of everything that can go wrong in a young life.

title: Syria: U.N. Notes Shameful Milestone
description: One million children are now refugees from the conflict raging in Syria, the United Nations reported Friday, calling it a shameful milestone in a crisis now well into its third year. Anthony Lake, executive director of the United Nations Childrens Fund, and Antnio Guterres, the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said in a joint statement that half of all refugees forced to flee Syria were children and that 740,000 of those children were younger than 11 years old. The statement also said that more than 7,000 children had been killed in Syria, where the total death toll in the conflict has surpassed 100,000.

title: On Detectives Play List, the Ballad of the Oblivious Victim
description: A 27-year-old Brooklyn man began last Saturday healthy enough, but by midmorning had four new holes in him. This much everyone agrees on.

title: Mexico: Bodies Linked to Abduction
description: The remains of five bodies pulled from a mass grave discovered this week in Tlalmanalco have been identified as members of a group of young people who vanished from a bar in May, the attorney general said Friday. Twelve people disappeared from the Heaven nightclub in a bustling neighborhood in Mexico City, where residents are not accustomed to the brazen acts of violence that have convulsed other regions of the country. Relatives of the victims have complained about the investigations slow progress. The mass grave, 30 miles east of Mexico City, contained 13 craniums, the attorney generals office said.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 24, 2013
description: I never intended to be a mayor who went out like this.

title: Man Arriving at J.F.K. Is Accused of Trying to Export Uranium to Iran
description: The request posted last year on the Web site alibaba.com was surprisingly straightforward for such a dubious proposition.

title: A Comeback for Negro Leagues Museum
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  With an actors showmanship, a man wearing black glasses and a white fedora described the player behind each of the 10 bronze statues that greeted a small group of visitors inside the lobby of the Negro Leagues Baseball Museum.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bloomberg Shares a Few Secrets of His Success: Be Early, Stay Late and Hold It In
description: He went from Eagle Scout to Wall Street titan, designed a machine that sits on bankers desks around the world and reshaped notions of New York City government.

title: 50 Years Later
description: As we approach the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, I have a gnawing in my gut, an uneasy sense of society and its racial reality.

title: Jets Activate Holmes, Who May Make Opener
description: Santonio Holmes was removed from the physically unable to perform list and added to the active roster Friday, a sign that he could be available for the Sept. 8 season opener. If Holmes is able to return then  or soon after  he will provide a lift to an unproven receiving corps, as well as to the quarterback, whoever wins that job.

title: Corrections: August 24, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Flip a Coin
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The Zairian ZAIRE, a now-defunct currency that bore the portrait of Mobuto Sese Seko, was replaced in 1998 by the Congolese franc after the nation changed its name to Democratic Republic of Congo. The zaire was one of just a handful of world currencies whose name matched, or roughly matched, the name of the country that issued it. Other examples include Afghanistans afghani, Bolivias boliviano and of course the French franc. This currency club is as varied in membership as THE UN, which is itself one of several internationally oriented answers in the all-encompassing Saturday puzzle from Frederick J. Healy that manages to touch on geography in GHANA and animal species in ASIA.

title: The New Nuclear Craze
description: There is a new discussion about nuclear energy, prompted by well-founded concerns about carbon emissions and fueled by a pro-nuclear documentary called Pandoras Promise. Add a statement by James E. Hansen  who famously sounded the alarm on climate change  and, of course, industry propaganda, and presto: We Love Nukes.

title: C Train Cafe? Transit Agency May Put Up Fight
description: New York is a hucksters paradise, the province of the fake Rolex and the sham Prada purse, counterfeit Yankees tickets and a Times Square teeming with impostor Elmos.

title: Tom Ewings Dirty War
description: Thomas Ewing Jr. was a conscientious man. Though never as flamboyant as his foster brother, William Tecumseh Sherman, Ewing was ambitious for political fame and fortune, as befitted the son of one of Ohios leading Whig politicians. His father had served both in the United States Senate and in the cabinets of Presidents William Henry Harrison and Zachary Taylor. Thomas Ewing Jr., or Tom, was his fathers personal secretary when the elder Ewing ran Taylors Department of the Interior.

title: Staten Island Ferry Exploring Free Wi-Fi Onboard and in Terminals
description: The Staten Island Ferry, known for its free rides and inexpensive beer, may soon add another amenity: Internet access.

title: New York City Election Choices
description: Public AdvocateThe job of public advocate is little more than a bullhorn, and sometimes not even that. The original purpose of this position was to give citizens a voice in City Hall and serve as a watchdog on the mayor and the city government. But the jobs influence has been whittled away by a succession of mayors, and its budget is a mere $2.2 million, barely enough to pay the electric bills and a few modest salaries. Its only real power comes if the mayor dies or resigns; the public advocate takes over until an election can be held in a few months.

title: Questions About Republicans Citizenship
description: Senator Ted Cruz faced criticism over his dual Canadian citizenship while campaigning against the Affordable Care Act in Texas. His birthplace calls into question his eligibility to run for president.

title: Inside Job Is Considered in Armored-Car Robbery
description: The armored truck was waiting near a Pay-O-Matic check-cashing store in south Brooklyn, when the driver heard a knock on the rear door. So he unlocked it. He later told investigators that he had assumed that the vehicles guard had been knocking, having finished his pickup at the check-cashing store. But the man who entered the armored truck was not his partner. It was a gunman with a scarf wrapped around his head.

title: Weighing Pain of Traffic for Preseason Games
description: Traffic is as much a part of the modern sports experience as the game itself, but not all event congestion is created equal.

title: Yankees Playoff Push Takes Step Backward
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  After a week spent beating up the worst team in the American League East, the Yankees were flush with confidence and energized to find themselves back in a playoff race most people thought had passed them by. But once they flew south to face off against one of the best teams in the division, things did not go quite as smoothly.

title: Jos Sarria, Gay Advocate and Performer, Dies at 90
description: Jos Sarria, a drag performer and gay rights advocate who many historians contend was the first openly gay person to campaign for public office in the United States when he ran for the San Francisco Board of Supervisors in 1961, died on Monday at his home in Los Ranchos de Albuquerque, N.M. He was 90.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business
description: Bloomberg L.P. said it would change its journalism operation, trading on the Nasdaq was halted for three hours and Home Depot reported earnings that exceeded projections.

title: Cabrera and Tigers Rock Matsuzaka in His Mets Debut
description: The last time Terry Collins saw Daisuke Matsuzaka pitch in person  a first-round matchup of the 2009 World Baseball Classic  Collins was Chinas manager and considered the Japanese ace to be one of the best pitchers in the world.

title: Red Sox Ortiz Plays Down His Remarks on Incident With Rodriguez
description: LOS ANGELES  If David Ortiz was bothered that his teammate Ryan Dempster plunked Alex Rodriguez, he found a new source of exasperation as he stood at his locker Friday afternoon  that people were still asking him about it.

title: Car Bombs Explode in Tripoli
description: The blasts killed at least 27 and wounded over 350, wreaking major destruction in the countrys second largest city

title: Criminal Complaint Against Patrick Campbell
description: Read the full criminal complaint against Patrick Campbell, accused of trying to sell yellowcake uranium to Iran.

title: Preserving the Games History
description: The Negro Leagues Baseball Museum displays players uniforms, signed balls and life-size sculptures of some stars.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) LIFE OF PI (2012) Based on the novel by Yann Martel and directed by Ang Lee, this tale chronicles the life of Pi Patel (Suraj Sharma, above), the son of an Indian zoo owner who becomes stranded on a boat in the Pacific and must fight not only dehydration and starvation, but also a Bengal tiger, to survive. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that this film, which received four Oscars, including best director, best cinematography and best special effects, unfolds in a setting that is one of the great achievements of digital cinema, and a reminder that the eclectic Mr. Lee is, among other things, an exuberant and inventive visual artist. He added: There are images in Life of Pi that are so beautiful, so surprising, so right that I hesitate to describe them. Suffice it to say that the simple, elemental facts of sky, sea and animal life are captured with sweetness and sublimity.

title: Fallen Chinese Official, at His Trial, Faces Accuser Who Set Scandal in Motion
description: JINAN, China  In a dramatic high point of his trial, Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, faced off in court on Saturday with Wang Lijun, the former police chief whose flight to an American consulate last year set off the biggest scandal to shake the party in decades.

title: 2 More Are Arrested in the Rape of a Photojournalist in India
description: MUMBAI  The police in Mumbai on Saturday arrested two more men accused of raping a photojournalist who was attacked while on assignment for an English-language magazine.

title: Obama and Advisers to Discuss Syria
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is expected to meet with his national security advisers on Saturday morning to discuss reports of a chemical weapons attack by the Syrian government and how the United States might respond, a White House official said.

title: VMware Killed the Past. Can It Claim the Future?
description: VMware is a 15-year-old tech company with a market capitalization of $36 billion. Next week, it will host 21,000 customers in San Francisco and will start to find out if that means it is young or old.

title: How Ballmer Missed the Tidal Shifts in Tech
description: By now, youve probably heard: Steven A. Ballmer will soon be stepping down as chief executive of Microsoft.

title: On The Symmetry Between Microsoft And Apple
description: I am not a tech industry maven, so I am busy coming up to speed on the implications of the Ballmer resignation. And what Im about to say may be obvious to many. Still, I think its worth saying: there is, once you look past the surface, a remarkable symmetry between Microsofts strategy in its heyday and Apples strategy today.

title: Trying to Inspire a New Generation
description: WASHINGTON  Half a century after the emotional apex of the civil rights movement, Martin Luther King Jr.'s I Have a Dream speech, tens of thousands of people retraced his footsteps on Saturday, and his successors in the movement spoke of the still-unmet promise of America, as he did, at the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Maybe Theyll Never Figure It Out
description: Kathleen Geier points to some polling Id missed: 39 percent of Americans agree that the government should stay out of Medicare, while only 46 percent disagree; the rest arent sure. She also points to the Suzanne Mettler work showing that many beneficiaries of Social Security and Medicare believe that they have never benefited from a government program.

title: Scenes From the 50th Anniversary of the March on Washington
description: Last Updated | 9:24 p.m. As my colleagues reported, tens of thousands of people from across the country streamed onto the National Mall on Saturday for a daylong commemoration of the approaching 50th anniversary of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom.

title: Growth in Tennis? Tape Measure Is Telling
description: One recent breezy evening in Montreal, Juan Martn del Potro traded powerful serves and thunderous forehands with Milos Raonic for two otherwise uninspiring sets, won by Raonic. This tale of tall tennis players highlighted what many have contended  and in some cases feared  will be the future of mens professional tennis.

title: In Race for N.L. M.V.P., Gomez Deserves Votes
description: For many years the basic formula for deciding who would win the Most Valuable Player award came down to the triple crown statistics  batting average, home run and runs batted in  and the record of the players team. There were occasional exceptions, but if a player had 140 R.B.I. for a first-place team, he had a good chance of receiving Major League Baseballs highest single-season honor.

title: Mandelas Condition Remains Critical but Stable
description: JOHANNESBURG  Former President Nelson Mandelas health remains critical but stable, the South African government said Saturday, but doctors are required to make medical interventions when his health becomes unstable, according to a statement released by the office of President Jacob Zuma.

title: Linebacker Settles In, at Last, With the Jets
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Linebacker Garrett McIntyre exuded pride as he assessed a seven-year professional football career that has taken him to two countries, three leagues and six teams.

title: Variety: Rainy Day Moods
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Todays food for thought comes from the American writer David Mamet, who comments on the nature of mans self-obsession and dramatization  going so far as to suggest that we all draw parallels between our internal lives and the weather. Since the weather reflecting mood trope is a common literary device, its entirely appropriate that this quote comes from a playwright.

title: Signs of Chemical Attack Detailed by Aid Group
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An international aid group said Saturday that medical centers it supported near the site of a suspected chemical weapons attack near Damascus received more than 3,000 patients showing symptoms consistent with exposure to toxic nerve agents on the morning of the reported attack.

title: What Happened to the Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby?
description: Have you looked at the cars around you recently? I mean, really looked at them? I guess it depends on where you live, but theres a pretty good chance that many of the vehicles you see at any given time will be silver, black, white, gray or some sort of brown or muted blue.

title: Game in Transition, Wozniacki Remains Relaxed and Confident
description: No one can accuse Caroline Wozniacki of lacking fighting spirit, on and off the court. She has landed her fair share of lashings from the news media over the years, but she isnt afraid of giving as good as she gets, given a chance.

title: Golf Couples Vows: To Love and to Honor, and to Read Greens
description: JERSEY CITY  Patrick Reed hit balls on the driving range while listening to the indie rock band Imagine Dragons on his MP3 player, which was in the left front pocket of his golf pants. Upon completing his warm-up, he pulled his ear buds out. For the rest of an abbreviated workday Friday at Liberty National Golf Club, Reeds wife, Justine, was in his ear.

title: Dean Meminger: The Dream Who Was a Delight to Coach
description: What Willis Reed liked to call Deans game was remarkable not only because the Knicks handed the Celtics their first Game 7 playoff defeat on their home floor. It was also because the great Earl Monroe never got off the bench after Dean Meminger replaced him at the start of the second quarter.

title: A New Book Offers a View of the Game That Tailgaters Rarely Encounter
description: Getting inside the body of the college football industry and examining it, organ by organ, might be compared to an exploration of the human body. The resulting emotions range wider than the country in which the sport is played  amazement and anxiety, wonderment and worry.

title: Aug. 24: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Guru of the Long Snap
description: AUBURN, Mass.  Chris Rubio was dissecting the art of long snapping for the benefit of 23 teenagers and their parents on an unseasonably cool morning last month. He used words like balance and extension as he dabbled in the minutiae of a craft that he considers a science.

title: Ignoring Qualms, Some Republicans Nurture Dreams of Impeaching Obama
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Kerry Bentivolio, a freshman Republican from Michigan, has a legislative dream. It is not to balance the federal budget, or find a way to help his ailing state or even take away money from the federal health care program, a goal that has so animated many other Republicans this summer.

title: Be Yourself,  Redfins Glenn Kelman Says, Even if Youre a Little Goofy
description: This interview with  Glenn Kelman, chief executive of Redfin, the online real estate site, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: For Red Bulls, First Place for the Taking
description: Only three points separate the top five teams in the Eastern Conference of Major League Soccer before games Saturday and Sunday. And the Red Bulls, a club that has lost only once in its past six games, is a prime position to take sole possession of the top spot.

title: At the Coaches Car Wash
description: Fifty top college football coaches flock to ESPNs headquarters to discuss the season. The event, known as the Coaches Car Wash, shows how the network has become as big as the games.

title: College Footballs Most Dominant Player? Its ESPN
description: The nations annual rite of mayhem and pageantry known as the college football season begins this week, and Saturday will feature back-to-back-to-back marquee matchups.

title: Steve Ballmer, Meet Ibn Khaldun
description: Microsoft is still a very profitable company; with some reforms, it will probably endure for a long time, sort of like the post-Diocletian Roman Empire. But you dont need David Pogue to tell you  although it helps  that Microsoft missed the boat, big time, on major shifts in the technological landscape. And now the very network externalities that solidified its former dominance probably stand in the way of any attempt to return to past glories.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Blocking Health Reform
description: Readers discuss Republican efforts to undercut Obamacare.

title: Coaches Talk of Injuries, Trying to Slow the Spread
description: In recent seasons, programs across the country turned toward sped-up spread offenses, often without huddles, schemes found at the intersection between football and track and field. It was the latest craze.

title: Where Sand Is Gold, the Reserves Are Running Dry
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  With inviting beaches that run for miles along South Floridas shores, it is easy to put sand into the same category as turbo air-conditioning and a decent mojito  something ever present and easily taken for granted.

title: A College President, Drawn to Uncertainties
description: I GREW up literally on the wrong side of the tracks in Paoli, Pa. My father was a printer  he fed paper into big presses; my mother sold Avon products and held various secretarial jobs. Because Paoli is adjacent to the more affluent Main Line of Philadelphia, I became sensitive at an early age to class differences and racial dissonance.

title: Amgen Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Onyx for $10.5 Billion
description: Updated, Aug. 25, 7:38 p.m. | Amgen announced on Sunday that it has agreed to buy Onyx for $125 a share.

title: Fresh Leadership for Stale Phillies
description: Ruben Amaro Jr. has prepared for this moment since before he was born, in Philadelphia in the winter after the 1964 baseball season, when a pennant slipped away from the Phillies. His father was the shortstop.

title: Thrill of Family Replaces Thrill of Game for Clijsters
description: Last years United States Open was Kim Clijsterss swan song. A three-time Open champion, Clijsters retired for the second time. This year, she will be watching the tournament from her home in Belgium, where she is expecting her second child, a boy, with her husband, the retired basketball player Brian Lynch. She has spent the year as a fan, particularly of her friend and fellow Belgian Kirsten Flipkens, who reached the semifinals of Wimbledon. She remains involved in tennis as a WTA ambassador for USANA Health Sciences, and is renovating and developing a tennis club and academy in her hometown, Bree. This interview was edited and condensed.

title: Addicted to Apps
description: SAN FRANCISCO  IN Silicon Valley, that fairy-tale land of robots and driverless cars, a deeply held belief motivates all: If you build it, they will come.

title: Monopoly Goes Corporate
description: ITS been a rough summer for Monopoly purists.

title: Reindeer Games
description: WASHINGTON  ON the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.s I Have a Dream speech, Kerry Bentivolio, a Michigan congressman, has a dream, too: to impeach the nations first black president.

title: A Different Kind of Division
description: THREE months before the 1963 March on Washington, whose 50th anniversary falls this week, officials in Birmingham, Ala., opened fire hoses and loosed dogs on civil rights protesters. Two months before the march, the civil rights organizer Medgar Evers was murdered outside his home in Jackson, Miss. And a few weeks after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s I Have Dream Speech echoed down the Washington Mall, a bomb ripped open Birminghams 16th Street Baptist Church, killing four little girls.

title: The Death Memo
description: Fifty years ago this month, a young man and an older man sat down and began to plot the end of the death penalty in America.

title: The Problem That Has Two Names
description: FIFTY years after Betty Friedans Feminine Mystique and countless principled-but-unwieldy hyphenated names later, the problem of married versus maiden names should be good and solved. But many women are still caught in an in-between purgatory: why have to choose?

title: Florian Ortkrass
description: Florian Ortkrass is a founder and director of Random International, a group of London-based artists who combine technology and natural elements to create temporary, interactive installations, including the recent Rain Room at the Musuem of Modern Art. Another work, Tower, an appearing and disappearing water structure, opened on Friday at the Ruhrtriennale international arts festival in Germany.

title: Foreign Policy by Whisper and Nudge
description: IF you follow the commentary on American foreign policy toward Egypt and the broader Middle East today, several themes stand out: People in the region argue: Whatever went wrong, the United States is to blame. Foreign policy experts argue: Whatever President Obama did, he got it wrong. And the American public is saying: Were totally fed up with that part of the world and cant wait for the start of the N.F.L. season. How do you like those 49ers?

title: Im Thinking. Please. Be Quiet.
description: SLAMMING doors, banging walls, bellowing strangers and whistling neighbors were the bane of the philosopher Arthur Schopenhauers existence. But it was only in later middle age, after he had moved with his beloved poodle to the commercial hub of Frankfurt, that his sense of being tortured by loud, often superfluous blasts of sound ripened into a philosophical diatribe. Then, around 1850, Schopenhauer pronounced noise to be the supreme archenemy of any serious thinker.

title: In Syria, America Loses if Either Side Wins
description: WASHINGTON  ON Wednesday, reports surfaced of a mass chemical-weapons attack in the Damascus suburbs that human rights activists claim killed hundreds of civilians, bringing Syrias continuing civil war back onto the White Houses foreign policy radar, even as the crisis in Egypt worsens.

title: Working for Nothing
description: After graduating from school I despaired of finding a job and applied instead for unpaid internships, landing at The Paris Review, a literary magazine in Manhattan. I read through the slush pile, learned how to fact-check and performed light janitorial tasks, like emptying the dishwasher and taking out the trash. It was a fine four months. My parents lived in the city, so I didnt have to pay rent; the editors were kind, smart people who seemed appropriately embarrassed by the trash situation.

title: How Technology Wrecks the Middle Class
description: In the four years since the Great Recession officially ended, the productivity of American workers  those lucky enough to have jobs  has risen smartly. But the United States still has two million fewer jobs than before the downturn, the unemployment rate is stuck at levels not seen since the early 1990s and the proportion of adults who are working is four percentage points off its peak in 2000.

title: Public Policies, Made to Fit People
description: I HAVE written here before about the potential gains to government from involving social and behavioral scientists in designing public policies. My enthusiasm comes in part from my experiences as an academic adviser to the Behavioral Insights Team created in Britain by Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: Around the Nation: Players, Teams and Story Lines to Watch
description: Examining some of the to players and intriguing story lines this season.

title: For a Chef, 41 Years in the Kitchen Takes Its Toll
description: STARTING as a dishwasher at the age of 17, the chef Mark Peel worked his way up at some of the great California restaurants: Ma Maison, Michaels, Chez Panisse, Spago, Chinois and, finally, for more than two decades, Campanile, his own place in Los Angeles.

title: New Jobs! If Only It Were True
description: CREATING jobs is an essential goal today, given our high unemployment rate. But when job programs rely on taxpayer backing, their success or failure should be clearly disclosed.

title: Accounts of Syrian Prisons Describe a Volatile Mix of Chaos and Control
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Ahmed Hamadeh had spent a year in a jail in a Damascus suburb when guards chained him to fellow inmates, marched them to an outlying military checkpoint, and ordered them to dig trenches for the soldiers. He concluded that the government had lost its mind, he recalled later, not only because the move risked a jailbreak, but also because of the arbitrary violence that followed.

title: Golden Rice: Lifesaver?
description: ONE bright morning this month, 400 protesters smashed down the high fences surrounding a field in the Bicol region of the Philippines and uprooted the genetically modified rice plants growing inside.

title: Dont Ask What Im Writing
description: No stage of the writing process  not the editors first response to the manuscript, not the review gauntlet  is as fraught for writers as those first few months of uncertainty: that miserable time when we think, believe, know with absolute assurance that weve found the key to the novel in our heads, though maybe, probably, definitely not.

title: What Is Economics Good For?
description: Recent debates over who is most qualified to serve as the next chairman of the Federal Reserve have focused on more than just the candidates theory-driven economic expertise. They have touched on matters of personality and character as well. This is as it should be. Given the nature of economies, and our ability to understand them, the task of the Feds next leader will be more a matter of craft and wisdom than of science.

title: The Chatter for Sunday, August 25
description: There will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings.

title: An Awkward Discovery at Work
description: Dear Workologist:

title: A Right Way to Be Wrong
description: IF the Haggler had a dime for every time hes said the real test of an organization is how it handles mistakes, the Haggler would now have four dimes. Maybe five. That may not seem like many dimes, especially now that a cup of coffee costs $2.50. But the Haggler does not enjoy repeating himself. Saying anything five times is excessive.

title: A Proud Nation Ponders How to Halt Its Slow Decline
description: PARIS  For decades, Europeans have agonized over the power and role of Germany  the so-called German question  given its importance to European stability and prosperity.

title: Power, Precision and Years to Grow
description: Madison Keys has begun her career with a bang, in large part because she begins points with a bang.

title: 5 Days After Closing Border, Egypt Opens Crossing to Gaza
description: GAZA  Egypt reopened its borders with the Gaza Strip on Saturday five days after closing the crossing, which had prevented people from entering or leaving the Palestinian enclave and deepened its isolation from the rest of the world.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Aug. 25
description: As the United Statesobserves the anniversary of the 1963 March on Washington, the Sunday shows will feature interviews with civil rights leaders and lawmakers about the state of the nation 50 years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s I Have a Dream speech.

title: Venus Williams Pushes Back, Hard, at the Twilight
description: During an appearance last week on Good Morning America to promote the United States Open, Venus Williams was barely a minute into the interview when the host committed an unforced error.

title: Central Bankers Say Emerging Economies Will Be Ready for Fed Exit
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  The stimulus campaigns of the Federal Reserve and the central banks of Europe and Japan, by depressing domestic interest rates, have helped to push trillions of dollars into developing markets in recent years.

title: Commercial Banks As Creators of Money
description: Thank you, Matthew Klein! In the course of critiquing Robert Halls paper for Jackson Hole, he mentions and links to another half-century-old paper by James Tobin, Commercial Banks as Creators of Money (pdf), that I had forgotten about, and is even more precisely on point than the Tobin-Brainard piece Ive been citing.

title: For Tennis Players, a Tech Lovers Paradise
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  The frontier of tennis technology is cordoned by a chain-link fence and protected from the elements by a yellowed canopy, a stretch of it torn away by one or another tropical storm. It is an open-air tinkerers garage, a 20-minute drive west from the beach here.

title: The Macroeconomics of Sisyphus
description: Simon Wren-Lewis is deeply annoyed at the IMF, and understandably so. How can you publish a paper about fiscal adjustment that explicitly takes no account of monetary policy, and claim that it has any relevance to current problems?

title: At 17, a Two-Time Grand Slam Finalist
description: With all the buzz around top players like Serena Williams and Tommy Haas playing well in their 30s, it might have been easy to overlook the teenage girl who made two Grand Slam finals this year.

title: At 40, a Doubles Specialist Just Keeps Going
description: When you have been on the tennis tour as long as the Canadian doubles specialist Daniel Nestor, there is no shortage of amusing stories, although the dates can get cloudy.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 3, Shot in Head, Police Say
description: A 3-year-old boy was shot in the head in his Brooklyn apartment early Saturday, the police said. A man, 22, who was in the apartment at the time was being questioned by detectives on Saturday evening, the police said.

title: Gilbert Enjoys Playing Name Games
description: Brad Gilbert is not necessarily the Chris Berman of professional tennis. He began experimenting with nicknames on the air seven or eight years ago, but his nicknames tend to be more off the cuff, more freewheeling, than preplanned. He does not always have carte blanche in sharing them.

title: Aug. 24: Speech by Representative Lewis
description: Representative John Lewis of Georgia addressed the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

title: Duda Is Back With the Mets
description: The Mets on Saturday recalled Lucas Duda from the minors and optioned outfielder Mike Baxter to Class AAA.

title: The Opens Breakthrough of 1973
description: Billie Jean King called it the year of insanity. She was talking about this year, when she has traveled around the world to promote the 40th anniversary of the Womens Tennis Association and to publicize two documentaries about her life.

title: Needed at Microsoft: A Catch-Up Artist
description: TWO months ago, Bill Gates met with members of the New York Times editorial board and a few editors and reporters. Public health was on his mind, and he spoke eloquently about the progress being made to combat diseases like tuberculosis and malaria, and the work of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

title: Capital Ls
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  It was right around the time that I came across the clue for John le Carr, the British writer who was once an employee of MI6, that I began to suspect that there was more to this Sunday puzzle than meets the eye. Was the mere inclusion of the author of spygame thrillers like Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy making me feel more paranoid?

title: Egypt Widens Crackdown and Meaning of Islamist
description: CAIRO  Having crushed the Muslim Brotherhood, the Egyptian authorities have begun cracking down on other dissenters, sometimes labeling even liberal activists or labor organizers as dangerous Islamists.

title: Aug. 24: Trayvon Martins Mother Speaks
description: Sybrina Fulton, Trayvon Martins mother, spoke to the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

title: The Next Mayor, a History
description: The New York Times has made an editorial choice in every mayoral election since 1897, a few years after the five boroughs of New York voted to consolidate into one city.

title: For New York Mayor
description: Christine Quinn, the Democratic Choice

title: Aug. 24: Martin Luther King III Speaks
description: Martin Luther King III spoke to the crowd during the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.

title: Five for the Heisman
description: A look at the top contenders to win the Heisman Trophy.

title: Fighting Education Overhaul, Thousands of Teachers Disrupt Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY  Mexicos highly anticipated education overhaul program  intended to weed out poorly performing teachers, establish professional hiring standards and weaken the powerful teachers union  is buckling under the tried-and-true tactic of huge street protests, throwing the heart of the capital into chaos.

title: Platinum Card and Text Alert, via Pawnshop
description: Linda Ballard, 61, uses the word love to describe her banking relationship, lauding the ease of cashing her bimonthly paycheck, the convenience of text alerts about her balance and the features on the platinum card that she was upgraded to in July.

title: Battling Superstition, Indian Paid With His Life
description: PUNE, India  For nearly three decades, an earnest man named Narendra Dabholkar traveled from village to village in India, waging a personal war against the spirit world.

title: Trump University Made False Claims, Lawsuit Says
description: The New York State attorney generals office filed a civil lawsuit on Saturday accusing Trump University, Donald J. Trumps for-profit investment school, of engaging in illegal business practices.

title: Father Knows Best: Romine Has Swing Coach Independent of Yankees
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Just by listening to his sons games on the radio, Kevin Romine can tell what Yankees catcher Austin Romine might be doing wrong at the plate. Kevin Romine played seven seasons with the Boston Red Sox, from 1985 to 1991, and knows plenty about hitting, and even more about his sons approach at the plate.

title: Other Nations Offer a Lesson to Egypts Military Leaders
description: LONDON  Is the era of the military big man back? In Egypt, where Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi led a populist putsch against the elected president, prison doors are swinging.

title: With Pressure Off, Murray Still Expects Some Nerves at U.S. Open
description: On media day at the United States Open, when many top players appeared eager to impress  or to at least manage expectations  no one looked more at ease than Andy Murray, the defending mens champion.

title: Harvey Isnt on His Game; With Scherzer Pitching, Neither Are the Mets
description: The indicators were plain: sliders that spun but did not swerve, fastballs that whizzed but failed to explode, changeups that floated along capricious paths.

title: Woodland Tied With Kuchar Atop Barclays
description: JERSEY CITY  The good news for Gary Woodland is he is tied for the lead at the Barclays with Matt Kuchar at 12-under-par 201. The better news is there is one round left to play in the first event of the FedEx Cup playoffs at Liberty National Golf Club, affording him a prime opportunity to reverse a disappointing trend.

title: In Travers, Colt Finally Attracts Attention of People Besides His Trainer
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.  No one was paying attention to D. Wayne Lukas and his colt as the spring turned to summer. If Will Take Charge had distinguished himself at all, it was for competing in all three legs of the Triple Crown. But he did not perform very well: he was beaten by a combined 45  lengths in those American Classics.

title: Cyberschools Grow, Fueling New Concerns
description: The number of full-time cyberschools serving Texas public school students will double in the coming school year despite a history of lackluster performance and a new law limiting the number of online courses that public school students are allowed to take at the states expense.

title: Ted Post, Director for Film and Television, Dies at 95
description: Ted Post, a prolific director who collaborated with Clint Eastwood on two hit films, directed hundreds of episodes of television series like Gunsmoke, Peyton Place and Rawhide, and made a low-budget film about the Vietnam War that was widely ignored when it was released in 1978 but is now regarded by many critics as one of the best in its genre, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 95. His son, Robert, confirmed the death.

title: Under a New Law, the Police Can Act as Gun Dealers
description: For decades, weapons confiscated by the police in Texas were supposed to be used for law enforcement purposes  or else destroyed. Starting next month, police departments across the state will be allowed to sell some of them.

title: Charles Pollock, Designer of Popular Office Chair, Dies at 83
description: Charles Pollock, an industrial designer whose vision of a simple line in space led him to develop sleek, functional chairs that became a hallmark of executive suites in the latter 20th century, died on Tuesday in a fire in South Jamaica, Queens. He was 83.

title: When Hill Country Feels Too Much Like Shreveport
description: By most standards, the new film Aint Them Bodies Saints should be a source of pride for Texas growing film industry. This thriller, which stars Rooney Mara, Casey Affleck and Ben Foster, is set in Central Texas; was written and directed by the Dallas-based David Lowery; and its producers include Toby Halbrooks, also of Dallas, and James M. Johnston, of Fort Worth.

title: Hamilton Earns Pole in Belgium
description: Lewis Hamilton left it to the last second to beat Sebastian Vettels time and secure his fourth straight pole position of the season at the Belgian Grand Prix. In a frantic finish under heavy rain at Spa, the lead changed hands in a flurry of activity as first Nico Rosberg, Mark Webber and Vettel all beat one anothers times, only for Hamilton to go fastest for the fifth time this season.

title: Making Some Effort, but North Texas Continues to Run the Water
description: DALLAS  On the northern edge of this city known for excessive water use, where residents have been subject to watering restrictions for more than a year, a cozy home on less than half an acre has one of the greenest lawns in town.

title: A Divided Dream
description: Fifty years after the March on Washington, Oris Stuart returned with his son and reflected on how far the country had come, and stood still, since then.

title: A Summer of Successes for Americas Young Stars
description: It has been a summer of triumphs for Americas best young players: three have become grandmasters, three have become international masters, and several more have earned one of the three norms  a measure of performance  needed to claim those titles.

title: Court Is One of Most Activist, Ginsburg Says, Vowing to Stay
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, 80, vowed in an interview to stay on the Supreme Court as long as her health and intellect remained strong, saying she was fully engaged in her work as the leader of the liberal opposition on what she called one of the most activist courts in history.

title: Few Answers in Game With No Real Winner
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The preseason game between the Jets and the Giants on Saturday night was meant to answer some questions for each teams coaching staff. Most notably, could the Jets rookie Geno Smith play well enough to win the starting quarterback job over Mark Sanchez, the incumbent?

title: Sabathia Briefly Finds Form, but Loses It (and Game)
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  For five superior innings Saturday, the world looked right again for C. C. Sabathia. He was pitching aggressively, boring in on the Tampa Bay Rays right-handed hitters and attacking them with his usual zest.

title: Iowas G.O.P. Fears Its Role in Presidential Selection Is Diminishing
description: AMES, Iowa  On the surface, Iowas Republican presidential caucuses seem healthier than ever: would-be candidates are flocking here mere months after the last White House race ended, drawing sizable crowds and ample news coverage. Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania were in this central Iowa college town for a Christian conservative conference this month, and Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky has come to the state twice since May.

title: Lottery Numbers
Smith vs. Sanchez Quarterback Duel Just Got Worse
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It could have been worse for the Jets. Maybe Geno Smith could have thrown four interceptions in his first seven drives Saturday night against the Giants, instead of only three. Maybe Mark Sanchez could have shredded both knees, instead of just injuring his right shoulder, playing in the waning minutes of a meaningless game after appearing to secure the Jets starting quarterback position by virtue of Smiths struggles.

title: Julie Harris, Celebrated Actress of Range and Intensity, Dies at 87
description: Julie Harris, the unprepossessing anti-diva who, in the guises of Joan of Arc, Mary Todd Lincoln, Emily Dickinson and many other characters both fictional and real, became the most decorated performer in the history of Broadway, died on Saturday at her home in Chatham, Mass. She was 87.

title: Risk at Coast From Fire at Yosemite
description: Gov. Jerry Brown of California declared a state of emergency for the city and county of San Francisco over the weekend, as a large wildfire near Yosemite National Park threatened water and electricity going to the area.

title: Film on Salinger Claims More Books Are Coming
description: LOS ANGELES  J. D. Salinger may not be done publishing after all, according to claims in a new film and book set for release next week.

description: Marika Anna Sawyer and Matthew Thomas Whitman were married Saturday at the Wainwright House, an event space in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Samora Smith, an interfaith minister ordained by the New Seminary, officiated.

description: Michelle Danielle Rose and Daniel Christopher Farmer were married Saturday evening at the Whittemore House, a historic home in Washington. Ann ORegan Keary, a judge of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia, officiated.

title: Vows: Danielle and Matthew
description: When Danielle Manning was 14, she interviewed the boy band Dream Street and made a lasting impression on 15-year-old Matthew Ballinger, one of the bands members. Years later, they reconnected.

title: Whats On Today
description: 9:30 P.M. (Encore) WHEN HARRY MET SALLY... (1989) Harry (Billy Crystal) and Sally (Meg Ryan, above) first meet on a road trip from Chicago to New York, where they discuss, among other things, whether men and women are capable of having asexual friendships. When their paths cross again 10 years later, they put that theory to the test as they bond over their mutual heartbreak from previous relationships in this romantic comedy written by Nora Ephron and directed by Rob Reiner. Mr. Crystal has the wittiest lines and snappiest delivery, but he also shows Harry to be remarkably gentle, a sensitive mensch, Caryn James wrote in The New York Times.

title: Grim World of Mumbai Rape Accused
description: MUMBAI  Three days have passed since a 22-year-old photojournalist said she was gang raped while on assignment in Mumbai, a city lined with luxury apartment buildings, glass office towers and marble megaliths of malls.

title: World Expositions Can Benefit or Haunt Host Cities
description: PARIS  Few visitors to Disneyland have a world exposition on their minds as they embark on the 15-minute Its a Small World boat ride. But it was for the 1964 New York Worlds Fair, as the expo was known, that Walt Disney designed the ride.

title: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official
description: JINAN, China  In the weeks before Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, went on trial here on corruption-related charges, senior officials from the powerful party investigation agency told him about two officials who had been tried earlier on somewhat similar charges, Mr. Bo said in court.

title: Two More Arrests Made in Gang Rape in India
description: MUMBAI, India  The fourth and fifth suspects in the gang rape of a 22-year-old journalist have been arrested, the police here reported Sunday, igniting new concerns about womens safety even in a city considered among Indias most progressive.

title: Its Not a Problem. Its Called Being a Child.
description: Heres the thing about most first graders: they are brittle, accusatory and rule-obsessed. They tense up or lay blame when something goes wrong, and they can spend an entire recess articulating regulations for games they never actually play. They are also adorable and amusing. Thank goodness, because any adult who tries to play cards with first graders soon discovers that they are incredible cheats.

title: Unnatural Models of the Labor Market (Wonkish)
description: Bob Halls paper for Jackson Hole (pdf) is, characteristically for Hall, a mix of very sensible stuff and strange-looking stuff that just might involve a deep insight. (Hall used to be famous at MIT for talks along the lines of Not many people understand this, but the IS curve actually slopes up and the LM curve slopes down  and then, not most of the time but often enough, his apparent craziness would turn out to be a big insight that changed the way you thought about a major issue.)

title: Confident Syria Used Chemicals, U.S. Mulls Action
description: WASHINGTON  Moving a step closer to possible American military action in Syria, a senior Obama administration official said Sunday that there was very little doubt that President Bashar al-Assads military forces had used chemical weapons against civilians last week and that a Syrian promise to allow United Nations inspectors access to the site was too late to be credible.

description: Im thinking about Ibn Khaldun this weekend, and there is, it turns out, at least one translation of Ibn Khalduns Muqaddimah (pdf) available online  and based on an initial skim, it truly is an awesome work, centuries ahead of its time. I was especially struck by his opening manifesto:

title: Disruptions: A Blogger Mocks the Denizens of Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sam Biddle may have one of the easiest jobs in technology journalism. That is, easy if you have the stomach for his line of work.

title: In Premier League, a Shuffle of Players, Then a Reshuffle
description: LONDON  Wayne Rooney, the England striker, might start for Manchester United against Chelsea on Monday night, then switch sides by the end of the week.

title: Aug. 25: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: A Rumble in the Sky, and Grumbles Below
description: It is known as the Flushing Climb  an airplane route born 23 years ago to prevent planes taking off at La Guardia Airport from disturbing fans at Arthur Ashe Stadium during the United States Open.

title: How to Charge $546 for Six Liters of Saltwater
description: It is one of the most common components of emergency medicine: an intravenous bag of sterile saltwater.

description: Three new movies quietly  very quietly  arrived in theaters over the weekend as the summer blockbuster season ebbed toward its end and previously released films continued to perform well.

title: Aziz Ansari Signs to Write a Book on Modern Romance
description: Aziz Ansari, the comedian and actor who plays the crass but endearing Tom Haverford on Parks and Recreation, has struck a deal to write his first book, an examination of modern romance, his publisher said last week. The Penguin Press acquired the book, described as an investigation into what Mr. Ansari calls an entirely new era for singles, in which the basic issues facing a single person  whom we meet, how we meet them and what happens next  have been radically altered by new technologies.

title: Rodriguez Out of Lineup in Final Game of Rays Series
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Alex Rodriguez was given the day off Sunday against the Tampa Bay Rays after playing three days in a row and going 1 for 11 in that span. Manager Joe Girardi said that with the Yankees playing six consecutive games on artificial turf, he wanted to give Rodriguez at least one day off, despite the fact that the infield at Tropicana Field is dirt.

title: Well-Mannered Thai Party Throws Down Its Gloves in Government Protests
description: BANGKOK  Booming loudspeakers, crowds of cheering protesters and the riot police on alert  after a relative lull of more than two years, politics is back on the streets in Thailand.

title: Sign-Language Interpreter Uses Newfound Fame to Advocate for the Deaf
description: For a week or so around the end of October, Lydia Callis seemed to be everywhere: On television, standing just to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs right as he, then she, urged New Yorkers to stay indoors while they waited out Hurricane Sandy. On Twitter, where admirers gushed that they could watch her for hours. And on Saturday Night Live  in caricature form, anyway  in a skit even Mr. Bloomberg could not resist mentioning.

title: Chinese-American Commentator and Investor Is Arrested in Beijing
description: SHANGHAI  A prominent investor and online social commentator was detained Friday in Beijing on charges of soliciting prostitution just after the government stepped up a campaign aimed at cracking down on online activism.

description: Athletes have arrived from all over the world to compete at the United States Open this week. It may be a surprise that the balls they play with typically travel far greater distances on the road to completion.

description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  This is from the Thought Youd Seen It All Department.

title: South Carolina City Takes Steps to Evict Homeless From Downtown
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  In South Carolinas capital, officials declare that their tree-lined Main Street, clogged with shops, banks, restaurants and hotels, is evidence that a long-sought economic revival has arrived.

title: Lundqvist Disagrees With Russian Law, but Supports Games
description: Last season, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist was one of the first professional athletes to participate in the You Can Play campaign, promoting respect for all athletes without regard to sexual orientation. That was why some were surprised when Lundqvist, in Stockholm earlier this month to prepare for the Sochi Olympics, declined to comment on a new law in Russia that has been criticized in the West as antigay.

title: On a Stage by Itself, Mozarts Appeal to Eternity
description: For the closing night of the Mostly Mozart Festival, the word mostly could have been eliminated from the title. While Mozart has shared the stage with various composers during the lineup this month, he had the spotlight to himself for the concluding event, conducted by Louis Langre on Friday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Paying Tribute to a Lost Star, With Help From Handel
description: When the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment chose a program to present at this years Mostly Mozart festival, it settled on an all-Handel tribute to the mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died in 2006.

title: Olbermann Set to Return to ESPN and Sports News
description: Sixteen years after an acrimonious parting, Keith Olbermann and ESPN are putting on happy faces for their highly anticipated reunion, the premiere on Monday of Olbermann on ESPN2, the spinoff channel that Mr. Olbermann helped start, falteringly, in 1993. This time, both sides say, no faltering.

title: New Surge in Shootings by Officers
description: The episodes ran the gamut of dangerous situations faced by New York City police officers: a man stabbing his ex-girlfriend; a driver fleeing the police in a stolen car; a group of young men thought to be heading for a hidden weapon; a gunman firing at plainclothes officers on a darkened street.

description: There are fine glimpses of the future throughout the Mets clubhouse these days, playing roles in wins and losses, producing runs and quality starts, learning and developing.

title: Edinburgh Strategy: Check Reviews, Take Chances, Hope for the Best
description: EDINBURGH  There are five possible endings and more than 1,500 routes to get to them in Choose Your Own Documentary, one of the 800-plus theater productions at the 2013 Edinburgh Festival Fringe, which concludes Monday. Inspired by the wildly successful Choose Your Own Adventure books, which sold hundreds of millions of copies during the 1980s and 90s, the show allows theatergoers, who are handed a remote-control voting devices on the way to their seats, directly to influence what happens at several moments in the story.

title: Hunting Again for Salinger Within the Silences and Secrets
description: In the J. D. Salinger story Zooey, the title characters mother says of him and his brother: Neither you nor Buddy know how to talk to people you dont like, adding: You cant live in the world with such strong likes and dislikes.

title: A Young Jazz Singer Reminds Her Elders How It Was Done
description: Like a lunar event or a geyser, it came at the expected hour: 5:45 on a late-August Saturday afternoon at the Charlie Parker Jazz Festival in Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem. (My notes from last year mark it at 5:30.) Its not planned, it just happens: the tempo shifts down and it becomes time for a few dozen audience members  mostly retirement age, probably sharper looking than you  to go down in front of the stage and dance together, full of grace. Its something you ought to see.

title: A Calculated Push Into Entertainment Lifts Duck Dynasty Familys Fortunes
description: Forget the ZZ Top beards and the Bayou accents, the Robertsons of West Monroe, La., are a family of traditional American entrepreneurs: ambitious, rich and spectacularly successful.

description: LOS ANGELES  The Guess clothing headquarters downtown here  once a humble distribution center, where stonewashed jeans were shipped around the country  looks more like an art gallery these days. Paintings by luminaries like Sterling Ruby and Carroll Dunham hang beside the famously sexy Guess billboard ads. And Mr. Ruby even stopped by to install a sculpture personally.

And at the center of those imaginings was a single figure, a woman who was said by day to be plain to the point of anonymity but who by night, once the curtain went up, became a beauty who could light up the dark.

description: On the cover of the current US Weekly  along with One Direction; Prince William and Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge; and Gia Allemand, the Bachelor contestant who recently committed suicide  is a smiling young couple, Mackenzie Douthit and Josh McKee, captured on their wedding day.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  At age 37 with cranky knees, Alfonso Soriano is not nearly as swift as he once was. In an earlier life with the Yankees in his middle 20s, Soriano was able to rely on sheer speed and agility as he twice recorded seasons with 40 stolen bases.

description: Strangle, strangle, strangle, strangle. The filmmaker Brian De Palma was contentedly narrating the action of his new frenemy thriller, Passion, for a visitor. The nightmare never ends, he said as the scene concluded.

title: Reality Bites TV Series
description: NBC is developing a half-hour television series based on the 1994 coming-of-age film Reality Bites, according to Varietys Web site. This single-camera comedy will follow the continuing romantic and professional misadventures of the movies heroine, Lelaina Pierce (originally played by Winona Ryder), and her group of 20-something slacker friends living in Houston during the 1990s. Helen Childress, who wrote the films screenplay, will also write the pilot script, and Ben Stiller, who starred in and directed the movie, will be an executive producer on the show. Casting has not been announced.

title: Linda Ronstadt Is Ill
description: The singer Linda Ronstadt has revealed in an interview with AARP Magazine that she has Parkinsons disease and that she is no longer able to sing as a result. Ms. Ronstadt, 67, received her official diagnosis eight months ago, although she had symptoms for the past eight years. I couldnt sing, she said in the interview, and I couldnt figure out why. I knew it was mechanical. I knew it had to do with the muscles. Her hands also began to shake, but she attributed that symptom to a shoulder operation. A neurologist then diagnosed Parkinsons. I wouldnt have suspected that in a million, billion years, she said. Ms. Ronstadts memoir, Simple Dreams, is to be released on Sept. 17 and chronicles her life and musical career. She has won 11 Grammy Awards and sold over 100 million records worldwide. But according to AARPs Web site, the book does not discuss her diagnosis or the loss of her voice.

title: A Final Book Is Planned From Elmore Leonard
description: Peter Leonard, a son of the author Elmore Leonard, who died last week at 87, hopes to complete his fathers last novel, BBC News reported. In an interview on the BBC Radio news program Broadcasting House on Sunday, Mr. Leonard, who is also a published author, said that the matter had been discussed among family members and Ive talked to Greg Sutter, Elmores longtime researcher. He added that he did not know how many pages his father had already written. The book, which has the working title Blue Dreams, was originally conceived to feature a rogue Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent, bull riding and Mr. Leonards popular federal marshal character, Raylan Givens.

title: The Decline of E-Empires
description: Steve Ballmers surprise announcement that he will be resigning as Microsofts C.E.O. has set off a huge flood of commentary. Being neither a tech geek nor a management guru, I cant add much on those fronts. I do, however, think I know a bit about economics, and I also read a lot of history. So the Ballmer announcement has me thinking about network externalities and Ibn Khaldun. And thinking about these things, Id argue, can help ensure that we draw the right lessons from this particular corporate upheaval.

title: From Italy, a Vintage Redolent of Horrors
description: COLLOREDO DI PRATO, Italy  Vini Lunardelli is no stranger to controversy. Every year, it seems, usually during the summer, a tourist will happen upon its wines with their outrageous labels and make a fuss that is then picked up by the local  and sometimes national and international  media.

title: Stream of Talent Continues to Flow From Cuba, With or Without Permission
description: From coast to coast this summer, the major league baseball season has had a strong Cuban influence.

title: Were All Still Hostages to the Big Banks
description: STANFORD, Calif.  NEARLY five years after the bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers touched off a global financial crisis, we are no safer. Huge, complex and opaque banks continue to take enormous risks that endanger the economy. From Washington to Berlin, banking lobbyists have blocked essential reforms at every turn. Their efforts at obfuscation and influence-buying are no surprise. Whats shameful is how easily our leaders have caved in, and how quickly the lessons of the crisis have been forgotten.

title: M.L.B. Media Company Buys Rights to Live Concert

title: Challengers to South Carolina Senator Are Lining Up on the Right
description: LAKE WYLIE, S.C.  Some of the early shots in the Republican primary battle against Senator Lindsey Graham have been fired from this tiny community on the northern border of the state where the Civil War began.

description: SEATTLE  Often a corporation with a grand dream to reshape a city wants tax breaks in return. Not Amazon.

title: Adrift on the Nile
description: IN May 2011, when the promise of the Arab Spring was still fresh and exhilarating, President Obama went to the State Department to proclaim an important reorientation of American policy in the Middle East. For decades America had defined its interests in utilitarian terms: regional stability, countering terrorism and nuclear proliferation (and, in the cold war years, Soviet influence), defending Israels security, assuring the free flow of oil and other commerce. That often meant alliances of convenience with brutal authoritarians.

title: Cave Collector in Minnesota Hunts for Additions to His Empire
description: RACINE, Minn.  John Ackerman has been called a tree hugger and a kook by two landowners and a devil worshiper by a local town board member. He has been accused of land snatching and gold prospecting. Others see him as an explorer and a fierce protector of an underground wilderness.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  As a young executive at Microsoft, Steven A. Ballmer helped topple older, slower-moving technology giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation, Wang and Novell.

title: Activist Running for Mayor of Moscow Is Briefly Detained
description: MOSCOW  Aleksei A. Navalny, the Internet activist and improbable opposition candidate in Moscows mayoral race, was briefly detained by the police on Sunday night after holding a rally here that attracted several thousand supporters.

title: Reading Tweets From Iran
description: Social media are an unorthodox, but useful, way to start to get a sense of Irans new president, Hassan Rouhani. In a flurry of English-language posts on Twitter since his election in June, Mr. Rouhani has given reason to hope that he is serious about resolving disputes with the United States and other major powers, most urgently about Irans nuclear program.

title: Federal Courts in Crisis
description: Observers of the federal court system cannot recall the last time such a thing has happened, if it ever has. Chief judges in 86 of the 94 Federal District Courts around the country  more than half of them Republican appointees  have now joined to sound an alarm about the grave damage to the nations justice system caused by years of flat financing followed by Washingtons lunatic across-the-board budget cuts known as sequestration. Their urgent plea to stop starving federal courts of adequate resources to fulfill the judiciarys constitutional responsibilities deserves a response from Congress.

A wildfire near Yosemite National Park  already one of the biggest in Californias history  continued to grow on Sunday, prompting mandatory evacuation orders for some residents and raising anxiety among officials because of the potential threat to a major source of San Franciscos water and power supplies.

Ashes Legacy on Display
description: Arthur Ashe kept everything: the receipt for his first Rolex, speeches scribbled on napkins, an autographed Time magazine with a note from Nelson Mandela on the cover. Ashe saved meticulous datebooks and his Life magazine cover story and more than 4,000 books, including several first editions, among them the first volume of poetry written by Phillis Wheatley in the 1700s.

She said she was looking forward to relaxing, and talked about marrying one day. She plans to travel, more for leisure than work. She will find new hobbies.

title: The Ad Campaign: Thompson Counterattacks

Thompson Jr., a Democratic candidate for mayor, spent much of the previous week arguing that Bill de Blasio, one of his rivals, was stretching the truth in his latest ad, which claims that Mr. de Blasio would be the only candidate to end a stop-and-frisk era that targets minorities. On Sunday, Mr. Thompson intensified the debate by attacking Mr. de Blasio directly in his own 30-second television advertisement, called Lived It. The ad marks the first time that a Democratic candidate has gone after a rival in a television ad, and comes just over two weeks before a primary vote that appears to be a tight race among Mr. Thompson, Mr. de Blasio and Christine C. Quinn.

description: 1:42 P.M. (Comedy Central) MY COUSIN VINNY (1992) Vincent Gambini (Joe Pesci), a lawyer from Brooklyn who recently passed the bar exam on his sixth attempt, is called to a small town in Alabama to defend his cousin Bill (Ralph Macchio) in a murder trial. Marisa Tomei, above with Mr. Pesci, in an Oscar-winning performance, is Mona Lisa Vito, Vinnys fiance, researcher, expert witness and conscience. In The New York Times, Vincent Canby wrote that this comedy is easily the most inventive and enjoyable American film farce in a long time, even during those extended patches when it seems to be marking time or when it continues with a running gag that cant stay the distance. He added that Mr. Pesci is a puzzled delight as he attempts to gather his wits, being helped not at all by Mona Lisas loudly articulated common sense and her ability to read law books and retain their contents.

title: Being Adoor Gopalakrishnan
description: If Adoor Gopalakrishnan had his way, India would celebrate the centenary of Indian cinema not this year, exactly 100 years after Raja Harishchandra, the first feature film made in India, but in 2055. For Mr. Gopalakrishnan, 72, one of Indias finest film directors, the birth of Indian cinema began in 1955 because it was the year that Satyajit Ray made Pather Panchali (Song of the Little Road).

title: Kerry Cites Clear Evidence of Chemical Weapon Use in Syria

title: Political Staging in Trial of Fallen China Official

description: QALANDIA, West Bank  Israeli security forces shot and killed three Palestinian men on Monday when violent clashes broke out during a raid on a refugee camp that lies between Jerusalem and the West Bank city of Ramallah, according to witnesses and the Israeli military.

title: Daily Report: Tech Upstarts Consider Their Mortality
description: As a young executive at Microsoft, Steven A. Ballmer helped topple older, slower-moving technology giants like the Digital Equipment Corporation, Wang and Novell. These days, its Microsofts turn to fend off the upstarts as it struggles to compete in a computing world that is increasingly mobile and based in a cloud of Internet-connected computers to which many customers gain access at the same time. It is all part of the inevitable life cycle for technology companies, Quentin Hardy reports.

I would soon be joined by my partner of 22 years, Tom Miller, who had remained behind in New York to tidy up his affairs before joining me in the (very) rural South.
