It was the latest in a series of terrorist attacks that have raised new fears that Iraq is returning to the bloody sectarian violence that nearly tore the country apart in 2006 and 2007.

As the childrens event went on down below  something with giant tennis balls and plastic cones  I leaned on the railing and gazed in the other direction, at the astounding scene on Courts P1 through P3: Roger Federer hitting with Tommy Haas, Rafael Nadal with Feliciano Lopez, Milos Raonic with Ernests Gulbis. title: A Better Way to Bring Your Desktop to Your iPad
description: You dont have to be a technophile to know a few things about compatibility. VHS tapes dont play on a laptop, iPhone apps dont run on your microwave and a CD wont play in a toaster.

title: Assessing the Costs of Caring for an Aging Relative
description: Faced with the high cost of in-home care, many Americans end up providing care themselves for an aging parent or relative with a chronic condition. But by doing so, you may be putting your own finances, and even your health, at risk.

title: Malnutrition Ravages Indias Children
description: BANDRICHIWADI, India  On the morning of July 23, Shakuntala Kirkire, a housewife in Bandrachiwadi village in the western state of Maharashtra, carried her 10-month-old daughter in her arms and walked in rain down the slope of a hill on which her village stands. Her husband, Ajay Kirkire, walked close to her, holding up an umbrella to protect their sick child as they tried to reach the government-run clinic in a neighboring village.

title: Like a Wheel, but Turning Slower
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The first thing to know about Linda Ronstadt is that if you ring the bell at her home here, on a sedate street with views of the ocean, shell answer the door herself. At least she did on a recent Monday morning.

title: Mark Leibovich Talks With the Stars From House of Cards
description: If the sordid world of Washington excites you; if Congressman Frank Underwoods salacious maneuvering on House of Cards shook you up; if you enjoyed the rollicking narrative Mark Leibovich delivered in his book, This Town: Two Parties and a Funeral  Plus, Plenty of Valet Parking!  in Americas Gilded Capital, which was excerpted in the magazine earlier this summer; then you should watch this Times Talk. The conversation, with the House of Cards star and executive producer Kevin Spacey, his co-star Robin Wright, the producer-writer Beau Willimon and Mark Leibovich, chief national correspondent for the magazine, was the first Times Talk to take place not in front of a live audience, but on the set of a show. Watch below:

title: 36 Hours in the Brandywine Valley
description: The physician and poet Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr. traveled through the gently rolling hills of the Brandywine Valley in southeastern Pennsylvania during the Civil War when he came there to search for his son, who he feared had been killed in battle. It was a grim mission  and luckily, his son survived  but the land made a strong impression. The grazing pastures were so green ... the houses were so comfortable, the barns so ample, the fences so well kept, that I did not wonder, when I was told that this region was called the England of Pennsylvania, Mr. Holmes wrote at the time.

title: As the Curl Turns ...(and Turns and Turns)
description: Curly-haired women like myself often recount adolescences spent yearning for sleek, straight tresses falling down their backs. But I was a child of the 80s, a perm-crazed time when women would stop my mother and me on the street and ask of my hair, Is it natural?

title: Gun Bill in Missouri Would Test Limits in Nullifying U.S. Law
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo.  Unless a handful of wavering Democrats change their minds, the Republican-controlled Missouri legislature is expected to enact a statute next month nullifying all federal gun laws in the state and making it a crime for federal agents to enforce them here. A Missourian arrested under federal firearm statutes would even be able to sue the arresting officer.

title: Marriage Equality in New Mexico
description: When arguing against same-sex marriage, opponents often stress that marriage has always been defined as a union between a man and a woman.

title: An Extra Day at Telluride, Making Time for Redford, the Coens and the Zapruder Film
description: TELLURIDE, Colo.  To celebrate its 40th anniversary, the Telluride Film Festival  which devotes each Labor Day weekend to restored classics, world cinema discoveries and possible Oscar contenders  has added an extra day of screenings. This means that the festivals lineup, a closely guarded secret, has been announced a day earlier than usual.

title: A Short History of the Highrise
description: A trailer of an interactive documentary by Katerina Cizek, coming on Oct. 8th.

title: Children of Israel
description: TEL AVIV  Israel likes children and it wants more of them. It has high fertility rates  the highest, in fact, of all the states in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development: almost 3 children per household, compared with an O.E.C.D. average of just over 1.7. It invests a lot of money in making fertility clinics and treatments accessible to its citizens.

title: Listen Up | The Garage-Rock Songstress Frankie Rose Gets in Touch With Her Inner Goth
description: Street of Dreams

title: Shorter Workweek May Not Increase Well-Being
description: Think a shorter workweek will make you happier? Maybe not, a new study suggests.

title: U.S. and Switzerland Are Close to Deal on Penalizing Banks in Tax Case
description: Updated, 7:38 p.m. |  Switzerland and the United States are close to announcing an agreement to end their long dispute over how to punish banks that helped Americans evade taxes, banking and government officials said on Wednesday.

title: Updates on the 50th Anniversary of Martin Luther Kings I Have a Dream Speech
description: On the 50th anniversary of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s iconic I Have a Dream speech, thousands of people descended on the Lincoln Memorial on Wednesday. Joined by the former presidents Bill Clinton and Jimmy Carter, President Obama paid homage to Dr. King and others involved in the civil rights era. And because they kept marching, America changed, the president said. Because they marched, the civil rights law was passed. Because they marched, the voting rights law was signed. More coverage from the days events.

title: Heading Into Preseason Finale, Giants Offense Is a Concern
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants faced fourth-and-goal at the 2-yard line late in the opening half of Saturday nights preseason game against the Jets when Eli Manning looked for Hakeem Nicks on a fade pattern. He later estimated that he underthrew the ball by a foot, the difference between allowing Nicks to snag it for a touchdown and having safety Dawan Landry render the pass incomplete.

title: Voices for Equality
description: A selection of speeches since Martin Luther King Jr.s address at the Lincoln Monument on Aug. 28, 1963, that have influenced the perceptions of race in America.

title: Homes for $625,000
description: A colonial with a surprising interior near Minneapolis, a stucco colonial in Pennsylvania and mountain views in Arizona

title: Holidays, High and Low
description: With the start of the school year come three Jewish holidays: Rosh Hashana, Yom Kippur and Sukkot. In What a Way to Start a New Year! Jacqueline Jules imagines what Rosh Hashana might be like for a young family whose new year is starting in a new house in a new town. Dina, who is about 7, finds nothing is as it should be: the friends she liked to visit for the holiday are now hours away, and her home is a mess of packing boxes. It doesnt feel like Rosh Hashana here, she complains. We dont even have a round challah. A series of mishaps makes the phrase What a way to start a new year! a common refrain in the house, until a colleague of Dinas father suggests the family join him at the temple he attends. Though the holidays are different than Dina remembers, she learns something about making friends and embracing change. Judy Steads illustrations, rich with festive pinks, greens and purples, are attractive and cheerful even when her charactersexpressive faces register disappointment or impatience. What a Way to Start a New Year! is notable in that Jules assumes a basic understanding of the holiday; making this amusing and less obviously didactic book a pleasure to read.

title: What You Get for ... $625,000
description: ST. LOUIS PARK, MINN.

title: Image of the Day: August 28
Building a Bridge From Combat to Civilian Life
description: Small things kill in combat. This truism is as old as war itself, but it proved especially correct in Iraq and Afghanistan, where a new pile of dirt or the glint off a wire in the desert sun could be the sole indication that a bomb lay beneath your feet. So at its heart, military training  from the first day of boot camp to the final predeployment war game  has always really been about paying attention to details. The military knows how to turn on hypervigilance. The question is how to turn it off.

title: Nashville Symphony Musicians Agree to Pay Cut
description: The musicians of the Nashville Symphony  which had been riding a wave of successes before the recession and a destructive 2010 flood imperiled their financial future  ratified a new one-year contract this week that will cut their pay by 15 percent.

title: Real Estate on Grand Cayman Island
description: The market in Grand Cayman, the largest of the three-island archipelago known as the Cayman Islands, remains tilted much in favor of buyers.

title: Wheelies: The Purloined Chevrolets Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Getaway'
description: Courtney Solomon, the director of the thriller "Getaway," discusses an early chase sequence from the film.

title: China Plans Its First Unmanned Moon Landing This Year
description: HONG KONG  China plans to land an unmanned exploratory rover on the moon by the end of 2013, a step forward in the countrys efforts to master the skills of space travel, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Wednesday.

title: House Hunting on ... Grand Cayman Island
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM SIX-BATH VILLA ON A CANAL NEAR SEVEN-MILE BEACH

title: Taliban Breach an International Base, Killing at Least 7
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban breached an international military base in eastern Afghanistan on Wednesday, in a complex attack that left at least one Western soldier, four Afghan police officers, and two other Afghans dead, Western and Afghan officials said.

title: In a Subdued Land, Passion Is a Heavy Burden
description: Plenty has been written about the essential qualities of J. M. Coetzees novels, their severity, restraint and erudition. Martin Amis put it most memorably, if not most accurately, when he remarked a few years ago that Mr. Coetzees whole style is predicated on transmitting absolutely no pleasure.

title: The Asian Crisis Versus The Euro Crisis
description: So, Im feeling young again  well, middle-aged, anyway. The rupiah is plunging again!

title: Ackman Should Stick With Heavy Industry
description: The activist investor William A. Ackman is more persuasive as an industrialist than as a shopkeeper.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of Getaway
description: How many cameras does it take to shoot a car chase sequence? In the case of the thriller Getaway, many more than one would imagine. In this video, the director Courtney Solomon breaks down an intricate chase scene featuring Ethan Hawke, and shot with multiple cameras mounted both inside and outside the vehicle.

title: Abortion Rights Arithmetic
description: In case you werent already alarmed by the barrage of state laws and regulations aimed at curtailing womens constitutionally protected right to an abortion, we now have a concrete understanding of their actual impact.

title: Murrays Victory Is Easy, but It Doesnt Come Quickly
description: It was 9:55 p.m. Wednesday when Andy Murray finally took his first steps toward defending his United States Open title, on a soggy court, in front of a weary crowd, at the end of a very long, very trying tournament day.

title: Death Penalty for Rampage at Fort Hood
description: KILLEEN, Tex.  Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, the Army psychiatrist who admitted to killing 13 unarmed people at Fort Hood nearly four years ago, was sentenced to death by lethal injection by a jury on Wednesday, becoming one of only a handful of men on military death row.

title: Culprit in Syrian Chemical Attack Is Unclear, China Insists
description: BEIJING  China, clinging to a longstanding policy of noninterference, said on Wednesday that it opposed military action against Syria and insisted that the truth about the chemical weapons attack against civilians last week remained unclear.

title: Oxford Dictionaries Online Adds Selfie, Emoji and Other Tech-Oriented Terms
description: Selfie, phablet, emoji. A few years ago, these words held little to no meaning for most Americans. But thanks to the onward creep of new and pervasive technologies like smartphones, Facebook and photo-sharing, and communication services like Snapchat and Instagram, they have become nearly ubiquitous.

title: Attention Helps Cyrus and Thicke Sales
description: Miley Cyruss rear-shaking, tongue-wagging performance at MTVs Video Music Awards on Sunday has been widely ridiculed by the news media. BuzzFeed has devoted at least 20 posts to it (so far); even Camille Paglia put it down.

title: New Beauty Products that Fight Sun Damage
description: Summer days at the pool and the beach make for fond memories, but the toll that the sun, salt and chlorine take on your skin and hair is something you would probably like to forget. Not surprisingly, there are several products that claim to help with end-of-season beauty woes like brown spots and brittle hair. Herein, three new choices.

title: Rolling Down the Road for Lobster
description: Foraging hits the blacktop in a new lobster-themed bicycle crawl from the White Barn Inn in Kennebunk, Me.

title: U.S. Open Food Review: Hidden Gems
description: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This month, short stories and novels explore troubled lives in vastly different worlds: the heartsick staff and residents of a psychiatric clinic, soldiers returning home to dead-end jobs, tigers maimed in a magical realm, and the passionate, reckless American abolitionist John Brown.

title: Oprah Winfrey at King Commemoration
description: Ms. Winfrey spoke on the 50th anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.s I Have a Dream speech in Washington.

title: Carter Remembers Coretta and Dr. King
description: Former President Jimmy Carter brings up the Voting Rights Act, gun rights and stand your ground during his speech on the National Mall.

title: Catching Up With the Owl and the Pussycat
description: Ever wonder what became of the owl and the pussycat from Edward Lears famous 1870 poem? Last seen, they danced by the light of the moon after having been married by a turkey.

title: A Look at September Fashion Magazines
description: Dear editors,

title: A Short History of the Highrise Trailer
description: Premiering October 2013, A Short History of the Highrise is an interactive documentary that explores the 2,500-year global history of vertical living and issues of social equality.

title: Kudos to Economix
description: The Times economics blog is now the second-most influential in the world, according to Onalytica. As Ive written recently, even though the economics profession is deeply troubled, this is actually a golden age for real-time economics discussion.

title: Bill Clinton at King Commemoration
description: In his commemoration of the I Have a Dream speech, the 42nd president noted contemporary debates over gun rights and voting laws.

title: Martin Luther King III in Fathers Place
description: The son of the civil rights leader spoke at the 50th anniversary of his fathers I Have a Dream speech.

title: Poll Shows de Blasio With Big Lead
description: After months in which his campaign struggled to find its footing, Bill de Blasio is now the front-runner in the Democratic primary for mayor of New York, according to a survey released on Wednesday.

title: Congressman Lewis Speaks in Washington
description: Representative John Lewis, the last living speaker from the 1963 March on Washington, spoke 50 years later about equality.

title: Federer Has Company on Tenniss Artists Colony
description: The word musician has practically disappeared from the English language because in recent years musicians have turned into artists. During this same time period, Roger Federer has, in tennis writing circles, morphed from a tennis player into an artist. He has defined, and, at times, dominated the sport in the last decade. Federer has done it with grace and style, but is he the only tennis player creating art on the court?

title: Obama Commemorates Kings Dream Speech
description: Following is the text of President Obamas speech at the Lincoln Memorial commemorating the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

title: Saluting a Dream, and Adapting It for a New Era
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama stepped into the space on Wednesday where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. once stood, summoning his iconic dream of a colorblind society in a celebration of a half-century of progress and a call to arms for the next generation.

title: Obama Remembers the March on Washington
description: President Obama addressed thousands of people gathered at the Lincoln Memorial on Wednesday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the landmark civil rights event.

title: Rev. Bernice King on Her Fathers Legacy
description: The daughter of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. asked new generations to make the anniversary of the March on Washington a day to reinvigorate the fight for equality around the world.

title: A Loss of Community
description: Neighborhoods across the country are being transformed, as houses built for homeowners are turned into rental properties. Residents of one such community in Memphis, Tenn., discuss the changes.

title: As Renters Move In, Some Homeowners Fret
description: MEMPHIS  Beneath the spreading shade tree in Laura Holcombs front yard, there are some 70 varieties of hosta, stands of elephant ear and a Japanese maple. For the 17 years she has owned the brick house on Rose Trail Drive in the Hillshire subdivision, Ms. Holcomb has devoted herself to her home and garden.

title: Danger: Earrings Ahead!
description: Hey, lady, is that a bee behind your ear?

title: Pension Plan in France Draws Few Admirers
description: PARIS  The governments much-anticipated proposal to change the generous but underfunded French pension system has been to the liking of very few here, with many critics on Wednesday calling it insufficient and others worried that it may herald a broader unraveling of the countrys cherished system of social protections. Nor are Frances European partners likely to view the plans as representing the sort of structural overhaul they have called for.

title: New Deadline Set in Minnesota Orchestra Labor Dispute
description: Updated, 4:44 p.m. | The make-or-break moment for the Minnesota Orchestra, which canceled its 2012-13 season after management locked out the players because of labor strife, is now Sept. 15.

title: Countdown to Fashion Week: Model Casting
description: In the fourth installment of Countdown to Fashion Week, designers Ryan Lobo and Ramon Martin of Tome search for models and muses to carry the spirit of their collection.

title: On Syria, a Drumbeat With Some Echoes of Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  A grim-faced secretary of state reading a bill of charges against a rogue Arab leader. The White House promising intelligence that will provide proof about weapons of mass destruction. Frenetic efforts to piece together a coalition of the willing. Breathless news reports about imminent bombing raids.

title: Countdown to Fashion Week: Model Casting About for Character
description: Designers tend to speak in code. Often they dont speak at all. That was the case last Thursday when Ramon Martin and Ryan Lobo, partners in Tome, a three-year-old fashion label, began scrutinizing the parade of comely young women filing into their studio on West 25th Street.

title: A Coach Joins a Short List by Announcing Hes Gay
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Once Simon Thibodeau convinced himself that it was all right to be gay, and then to be open about it in front of others, he gathered his womens tennis team in May at the University of California, Santa Barbara. The dozen players in the room wondered why their head coach was so nervous.

title: Escape From Times Square
description: Since 2007, when she arrived in New York from Texas, Christina LaScalea had lived in a high-rise rental building on West 42nd Street. She occupied the bedroom while her roommate  she went through three  had the converted living room. The rent started at $3,100 a month, dipped and rose again. The most Ms. LaScalea ever paid for her share was $1,800.

title: U.S. Government Issues Warning About Security on Android Phones
description: Updated, 9:51 a.m. | Adding Googles response.Googles Android operating system is the most widely used mobile software system in the world, which makes it a big target for makers of malicious software, the way Microsoft Windows system is. Now the American government has issued a warning about the potential security threat of Android.

title: Hands and Clay
description: The artist Edmund de Wall is preparing for his first exhibition in the United States.

title: Putins Silence on Syria Suggests His Resignation Over Intervention
description: MOSCOW  Russia has made its opposition to military intervention in Syria vehemently clear. The foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, warns daily about the risk of an escalating conflagration. A deputy prime minister said the West dealt with the Islamic world like a monkey with a grenade. A few commentators on the fringe have warned of World War III.

title: Dashed Dreams
description: Since peaking in 2004 at 69 percent, the share of households that own their home has dropped about 4 percentage points.

title: 'Choices'
description: The most recent ad from the Weiner campaign focuses on the middle class.

title: Should Hasan Get the Death Penalty?
description: A military jury on Wednesday sentenced Maj. Nidal Hasan to death, surprising no one. Major Hasan never denied killing 13 people and wounding dozens at the Fort Hood military base in 2009. He refused representation and cant really be said to have defended himself. He said hed killed Americans in the name of Islamic insurgents abroad.

title: Goodbye, Gus
description: Video of Gus, a polar bear at the Central Park Zoo, from the Wildlife Conservation Society. Gus was euthanized after medical professionals found an inoperable tumor. He was 27.

title: A Survivor of a Play Resurfaces
description: Joseph Papp, who as artistic director of the sprawling Public Theater had several performance spaces at his disposal, wasnt known for mothballing projects. Rising young playwrights dont typically rewrite their endings because the actors would rather not say the lines. And plays tend not to lose their leading men the day after the reviews come out, especially when the reviews are good.

title: What I Learned Driving Through the Heartland
description: The udder on this cow just keeps getting better and better as the day goes on, remarked Barry Visser, Kandiyohi County Fair dairy cattle judge, over the PA system. A boy led his prizewinning Holstein away as a friendly crowd of western Minnesotans, and one out-of-place New Yorker, looked on from the modest stands. The dairy cow competition was nearing its end; the rabbits, hens and pigs had already had their days of judgment  no udders required  and were unwinding one building down. Up the hill, workers prepared rides and games and funnel cake stands to open.

title: Your Road Trip Discoveries
description: Readers share stories of what they found during drives in America.

title: In N.Y. Mayoral Race, Small Checks From Hedge Fund Giants
description: Hedge fund titans are making a $170,336 bet that Christine C. Quinn is the best candidate to run New York.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Israel, Jordan, Iraq and India.

title: Where the Arty Flock in Seoul (Hint: Its Not Gangnam)
description: The Hapjeong neighborhood is lined with narrow streets full of cafes, music spaces and galleries.

title: Something in the Way He Moves Attracts Listeners
description: Its hard to put your finger on just what it is that makes the pianist Taka Kigawa a phenomenon, but theres no denying that hes something special. True, other pianists have made a specialty of the demanding modernist works that Mr. Kigawa favors. Webern, Boulez, Xenakis and Stockhausen are among his staples. (Bach, too.) And in his considerable technical prowess, Mr. Kigawa is not without peers.

title: The Ad Campaign: Speaking in Support of Weiner
description: After soaring to the top of the Democratic mayoral primary field in some polls earlier this summer, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner is now struggling, and viewed as a long shot to make it to a runoff. But one asset he still has is a robust campaign war chest, so this week, he released three more television commercials. Perhaps the most notable one is Choices, because it represents the first time he has deployed surrogates  not himself  to make his campaign pitch.

title: All Around the World in Just Two Film Roles
description: LOS ANGELES  The actor Daniel Brhl, who is Spanish and German, will soon have a global moment in Toronto.

title: Richard Eyre to Direct Figaro at the Metropolitan Opera
description: Opera companies have long been accustomed to changing casts around, sometimes at the last minute. Now the Metropolitan Opera, which has been placing a premium on theatrical values in recent years, is growing adept at switching directors, too.

title: That 40s Pas de Deux? You Can Still Catch It
description: On my first day in New York, I struck gold. It was 1979; Id become a dance critic the year before and was here to learn; but at 23, I knew nothing about the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. Fortunately, a man I met in line that morning for standing-room tickets to see the New York City Ballet kindly led me there, in particular to the Jerome Robbins Dance Division on the librarys third floor, and showed me how to find my way around its incomparable archive of dance on film.

title: U.S. Victory at World Youth Open Championships
description: ATLANTA  At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here this month, the final of the Junior Knockout Teams was between Australia and one of the United States teams.

title: The Other Server Makers Are Gaining Ground
description: This quarters market-share reports on computer server shipments and sales from Gartner and IDC are an unusually eloquent statement about the worlds transition to cloud computing and commodity machines that dont command a big profit margin.

title: Despite Pledge, France Lags in Hunt for Looted Art
description: PARIS  When Frances culture minister, Aurlie Filippetti, handed over six looted 18th-century paintings to a Boston man in March, she declared a new proactive approach to tracking the original owners of recovered artworks that were stolen by the Nazis.

title: A Mens Fall Wardrobe That Women Can Use, Too
description: The way we see it, many of this falls wardrobe ideas for men and women are remarkably similar. There is the statement coat, which can serve as an instant fix-me-up (er  cover-up) for almost any outfit. There are upgraded sweats (always cool when worn under good outerwear), new laid-back backpacks and, as always, reimagined staples. This selection is geared to the menfolk, but, ladies, you might want to get your hands on some of it, too.

title: Argentine Technology Firm Plans I.P.O. on N.Y.S.E.
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Globant, an Argentine software and information technology services company, has filed to go public on the New York Stock Exchange, in a move to broaden its reach.

title: A New Home Dcor Magazine, but Why?
description: Next month, Milieu, a quarterly magazine about home dcor, will make its first appearance on newsstands, showcasing international houses and gardens the old-fashioned way: on thick, glossy paper. Its founder and chief editor is Pamela Pierce, 63, an interior designer in Houston who is embarking on her first publishing venture. Speaking to a reporter recently, she sounded self-assured, but didnt shy away from the word crazy.

title: Knock Twice for Offbeat Design
description: Studio O+A, a San Francisco design firm, is expert in nontraditional offices, having created workplaces for Facebook and PayPal. So imagine what kind of office it would make without a client breathing down its neck.

title: Irene Neuwirths Eight Great Days in Greece
description: Irene Neuwirth, the fine jewelry designer whose colorful statement pieces are red carpet regulars and top sellers at Barneys New York, calls herself a seasoned traveler. Yet after her long flight from Los Angeles to London to Athens, and then her eight-hour overnight boat ride from Athens to Patmos, she said, I was proud of myself for making the trip. The cabin was disgusting, and people were drunk and sleeping on the stairs. I got there and was like, Maybe I made a mistake coming here. And then you drag your bags down, and youre waiting in the bottom of the boat where they let the cars out, and it opens out into paradise. Its so gorgeous.

title: Its Enough to Give You Hiccups
description: When you say something is bubbly, youre talking about something that is light and free, said Rita Motta, an Italian-born interior and product designer who has made spherical forms a signature. Ms. Motta  a founder, with her husband, Michael Perez, of the Miami design studio Mr. O  first put bubbles on cabinets and side tables. Now they have been hand-sheared into rugs for Tai Ping. The wool and silk rugs come in effervescent colors like magenta, vermilion (shown), citron and violet. Following their introduction last winter at Design Miami, Ms. Motta said the jewel tones stood out among the neutrals favored in showrooms.

title: Nobody Knows the Crumbs Theyve Seen
description: Who thinks to regularly wipe down all the electronic gadgets that run our lives? Not me, for sure, at least not until several eye-pleasing cleaning tools appeared on my desk. AM, a Copenhagen company that started in the 1970s with cleaners for vinyl records and record players, has just released a suite that includes brightly colored microfiber-wrapped atomizers for both spraying and wiping phones and computers (about $15 to $35, depending on size); miniature microfiber sponges that can squirm between the Z and X keys on a crumb-filled keyboard (about $15 for five); and wet wipes, which the company says are free of harsh chemicals and can safely clean any screen (about $10 for 18).

title: Using a Garden to Great Advantage
description: Q. Are there any particular kinds of plants or flowers I should add to my garden before putting my house up for sale?

title: Sales at Nest Interiors, Lron and Others
description: Agate bookends, originally $199, are $139 at Nest Interiors to Wednesday; 172 Ninth Avenue (West 21st Street), (212) 337-3441, nestinteriorsny.com.

title: Vases That Make a Statement
description: Whats the point of a vase? Many people would say that vases are mainly for holding flowers.

title: Linda Ronstadt on Her Memoir and Parkinsons
description: Simple Dreams is less an autobiography than an artists bildungsroman. In it, Ms, Ronstadt recalls her musical journey phase by phase, beginning with her childhood in the Sonora desert.

title: Paws Off My Watermelon!
description: In Long Island City, Queens, one woman has turned an unlikely space into a plant nursery.

title: The Scandinavian Way
description: Jerry Helling, president of Bernhardt Design, makes a habit of boosting the careers of young designers. His latest protgs are Christoffer Angell, Oyvind Wyller and Simen Aarseth, founders of AWAA, a Norwegian studio, whom he met at a cocktail party and asked to create a side chair with arms. They returned with Oslo, a chair that will be introduced at the London Design Festival on Sept. 18. The trio, who had never designed a commercial product, focused first on the chairs skeletal structure, creating a sturdy frame of solid walnut. They added a sling seat and a back that is attached to the frame with buttons. The look reminds Mr. Helling of a messenger bag; others see it as a faithful homage to Scandinavian modern.

title: The Fire-Escape Nursery
description: My friend Tonice Sgrignoli is growing two Early Moonbeam watermelons in a 12-inch clay pot on her fire escape in Long Island City, Queens. This is not easy, considering how much water and nutrients melons require. Its also illegal.

title: The Plant Whisperer
description: In Los Angeles, one woman lives in a miniature botanical garden of her own creation, with fruit trees and a turtle named Ting.

title: A Haven for Making Music With Plants
description: LOS ANGELES  Mileece Petre, a 35-year-old English artist and musician known professionally as Mileece, is a plant whisperer of sorts. In a digital-age spin on The Secret Life of Plants, the 1973 book that suggested plants are sentient, she attaches electrodes to leaves. The electromagnetic current is fed into software she wrote that turns the data into musical notes, so a garden becomes an orchestra (she especially likes philodendrons; their hearty leaves offer better support for the electrodes).

title: Finding Refuge in the Barns
description: Lucinda and David Schiff will tell you that the recent redo of the midcentury barn in Sagaponack, N.Y., that is their home each August was the product of a summer romance.

title: From Barn to Beachhouse
description: Built in the 1970s by Tod Williams, this recently renovated vacation home in Sagaponack, Long Island, maintains rustic touches.

title: West Debates Legal Rationale for Syria Strike

But in Berlin, with Hitler in the stands, Mr. Glickman and Sam Stoller  the only Jews on the relay team  were replaced the day before the event by Jesse Owens and Ralph Metcalfe, ostensibly because secret German runners were expected to challenge for the gold. (Mr. Glickman, who died in 2001, maintained that anti-Semitism was at work.) The Americans won the race; the Germans finished a distant fourth. After returning to the United States, Mr. Glickman eventually found his niche in basketball and football broadcasting. Despite being rejected for a more Midwestern announcer when the N.B.A. finally signed a network contract, he became the voice of the Giants during the 1950s and 60s and the Jets in 1972. This documentary from James L. Freedman, who produced Mr. Glickmans late-night radio show as a high school senior, brings to light some of his pioneering techniques, phrases and programming innovations. title: Training Day, Starring Li Na

I needed someone really tough, she told me. Even at 31, five years after flying solo from Chinas state sports system, Li still possesses the punishing work ethic inculcated by her Chinese coaches. Two years ago, she fired a foreign coach because, she said with a laugh, he was way too nice. Rodriguez is gentle on the outside, too. But the wiry Rodriguez, an Argentine, who coached the former world No. 1 Justine Henin for 15 years, is renowned for his insistence on peak physical and psychological fitness. With Kaluosi, as she calls him (a transliteration of Carlos), Li knew she was signing up for pain. She just didnt know how much.

title: Saving Grace
description: Like J. M. Coetzees richly symbolic early novels Waiting for the Barbarians and Life and Times of Michael K, his starkly narrated new novel plunges us at once into a mysterious and dreamlike terrain. But where those books evoke Coetzees native South Africa and the madness of apartheid, immersing the reader in situations of nearly unbearable intensity, The Childhood of Jesus is set in a possibly posthumous limbo in which a haze of forgetfulness has enervated most of the characters, as in a paralyzing smog. We arrive by boat in a city called Novilla, in an unnamed but possibly southern European country, in the company of a man named Simn, who has taken under his protection a child named David  Not my grandson, not my son, but I am responsible for him. It would appear that the travelers are refugees: they have come from a camp, a place called Belstar, where they were given Spanish lessons and two passbooks. The child has been separated from his parents. Simn seems to have no family at all. Having, like all his fellow travelers, been shorn of his memory on the voyage to Novilla, Simn arrives in unknown territory and must establish himself; he must find shelter and he must find work to support himself and the boy. If Simn has had a profession or a trade in his former life, he cant recall it; he is grateful to find work as a stevedore, for which he is barely qualified. It will be Simns obsession to locate Davids mother, whose name he doesnt know and of whom he knows nothing, not even whether she has arrived in this strange, nameless country.

description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Want to See the Wife Again? Just Follow Directions
description: One can only guess why Ethan Hawke felt compelled to make a high dive from the sublimity of Before Midnight into the twisted rubble of Getaway. What other reason could there be for a star to attach his name to a mindless demolition derby but the payday? Furthermore, Mr. Hawke is only the nominal star of a movie whose driving force is the ultimate muscle car  an armored Ford Shelby GT500 Super Snake  that runs amok in the streets of Sofia, Bulgaria.

title: Match of Teenagers Provides Glimpse of Future
description: Teenagers like Tracy Austin and Martina Hingis used to turn in dominant seasons on the womens tennis tour. Today major success tends to arrive later. The talented 19-year-olds Laura Robson and Caroline Garcia are not yet seriously challenging for Grand Slam titles or the top ranking. But their second-round United States Open match Wednesday night was an opportunity to check on the progress of two promising young players.

title: This Weeks Movies: Aug. 30, 2013
description: The New York Times film critics on Passion, One Direction and Abigail Harm.

title: Sisters, Cracking Wise or Sweetly Harmonizing
description: Was it 5 or 10 years ago that Liz and Ann Hampton Callaway first performed Sibling Revelry, spoofing sisterly show business competition? Actually, it was 18 years ago. These sisters, from Chicago, introduced this musical-comedy comfort food at Rainbow and Stars in 1995. Now, years after that club closed, the show is back (at 54 Below), essentially unchanged with the same director (Dan Foster) and arranger-pianist (Alex Rybeck).

title: Drawn From Nature
description: Michelle Stuart brings art into the landscape, and vice versa, as seen in a survey of her work.

title: Spare Times for Aug. 30-Sept. 5
description: Great North River Tugboat Race and Competition (Sunday) Tugboats and their operators will be duking it out  in a nautical sense  at this annual event in and along the Hudson River, from 44th Street to just south of the 79th Street Boat Basin. A main objective of the day is to educate the public about the ecological importance of the harbor as the greenest way to ship things, said Capt. John Doswell, executive director of the Working Harbor Committee, one of the event sponsors.

title: Rwanda Warns Congo After Shells Hit Its Territory
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The escalating conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo threatened to embroil Rwanda after a woman there was killed and her baby wounded in shelling on Thursday, Rwandas government said.

title: Just Holding on Through the Curves
description: My daughter just turned 30. How is this possible when it seemed like only a week before she was a scrappy, sassy teenager? Like mothers everywhere, I dont think Im old enough to have delivered a baby girl who could hit such a milestone.

title: Photo Op
description: I went to a dinner party while my wife and daughters were on an exotic vacation. A woman asked about them, so I gave a quick update and opened the photo file on my iPhone and showed her a picture of them riding camels. I expected her to pass the phone around the table. Instead, she began thumbing through all of the other photos on my phone  some of which were extremely revealing. Panicking, I retrieved the phone by saying, You dont want to see all of those. The woman made a snarky comment about my obviously having something to hide. Was I wrong to give her the phone? Don, Cincinnati

title: From an Open Kitchen, Eye-Pleasing Plates
description: Theres great energy at Blue Water Seafood in Red Bank: the art, the seafood display, the open kitchen. Others seem to agree: On both my visits  one on a weeknight, the other on a weekend  there was a crowd in the downstairs dining room, a respectable gathering at the sidewalk tables and a steady stream of traffic up and down the stairs to the second dining room.

title: It Gets Curiouser and Curiouser
description: The independent movie Abigail Harm opens with the curiously named title character (Amanda Plummer) reading aloud to a blind man from Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There. The two are seated apart in a poorly lighted room, and shes reading from Chapter 3, the part after Alice has read Jabberwocky and discovered a garden with talking flowers. Now, in some woods where things have no names, Alice meets a fawn. Together, they walk a bit, her arms around the fawn. But when they leave the forest, the animal recognizes what they are  Im a Fawn! it cried out in a voice of delight, and, dear me! youre a human child!  and darts away.

title: Mom Comes Home With a Stripper
description: How can I complain? Women in Darfur walk 14 miles to get water and are raped on the way.

title: Its Vacation Time, Grief Stalker
description: Suri Krishnammas Dark Tourist takes an effectively unpleasant trip down the lost highway of a morbid mind before its bad choices start catching up with it.

title: Seafood With a Scenic Distraction
description: It was Saturday night in Seaford, and a boat called Love on a Thursday bobbed gently at the dock in front of the Parkside Caf. Two couples had just climbed aboard after dinner at the restaurant and seemed in no hurry to motor off into the sunset.

title: A Jaded Boomerang Returns
description: Tales of summertime (or lifelong) regression have tended to involve comically adrift men, but The Lifeguard follows a woman just shy of 30 as she moves back in with her family in Connecticut. This directorial debut by Liz W. Garcia, a writer for television, bears some echoes of its creators origins, going from deft to trite in its drama and setting up character arcs that feel sappily resolved within its feature length.

title: Brooklyn Fire Injures 11
description: A suspicious fire ripped through a Brooklyn brownstone on Thursday morning, injuring 11 people, four of them critically, according to fire officials.

title: New Neighbors Agenda: White Power Takeover
description: LEITH, N.D.  The bearded man with thinning, gray-and-bleach-blond hair flapping down his neck first appeared in this tiny agricultural town last year, quietly and inconspicuously roaming the crackly dirt roads.

description: Stabilized Tenant Plans to Marry

title: Sisters in Arms (and in Pricey Couture)
description: Lena Dunham and Girls can have Brooklyn. In Tiny Times 2, the writer and director Guo Jingming continues his adaptation of his coming-of-age trilogy about four young women, besties at least from high school, as they make their way in todays careerist, consumerist Shanghai. Sisterhood is powerful, it turns out, translates easily to Mandarin.

title: European Officials Want to Hasten the Sale of Greek Assets
description: ATHENS  Greek officials sought Thursday to deflect reports that administrators of the euro zones main bailout fund had proposed that an outside company manage the sale of state-owned real estate.

title: With Youth Tanning Law, Texas Aims to Lower Melanoma Risk
description: When she was 16, Cheri Huber considered her skin splotchy and pasty. She began going to a tanning salon about three times a week.

description: If someone wrote an operating manual for politics, it would have a section on why the political season doesnt really start until Labor Day.

title: Tracking the Wildfire Near Yosemite With Online Tools
description: Last Updated | 9:45 a.m., Aug. 30 A handful of online tools are helping people monitor the wildfire burning near Yosemite National Park, which has become the sixth largest wildfire in Californias recorded history.

title: Struggling for Mastery of Life and Limb
description: Professional climbers find El Capitan, about 3,000 feet of sheer rock from base to summit in Yosemite National Park, a physical challenge. So does Steve Wampler, the blond, handsome father of two who is the physically challenged focus of the documentary Wamplers Ascent.

title: Facebook to Update Privacy Policy, but Adjusting Settings Is No Easier
description: Facebook announced Thursday that it planned to enact changes to its privacy policies on Sept. 5.

title: A Regents Chief Determined to Avoid the Fray
description: After Paul L. Foster was named chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents in August, Charles Miller, a Houston businessman who had served in that position for more than three years, sent him a note.

title: Wandering Souls, United in Rebellion
description: Matas Meyers third feature, The Last Christeros, is about popular culture, though not in the conventional sense of light, disposable entertainment. Set in 1930s Mexico, this spiritually driven film treks through the scrubby sun-streaked countryside with a band of Roman Catholics who took up arms against governmental persecution of people of their faith, practiced by a vast majority of the population.

title: Soccer Clubs Latest Stadium Proposal Would Give the Yankees a New Neighbor
description: A Major League Soccer franchise, whose plans to build a stadium in a Queens park were interrupted by community opposition, has a new site in mind: just south of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx.

title: Harbinger to Take an Insurance Business Public
description: The Harbinger Group moved on Thursday to take one of its insurance businesses public, just over a week after its hedge fund parent agreed to a tougher compromise with the Securities and Exchange Commission over accusations of market manipulation.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Blowing the Smooth Out of the Summer
description: Imagine for a moment that you are the person charged with orchestrating performances at this years MTV Video Music Awards. The show falls near the end of summer, and as summers go, 2013 was soporific. For 11 weeks, Robin Thickes Blurred Lines, a lite-funk jazzercize workout that titillates in spite of itself, has been the most popular song in the country. America is lightly snoring.

title: Talks to Avert a Fiscal Crisis in the Fall End With No Result
description: WASHINGTON  A White House meeting with Senate Republicans to try to find a path forward on deficit reduction and avert a fiscal crisis in the fall ended Thursday with both sides saying the talks have proven fruitless and might not continue.

title: Taliban Attack Prompts Call for Coalition Air Support
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban ambushed an Afghan police convoy on the main highway between Herat and Kandahar on Thursday, setting off a firefight that left 15 police officers dead and grew so intense that the police called in international air support, officials said.

title: Wildfire Chokes Off Tourist Towns Livelihood
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK  Greg Jones has not seen a tourist in almost a week.

title: Myriad Menus, Casual Comfort
description: Billy Grant, the chef and co-owner, is the force behind Restaurant Bricco, the West Hartford powerhouse renowned for its deep-dish pastas. Around the corner, meanwhile, Mr. Grant has revised the menu at Grants, his flagship restaurant, which he owns with two of his brothers, adding burgers, blue-plate specials and other comfort-food touches to knock down prices and make things more casual.

title: For a Veteran of the Era of a 5-Cent Subway Fare, the Retirement Age Is 91
description: Inside an open-air wooden booth, with only bars separating him from the public, Thomas Henry Merrick started what became nearly seven decades of helping to move New York by making change for people who needed a nickel for the turnstile.

title: Apache to Sell Stake in Egyptian Holdings to Sinopec for $3.1 Billion
description: The Apache Corporation agreed on Thursday to sell a third of its Egyptian oil and gas business to Sinopec, the big Chinese petroleum company, for $3.1 billion in cash as part of a continued effort to sell off assets and rebalance its portfolio.

title: As Floods Ravage Sudan, Young Volunteers Revive a Tradition of Aid
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Their temporary headquarters are a beehive of young volunteers buzzing in and out of rooms, up and down stairs, carrying bags of donated food, medicine and large packets of plastic sheets.

title: Portraits of Antisocial Individualism
description: James Cagney spent much of the 1940s trying to distance himself from the swaggering, tough-guy roles that had made him one of the definitive stars of Depression America. After extricating himself from his Warner Brothers contract in 1942, Cagney formed his own independent company, Cagney Productions, with his younger brother William, to make films for release through United Artists.

title: For Weiner These Days, Crowds Arent Easy to Find
description: A few short weeks ago, Anthony D. Weiner stood at the pinnacle of political celebrity, his every voter handshake chronicled by a voracious mob of reporters.

title: Taylor Farms, Big Food Supplier, Grapples With Frequent Recalls
description: Taylor Farms, the large vegetable producer whose salad mix is being investigated in connection with an outbreak of illness involving hundreds of people in 22 states, has had an unusual number of voluntary recalls for potentially tainted products in the last three years.

title: Recalls by Taylor Farms
description: JUNE 2013 Salad greens used in restaurants. Tainted with bacteria sickening more than 600 people. A little more than 200 of those cases were linked to greens supplied by Taylor.

title: Toxic Populi
description: By now, most people have heard something about Delbert Belton, known as Shorty, the World War II veteran beaten to death last week in a parking lot of the town where I grew up, Spokane, Wash. At age 88, Belton was the Greatest Generation in a five-foot frame: he survived the Battle of Okinawa and worked 30 years in the cauldron of the local aluminum plant, only to get his head bashed in by couple of thugs in search of his wallet, as police reported.

title: Aim of U.S. Attack: Restore a Red Line That Became Blurred
description: WASHINGTON  The goal of the cruise missile strikes the United States is planning to carry out in Syria is to restore the smudged red line that President Obama drew a year ago against the use of poison gas.

title: Tilting Toward Portugal
description: On a sultry August night, two women stood just inside the door at Bistro 12, appraising the menu. Regrettably, their eyes did not wander to our table, where summery dishes were arrayed like so many luminous seashells: grilled octopus on a bed of wilted, garlic-strewn escarole; red and golden beets crowned with crescents of fresh orange; chunky red tomatoes and slips of purple onion tossed in a oregano-flecked vinaigrette; and fresh sardines cradled in endive leaves. As they turned to leave, having decided to try their luck elsewhere, my impulse was to jump up and tell them to stay.

title: Family Problems With Delicate Solutions
description: Among the Yoruba of Africa, said Andrew Dosunmu, the Nigerian-born director and photographer, uncles are held in special regard. If my uncle walks in here, he said over lunch in Brooklyn, I introduce him as my dad, because hes responsible for me if my fathers not around. Your uncle is the same as your dad. The idea is, its the same blood, and theres an obligation.

title: In Thailand, Rubber Price Plunge Has Political Cost
description: KHUAN NGOEN, Thailand  The rubber farmers of southern Thailand are inured to hardship, whether from the toilsome predawn harvests in mosquito-infested plantations or the vagaries of the market for their latex. But this month, they snapped.

title: One Great Big War
description: Whats the biggest threat to world peace right now? Despite the horror, its not chemical weapons in Syria. Its not even, for the moment, an Iranian nuclear weapon. Instead, its the possibility of a wave of sectarian strife building across the Middle East.

title: An East End Study in True Beach Living
description: It was one of those late summer Saturdays when the air carries a slight chill and a hint of dread; the end of the season could no longer be denied.

title: The Face Scan Arrives
description: WASHINGTON  THE future of technological surveillance is fast approaching  and we are doing far too little to prepare ourselves.

title: Gothams Towering Ambitions
description: FOR much of the last century, New York City has been the financial, cultural, media, retailing and fashion capital of not just the country but the world. Yet the great Hudson River metropolis is in danger of losing that status because of a growing local attitude that favors the old over the new, stability over growth, the status quo over change and short buildings over tall ones.

title: Facebook Post Said to Be by Assads Son Dares Americans to Attack
description: A Facebook post said to be written by the 11-year-old son of the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, and liked or commented on by several people who appear to be the children and grandchildren of other senior members of Mr. Assads government, may offer a glimpse into the mindset of Syrias ruling elite as the country braces for a potential Western strike in response to a chemical weapons attack on Aug. 21.

title: In New Wave of Walkouts, Fast-Food Strikers Gain Momentum
description: As a wave of one-day walkouts by fast-food workers gains momentum in a push for a $15 hourly wage, the movement has been notable both for the prominence of young faces and for the audacity of their demand.

title: Lottery Numbers
Some Good News for the Yankees: Nunezs M.R.I. Is Negative
description: The Yankees said the magnetic resonance imaging test on Eduardo Nunezs right knee came back negative Thursday, a morsel of good news in what is turning into a frustrating season. Nunez, who twisted his knee on the turf in Toronto on Tuesday, is listed as day-to-day. He was not able to play Wednesday, nor was the regular second baseman Robinson Cano, who was hit in the left hand with a pitch Tuesday.

title: Determined Romanian Women Finding Success
description: Simona Halep has recently been best known as the player who ended Marion Bartolis career, bringing the Wimbledon champion to tears after defeating her in Cincinnati.

title: The Unsaved World
description: The rupiah is falling! Head for the hills! On second thought, keep calm and carry on.

title: E-Cigarette Makers Ads Echo Tobaccos Heyday
description: Electronic cigarettes may be a creation of the early 21st century, but critics of the devices say manufacturers are increasingly borrowing marketing tactics that are more reminiscent of the heady days of tobacco in the mid-1900s.

title: Cracking Down on Predatory Payday Lenders
description: The predatory industry known as payday lending is finally feeling the bite of state authorities alarmed that low-income borrowers are being gouged into long-term debt running at impossible interest rates of 500 percent and more.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 30, 2013
description: Once you realize youre not going to die or get covered in toxic sludge, its pretty relaxing.

title: Looming Airstrikes in Syria Pose Test for Egypts Leaders and the Opposition
description: CAIRO  Egyptians on Thursday braced for the ninth weekend of protests against the militarys ouster of the countrys president as the looming possibility of Western airstrikes against Syria injected a new element of volatility onto the streets.

title: Statehouse Swagger in the Gun Debate
description: As a measure of the gun cultures dangerous sway over statehouse politicians, it is hard to top the pending proposal in Missouri that would pronounce all federal gun safety laws null and void in the state and allow the arrest of federal agents who try to enforce them.

title: In Losses, Blake Still Controls Exit
description: Two and a half days after he had announced his career was ending, James Blake found himself saying goodbye Thursday just after midnight, giving an emotional on-court interview after his loss in a fifth-set tiebreaker in his first-round match against Ivo Karlovic.

title: Protesters Demand Montana Judge Resign Over Rape Sentencing
description: Angry that a Montana judge sentenced a former teacher who had admitted to raping a 14-year-old student to only a month in jail, several hundred people gathered outside the Yellowstone County Courthouse in Billings on Thursday, demanding that the judge resign. The victim committed suicide three years after the rape, just before her 17th birthday.

title: Retracing a Long and Winding Road
description: There are places Freda Kelly will remember all her life  sights she saw and experiences she gained as the secretary to the Beatles, their fan club and their manager, as well as a friend and trusted confidante of John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr for nearly the entire duration of their history-shaping rock group.

title: Settlement Is Given a Mixed Reception
description: When news circulated Thursday that the N.F.L. had agreed to pay $765 million to settle a concussion lawsuit, it was met with mostly positive reactions from some family members of players involved in the suit.

title: When Money Shouts
description: A tsunami of outside political money is cresting and crashing on the New York City primary election. The debris is all around: glossy leaflets, harsh TV ads, robocalls and pseudo-grass-roots events like the rally Wednesday in Greenwich Village denouncing the City Council speaker, Christine Quinn, who is running for mayor. The event was sponsored by a group called NYC Is Not for Sale, a creation of one union boss and two wealthy business executives, who have channeled their antipathy  and about $1.4 million  into an all-negative campaign for the notional candidate they call Anybody but Quinn.

title: In Trial Account, Chinese Ex-Official Strays From Script
description: BEIJING  In secret remarks on the final session of his trial, Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party star, denied on Monday that he had tried to upset the partys selection of top leaders or grab extensive new powers for himself, according to a court observers written record of his closing statement.

title: Law Banning Gay Cure Is Upheld in California
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal appeals court on Thursday upheld Californias ban on therapies that aim to change the sexual orientations of gay and lesbian minors.

description: The program was originally called Sons and Daughters. And although it was supposed to protect JPMorgan Chases business dealings in China, the program went so off track that it is now the focus of a federal bribery investigation in the United States, interviews and a confidential government document show.

title: Democrats See Value in Texas in Candidacy for Governor
description: FORT WORTH  Early this month, Wendy Davis, the unknown Texas state senator who rocketed to fame this summer with her 11-hour filibuster to block an anti-abortion bill, met with strategists of the Democratic Governors Association at their K Street offices in Washington. They were urging her to run for governor next year, even though Texas is not among their realistic targets for flipping a Republican-held executive mansion.

title: California: Veterans Center Lease Ruled Illegal
description: Judge S. James Otero of Federal District Court ruled Thursday that the Department of Veterans Affairs violated federal law in leasing for commercial use parts of its campus in West Los Angeles. The ruling was in response to a class-action lawsuit on behalf of four homeless veterans, who objected to the lease when homelessness among veterans was high. Judge Otero ruled that Congress permitted such lease agreements only if the property was going to be used to provide health or other services for veterans. The campus has been leased for, among other things, a laundry for a luxury hotel.

title: Massachusetts: Ex-Official Refunds Contributions
description: Former Lt. Gov. Timothy P. Murray on Thursday agreed to refund $50,000 and pay a $30,000 fine to settle accusations that he accepted illegal campaign contributions. Attorney General Martha Coakley said Mr. Murray received $50,000 in contributions illegally solicited by two public employees. One of them, Michael McLaughlin, an ex-housing official serving a three-year sentence for lying about his income to federal authorities, was indicted Thursday on charges of unlawfully soliciting campaign contributions from state employees.

title: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspects Classmate Charged
description: A classmate of Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the Boston Marathon bombing suspect, was indicted Thursday on two counts of making false statements during the investigation. The man, Robel Phillipos, 19, is accused of concealing from investigators the fact that he accompanied two of Mr. Tsarnaevs other friends, Dias Kadyrbayev and Azamat Tazhayakov, to Mr. Tsarnaevs dormitory at the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth days after the bombing. Investigators say that the men removed items including a laptop and a backpack, and that Mr. Kadyrbayev disposed of the backpack. Mr. Phillipos could face up to eight years in prison on each count and a $250,000 fine. Mr. Kadyrbayev and Mr. Tazhayakov have been charged with obstruction of justice.

title: 2 Guantnamo Detainees Transferred to Algeria
description: The Pentagon announcedon Thursdaythat it had transferred two Algerian detainees from the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to their native country. The two men, Nabil Said Hadjarab and Mutia Sadiq Ahmad Sayyab, who have spent more than a decade incarcerated without charges, were the first detainees to leave the prison since President Obama renewed his pledge to close it in May.

title: Survivor of Back Woes Soldiers On
description: NORTON, Mass.  Tiger Woodss back woes dominated the news on the eve of the $8 million Deutsche Bank Championship. Fifteen of the 24 questions he fielded on Thursday  and 12 of the first 14  concerned his back, which bothered him last weekend at the Barclays in Jersey City.

title: U.N. Leader Urges Obama to Hold Off on a Strike
description: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, cut short a European trip and rushed home on Thursday to prepare for a weekend briefing by his team of chemical weapons inspectors on the ground in Syria. He implored President Obama to refrain from a threatened military strike and to allow the procedures enshrined in the United Nations Charter to take their course.

title: A Resident Shocks a Small Town
description: Paul Craig Cobb, 61, has been buying up property in an effort to transform Leith, N.D., into a colony for white supremacists.

title: Frank Pulli, First Umpire to Use Replay, Dies at 78
description: Frank Pulli, who in 1999 became the first major league umpire to use instant replay to verify a call, nearly a decade before the league approved the practice, died on Wednesday at his home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 78.

title: Astors Son Was Contrite Ahead of Release From Prison
description: After declining to speak at his trial or sentencing, Anthony D. Marshall was recently given one more chance to express remorse for stealing millions of dollars from his mother, the philanthropist and socialite Brooke Astor, in her waning years.

title: Rival Speaks of Bookers Sexuality, Leading to Charge of Homophobia
description: The New Jersey Senate race has lacked much in the way of drama, with Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark, a Democrat, holding a commanding lead in the polls against the Republican nominee, Steve Lonegan.

title: Monfils Wins Crowd by Charming It, but Isner Takes the Match by Force
description: The highest-seeded American male at the United States Open, John Isner, left the court after the third set of his second-round match Thursday to resounding cheers for his opponent, Gal Monfils.

title: Rules Trickle Down; Money in Settlement Wont
description: When more than 4,000 retired players agreed to accept $765 million to settle their lawsuit with the N.F.L., the league was able to cling to its most valuable claim of all  that it never ignored or obscured the risks of concussions.

title: Sathima Bea Benjamin, Jazz Singer and Activist, Dies at 76
description: Sathima Bea Benjamin, who as an internationally recognized jazz singer became both an ambassador for her South African homeland and a beacon of principled objection to apartheid, died on Aug. 20 at her home in Cape Town. She was 76.

title: Bruce C. Murray, Who Helped Earth Learn of Mars, Dies at 81
description: Bruce C. Murray, a planetary geologist who won his spurs interpreting findings of early missions to Mars and who led NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory through a time of flagging support for new flights in the late 1970s, died Thursday at his home in Oceanside, Calif. He was 81.

title: History as a Guide in Syria
description: Analysts looking for historical parallels to the current situation in Syria say that past military engagements seen as successful have tended to have limited and clear objectives.

title: Powerful Forehand Propels Sock at Open
description: Jack Socks forehand is best described as a windshield wiper stuck on double speed.

title: Giant Breaks Left Leg Again
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The sight of Andre Brown limping off the field in the first half was troubling for the Giants. The announcement in the second half that he had broken his left leg  again  was potentially devastating.

title: The Mayoral Candidates on the Parks
description: The parks system in New York City expanded and  many would argue  flourished under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, with the creation of nearly 800 acres of new parkland, reclaimed stretches of waterfront and myriad park renovations.

title: The Mets, Brought to You in ...
description: The Mets are headed for their fifth straight losing season, with no guarantee the streak will end in 2014. Their captain and best everyday player, David Wright, has been sidelined with a hamstring strain for nearly a month. Their best pitcher, Matt Harvey, has gone from Cy Young Award candidate to someone who may soon need Tommy John surgery. He might not pitch again for a year.

title: Teenage Qualifier Shows Her Potential, and Age, in a Second-Round Defeat
description: They cheered and shouted her name before she took out her racket. When Victoria Duval made her appearance at the United States Open on Thursday, the fans wanted Americas newest tennis darling to continue her magic, to jump joyfully in the air as she did Tuesday and make an impressive landing in the third round.

title: Michael Voltaggios Gutsy Food Adventure in Copenhagen
description: Earlier this week, the brothers Michael and Bryan Voltaggio, American chefs and former Top Chef contestants, traveled to Copenhagen for the third MAD Symposium, an annual food festival that brings together chefs and farmers. Curated by David Chang and his Lucky Peach team, this years two-day sold-out symposium was dedicated to guts  meaning both innards and courage. Chang introduced the theme literally, however, by bringing out the butcher Dario Cecchini, who proceeded to carve a pig on the stage. Between events, Michael, the chef and owner of Ink in Los Angeles, and Bryan, the executive chef of Volt restaurant in Maryland, caught up with fellow chefs and friends. Here, Michael shares his photos from the event.

title: The Central Challenge in U.S. Health Policy
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Word of the Day | mishap
description: mishap \mis-hap, mis-\ noun

title: Jets Backups Make Final Push for Roster Spots
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It was fairly easy to identify the division on the Jets sideline Thursday night. The players wearing baseball caps or team-issued workout gear had secured roster spots. Those still competing for roles, or promotions on the depth chart, held their helmets or wore them.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10 P.M. (Discovery) ALASKA STEEL MEN From repairing a hull underwater in frigid seas to sealing a cracked vessel that has struck ice, there is no nautical task that Dennis Butts; his wife, Theresa; and their crew of welders and pipe fitters at Quality Marine in Kodiak, Alaska, arent willing to try. No matter how tough you are, Mother Nature is tougher, Mr. Butts says in this new three-week series. Were talking boats sinking to the bottom of the ocean. You make a mistake, people die.

title: Walk-On Ritual
description: West Virginias annual tryout for football walk-ons draws roughly 80 students seeking one of about five spots. Even those chosen are unlikely to see any game action.

title: News Quiz | August 30, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/Siena College poll of New York City consisted of telephone interviews with 1,561 adult residents throughout the city conducted Aug. 19 to Aug. 28. Of these residents, 1,162 said they were registered to vote.

title: Stringer and Spitzer Seek Votes of Women
Democratic Voters on the Candidates
description: The New York Times and Siena College asked likely voters in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary for their opinions on the candidates for mayor and comptroller.

title: Leading Democrats, de Blasio Has Broad Support as Primary Nears
description: Frustration with New York Citys unaffordability and its aggressive police tactics is elevating Bill de Blasio, once dismissed as a left-leaning long shot, into the lead of the Democratic mayoral primary field, according to a poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 7 Mourners in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber pretending to be among the people receiving guests at a mourning ceremony in northern Afghanistan on Friday detonated his explosive and killed at least seven people, including the local district governor, according to the governors spokesman.

title: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Aug. 30, 2013
description: Take the Quiz

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Tour of Graffiti Art Around New York City
description: In the article A Feast of Urban Scrawl, Luminous and Legal, Randy Kennedy provides a guided tour of what he considers to be the best graffiti art around New York City.

title: The Amazon, Through an Anthropologists Eye
description: Nicolas Janowski lives in Buenos Aires, one of the most cosmopolitan cities in South America. But in recent years he has spent as much time as he can traveling around a region that is about as different from his home town as can be imagined  the western reaches of the Amazon, with its dizzying and imposing mix of jungle, rivers, mountains and savannah extending over Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru.

title: America Movil Threatens to Pull Bid for Dutch Cellphone Operator
description: LONDON  The Latin American telecommunications giant Amrica Mvil threatened on Friday to walk away from its proposed bid of 7.2 billion euros, or $9.5 billion, for the Dutch cellphone operator KPN after a local foundation moved to block the takeover.

title: U.S. Releases Detailed Intelligence on Syrian Chemical Attack
description: PARIS  Seeking to move beyond Britains blindsiding rejection of military intervention in the Syrian conflict, the Obama administration received strong support from France on Friday and released a detailed intelligence summary to buttress its contention that the Syrian government used chemical munitions in an Aug. 21 attack, asserting for the first time that it had killed 1,429 people, nearly a third of them children.

title: New York Today: Summers End
description: Its the last weekday of what is, unofficially, the last week of summer.

title: A Preview of  Retro Reports Season Two
description: After a summer hiatus, our weekly online video feature, Retro Report, has returned with a fresh look at one of the biggest stories of the summer of 1988, the unsuccessful attempts to control wildfires that burned through Yellowstone National Park for months.

title: Look, Its a Trabant, Its an El Camino. Its the Trabantimino.
description: The town of Espaola, N.M., bears the nickname, The Lowrider Capital of the World. Each summer, the town holds the annual MainStreet ShowDown, a lowrider show sponsored by Lowrider Magazine that draws several hundred cars to compete for top honors.

title: What to Watch at the U.S. Open on Friday
description: After spending most of her career chained to the baseline, Li Na has suddenly fallen in love with the volley.

title: Number of Jobless People Declines Slightly in Europe
description: PARIS  While unemployment remained at record levels in percentage terms, the actual number of jobless people in the euro zone fell slightly in July, according to data published on Friday, offering fresh evidence that Europes struggling economy was taking tentative steps toward a recovery.

title: A Top Bankers Image, Clouded
description: FRANKFURT  During a long career that took him to the top of the European banking world, the Swiss executive Josef Ackermann has survived countless boardroom intrigues and even a criminal prosecution.

title: Daily Report: Start-Ups That Could Be the Next Big Thing
description: When it comes to technology start-ups, there are a lot of paths to success, Jenna Wortham reports.

title: China Brokerage Firm Fined $85 Million Over Fat-Finger Trades
description: Updated, 11:51 a.m. |

title: Seamus Heaney, Irish Poet of Soil and Strife, Dies at 74
description: Seamus Heaney, the 1995 Nobel laureate in literature, who was often called the greatest Irish poet since Yeats, died on Friday in Dublin. He was 74.

title: Indias Lower House Passes Land Acquisition Bill
description: NEW DELHI In the footsteps of the passage of the food security bill earlier this week, Indias lower house of Parliament, the Lok Sabha, passed the populist land acquisition bill on Thursday with an overwhelming majority.

title: JPMorgans Sons and Daughters Program
description: AT JPMORGAN, A PROGRAM TO HIRE CHINAS ELITE | JPMorgan Chase started a program in 2006 called Sons and Daughters, as friends and family of Chinas ruling elite were clamoring for jobs at the bank, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. Although it was originally supposed to protect the banks business dealings in China, it went so off track that it is now the focus of a federal bribery investigation in the United States, according to interviews and a confidential government document.

title: Why We Fight Terrorism
description: Film lovers in Pakistan have for a while been writing obituaries about Lollywood, the countrys film industry, named after the city of Lahore where it is based. At its peak in 1968, the industry released 128 films in one year; last year, only five new local films hit the cinemas.

title: Hot Night on a Slow Bus
description: Dear Diary:

title: God, She Said, Went Gotcha, but Their Marriage Got Stronger
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Today in Small Business: Optimism!
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: The Making Of | A Restaurant in Harlem Where Everything Old Is New Again
description: We can all agree on the value of reuse, repurposing, recycling, upcycling. But too often in interior design projects, these processes are treated as ends rather than means, with results that are usually more earnest than elegant. At Vinatera, a Harlem restaurant that opened in April, almost every material has had a previous life (or lives), but thats not what you notice about the room. Instead, you see a subtle layering of color and form and sophisticated details. Yes, the design is environmentally friendly. But above all, Vinatera is chic.

title: The Baht and the Bubble Excuse
description: Kevin ORourke has been saying for a while that its useful to think of Ireland as Thailand without the baht. In this context, the history of the Asian crisis sheds some light on one of the ways defenders of European austerity policies move the goalposts: by claiming that the pre-crisis peak isnt relevant for comparison purposes, because it was inflated by a bubble.

title: The Advantages of Being Asaram Bapu
description: Asumal Sirumalani, a popular Indian spiritual leader who is known to his followers as Asaram Bapu, has fought a long battle against sex.

title: The Gold Mine in the Hall
description: Now is the season for management companies to begin assembling next years budget for their co-op and condo clients. And guess what, folks: your maintenance is going up.

title: Its a Madhouse: Winner Declared in Chimpanzee Art Contest
description: How much more like humans can chimpanzees be? They share what is believed to be more than 90 percent of our DNA, they seek to express themselves creatively and when they win prestigious art contests they cant be bothered to get on the phone to express their gratitude.

title: The Cadillac Elmiraj Concept: A Little British, a Little French, a Lot American
description: Sometimes, getting at the essence of something involves taking a step back, approaching from a fresh angle. Perhaps thats what happened at Cadillac when the sleek Elmiraj concept was created.
