Its designers are an Englishman and a Frenchman, but they seem to have been very focused on the best facets of American design.

title: Fantasy Football: When to Take a Chance on Injury-Prone Players
description: Its a fantasy football dilemma every season: if, and when, do I take a chance on those talented players who never seem to stay healthy? If you time these picks right, it could give you a major advantage in your league. If not, you could be in for a very long season.

title: Hurricane Marco Rubio  A Winning Climate Campaign?
description: Climate campaigners seem to think they have a winner with this takedown of elected officials who reject global warming science, in which fake news reports talk of the turmoil and tragedy created by Hurricane Marco Rubio, Hurricane James Inhofe, Hurricane John Boehner and more.

title: Aug. 30: Where the Candidates Are Today
description: Planned events for the mayoral candidates, according to the campaigns and organizations they are affiliated with. Times are listed as scheduled but frequently change.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: Tattoos Cause a Bridal Party Problem

title: Pynchons Gravitational Pull
description: In an essay in the September issue of Harpers, Jonathan Franzen quotes  at what he concedes is embarrassing length  from letters he sent to his fiance when he was 22. I recognize Pynchon as my major precursor, the young, besotted Franzen wrote. The better he is the more I want to hate him but the less I can. In an interview with The Paris Review in 2010, Franzen described discovering Gravitys Rainbow: It was like getting the flu to read that book. It was like I was fighting off some very aggressive infection. He wrote to his then-fiance: Ill get over Pynchon somehow. Maybe through criticism, some discontinuity, some dialectic, that will enable me to forget him. His future wife proved a stronger motivation than any dialectic. About his Pynchonian love letters, Franzen told The Paris Review, I think its significant that she hated those letters and made her hatred of them known, and that I steered away from that voice.

title: Stay of Execution
description: Furman v. Georgia is among the oddest Supreme Court cases in American history. Decided in 1972, it struck down every death penalty statute in the nation as then practiced without outlawing the death penalty itself. The ruling, based on the constitutional protection against cruel and unusual punishment, stunned even the closest court watchers. The death penalty seemed impregnable. It was part of the bedrock of Americas legal system, steeped in the intent of the founders, the will of most state legislatures and the forceful  if occasional  rulings of the courts.

title: Paperback Row
description: INSIDE SCIENTOLOGY: The Story of Americas Most Secretive Religion,  by Janet Reitman. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $15.95.) This is a meticulous history of the Church of Scientology, from its birth as a 1950s self-help system in the science fiction imagination of L. Ron Hubbard (1911-86) to its current status as a worldwide movement. Reitman, who spent five years piercing the walls Scientologists put up against outsiders, has rendered what our reviewer, Garry Wills, called the most complete picture of Scientology so far.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE SMARTEST KIDS IN THE WORLD: And How They Got That Way,  by Amanda Ripley. (Simon & Schuster, $28.) A look at countries that are outeducating us (Finland, South Korea, Poland) through the eyes of American high school students abroad.

title: Arbor Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Discomfort
description: Tell about the South, his Harvard classmates beseech Quentin Compson in Absalom, Absalom! Youll notice he doesnt have to be asked twice. Sensitive Southerners  and Southern writers most of all  seem to love nothing better than explaining themselves and their region to outsiders (or to themselves, if no outsider is handy). There are exceptions, though, and Wilton Barnhardt would stand at the head of any list: though born and reared in the South, he has, over the last two decades, produced three well-regarded novels that almost never stray south of the Mason-Dixon line. There ought to be a prize for such forbearance. Or maybe he was just biding time, stockpiling ammunition. Because at long last he has tackled the South head on. Lacerating but affectionate, as exuberant as it is shrewd, Lookaway, Lookaway is a Southern novel so sure-footed the only real question for Barnhardt is, What took you so long?

title: His Favorite Wife
description: Ive often wondered what it takes to be the wife of a captain of industry. What combination of boundless optimism and self-delusion is necessary to live with someone whose real lover is his work, who cannot turn off his competitiveness when he walks through the door, whose wealth means his opportunities and temptations with women are somewhere between a lot and infinite, and whose children and wife exist as a beautiful backdrop to what he considers his real accomplishments?

title: Island Magic
description: At first, I resisted what appeared to be the fablelike delicacy of Edwidge Danticats new novel, Claire of the Sea Light. Was it going to be too precious? Would her lyricism camouflage or ennoble Haitis life-or-death struggles? But it quickly became apparent that her hypnotic prose was perfectly suited to its setting, the tragic and yet magical seaside town of Ville Rose.

title: Will the Mile-High Club Shut Down?
description: The first college Meh List; Mario Batalis Labor Day drink recipe; how Eric LeGrand stayed positive after paralysis.

title: There Are No Sound Moral Arguments Against Performance-Enhancing Drugs
description: The argument against performance-enhancing drugs in sports is that the drugs give players an unfair advantage. But how do P.E.D.s differ from Tommy John surgery? Or pre-emptive Tommy John surgery? What about rich kids? Is their access to superior coaching, facilities and equipment a similarly unfair advantage? In a society that embraces plastic surgery, Botox injections, Viagra and all kinds of enhancements, what moral line do P.E.D.s cross? LYNN MOFFAT, SLEEPY HOLLOW, N.Y.

title: Two (Sucked) Thumbs Up
description: A year ago, on the day my wife, Liz, would give birth to our first child, we sat down to watch The Avengers. Shed already seen it, and it wasnt something I was particularly dying to see  superhero movies arent usually my thing. My cinematic taste generally tends to the somewhat obscure and the challenging  Id much rather rewatch anything by Rainer Werner Fassbinder than sit through any of the Fast and Furious sequels. But Liz had started to feel the fluttering of early labor, and our birth-class instructor had advised us that this particular stage could last for several hours. The best thing to do, she said, was find a distraction: go for a walk, play cards or watch a dumb movie. As it turned out, there wasnt going to be a need for any distractions. Within minutes, that fluttering became what Liz described, with some understatement, as cramps. What followed was such an incredibly compressed labor that theres actually a special name for it: precipitous labor, which happens less than 3 percent of the time. Our son, Jack, was born an hour and a half later, at home, in our bed. I still havent seen The Avengers.

title: Googling Yourself Takes on a Whole New Meaning
description: Heres what you see if you look at my face: a skinny titanium headband stretched across my forehead. It looks like a futuristic pair of sunglasses, minus the lenses. On my right-hand side theres a computer, a metal frame with a small, clear cube of plastic perched just over my eye. When I tilt my head upward a bit, or run my finger along the side of the frame, the cube lights up. What I see, floating six inches in front of me, is a pinkish, translucent computer screen. It gives me access to a few simple apps: Google search, text messaging, Twitter, a to-do list, some hourly news headlines from CNN (See a Truck Go Airborne, Fly Over Median, Dolphin Deaths Alarm Biologists). Beside the screen is a teensy camera built into the frame of the glasses, ready to record anything Im looking at.

title: Images of Jazz Greats
description: Previously unpublished pictures of Billie Holiday, Duke Ellington, Dizzy Gillespie and more.

title: The 8.18.13 Issue
Who Made That Traffic Radar?
description: He kept the lights off, because he didnt want anyone to see in, says John L. Barker of the rooms his father rented to test a radar system he was making for the U.S. military. John L. Barker Sr.  then an engineer at Automatic Signal Company  had been working on traffic lights in the 1930s, but during World War II, he dedicated himself to military research. He pointed the machine out a window, and he tested it on cars that drove through an intersection. Barker was about 8 years old at the time and admits that his memories are hazy. I have no idea why I was even involved, he says.

title: Thomas Menino Is a Cranberry-Juice-Drinking Workhorse
description: Theres an old maxim that politicians are either show horses or workhorses. After 20 years as mayor of Boston, youve won a reputation as a workhorse. What do you think the show horses can learn from the workhorses?  Well, a mayor has to be a workhorse. You cant be a show horse, because people depend on you. We see our constituents every day. You go buy a newspaper, go to a coffee shop, buy gas for our car  you see them.

title: A Brief Vacation From Myself
description: I was looking in my closet, choosing a shirt, when I lost my mind.

title: Alternate Realms
description: In Aimee Benders short stories, the value of life is measured in terms of goodness, succulence and simplicity, all qualities that can be tasted, chewed and ultimately swallowed by the mouth or the mind. In Appleless (one of this new books many parable-like fictions), the nameless narrator distrusts a girl who doesnt appreciate the bright-hued, hand-clutched density and watery meat of apples  and the narrator goes on, with the help of others, to devour every last apple in sight. The overachieving seamstress of Tiger Mending isnt satisfied with simply stitching up cut lips and handkerchiefs; she eventually takes a job in a faraway country sewing the stripes back on ruptured tigers (who apparently yawn too widely for their own good). And in one of Benders best stories, The Red Ribbon, a bored wife cant enjoy sex with her husband unless he pays her. She likes to keep track of their accumulating ecstasies in a ledger:  I need a specific amount, each time, she said, or, clearing her throat, I feel I will melt into nothingness.

title: Big Brother
description: Dennis Bocks third novel, Going Home Again, begins ominously: On the Friday evening before Kaj Adolfsson was killed, I was actually feeling pretty good about things. But readers expecting Nordic noir will be disappointed. The murder, when we finally hear about it in the last few pages, is a minor plot point. This is not a whodunit but a story about reckoning with the past.

title: Free Range
description: Major poets, like trick-or-treaters, tend to arrive in pairs or small groups (whether this is a matter of fate or academic convenience may be debated). And yet from roughly 1930 to 1950, British and Irish poetry seemed to fall under the sway of a single writer: W. H. Auden. Auden was hardly a solitary figure, of course  his compatriots included Louis MacNeice, Stephen Spender and Cecil Day-Lewis (father of Daniel), and the four writers were once thought to be so intimately related that the poet Roy Campbell referred to them as MacSpaunday. But it wasnt a relationship of equals: the MacSpaunday poets were usually considered notable not because of how closely they resembled one another, but because of how much the other three looked like Auden.

title: Fascist Designs
description: As capitalism transformed European economies during the second half of the 19th century, the rise of the masses revolutionized political life. Searching for identity and purpose in a confusing and changing world, many took refuge in nationalism  a continentwide phenomenon that found its most virulent expression in newly created countries like Germany and Italy, where it soon upended culture along with everything else.

title: Land of Mystery
description: A quarter-century ago, North Korea seemed to teeter on the brink of collapse. The end of the cold war in the late 1980s and the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991 suggested that the era of reclusive Communist dictatorships was over. How, asked hopeful observers around the world, could Kim Il-sungs Stalinist wasteland possibly survive under the pressure of its spectacular economic failures and the tide of democracy and capitalism rising around its borders?

title: Winters Bane
description: A four-day blizzard has left the village of Three Pines looking like a toy town sheltered under a snow globe. But this secluded Canadian hamlet, tucked away in a valley deep in the mountains, contributes more than its picturesque setting to Louise Pennys latest mystery, HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN (Minotaur, $25.99). You might even say Three Pines is the hero of the novel.

title: Bon Courage
description: In Paris, during his sabbatical in the early 1980s, a dear friend proposed we meet not for drinks at the Caf de Flore but for ice cream at Berthillon. The doctors have forbidden me alcohol, he said. In France! Can you imagine? Hed been having odd health problems, one after the other, that they couldnt explain. Months later, he developed Pneumocystis pneumonia and got his explanation. He died soon thereafter; our nave days were at an end.

title: Small-Town Savant
description: Ten years ago, when Mark Haddons Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time turned up on the best-seller list and won a number of literary awards, the novels autistic narrator beguiled readers with his unconventional point of view. Today, even as controversy surrounds the revised classification of autism in the latest version of the American Psychiatric Associations Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, the quirky yet remarkably perceptive points of view of autistic narrators have become increasingly familiar in every category of fiction, from young adult to science fiction to popular and literary fiction.

title: Chronicle: Fiction in Translation
description: THROUGH THE NIGHT  By Stig Saeterbakken  Translated by Sean KinsellaDalkey Archive, paper, $15.

title: Inside the List
description: Dark Corners: Marisha Pessl made a lot of noise with her first novel, Special Topics in Calamity Physics  it spent three weeks on the hardcover fiction list in 2006, and was named one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of the year. Her follow-up, Night Film, hasnt collected quite the same level of praise; in the daily New York Times, Janet Maslin cited a haunting suspicion that the book was more exciting to write than to read.

title: Video Reviews of Passion, One Direction and Abigail Harm
description: In this weeks video, Times critics look at Passion, One Direction: This Is Us and Abigail Harm. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Oral Infections Causing More Hospitalizations
description: Left untreated, a serious tooth abscess can eventually kill.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Life With J. Paul Getty
description: This week, Judith Newman discusses Teddy Getty Gastons memoir, Alone Together; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Evan J. Mandery talks about A Wild Justice, his new book about the death penalty in the U.S.; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Fertility Treatments Produce Heirs Their Parents Never Knew
description: THE number of children conceived through in vitro fertilization has doubled over the last decade. The technology that has made these children possible has also challenged inheritance laws, especially in circumstances when a child is conceived after the death of a parent.

title: Aging Euroskeptics
description: Prakash Loungani has an interesting (but fairly technical) presentation on one of my favorite subjects: comparing the performance of nations within the euro with performance of states within the United States. He also digs up a blast from the past: a 1992 report on a discussion at MIT about the desirability of the euro. The professors  whose names you may recognize  were all euroskeptics.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Life With J. Paul Getty
description: This week, Judith Newman talks about Teddy Gaston Gettys new memoir and Evan J. Mandery discusses A Wild Justice.

title: For Girls in India, the Pressure to Conform Comes From Family
description: I recently watched the remarkable Malala Yousafzai speak at the United Nations to commemorate a day that is named after her. The 16-year-old who was shot by the Taliban, and has since become a celebrated activist for education and womens rights, said that Malala Day was for every boy and every girl who have raised their voice for their rights. She bravely reinterpreted Islam and accused the extremists of being afraid of books, pens and education. The power of the voice of women frightens them, she said.

title: Call It Beyrouth: Beirut With a French Accent
description: I was finishing an aperitif on the porch at Villa Clara while other guests tossed ptanque balls in the nearby yard. The hotels 4-year-old namesake cozied up to her papa, showing off her latest crayon creation. Oh, cest magnifique, said Olivier Gougeon, a French chef and an owner of the property with his wife, Marie-Hlne, an editor of a French-language home dcor magazine.

title: Reader Idea | Considering the Varying Viewpoints on a Pregnancy Prevention Campaign
description: This idea comes from a high school teacher in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Off the Charts: Some Banks Recover, Most Dont
description: Five years ago, the financial crisis was on the verge of getting much worse. Now, an index of bank stocks around the world has recovered most of the ground it lost. But most large banks are still down, some by significant amounts.

title: Too Little, Gone Too Soon
description: One of the things you always heard, back when we were actually talking about stimulus rather than fighting a rearguard action against destructive austerity, was the claim that stimulus spending would inevitably end up becoming a permanent fixture of the economy. This was always said with an air of worldly wisdom  of course thats how these things work!  even though history said very much the opposite.

title: Verizon-Vodafone Deal Would Be a Big Payday for Deal Makers
description: Though deal makers often complain about the slow pace of business in the summer, it appears that one of the biggest takeovers in years is near.

title: A Chicago Church Sees Justice in Lands Bounty
description: CHICAGO  Two generations and 700 miles away from her grandparents farm in Mississippi, Juanita ONeal sat in a parking lot beside the four lanes of West 95th Street here, selling peas and okra and peaches. She wore an apron embroidered with the image of a ripe tomato and the words, Granny and Kids Garden Patch.

title: With Britain Haunted by Iraq, a Harsh Lesson for Cameron
description: LONDON  Humiliated by lawmakers over Syria, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain seems destined to cut a lesser figure, weakened both at home and abroad by a self-made debacle that has also highlighted his war-weary countrys reluctance to get involved with another American project in the Middle East.

title: Seamus Heaneys Journey Into the Wideness of Language
description: Seamus Heaney, the esteemed Irish poet who died on Friday at 74, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1995. At the time, the poet Derek Walcott, a fellow Nobel winner, called Mr. Heaney the guardian spirit of Irish poetry.

title: Hynes Is Attacked by Rival on Felony Conviction Rate
description: Charles J. Hynes, who is running for a seventh term as Brooklyn district attorney, has a long record to scrutinize, and his opponent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, Kenneth P. Thompson, has seized on one statistic that has barely improved since Mr. Hynes took office: his felony conviction rate.

title: Rupee Drops, and Outlook Grows Darker for India
description: MUMBAI, India  The statistical evidence is piling up that Indias economy may be in even worse shape than had been thought.

title: The Importance of Morgan State vs. Army
description: By August 1968, the dream described so eloquently by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. five years earlier had been punctured.

title: Republicans Brush Off the Heritage Foundation
description: It turns out that you can be too crazy even for the right-wing Republican Congressional Caucus. This week, the National Journal reported that the Republican Study Committee, a group of 172 conservative Congressmen, had banned Heritage Foundation employees from its weekly meetings.

title: Exclusive | 104 Willow Street, Brooklyn Heights
description: A Federal-style town house dating to1826 was originally home to an importer of Merino sheep. Its on the market for $12 million.

title: Built When Sheep Grazed in Brooklyn Heights
description: The exquisitely renovated and inventively painted Federal-style town house at 104 Willow Street in Brooklyn Heights began its tenure in 1826 as a custom-built farmhouse with trees as its nearest neighbors.

title: Image of the Day: Aug. 30
Big Ticket | Terrace Swimming for $14.7 Million
description: A sprawling seven-bedroom, nine-and-a-half-bath duplex with a 3,800-square-foot terrace including a private outdoor swimming pool at the Aldyn, at 60 Riverside Boulevard near 63rd Street, sold for $14,711,621.25 and was the most expensive sale of the week, city records show.

title: Five Years After Chaos, Shares of Many Big Banks Are Still Struggling
description: FINANCIAL markets were nervous five years ago, as September 2008 began, but hopeful that the world would stabilize.

title: In Book and Magazine Profile, Views Into Djokovics World
description: Heading into his second-round match against Benjamin Becker on Friday afternoon, top-ranked Novak Djokovic has been on court for only 1 hour 22 minutes at the United States Open. But he has remained in the headlines this week.

title: A Lesson for Boardroom Battles
description: Proxy access may be dead in the United States, but it lives in Israel, to the great regret of Taro Pharmaceutical Industries.

title: Review: 2014 Kia Cadenza
description: Priced at nearly $42,000 for a fully loaded model, the 2014 Cadenza is aimed at upscale buyers, not dancing hamsters. Can the budget brand compete with the Avalon, Impala and Maxima?

title: At 11th Hour, North Korea Cancels Visit By U.S. Envoy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea has rescinded its invitation for a senior American diplomat to travel to Pyongyang on a mission to secure the release of an American Christian missionary imprisoned on charges of committing hostile acts against the government, the State Department said on Friday.

title: Long Odds for Authors Newly Published
description: The Cuckoos Calling became the publishing sensation of the summer when word leaked that its first-time author, Robert Galbraith, was none other than J. K. Rowling, the mega-best-selling creator of Harry Potter.

title: Book Review Podcast: Life With J. Paul Getty
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Judith Newman reviews Alone Together, the new memoir by Teddy Getty Gaston, the fifth and last wife of the billionaire J. Paul Getty. Ms. Newman writes:

title: A Closers Stumbles Are Outnumbered Only by His Saves
description: Where would Jim Johnson, the Baltimore Orioles closer, be without Jerome Holtzman?

title: Calendar: Coming Events in Budapest; Portland, Ore.; South Dakota
description: Budapest InternationalWine Festival, BudapestHeld in Budapest, above, at Buda Castle, this wine event, from Sept. 11 to 15 will salute female winemakers in interviews and special tastings amid the showcase of nearly 200 Hungarian wineries. Guided tastings cover pinots, rieslings and merlots along with the Tokaji wines. Musical programming highlights Hungarian jazz and folk bands. Dairies from 15 nations will participate in the festivals inaugural European cheese contest.

title: What I Love | Lee Child
description: Lee Child, the author of the Jack Reacher books, lives in a Manhattan apartment thats stripped down for action.

title: Lee Child and the Macho of Minimalism
description: To hear Lee Child tell it, the whole thing began well over half a century ago with a picture book.

title: U.S. Assessment of Syrian Use of Chemical Weapons
description: The White House released a report contending with high confidence that the Syrian government used chemical weapons near Damascus.

title: A Soap Opera Bent Out of Shape
description: Patton Oswalt moved gingerly as he eased onto a sofa on the Bushwick, Brooklyn, set of The Heart, She Holler. He was slowed, perhaps, by fatigue after a full morning of shooting this show, a Southern gothic horror-comedy. Or maybe it was the bloody rabbits foot sticking out of his chest.

title: Empty-Handed Guests? Just Forgive or Forget
description: The Field Notes column last Sunday, When You Cant Forget the Gifts You Didnt Get, about those who cannot forgive or forget guests who failed to give a wedding gift, drew nearly 300 comments. And the overwhelming sentiment among the respondents was more generous than the empty-handed guests: they would ignore the oversight, whether it was intentional or not.

title: Kerry Becomes Chief Advocate for U.S. Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Jabbing his finger at the lectern, his voice forceful, his words brimming with indignation, John Kerry laid out the case like the prosecutor he once was, making a closing argument to a skeptical jury.

title: After British Vote, Unusual Isolation for U.S. on Syria
description: WASHINGTON  With a few exceptions in the past half-century, there has been a simple rule of thumb when it comes to international conflict: America does not use force without Britain at its side.

title: New Uses for Cucumbers
description: Last spring, on a whim, I planted one cucumber plant in my small tomato garden and it grew like Jacks beanstalk. Its been putting out long, straight, sturdy seedless cucumbers all summer and Ive been inspired to go beyond the Greek salads and Balkan cucumber and yogurt soups that I customarily enjoy throughout the season.

title: Seamus Heaney Was a Funny Guy
description: Seamus Heaney, who died on Friday, was a great poet, a scholar, a translator of Beowulf, et cetera and so on.

title: Miley Cyrus and the Summer of Smooth
description: Jon Carmanica and Ben Ratliff on the pop stars controversial VMA performance and how it relates to the summer hits of 2013.

title: Congress Points Out the Cost of War
description: President Obama may go it alone with a military strike against the Syrian regime, but for the financially struggling Defense Department there will be a price  and skeptics in Congress appear ready to play the money card.

title: Kerry on Syrias Use of Chemical Weapons
description: A day after the British Parliament voted against military intervention in Syria, the Secretary of State made the case for U.S. involvement.

title: Dress Up Your Salad With Grains
description: You can turn a simple salad into a hearty, texture-rich dish just by adding a few grains, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: The Whole Fish and Nothing But
description: It was thrilling to move to the West Coast after a childhood and adolescence spent well inland, deprived of the oceans bounty.

title: Mediterranean Escher: A Glimpse Inside Tel Avivs Central Bus Station
description: TEL AVIV  As Labor Day weekend approaches, hundreds of thousands of bus passengers, eager to savor summers last gasp, will pass through the Port Authority Bus Terminal. As baffling as some tourists  and even New Yorkers  find the place, imagine that sort of human traffic scurrying through a labyrinth of oddly placed stairways and market stalls. Picture that in your minds eye, and youll know what its like to travel by bus through Tel Aviv.

title: Major Surge Is Unlikely for Prices of U.S. Gas
description: HOUSTON  With all the saber-rattling surrounding Syria and the spike in oil prices over the last week, gasoline prices rose by 2 cents a gallon for a second day in a row on Friday as motorists began to fill up their tanks for the Labor Day weekend.

title: Bill Clinton to Raise Cash for Democratic Governors
description: Bill Clinton, who was the governor of Arkansas before moving to the White House, will return to his political roots  and earn a few more chits for his wifes political future  next month by raising money for the Democratic Governors Association at a high-dollar New York City fund-raiser.

title: With More Aggressive Game, Li Avenges Open Defeat
description: In the year since an up-and-coming youngster crushed her chance to win her favorite Grand Slam event, Li Na has accomplished something remarkable: she seems to have gotten younger.

title: Seamus Heaney in His Own Voice
description: Seamus Heaney, the accomplished and admired Irish poet, reading from his work over the years.

title: Tax Haven Closes for Wealthy Americans
description: LONDON  A tax deal reached between Switzerland and the United States on Thursday effectively put an end to the status of the small Alpine country as a tax haven for wealthy Americans.

title: A Quiet Beauty Flying By
description: Each summer, a quiet migration gets under way for North American shorebirds. Measured in sheer numbers, the volume is astounding as millions of birds collect along the Atlantic coast. What is both miraculous and unnerving is that the North Atlantic Flyway guides them directly through some of the densest population centers on earth virtually unnoticed. Except for delighted bird watchers and worried managers at local airports, most New Yorkers are unaware that outside their windows, birds are coursing along an ancient migration route.

title: Ex-Goldman Trader Fined $500,000
description: A former Goldman Sachs trader who pleaded guilty in a criminal case earlier this year to fabricating huge positions to protect his bonus agreed on Friday to pay a $500,000 fine in a related civil matter.

title: The Audacity of the Fight for Higher Wages
description: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: In Life's Race, the Pastor Burns Rubber
description: The Rev. Scott Kraniak, chaplain at the Riverhead Raceway stock car track on Long Island, asks God to watch over drivers.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A seven-bedroom split-level ranch in Hewlett Harbor and three-bedroom town house in Tarrytown.

title: In California, Intense Debate Over Home Care
description: An important struggle over home health care is playing out in California, the nations most populous state, including nearly five million residents age 65 and older.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Two-bedroom co-ops, in Chelsea and on the Upper West Side and a town house in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Tale of the Stingray
description: The Corvette Sting Ray arrived for 1963 and was a landmark for the brand.

title: In News Coverage and Editorials on Syria, How Much Skepticism in The Times?
description: Many Times readers are looking at recent news coverage of Syria, and editorials on the same subject, through the lens of another international conflict: the United States invasion of Iraq.

title: Pray, Then Hit the Gas
description: Just before the cars took the track at Riverhead Raceway on a recent Saturday night, a souped-up 1965 Comet Cyclone roared out and roused the crowd by squealing and smoking its wheels and peeling out.

title: Tennis in Harlem
description: At the U.S. Open this week and next, thousands of tennis fans have been and will be visiting Arthur Ashe Stadium at the tournaments site in Queens. Its not all that far from where Ashe spent some time in Harlem honing his skills with a tennis coach named Sydney Llewellyn. According to another former tennis student, Bob Davis, Llewellyntaught more African-American national champions than any other coach  among them Althea Gibson, to whom he was married for five years in the mid-80s.

title: A Chameleon Onstage and on TV
description: Sesame Street was looking for a Latino guy; stop. reset. was looking for an African-American guy; The Good Wife was looking for a white guy. They all ended up with Ismael Cruz Crdova, who was born and raised in Aguas Buenas, P.R.

title: The Black Budget, Revealed
description: For budget-watchers, it was a voyeuristic thrill to read through the Washington Posts article today exposing the secret details of the intelligence communitys black budget. The world now knows that the C.I.A. gets the biggest chunk of intelligence spending at $14.7 billion for 2013, and that a little-known agency, the National Reconnaissance Office, gets $10.3 billion, almost as much as the National Security Agency. (The reconnaissance office builds spy satellites, which are apparently rather pricey.)

title: John Legend, From Rugged to Clean
description: The R&B singer talks to the Styles sections Bee Shapiro about coming from a family of tailors and how that has influenced his personal style evolution.

title: For John Legend, No Colors Anymore, Except for Swimming
description: The Grammy-winning singer and songwriter John Legend, 34, has a new album, Love in the Future, scheduled for release on Tuesday. He lives with his fiance, Christine Teigen, a model, in New York and Los Angeles.

title: Video: With the Cadenza, Kia Moves Into a Nicer Neighborhood
description: Five years ago, the suggestion of a Kia with a retail price of nearly $42,000 would have been met with laughter and incredulous looks. But just as Toyota and Honda moved up in the 1970s and 80s from their economy car roots, Kia has branched out with a range of new models, each generation showing more polish and sophistication than the cars that came before.

title: At 67, Coughlin Proves a Taskmaster Can Be Tender
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  When Tom Coughlins children were growing up, they developed a routine when it came time to ask their father for something.

title: Wagons Ho!
description: The station wagon has been slowly fading away, but with the 2013 3 Series Sports Wagon, BMW is doing its part to keep the cars from extinction.

title: Dave Chappelle Cuts Short a Stand-Up Show
description: A live appearance by Dave Chappelle can be an unpredictable affair, promising either brilliance or petulance, and audiences who saw him perform Thursday night in Connecticut got a little bit of both, when this onetime Comedy Central star halted his stand-up act in mid-performance and proceeded to run out the clock.

title: Tennis in the Background
description: Tennis is a game of tradition. And for some fans, the annual visit to the United States Open in Queens is as much about soaking up the atmosphere as seeing the matches. Especially when it rains. For them, the Mojito Bar and Restaurant has provided sit-down dining and people-watching outside Arthur Ashe Stadium since 2003 (the year that Andy Roddick, now retired, won). The restaurant, which serves Latin-influenced fare, was redesigned this year to evoke South Beach. Its Florida  la Flushing, punctuated by red and gold patio umbrellas on the terrace and artsy chandeliers inside.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 30
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a boat club on Newtown Creek, the race for mayor and a baby snow leopard at the Bronx Zoo.

title: Yankees Stumble at the Gate
description: The Yankees are back home this weekend, with 29 games left on their schedule and at least an outside chance to end up with a playoff spot when the season comes to an end on Sept. 28. They have picked up some ground lately in their playoff quest but, interestingly enough, continue to lag when it comes to putting people in the seats.

title: Arriving in Style Just as the Tailgate Party Winds Down
description: Considering the rarity of station wagons in America, BMWs new tailgating 3 Series set me wondering: who exactly spends $50,000 or more on a compact wagon, instead of going the usual American route with an S.U.V. or a crossover?

title: Lose Your Keys? Use Your Phone
description: My quest to test an app called KeyMe started with five keys.

title: Keeping a Connection, Even on the Open Road
description: While distracted driving is a problem in any vehicle, the consequences are potentially greater on a motorcycle. So the designers of communication headsets for riders face a decision in striving to make systems safe to use.

title: Fast-Forward Lessons in Corvette Genealogy
description: SEASIDE, CALIF.  The Chevrolet Corvette has, over its 60 years of production, reflected the changing styles and tastes of America, says Mark Reuss, president of General Motors North America.

title: A Revered Nameplate Makes an Encore
description: The champions of the Chevrolet Corvette have included Bill Mitchell and Ed Welburn  Mr. Mitchell of the Sting Ray and Mr. Welburn of the Stingray, the difference in the rendering of the model names reflecting the different eras in which they worked.

title: Choicest Bites of Stingray
description: Riskng bar fights at future reunions, Corvette experts offered opinions of the greatest Sting Rays and Stingrays. Price ranges from Sports Car Market magazine, reflecting varying conditions of cars at auction.

title: From McQueen to Venus: Brave Women
description: Before getting knocked out of the U.S. Open this week, Venus Williams made quite a statement with her purple braids, piled in a knot above her visor and complimenting her printed tennis dress. You may cry fault: what about another player, Bethanie Mattek-Sands, who seems to be working on the colors of the rainbow? Shes also tattooed. People who grew up in the Evert-Connors era may gag, but exotic hair color on the courts is merely a step from the streets, and, in fact, its a lot more compelling.

title: Obama Makes Remarks on Syria
description: President Obama said that he had not made a final decision about Syria, but that he was not considering any military action that would require a long-term campaign or troops on the ground.

title: Unleashing the Potential of the Strings
description: PLAINFIELD, Mass.  On a recent sunny afternoon, Matt Haimovitz entered a carpentry workshop here that doubles as a music studio and gently pulled the door shut. The garden of the 19th-century farmhouse echoed with the shouts of children. But the newest family member was quietly leaning against the wall. It was darker than its sibling next to it and covered in pockmarks, but Mr. Haimovitz cupped his hand around its neck with loving pride: This is my Beethoven cello.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Q. This year is the 150th anniversary of Lincolns Emancipation Proclamation. When was slavery abolished in New York?

title: Twitter General Counsel Leaves as Company Prepares to Go Public
description: Alex Macgillivray, Twitters chief lawyer and the Internet industrys most prominent champion of free speech rights, announced on Friday that he would step down from his post, as the company expands its global footprint and prepares for a widely anticipated public offering sometime next year.

title: Week in Review: A $125 Billion Bet on a Multitrillion-Dollar Market
description: Verizon Communications is in talks with Vodafone to buy the British telecommunication giants 45% stake in Verizon Wireless. The deal, worth at least $125 billion, would be one of the biggest takeovers in history, but the burgeoning wireless industry makes the buyout attractive.

title: Taking Their Very Sweet Time
description: Neon beer signs, sports team logos and sexy posters may be de rigueur in the dorm rooms of college males, but while at the University of Florida in Gainesville, Udonis Haslem went one better. Somehow the Gators basketball player managed to keep a pit bull hidden in his room  which at the time was more emblematic of where hed been than of where he was going: Mr. Haslem is now a captain of the Miami Heat and has won three N.B.A. championships with the team.

title: A Travel Book With a Global, and Personal, Touch
description: A 21-year-old artist has reinvented a cherished commodity for world travelers seeking an authentic experience in a new place: a locals recommendation.

title: Work, Work, Family, Work
description: Ban Ki-moon, 69, has been the secretary general of the United Nations since 2007. A South Korean, Mr. Ban spent his childhood in a war-torn country and later experienced its rebirth as an industrial power in Asia. His job never stops, so on Sundays he works, taking calls on his BlackBerry and responding to queries from his staff or heads of state. Mr. Ban lives with his wife, Yoo Soon-taek, 68, in a United Nations town house on Sutton Place, where visits from their three grown children and four grandchildren offer a break from the rigors of trying to solve the worlds problems.

title: The Littlest Ninja Gets a Stiff Shot of Power
description: TESTED 2013 Kawasaki Ninja 300

title: Quinn, in Times Square, Offers Plan for Veterans
description: Holding a news conference in Times Square is akin to  well, maybe not walking into the line of fire, but certainly tempting the urban gods. As a politician, you risk being photobombed by the Naked Cowboy or groped by Elmo, or simply encountering a critic who, inspired by the crowds, will deliver a monologue on your misdeeds at a volume intended to reach the back rows.

title: Weather and Violence
description: AS temperatures rise, tempers flare. Anyone who has experienced the hostility of a swelteringly hot summer day in the city can attest to that.

title: Smoky Eggplant Dip With Pita Chips
description: Melissa Clark makes a dip that even eggplant haters cant resist.

title: Ivanka Trump, Never Far From the Family Name
description: Ivanka Trump has quietly carved out a niche in the fashion industry that nobody seemed to want after we tossed out our shoulder pads: professional attire.

title: Just One Big, Happy Family?
description: This summer, 39 members of the Peters family gathered in Smith Mountain Lake, Va., just outside Roanoke, for their 40th family reunion. What started with five nearby families in 1970 has grown to 10 families, some from as far away as Alaska and Washington State. Activities included water-skiing, a pickleball tournament and TV theme-song trivia night.

title: U.S. Open Food Review: An Indian Oasis
description: Because eating at the United States Open is a high-stakes game, we will feature a daily review of items available at the food courts at the National Tennis Center.

title: Getting a Doubter to Dip Into Eggplant
description: The most persuasive way to convert an eggplant hater is to fry it (the eggplant, not the hater). A less messy approach, however, is to make dip. Velvety, smoky dip with a tangy bite has seduced many an eggplant-hating guest.

title: Apple Expands iPhone Trade-In Program to Its Stores
description: Apple is trying to give people another reason to come to its elegant retail stores: Trading in old iPhones for a store credit toward a new phone.

title: What Makes for a Successful Family Reunion?
description: Given the undercurrent of hostility, as well as the myriad problems that may arise  drunk uncles, political catfights, whos gluten free and who eats only what they kill  how is a modern family to survive these squabbles?

title: De Blasio Sees Surge in Fund-Raising
description: Its good to be the front-runner, at least when it comes to raising money, as Bill de Blasio is now discovering.

title: Job Titles Retailored to Fit
description: Consider this roster of titles:

title: A Tales Kafkaesque Transformation
description: LONDON  A man wakes up one morning to find himself turned into a giant insect. Its the famous, improbable opening of Kafkas novella The Metamorphosis, and it popped into the choreographer Arthur Pitas head one day when he was thinking about working with the Royal Ballet principal dancer Edward Watson.

title: I Actually Work. Im in the Studio 24/7. Its Definitely a Grind.
description: As a member of the Memphis group Three 6 Mafia, the rapper Juicy J memorably collected an Oscar in 2006, for Its Hard Out Here for a Pimp. And his career has continued to follow a series of unexpected turns, from occasional actor to Twitter star (more than one million followers) to, lately, solo artist. On the heels of the platinum single Bandz a Make Her Dance, featuring Lil Wayne and 2 Chainz, his third solo album and major label debut, Stay Trippy, was released late last month on Kemosabe/Columbia Records. A few years ago, he had never performed onstage alone; now he is completing a sold-out, 40-city tour.

title: The Few Who Elect the Mayor for All
description: As conventional wisdom has it, New Yorkers are seeking a striking change in tone in the coming mayoral election, one that makes the selection of a Democratic mayor seem almost inevitable and the partys primary process likely to represent the conclusion of the story rather than the plot-escalating middle. As weve also been made to understand, a relatively small number of voters will determine the outcome of the primary race.

title: Singles Become Doubles
description: This last July, on a searingly hot day, as the tennis player Andy Murray closed in on a historic sporting achievement  to be the first British man to win a Wimbledon singles title since Fred Perry in 1936  the BBC cameras kept shifting their gaze from one key character to another as the match entered what would be its final game.

title: Movie Review: 'Passion'
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Passion."

title: Movie Review: 'This Is Us"
description: The Times critic Miriam Bale reviews "One Direction: This Is Us."

title: Movie Review: 'Abigail Harm'
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Abigail Harm.

title: Calvin Kleins Hamptons House Is Nearing Completion
description: For nearly half a decade, Mr. Klein, the fashion designer, has been erecting a minimalist palace the likes of which is seldom seen in an area of increasing architectural homogeneity.

title: The House That Calvin Built
description: For just $15 a day, Suffolk County residents can drive up in an R.V. and stay at the park at the end of Meadow Lane in Southampton, N.Y., where the views of the Atlantic Ocean on one side and Shinnecock Bay on the other are considered to be among the most spectacular on the East End.

title: New Ad Organization to Promote Cross-Cultural Marketing
description: Five big names on Madison Avenue are joining forces to start an organization devoted to promoting what is known as cross-cultural marketing: pitches directed at a general market whose demographic makeup is becoming much more diverse.

title: Bill Cunningham | Never-Changing City
description: Echoes of the artist Reginald Marshs work from the 1930s are seen from Coney Island to Fifth Avenue to West Village street festivals. Marsh said he wanted to capture the chaos of the city.

title: The Summer After the Storm
description: LONG BEACH, N.Y.  There was Jonathan Goldman one perfect August afternoon, happily traipsing down the Long Beach Boardwalk, dispensing wisdom to unsuspecting strollers and leaving snippets of rimshot patter floating in the salty air.

title: Low Ratings for Low Winter Sun
description: AMCs Breaking Bad has been one of the summers great ratings success stories, a testament to the power of binge watching and word of mouth.

title: Malevichs Burial Site Is Found, Underneath Housing Development
description: MOSCOW  The burial site of the Russian avant-garde artist and theorist Kazimir Malevich, in a field near Moscow, has been covered in concrete by a real estate developer to make way for luxury housing, says an enthusiast who spent years looking for the site.

title: Changing It Up in the Bedroom
description: If youre watching a channel called Discovery Fit & Health and someone starts talking about the lifestyle, you might assume the reference is to a triathlon training regimen or a vegan diet. Not on a new show the channel offers on Saturday. The lifestyle in question involves spouse swapping and other alternatives to monogamy. The show, a four-part reality series, is called Secret Sex Lives: Swingers, and it looks at five couples who like to mix things up occasionally in the bedroom. And they could be that ordinary-looking couple next door.

title: Identity Puzzles From U.S. and Iran
description: More than ever, tension among forces of cosmopolitan democracy, religious traditionalism and militaristic order roil the Middle East. So Asia Societys Iran Modern, an exhibition of more than 100 artworks made in Iran in the two decades before the revolution of 1979, should be something to see. Modern art was starting to thrive then, as artists explored new possibilities of identity. It opens Friday. (Through Jan. 5, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, asiasociety.org.)

title: In Store | The Wythe Hotels New Concept Shop Is a Family Affair
description: To some, the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg may represent the way Brooklyn is changing, but its sticking with the boroughs tradition of keeping it in the family. Opening next Tuesday is a new boutique known as the Shop, with a theme and offerings chosen by one local mastermind, which will change every four to six months. The first curator is the fashion designer Caron Callahan, whose label is based in the neighborhood. (Her husband, Sean Rembold, is the executive chef at the restaurant Marlow & Sons, owned by Andrew Tarlow, who is also the man behind the Wythe.) They were looking for something that gave a little energy to that nook, Callahan said. Theres so much happening here, and the taste level is super-high.

title: Its Pre-Season at Poisson Rouge
description: The fall season is looming, but plenty of ambitious artists are not content to wait for any official starters pistol to sound, and this week three of them come to the stylish Bleecker Street nightclub Le Poisson Rouge. Two are coming together. On Tuesday, the excellent young pianists Ran Dank and Soyeon Kate Lee present an evening of works for piano duo, including the premiere of Frederic Rzewskis Four Hands, as well as Brahmss 16 Waltzes, Op. 39 and an arrangement of Stravinskys Rite of Spring.

title: Exploring Gender and Sexuality
description: With the Supreme Court overturning the Defense of Marriage Act, and gay marriage being legalized in one state after another, the struggle for sexual equality has taken precedence over the fact of sexuality in the gay, lesbian and transgender liberation movement. But sex, in all its variety, some of it explicit, is the main subject of NewFest, the New York L.G.B.T. Festival.

title: Putting Poetry Above Politics
description: The songwriterMohsen Namjoostirs things up in Iran. Mr. Namjoo, who performsSaturdayat the Asia Society, plays the setar, a long-necked lute, and is steeped in Persian classical and literary traditions. But in Iran, where Western music was banned in 2005, Mr. Namjoo decided to fuse Persian music with rock and jazz and to sing  in a voice that can push from the nuances of Persian improvisation to the rougher attack of the blues  about the conditions facing his generation: unemployment, repression, violence. Though he was not allowed to perform in public or licensed to sell CDs, his music spread in private events, on the black market and via YouTube and radio.

title: A Broader Look at the War Across Syria
description: Uncertainty about how an outside attack could affect Syrias civil war is one of the factors leading to disagreement among Western countries about how to respond.

title: Road Trip to New Fringe
description: Its a sleepy week for dance in New York; most theaters are dark, and the late-summer lull has set in. For ambitious dancegoers, a road trip might be in order, namely to Philadelphia, where the 16-day Fringe Festival gets under way on Thursday. Formerly known as the Philadelphia Live Arts Festival and Philly Fringe, a restructured entity, FringeArts, presents this years thoroughly interdisciplinary mix.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Skype a Decade Later and Why There Arent Enough Women in Tech
description: Every day, The New York Timess staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

title: A Rebuilt Revis Is Looking Ahead, Not Back
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Darrelle Revis leaves his waterfront residence downtown every morning and drives to an office whose entrance is flanked by palm trees. It is always warm, always sunny, and even if it isnt, it still seems that way to Revis. Sometimes, he said with a laugh, he has to tell himself that he is not on vacation.

title: Ona at Barclays Center
description: A 19-foot-high cast-bronze sculpture by the artist Ursula von Rydingsvard now stands in front of the Brooklyn arena.

title: Tempest in the City
description: A new Public Theater production of Shakespeares The Tempest features more than 200 actors, only 6 professional.

title: In Des Moines, a Bonanza That Not Everyone Wants
description: DES MOINES  Nearly a decade ago, Lisa Connett, newly divorced and struggling on a tight budget, decided to fight City Hall over its franchise fee on residents utility bills. Now, as a result of her class-action suit, consumers here stand to collect some $40 million in refunds on fees that courts deemed an illegal tax.

title: Turning Chaos Into Theater, With a Cast of 200
description: Donald Gray, who will make his theatrical debut in a musical version of Shakespeares Tempest in Central Park next weekend, has taken an unconventional route to the stage. Mr. Gray, 53, was arrested for the first time at age 15, for selling drugs, and spent the next decades running the streets or in prison.

title: All Eyes on Her
description: She has arrived.

title: Pictures of the Day: Tunisia and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Tunisia, Yemen, Kashmir and the Philippines.

title: Kerrys Remarks on Chemical Weapons in Syria
description: Following is the text of Secretary of State John Kerrys remarks on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

title: A Parade Passing By? Not Likely
description: The historically gay Fire Island community of Cherry Grove has welcomed a parade of gay icons this summer, among them John Waters, Lynda Carter and Chita Rivera.

title: Obamas Remarks on Chemical Weapons in Syria
description: Following is the text of President Obamas comments on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, as transcribed by Federal News Service:

title: To Sleep, Perchance to Dream Anothers Reality
description: I read in some crazy book you bought me that weird comes from the Anglo-Saxon word for wise.

title: Another Kind of Music
description: I was in the audience at the Abbey Theater in Dublin on June 9, 1991, when Seamus Heaney read from his new book of poems, Seeing Things. I know the exact date because he kindly inscribed his book for me and dated it. But I wouldnt have forgotten that night, with or without the month and year. Seamus gave a mesmerizing, witty and emotional performance, and it was a rare opportunity for me to hear the sound of his words spoken with their true accent.

title: Microsoft Cuts Deal With Activist Shareholder to Avoid Fight
description: The saga of Steve Ballmers departure/retirement from Microsoft continued Friday with an agreement between Microsoft and an activist shareholder, ValueAct Capital, that averts a potentially nasty battle over the companys lagging performance.

title: Knockout Teams at World Youth Open
description: ATLANTA  At the 3rd World Youth Open Championships here this month, in the Youngsters (under 21) Knockout Teams, eight teams, three Chinese and five American, qualified for 32-board quarterfinals, semifinals and final.

title: A Musical Homecoming
description: Will Sheff, front man for the rock band Okkervil River, shows reporter Larry Rohter around his small New Hampshire hometown, which inspired the bands forthcoming album, The Silver Gymnasium.

title: Capturing Rhythms of Nature in Poems
description: In his Nobel acceptance speech, Seamus Heaney said that he prized the sort of poem that provides not just a surprising variation played upon the world, but a retuning of the world itself  delivering a visceral surprise, like the impatient thump which unexpectedly restores the picture to the television set, or the electric shock which sets the fibrillating heart back to its proper rhythm.

title: Lower Labor Day Gas Prices
description: Despite turmoil in the Middle East and potential Western involvement in the Syrian crisis, the price of oil has been relatively stable and the price of gas this weekend will be lower than it was in the last two years.

title: A Treasure Map of a Childhood, Filled With Magic and Newts
description: MERIDEN, N.H.  The singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist Will Sheff founded the indie-rock band Okkervil River in Austin, Tex., in 1998 and now lives in Brooklyn. But memories of his years growing up in this bucolic New England hamlet in the 1980s have never been far from his mind, so when it came time to make a new CD, he decided to return home  in song and in person.

title: Minnesota Orchestra Calls in Big Gun in Dispute
description: He brokered peace in Northern Ireland and spent two frustrating years as an envoy in the Middle East. Now George J. Mitchell, the former senator from Maine, is trying to bring peace to the Midwest, as the mediator in the Minnesota Orchestras bitter labor dispute.

title: Have You Met the Bergers? Of Course, You Have
description: Sometimes you walk into a thimble-size theater where the stage is just the floor, flanked by 50 or so chairs, and you think, Lord, this is going to be way too cozy.

title: Violin and Bass Trombone Finally Meet, and Its Love
description: The first concert of this years Labor Day Festival of contemporary music at Bargemusic included four world premieres. But the composer of one, David Del Tredici, insisted that his Dynamic Duo Farewell for Violin and Bass Trombone was more than that: a civilization premiere, the first pairing  ever, anywhere  of those two instruments.

title: The Week in Pictures for Aug. 30
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a boat club on Newtown Creek, the race for mayor and a baby snow leopard at the Bronx Zoo,

title: Friday Night Music: Missing the Civil Wars
description: The Civil Wars have a new, and presumably final album. Its lovely; but I havent been able to bring myself to post any of the official videos, because I keep thinking of what we lost when they had their falling out. What I always loved most was the magic of those live performances, and it doesnt look as if well have those ever again.

title: Seven Days of Chic | Fashion Pills and Furry Shoes
description: 1. Girls GirlJemima Kirkes druid-chic getup at the VMAs was amazing. Totem-pole-printed gauze atop a Shes All That-style little red dress? Sure, why not?

title: Evangelists Flock Keeps the Faith After His Brush With the Law
description: TRUSSVILLE, Ala.  Inside a darkened, sweltering room here one night this week, the evangelist Matt Pitt roused a couple hundred members of his young congregation in between raucous songs and a skit about prom dates.

title: Making the Safety Net More Visible in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  Like many poor people in this city, Gladys James did not know she was entitled to free home help or discounted water bills. She had no idea she was eligible to re-enroll for food stamps after being cut off last year because of a misunderstanding.

title: Judge Says Search Warrants for E-mails Must Be Limited
description: Can law enforcement obtain a search warrant to dig through a vast trove of e-mails, instant messages and chat logs because they have reasonable suspicion that the owners of those accounts robbed computer equipment from a private company?

title: Giants Take Wait-and-See Approach After Browns Injury
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants have lost so many starting players during the preseason that after another key contributor went down Thursday night, it did not discernibly rattle the mood inside the teams locker room the next day.

title: Yankees Keep Hughes in Rotation, Just Not Against Orioles
description: The Yankees tweaked their rotation Friday so that the slumping Phil Hughes would avoid facing the Baltimore Orioles, a team the Yankees trail in the wild-card chase, in a crucial series this weekend. Originally scheduled to pitch Sunday, Hughes will switch with Andy Pettitte, who was originally set to pitch Monday against the Chicago White Sox. Pettitte will now pitch Sunday, and Hughes will pitch Monday.

title: For News From Syrian Battleground, a Reliance on Social Media
description: When Secretary of State John Kerry delivered the United States report on Friday about the use of chemical weapons in Syria, he noted that all hell broke loose in the social media just 90 minutes after the alleged attack. As evidence of atrocities, the report cites thousands of social media updates and videos, along with reports from intelligence agencies, journalists and medical personnel.

title: Gay and Married Couples in New Land of Taxation
description: Its now official: same-sex married couples across the country are allowed to check one of the married boxes on their federal tax returns, even if their own state doesnt recognize their union.

title: A Colored Mans Constitution
description: Patrolling the streets of New Orleans on the evening of Sept. 1, 1863, a police officer found a small sheaf of handwritten papers. They were hard to read, written mostly in halting, misspelled English. Glancing over a page, the policeman may have seen at first only snatches of apparently incoherent prose: Carrige Drivers preachers of the Gospel the best Soldiers the united States Can Raise but the tel lies Sometimes and so dos all negro traders the get Drunk and lawiers and merchants.

title: The Luck of an Unlicensed Barber Runs Out
description: Three or four barbers were working that Thursday evening at Corner Cuts in Ridgewood, Queens, when the police walked in.

title: L.I.R.R. Train Kills Dog in Queens, Disrupting Service for 45 Minutes
description: For the second time in two days, pets forced the suspension of service on a major transit line in New York City. On Thursday, two kittens were rescued from the tracks of a Brooklyn subway station. But on Friday, the escape of a dog from a Queens yard turned into a pet owners nightmare: The dog, a female pit bull, was struck and killed by a Long Island Rail Road train, and her owner was grazed trying to get her back.

title: Fallen Officials Defense: He Was Obeying Orders
description: BEIJING  Bo Xilai, the fallen Communist Party official, said in secret testimony during his recent trial that he was obeying orders from a powerful party agency in charge of security when he took steps to cover up the flight of his police chief to an American Consulate, according to a court observers written record of trial statements.

title: U.S. Moves Ahead on Plan to Sell Plum Island, Home of a Research Laboratory

In real life, it was home to a high-security federal laboratory that did important research on contagious animal diseases.

title: Why Indias Economy Is Stumbling
description: WASHINGTON  FOR the past three decades, the Indian economy has grown impressively, at an average annual rate of 6.4 percent. From 2002 to 2011, when the average rate was 7.7 percent, India seemed to be closing in on China  unstoppable, and engaged in a second tryst with destiny, to borrow Jawaharlal Nehrus phrase. The economic potential of its vast population, expected to be the worlds largest by the middle of the next decade, appeared to be unleashed as India jettisoned the stifling central planning and economic controls bequeathed it by Mr. Nehru and the nations other socialist founders.

Our president, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, is a Nobel laureate who is celebrated by the likes of Bill Gates, Warren E. Buffett and Bono and has positioned herself as a champion of a free press.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) LES MISRABLES (2012) Hugh Jackman (above, who earned an Oscar nomination for his role in the film), Anne Hathaway (who won for best supporting actress), Russell Crowe, Amanda Seyfried and Eddie Redmayne sing their hearts out in this adaptation of the Victor Hugo novel about an inspectors pursuit of a convict and the love between a young woman and a firebrand of the French Revolution. The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. Ms. Hathaway, though, as Fantine, the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping I Dreamed a Dream, her gaunt face splotched red and brown, she wrote, holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion. But while the director, Tom Hooper, demonstrated in The Kings Speech that he can be very good with actors, his inability to leave any lily ungilded  to direct a scene without tilting or hurtling or throwing the camera around  is bludgeoning and deadly, she added. By the grand finale, when tout le monde is waving the French tricolor in victory, you may instead be raising the white flag in exhausted defeat.

title: A Data Broker Offers a Peek Behind the Curtain
description: IT can be disconcerting to learn what, not to mention how much, marketers know about us. Consider a consumer like Scott E. Howe.

title: Ford Recalls 370,000 Sedans
description: Updated, 2:36 p.m. |

title: Managing Risk on the High-Stakes Formula One Circuit
description: SPA, Belgium  The fundamentals of the epic racetrack here have not changed.

title: Who Will Prosper in the New World
description: Self-driving vehicles threaten to send truck drivers to the unemployment office. Computer programs can now write journalistic accounts of sporting events and stock price movements. There are even computers that can grade essay exams with reasonable accuracy, which could revolutionize my own job, teaching. Increasingly, machines are providing not only the brawn but the brains, too, and that raises the question of where humans fit into this picture  who will prosper and who wont in this new kind of machine economy?

title: Olympic Wheel of Fortune
description: ONE of the years most heated competitions in all of sports will take place in a Hilton hotel conference room in Buenos Aires. But unless any of the participants get a case of the jitters, you wont see a lot of sweat. You wont see many athletes, either, or any courts, nets, uniforms or scoreboards.

title: A Big Bet on an Olympic Jackpot
description: Viewed strictly from a business perspective, a spot in the Olympics is the most lucrative investment a sport can make. But the competition is stiff and usually lasts for years. And according to sports lobbying consultants, it isnt cheap.

title: Vive le Terroir
description: CASTELNAU DE MONTMIRAL, France  JRME GALAUP, a fourth-generation farmer here, and his wife, Nathalie, a teacher, share a dream: to combine their professions and create a teaching farm, where new generations can learn about the particularities of this hilly bit of French soil  this terroir.

title: Explaining Twerking to Your Parents
description: Every child dreads this day: sooner or later, your parents will come to you, innocently wide-eyed, to ask you about twerking. How you handle this difficult conversation is extremely important and could have a significant impact on the way your parents think about twerking for years to come. You may prefer to put off the big twerk talk, but remember that its far better for you to be the one to explain than for them to learn on their own by searching YouTube.

title: Political Choices
description: Leaders of the Federal Reserve and Supreme Court after World War II, and the presidents who chose them.

title: A Year in the Life of a Watchdog
description: ITS a Monday morning in August  last Monday, to be precise  and more than 500 e-mails have arrived in the public editors in-box. Some are spam. Some are requests for corrections or assignments, which can be sent to another desk. But a bunch, maybe two dozen, are legitimate topics for investigation or exposition. As my crack assistant, Meghan Gourley, does triage on the e-mail, I pick a subject for a blog post that seems timely, important and of broad interest  The Timess use of anonymous sources, particularly on that days front page  and start reporting it.

title: Silver Lining in Chinas Smog as It Puts Focus on Emissions
description: HONG KONG  Jiang Kejun may be one of the few Beijing residents who see a ray of hope in the smog engulfing the city. A researcher in a state energy institute, he is an outspoken advocate of swiftly cutting Chinas greenhouse gas output, and he says public anger about noxious air has jolted the government, which long dismissed pollution as the necessary price of prosperity.

title: Catching Up With France on Day Care
description: PARIS  PRETTY much from the moment I got pregnant, neighbors and friends began urging me to apply for a spot in one of Frances state-run day care centers.

title: For Some Afghans, Cost of Doing Business Includes U.S. Lawyers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Dollar for dollar, Mahmood Karzai may well hold the title for getting the least value out of his pricey American lawyers. Mr. Karzai, a brother of President Hamid Karzai, paid one of them $100,000, and all he got was a single meeting and one follow up e-mail  and then the lawyer died.

title: Sunday Dialogue: Economics Ups and Downs
description: Readers discuss the nature of economics and science.

title: The Chatter for September 1, 2013
description: Theres room for improvement, and weve seen some missed opportunities.

title: Women, Bought and Sold in Nepal
description: NEPAL may be known for natural beauty and Mount Everest, but there is a dark side to this small, picturesque country. Women and girls are being bought, sold and smuggled across the Nepal-India border. Although reliable data on the scope of the issue is difficult to gather, Unicef reports that as many as 7,000 women and girls are trafficked out of Nepal to India every year, and around 200,000 are now working in Indian brothels.

title: Women, Bought and Sold in Nepal
description: Katie Orlinsky travels to Nepal to document the growing problem of sex trafficking.

title: Labor, Then and Now
description: On Thursday, the day after the 50th anniversary of the March on Washington, thousands of fast-food workers in 60 cities walked off their jobs, the latest in an escalating series of walkouts by low-wage workers demanding higher pay and the right to organize without retaliation.

title: The Hazard of Free-Trade Tobacco
description: Give thanks to Malaysia for heading off, at least temporarily, an American effort to weaken the ability of countries to impose stiff rules on the sale of cigarettes and other tobacco products within their own borders. The Malaysian proposal to preserve that ability led to a stalemate at a Trans-Pacific Partnership trade meeting in Brunei last week and forced the deferral of the issue to future meetings.

title: Doctors and Their Medicare Patients
description: Critics who want radical changes in Medicare, the public insurance program for the elderly and disabled, often allege that the program is heading for disaster because stingy payments from the government are causing a rising number of doctors to refuse to serve Medicare patients.

title: New Yorks Living Wilderness
description: For those who cherish New York States magnificent Adirondack Park, Gov. Andrew Cuomos summertime efforts to promote tourism there  like racing Mayor Michael Bloomberg in a white-water rafting competition on the Indian River  have offered diversions from local economic worries, uncertain weather and supersized mosquitoes. He has also been busy hawking the regions wine, beer, food, hikes and kayaking.

title: Plan B for Voting Rights
description: Voting-rights advocates generally dont look to Justice Antonin Scalia for comfort. During oral arguments earlier this year in Shelby County v. Holder, the case in which the Supreme Court struck down a central part of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, Justice Scalia called the act a perpetuation of racial entitlement.

title: A Reason to Believe in Clutch Hitting
description: PITTSBURGH  One strike from elimination in the 2011 World Series, the St. Louis Cardinals roared back and won. One strike from elimination in their division series last fall, the Cardinals did it again. So it should be no surprise that the Cardinals have been unusually clutch at the plate this season.

title: Obama Speaks on Syria
description: President Obama spoke in the Rose Garden at the White House on Saturday, saying that he would seek Congressional approval for a strike on Syria.

title: Season Record for Doubles Is Secure for Another Year
description: On July 6, in a loss to the Yankees, Manny Machado, the Baltimore Orioles phenom, hit a ball to left field in the third inning for his 39th double of the season. At the time, it seemed that Machado, 21, could be a serious challenger to Earl Webb, who has held the record for doubles in a season, with 67, since 1931. There was no way anyone could have known that would be the only double Machado would hit that month.

title: The Dog That (Almost) Roared
description: BEIJING  IF it quacks like a duck, its probably a duck.

description: WASHINGTON  FOR more than a quarter century, Republicans have held a lock on two of the most important jobs in the federal government.

title: Riske Upsets No. 7 Kvitova in Days Lone Bright Spot for U.S. Players
description: In her hotel room in Manhattan, Alison Riske has tucked away a small piece of tattered fabric, a remnant from a blanket that was given to her at the moment of her birth.

title: My Filthy Secret
description: For years, it was my filthy secret, my private shame. I was allegedly a novelist; a crime writer, no less  a gritty, hard-boiled practitioner in the dark art of killing on the page. I was supposed to be a spinner of the tallest of tales. My books began with the disclaimer, This is a work of fiction

title: Squirrel Power!
description: SOME say the world will end in fire. Some say ice. Some say coordinated kamikaze attacks on the power grid by squirrels.

title: President Pulls Lawmakers Into Box He Made
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas aides were stunned at what their boss had to say when he summoned them to the Oval Office on Friday at 7 p.m., on the eve of what they believed could be a weekend when American missiles streaked again across the Middle East.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Sept. 1
description: With President Obamas announcement Saturday that he will seek Congressional approval to strike Syria, Secretary of State John Kerry will appear on the five major Sunday shows  on ABC, CBS, CNN, Fox and NBC  to talk about the administrations approach to the crisis.

title: Beauty and the Beasts
description: DURING an August vacation with my family, I enjoyed lodgings so spectacular that not even Bill Gates or Warren Buffett could ever buy or rent them.

title: Lawmakers Respond on Twitter to Obamas Statement on a Syria Vote
description: Both chambers of Congress are on recess, and many of their members are far from Washington. But the distance did not stop some of them from responding to President Obamas statement on Saturday afternoon that he would seek Congressional authorization before launching a military strike in response to Syrias use of chemical weapons. Many representatives and senators took to Twitter with their reactions.

title: For the A.T.P., There Is No Tale of the Tape, and Thereby Hangs a Tale
description: It has been one of the more lucrative summers of John Isners career. Over the course of five tournaments in July and August, he gained 1,250 ranking points, $551,975 in prize money, and an inch.
